ARCH√ÜOLOGICAL SURVEY OF INDIA.

‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

EPIGRAPHIA INDICA:

A COLLECTION OF INSCRIPTIONS
SUPPLEMENTARY TO

THE CORPUS INSCRIPTIONUM INDICARUM

OF THE
ARCH√ÜOLOGICAL SURVEY.

TRANSLATED BY SEVERAL ORIENTAL SCHOLARS.

EDITED BY

JAS. BURGESS, LL.D.; C.I.E.,

MON. A.R.I.N.A., F.R.C.S., M.B.A.S.; M.SOC. AS. PARIS;

MON. COR. MEN. BERLIN SOC. OFANTHROPOLOGY, ETC.; AND OFBATAVIAN SOC., OFARTS AND SCIENCES; FELLOW OF THE UNIVERSITY OF BOMBAY, ETC. LATE DIRECTOR‚ÄìGENERAL OF THE ARCH√ÜOLOGICAL SURVEY OF INDIA.

ASSISTANT EDITORS.

E. HULTZSCH, PH.D.,
EPIGRAPHIST TO THE GOVERNMENT OF MADRAS

A. FUHRER, PH.D.,
ARC√ÜOLOGICAL SURVEYOR, NORTH‚ÄìWESTERN PROVINCES AND OUDH.

‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

VOLUME I.

‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

CALCUTTA:

PRINTED AND PUBLISHED BY THE SUPERINTENDENT OF GOVERNMENT PRINTING, INDIA.

CALCUTTA‚ÄìTHACKER, SPINK & Co. BOMBAY‚ÄìTHACKER & Co., LD.
LONDON‚ÄìKEGAN PAUL, TRENCH, TRUBNER & Co., BERNARD QUARITCH, LUXAC & Co.
PARIS‚ÄìE. LEROUX. LEIPZIG‚ÄìOrro HARRASSOWITZ.

1802.

All rights reserved.

PREFACE.

THE Epigraphia Indica originated in a proposal, submitted to the Government of India in February, 1887, for the printing of a Record to include not only translations of inscriptions‚ÄìSanskrit, Persian, Arabic, and other‚Äîbut lists of them and other miscellaneous antiquarian information, including such materials as had been published for the Arch√¶ological Survey of Western India in the Memoranda issued by the Bombay Government from time to time between 1874 and 1885. On the 17th October following information was asked by Government and submitted, giving details for a quarterly issue of fasciculi. After further correspondence the publication was sanctioned, and the first part was published in October 1888. After the third part, however, owing primarily to unavoidable delays by the press, it was found impossible to keep the publication up to the quarterly date, and the volume has consequently extended over a longer term than was contemplated; this however is really of little consequence. The materials other than inscriptions, sent to me during the first year, were of little general and permanent interest, while the partial breaking up of the surveys, and my leaving India in 1889, prevented any special effort on behalf of the subsidiary features of the original prospectus. Hence the work has come to be devoted entirely to pal√¶ography, which was, indeed, from the first its main purpose.

Indian inscriptions‚Äîmore so even than those of any other country‚Äîare the real archives of the annals of its ancient history, the contemporaneous witnesses of the events and of the men whose deeds they hand down; and their authenticity renders them most valuable for the historian and deserving of careful record. They supply important data bearing on the chronology, geography, religious systems, affiliations of families and dynasties, taxes, land tenures, magistrates, customs, manners, organization of societies, language and systems of writing of ancient times. Hence the great need for collecting and publishing them with the best translations and comments that modern scholarship can supply. The early pioneers of Indian research fully recognized this, and men like Wilkins, Colin Mackenzie, Colebrooke, Babington, Drs. Mill and Stevenson, Wathen, W. Elliot, and J. Prinsep, laid the foundation of, and made important contributions to, Indian pal√¶ographic study. So early as 1835, M. Jacquet of Paris projected a Corpus Inscriptionum, and made arrangements to include in it the collections formed by Colonel Colin Mackenzie; but an carly death prevented this young French Orientalist from realizing his purpose. The Bombay Temple Commission, in 1851, recalled attention to the inscriptions, and, in 1856, they reported on “the extreme

“desirableness of the publication, under the auspices of Government, of fac-“similes or copies, with decipherments and translations”. The report added that “the publication of such a Corpus Inscriptionum appeared to be an object “of such importance in an antiquarian and historical point of view (for it “would embrace the most important documenta of Indian history), that it well “merited the combined attention of Government, of learned societies, and of “individual orientalists”. This project also remained unfulfilled, and it was not till 1877 that Major-General (now General Sir) A. Cunningham, C.S.I., issued the first volume of his Corpus Inscriptionum Indicarum, the object of which was “to bring together in a few handy and accessible volumes all the “inscriptions of India which now lie scattered about in the Journals of our different Asiatic Societies.” This volume (in demy quarto) contained the Asoka inscriptions in twenty-six lithographed plates of reductions, made by a native, draftsman, from the impressions available. The second volume has not appeared; but the third, containing the inscriptions of the early Gupta kings and their successors, was prepared by Mr. J. F. Fleet, C.I.E., Bo.C.S., and published in 1887 in a large super‚Äìroyal quarto volume,‚Äîthe plates being photo‚Äìlithographie reductions from mechanical impressions taken from the originals, and the wholeedited with Mr. Fleet’s usual care and scholarship.

To attempt collecting the ancient and medi√¶val inscription of India, however, in separate volumes, arranged by dynastiesor even periods, would necessitate indefinite delays and would still be imperfect; and therefore it seems altogether better to publish them as they are found in the fasciculi of the Epigraphia Indica, and trust to the index of the volume to facilitate references. This volume is thus to be regarded as properly one of the series of the Corpus Inscriptionum Indicarum, and practicallymay stand as the fourth volume of that publication.

The contents of this volume speak for themselves. The newly discovered twelfth Asoka edict from Sh√¢hb√¢zgarhi, the great S√Æyadon√Æinscription found by me in the Lalitpur District, the new inscription of Toram√¢na Sh√¢ha, the ancient H√Ærahadagalli copper‚Äìplate grant, the complete text of the LakkhaMandal inscription, and the important series of Jaina inscriptions found by Dr. Fuhrer in the excavations at Mathur√¢,‚Äîare only part of the important fresh contributions to epigraphy included in it. Facsimiles of the more important inscriptions are also given.

With the numerous epigraphs that have not been published before, it supplies also corrected editions from facsimile impressions of others that had been quite inadequately edited. The scholarship and special experience of the various translators,‚ÄîProfessors G. B√ºhler, Ph.D., LL.D., C.I.E, of Vienna, F. Kielhorn, Ph.D., C.I.E., of G√∂ttingen, and J. Eggeling, Ph.D., of Edinburgh, E. Hultzsch, Ph. D., and J. F. Fleet, C.I.E., Bo.C.S.‚Äîare a

sufficient guarantee for their notes and versions. To all of them my best thanks are due for the care and attention they have given to the work submitted to them; and specially to Dr, E. Hultzsch, who has givenun flagging aid in revising the proofs for the press. Dr. F√ºhrer; also, has contributed many most valuable impressions for translation, including the whole of the Jaina inscriptions from Mathur√¢.

The paper by Professor H. Jacobi, Ph.D., of Bonn University, on the computation of Hindu dates, is one of special and permanent value to all students of Indian chronology.

The Government, of India has sanctioned the continuance of the work in a second volume, and much progress has already been made in preparing the materials for it. It will contain a revised edition, with facsimiles, of the great inscriptions of A≈õoka by Professor G. B√ºhler, whowill also supply other papers on further Jaina inscriptions from Mathur√¢, on the S√¢nchi inscriptions, etc. At my request the Government of India has kindly secured an impression of the Badal pillar inscription, and through the favour of Colonel S. S. Jacob, C.I.E., of Jaypur, estampages of the Harsha inscription have been obtained, which, together with others, have been edited by Professor F. Kielhorn. Then Muhammadan inscriptions have hitherto been overlooked or but sparingly edited; and it is intended to give them a place in the next volume, for which two series of considerable length have been already prepared.

JAS. BURGESS.

25, SETON PLACE EDINBURGH:
5th October 1891.

EPIGRAPHIA INDICA.

‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

SANSKRIT AND PRAKRIT INSCRIPTIONS.

The great importance of Indian Inscriptions as a means of illustrating and completing our knowledge of the history of the country, fixing the eras of its dynasties, the character of its peculiar land tenures, the derivation and developement of its various alphabets, and other subjects of like importance, has been long since recognised by Colebrooke, Prinsep, Lassen, and all orientaliats. Of late years, increasing attention has been given to the study of these ancient records‚Äîpreserved on stone and copper‚Äìplates, and which primarily served as the title‚Äìdeeds of grants and endowments made by kings or chiefs to temples and religious personages or communities. Most of the earlier collections of transcripts made from these documents1were only eye‚Äìcopies, and, however carefully prepared, were but very rarely sufficiently torrect and reliable for purposes of critical translation. The late Sir Walter Elliot,, K.C.S.I., LL.D, when in the Madras Civil Service, was the first to employ, to any large extent, the system of taking direct ink impressions from copper‚Äìplate grants. Many of these were afterwards published by me in The Indian Antiquary. This method, Like photography, provided the means of supplying to scholars facsimiles of the documents free from clerical errors or modification of the alphabets. Methods of taking direct inked impressions from stone, also, have been devised; and estampages can thus be taken, having the advantages of presenting a direct reading of the inscription on the inked face and a mould from it on the back, so that the slightest scratch on the stone is retained on a carefully‚Äìtaken impression. With such a copy before him, the epigraphist can leisurely decipher the inscription in his study with about the same accuracy and facility as if he had the lithic record before him.

The inscriptions in the following pages have been prepared from such impressions and edited by most competent scholars, with comments, texts, and translations. The publication of them will thus place in the hands of European and other students of Indian history and antiquities, trustworthy texts and versions of the inscriptions collected by the Arch√¶ological Surveys3,and will be a reliable source from which to obtain the materials required in the prosecution of their studies in the historical, antiquarian, philological, or other branches of Oriental research. Selected facsimiles of the more notable inscriptions, on a reduced scale, accompany the texts.

I.‚ÄîA PR√ÇK·πúIT GRANT OF THE PALLAVA KING SIVASKANDAVARMAN,
By G. B√úHLER, Ph.D., LL.D., C.I.E., VIENNA.

For the edition of the subjoined grant I have used a photograph and two rubbings (A and B), made over to me by Dr. J. Burgess, C.I.E., Director General of the Arch√¶ological Survey of India. The original plates were purchased from Chennappa, a merchant of Hiraha·∏çagalli in the Bellari district. They are eight in number and measure each 8 inches by 3¬æÃã. They are numbered with the ancient numeral signs of the aksharapalli; but, contrary to the ordinary usage, the figures are found on the first side of each street4.The plates are held together by a single ring which passes through holes in the upper right‚Äìhand corners.

The technical execution is extremely rude and so careless that the holes for the ring have been cut, after the engraving had been done. Portions of several aksharas, e.g, of the second on plate TIa,1.T; have thus been destroyed. The preservation is good. Only in the last line of plate IIa one important word has become illegible. The characters closely resemble those used in Sir W. Elliot’s grant of Vijayabuddhavarman’s queen.5 1. 9. Nivattand and amhehi, for nivattane, adh√ª(?)hi. 1. 10. Sampadatt√¢ ta·πÅ n√¢t≈Ø·πáa g√¢meyik√¢ √¢yutt√¢ for samya datt√¢ ta·πÅ t√¢l√ªna-g√¢me yekd 200 (?) 40 (?) ttara. 1. 11. Savvaparih√¢rehi parihara·πÅdha pariharaya·πÅ for sa·πÅya parihar√Æhi parih√¢radhaparihaya. If the last two words are changed to parihara·πÅtu and parih√¢raya·πÅtu [cha], a translation of lines 8‚Äì11 is possible, and it will be “)The letters ta da and da look frequently much alike, and the same remark applies in some cases to taand na as well as to ta and bha. The anusv√°ra is indicated by a small cross. Among the numeral signs there are several remarkable forms. Thus the figure 2 is expressed by a dot and a slanting straight line, the figure 3 by a peculiar combination of three straight lines. On the other hand the figure 1 is expressed by a curved stroke, as in the grant edited by Mr. Fleet.

With the exception of the last line, which contains a final mangala in good Sanskrit, the grant is written in a Pr√¢krit dialect, which comes close to the literary P√¢li, but shows also a number of peculiarities and divergent forms. The majority of the latter is traccable partly in the edicts of A≈õoka and partly in the inscriptions of the caves of Western India and of the Amar√¢vat√Æ St√ªpa, while a few occur only in other literary Pr√¢krits. The points which here deserve special mention are the following:

  1. The palatal ja is used frequently for ya. It appears throughout in the names, which in Sanskrit end in √°rya, e.g., Golasamajasa (1.12), Agisamajasa (1.13), i.e., in Sanskrit Agni≈õarm√°ryasya, &c. In other words, the change is less constant. Thus we have

k√¢reyya (1.40) and kareyy√°ma (1.41) against k√°ravejj√° (1.40), vatteja (1.46), and hoja (1.48); yo (1.46) against jo (1.44); ^(·µí)ppayutte (1.6) against ^(·µí)sa·πÅjutto (1.47). A great many other words, like y√¢ji (1.1), visayesa¬∫ (1.8), show only ya. The occasional change of ya to ja separates the language of the inscription from the literary P√¢li and the dialects used in A≈õoka’a inscriptions, while it agrees with the practice followed in the cave-inscriptions. An instance of the change, which inliterary P√¢li is very rare, of ja to ya, occurs in Bn√°radd√°ya (1.2,16,19), for Sanskrit Bh√°radv√¢ja.

  1. A very peculiar principle is observed in the change of na, to na. It almost invariably takes place in the affixes of inflection, Pallav√°na (1.2), ma·πáus√°·πáa (1.7),vatthav√°na·πÅ(1.8), bamban√¢na·πÅ(1.8,27,30,38); bh√¢tyk√¢ne (1.18), pamukh√¢·πáam (1.27, 38), likhitena (1.51), k√°l√∫·πáa·πÅ, (1.10, 29), n√°t√∫na·πÅ, the only counter-instance being madena (1.40). In other casesfrequently, though not invariably, a single medial na suffers the same change, while initial na and medial nnaalways remain unchanged. On the whole the lingual na occurs more frequently than in P√¢li, in the Girn√¢r redaction of A≈õoka’s edicts and the cave-inscriptions, but more rarely than in the Pr√¢krit of the Jainas, where it has nearly supplanted the dental nasal.

  2. Some cases in which hard consonants are softened likewise come nearer to the usage of the Jaina and Mah√¢r√¢shtr√Æ dialects, than to that of the P√¢li and of the older inscriptions. Thus we find Kassava^(¬∫) (1.18) for K√°≈õyapa^(¬∫) k√¢ravejja (1.40), anuva·π≠·π≠h√°veti (1.45), and vi (1.6,29), while the original consonant is preserved in parih√¢petavva (1.37), and api (1.37). With these instances may be comparedbha·∏ça for bh√¢»õa (1.7,43), and kada or kada (1.51) against adhikata (1.4). An exceptional case of hardening occurs in maj√¢t√¢ye for Sanskrit mary√¢day√¢. The representation of Sanskrit varsha by v√¢sa (1.48,49) and varisa (l.42) is against the usage in P√¢li and in most of A≈õoka’s edicts, but is found in the cave-inscriptions.

  3. Some peculiar forms, in the declension especially of pronouns and numerals, which deserve to be noted, are: the masculine sammo (1.46) instead of the neuter samma·πÅ, Sanskrit ≈õarma, the nominative plural masculine chatt√¢ri (1.18,39) instead of chatt√¢ro, the instrumental singular ^(¬∫)maj√¢t√¢ye (1.43), the form be (1.14,20,39) for dve or duve, the genitive plural amha·πÅ (1.3,42) instead of amh√¢ka·πÅ, the genitive plural etesi (1.27) for etesa·πÅ, and chasi (1.46), i.e., cha esi6, for cha esa·πÅ, the genitive plural chatunha·πÅ (1.18) instead of chatunna·πÅ. Analogies for the first three forms occur already in A≈õoka’s edicts. The last five are known from the cave-inscriptions and the later Pr√¢krits. Most remarkable is the inflection of the Dvandva compound in the phrase Kum√¢rana·πÅdi- Kum√¢rasama-Ko·π≠·π≠asama-Sattissa cha chatunha·πÅ bh√¢tuk√°·πáa chatt√¢ri pattibh√¢g√¢ (1.17), where we should expect the termination of the plural instead of that of the singular. The preceding adjective Kosikasagotasa and the following cha show that we have not to deal with an accidental mistake. Analogies are found in the Sanskrit S√ªtras7. Thus we find in √Çpastamba’s Dharmas√ªtra, I.31,21, pr√¢yatyabrahmacharyak√¢lecharyay√¢cha.

  1. There are further several cases, which exhibit a curious disregard of the rules of concord:‚ÄìL.,10-11 the adjectives appatihatas√¢sanasa and anekahi[rana]kodigohalasatasahassappad√¢yino, standing in the genitive singular, have to be taken with the

substantive mah√¢r√¢ja‚ÄìBappasam√≠hi, which stands in the instrumental plural. Again, the names of the officials in l.3-6, visayesa‚Äìadhikat√¢d√Æke and so forth, stand in the accusative plural, but the last noun of the series, which must have been governed by the same omitted verb as the others; bhadamanus√¢na (1.7), shows the genitive plural. The explanation of these two anomalies seems to be that two constructions, either of which would be permissible in itself, have been mixed up. In the first case the word which governs the three nouns is puvvadatta·πÅ (1.12), and this might in Pr√¢krit be construed either with the genitive or with the instrumental. Moreover, as the substantive is the name of a royal personage, the use of the plural instead of the singular is also permissible. The construction, which the passage shows, has, I think, been caused thereby, that the writer first intended to use the genitive singular throughout and then changed his mind, preferring the construction with the instrumental and the plural. Want of care or the idea that constructions, differing in form but identical in sense, may be used indiseriminately, made a correction appear unnecessary. The same remarks apply to thesecond case, where either the accusative or the genitive used throughout would be correct8. More difficult is the explanation of the construction of the masculine sa·πÅpadatto (1.30) with the neuter puvvadata·πÅ, which latter agrees with the omitted substantive v√¢»õaka·πÅ. If the anomaly has not been caused by a mere lapsus styli, it seems to point to an utter loss of feeling, for the differences of gender. The fact that the neuter chatt√¢ri is used as a masculine, speaks in favour of the second alternative.

  1. Finally, the spelling of the inscription calls also for a few remarks. It shows throughout a mingling of two different methods, the abbreviated of the official and commercial classes and the etymological of the Pandits. According to the former, which is, used nearly throughout, as might be expected, in the edicts of A≈õoka and mostly in the cave-inscriptions, and which was until a short time ago universally prevalent in government and merchants’ offices, each single consonant may also be read double. Hence we find Sivakha·πÅdavamo (1.2) for ^(¬∫)vammo, gumike (1.5) for gummike, dham√¢¬∫ (1.9) for dhamm√¢^(¬∫), Agisamajasa for Aggisammajjassa, and numerous similar instances, while the spelling of aggitthoma^(¬∫) and dhamma^(¬∫)(1.1), and of a great many other words, follows the etymological principle. In some cases the latter is adopted, though it violates the phonetic laws of the Pr√¢krit. Thus √Çtteya^(¬∫)(1.13) is a close transliteration of √Çtreya, but the Pr√¢krit dialects admit only the forms √Çteya and Atteya. A word in which both principles of spelling seem to be blended, is Vatsasagotasa (1.22), which corresponds to Sanskrit V√¢tsyasagotrasya. The correct Pr√¢krit spelling would be Vachehhasagottassa. It may, however, be that the writer put tsa because he was accustomed to pronounce it like chha.

The historical information, which the grant conveys, is scanty, and in the present state of our knowledge of the history of Southern India not particularly useful. The Pallava king ≈öivaskandavarman of K√¢√±ch√Æ, who was affiliated to the Brahmanical gotra of the Bh√¢radv√¢jas, confirmed and enlarged, in the eighth year of his reign, a donation, made formerly by the great king, the lord Bappa (i.e., probably by his father), to certain Brahmans, who resided at √Çpitti or √Çpi·π≠·π≠√Æ, and were bhajakas, i.e., probably freeholders of the village Chillarekakodu·πÅka or Chillerekakodu·πÅka. The latter village was included in the S√¢t√¢hani district (ra·π≠·π≠ha). The gift consisted of

a garden in Chillarekakodu·πÅka, the income from which was to be divided in the manner specified, of two pieces of land in √Çpi·π≠·π≠√Æ, and of some serfs. The writer of the grant was the privy councillor (rahas√¢dhikata) Bha·π≠·π≠i≈õarman, who is called Koliv√¢labhojaka, i.e., the In√¢mdar of Koliv√¢la. It is for the present impossible to say how the donor is connected with the other Pallava kings, known from the ≈õ√¢sanas as yet published, or to fix the period when he reigned.With respect to the latter point I am, however, inclined to assume with Mr. Fleet (Indian Antiquary, vol. IX, p. 101), that the kings, named in the Pr√¢krit grants, belong to an earlier time than those who issued the Sanskrit ≈õ√¢sanas. The want of accurate maps makes it impossible for me to identify the villages and the district named.

In spite of these drawbacks our grant possesses a very great importance. Like the great N√¢n√¢gh√¢t inscription of S√¢takanni’s widow N√¢yanik√¢ and like the Elliot grant, of Vijayabuddhavarman’s queen, it shows that the use of Pr√¢krit in the older inscriptions is not due to the influence of Buddhism, but that in early times Pr√¢krit was the official language of the Indian kings, while the use of Sanskrit was still confined to the Brahmanical schools. Our grant and the other two documents mentioned were issued by adherents of the Brahmanical faith. The use of Sanskrit in the comminatory verses, included in the Elliot grant, and in the ma·πÖgala at the end of our grant, show that the said language was not unknown to the persons who composed the textIf, nevertheless, the chief portions of the grants are written in Pr√¢krit, some reason, not of a religious nature, must have dictated the use of the vulgar idiom. This reason, I think, can only have been official usage. The results of the recent epigraphic and linguistic studies are most unfavourable to the theory that there was in India once a golden age during which kings, priests, and peasants spoke the language of P√¢nini. They rather tend to show that the classical Sanskrit is a Brahmanical modification of the, or a, northern dialect, elaborated by the grammatical schools, which very slowly and in historical times gained ascendancy throughout the whole of India and among all the educated classes. Our inscription is an important link in a long chain of arguments supporting this view. Its full importance can, however, only be made apparent in a comprehensive discussion of the history of the Aryan languages of India.

TRANSLATION.

“Success! From K√¢·πÅchipura‚Äîthe righteous9 supreme king of great kings of the Pallavas Sivakha·πÅdavama (≈öivaskandavarman), a Bh√¢radd√¢ya10 (Bh√¢radv√¢ja) an offerer of Agnish·π≠oma, V√¢japeya and A≈õvamedha (sacrifices) [issues the following orders]:

“*[We send greeting11*] to our lords of provinces, vatthas12, royal princes, generals, rulers of districts, custom‚Äìhouse officers13, prefects of countries and others, to the freeholders of various villages14, to herdsmen, cowherds, ministers, foresters, gumikas, t√ªthikas,

L. 44. Bhaye looks nearly like taye.

L. 45. Stands for a·πáuva·π≠·π≠√¢veti, which perhaps should be restored.

L. 51. Perhaps ka·∏ça is to be read.

neyik√¢s15, and all others employed in our service, to roaming (spies) and warriors16, and we grant here an immunity (viz.) the garden in Chillarekako·∏çu·πÅka, which was formerly given by the great king, the lord Bappa,17 a giver of many, krors of gold and of one hundred thousand ox‚Äìploughs,‚Äîwhile he made (the gift) a means of the increase of the merit, longevity, power and fame of (his) own family and race‚Äîto the Br√¢hmans, freeholders of Chillarekako·∏çu·πÅka (and) inhabitants of √Çpi·π≠·π≠√≠, (viz.) to Golasamaja (Gola≈õarm√¢rya) one share of the produce,18 of ploughs (of land)‘Regarding the various kinds of the measure of land, called ‘a plough, ‘see Kull√ªka on Manu, VII, 119.”) to Agisamaja (Agni≈õarm√°rya)of the √Çtteya (√Çtreya) gotra four shares of the produce, to M√¢dhara (M√¢·π≠hara) two shares of the produce, to (his) son-in-law (?) Agilla (Agilla) one share of the produce, to K√¢lasama (K√¢la≈õarmen) of the Il√¢rita gotra two (?) shares of the produce, to Kum√¢rasama (Kum√¢rasarman) of the Bh√¢rad√¢ya (Bh√¢radr√¢ja) gotra two shares of the produce, to the four brothers Kum√¢rana·πÅdi, (Kum√¢ranandin), Kum√¢rasama, (Kum√¢ra≈õarman), Ko·π≠·π≠asame (Ko·π≠·π≠a≈õarman) and Satti (≈öakti) of the Kosika (Kau≈õika) gotra four (4) shares of the produce, to Bha·π≠i (Bha·π≠·π≠i) of the Kassava (K√¢≈õyapa) gotra one share of the produce, to Kha·πÅdako·πÅ·∏çi (Skandako·π≠i ?) the Bh√¢rad√¢ya (Bh√¢radv√¢ja) two shares of the produce, to Khamda·∏çha (Skanda-riddha) one share of the produce, to Bappa one share of the produce, to Dattaja (Datt√¢rya) two shares of the produce19, to Na·πÅdija (Nandy√¢rya) three shares of the produce, to Rudasama (Rudra≈õarman) of the V√¢tsya gotra one share of the produce, to D√¢maja (D√¢m√¢rya one share of the produce, to S√¢lasama (≈öy√¢la≈õ√°r·πÅan ?) one share of the produce, toParimita20 (?) one share of the produce, to N√¢gana·πÅdi one share of the produce, to Goli (?) one share, of the produce, to Kha·πÅdasama (Skanda≈õarman) one share of the produce; to, S√¢mija (Sv√¢my√¢rya) one share of the produce.

“By Us also the formerly-given (garden)21 (situated), on the southern sun, in the village of Chillarekakodu·πÅka (and) in the province (ra·π≠·π≠ha) of S√¢t√¢hani, has been granted to the above-mentioned Br√¢hmans, chief among whom is Agisamaja (Agni≈õarm√¢rya), (the gift) being confirmed by a libation of water and being made (valid) as long as the moon and stars endure.

This garden in Chillarekako·∏çu·πÅka, which belongs to the Br√¢hmans, (is to be) free from taxes …., free from the taking of sweet and sour milk,22………..free23‚Äîara·π≠hasarinayika, my former explanation of which cannot stand.”)

from troubles about salt and sugar24, free from taxes, forced labour………, free from the taking of the oxen in succession25, free from the taking of grass and wood, free from the taking of vegetables and flowers; with these and other immunities of the eighteen kinds it must be exempted and caused to be exempted by the inhabitants of the province by the inhabitants of √Çpi·π≠·π≠i and by the inhabitants of Chillerckakodu·πÅka.

“Moreover, in √Çpi·π≠·π≠i (one) nivartana (has been given) to the Br√¢hmans, chief among whom is Agisamaja (Agnisarm√¢rya), for a threshing‚Äìfloor, (one) nivartana for a house, four labourers26 receiving half the produce (addhik√¢), two Kolikas27.

“Now (if) anybody, knowing this, proud of (being) a favourite (of the king), should cause of cause to be caused a small obstacle (to the donees) him, forsooth, we shall restrain by punishment. And further I pray both the future great warriors of our Pallava race, (who may rule) within a period exceeding one hundred thousand years, as well as kings, differing from us (in descent), saying (unto them): ‘To him among you blessings, who in his time makes (the people) act according to the rule, written above¬π. But he who acts contrary to it shall be the lowest of men, loaded with (the guilt of) the five mortal sins.’ A charter (valid) for one hundred thousand years has been given on the fifth day, in the sixth (fortnight) of the rainy season, in the year,eight. (My) own order. The charter has been prepared in his own handwriting by, the priyy councillor Bha·π≠·π≠isama (Bha·π≠·π≠i≈õarman), the Koliv√¢la freeholder.’ Welfare to cows, Br√¢hmans, the writer, the readers and the hearers.

POSTSCRIPT.

After writing the article printed above, I have received from Dr. J. Burgess the original plates of the grant for inspection and am now able to give the following additions.

The plates are still held together by a single ring to which a nearly circular, somewhat battered, seal about an inch in diameter is attached. This seal shows as emblem an animal, facing the proper right, which may be intended for a deer or a horse. Below there stands the word ≈öivaskandavarma·πáa·∏•, the last three aksharas of which are much defaced and doubtful. The first four aksharas are perfectly plain and leave no doubt that this part of the grant was in Sanskrit, just like the ma·πÖgala at the end.

On the otherwise blank outside of the first plate the word ditha·πÅ is inscribed in very large letters. It is obviously the equivalent of Sanskrit d·πõish·π≠am, which according to Dr. Bhagv√¢nl√¢l and Mr. Fleet occurs in the beginning of the Chammak and Sivani grants of the V√¢k√¢·π≠aka king Pravarasena II. I have formerly tried to show that, though the resemblance of the letters in the latter two documents to d·πõish·π≠am is indisputable, they must be read o·πÅ o·πÅ or o om. In face of the plain reading on our plate, it is no longer possible to uphold the latter view. The existence of the word d·πõish·π≠am must be acknowleged. As regards its meaning, I think that we may take it in its literal sense and translate it by ‘SEEN,’ the note indicating that the copy of the grant
_________________________________________

1.I transliterate and complete this ‚Äî “yah svakakala uparilikhitamaryadaya (janan) anuvartayattaya rah sarmoti.

given to the donees had been seen, and was acknowledged to be correct by the minister or by the keeper of the records. This explanation is suggested by the position of di·π≠ha·πÅ in our grant, where it occupies much the same place as tho, Vide or Visum in certain modern official documents. If d·πõish·π≠am‚Äîdi·π≠ha·πÅ were to be taken as a ma·πÖgala, as might be supposed on account of its position in the two V√¢k√¢taka grants, it would be difficult to say how it came to be used in that sense.

II. THE PRA≈öASTIOF THE TEMPLE OF LAKKH√Ç MAN·∏åAL AT MA·∏åH√Ç,
IN JAUNS√ÇR B√ÇWAR,

BY G. B√úHLER, Ph.D., LL.D., C.I.E.

The subjoined edition of the Pra≈õasti of the temple of Lakkh√¢ Ma·πá·∏çal at, Ma·∏çh√¢ in the Jauns√¢r B√¢war district on the Upper Jamn√¢, has been prepared according to an impression supplied by Dr. J. Burgess.28 The inscription seems to be incised with great skill and neatuess and to be in an almost perfect state of preservation. The letters are very closely allied to the Br√¢hma aksharas of the Horiuzi palm‚Äìleaves and to the characters of Dr. Bhagv√¢nl√¢l’s Nep√¢l inscriptions Nos. 9-15, as well as of those of K√¢mavana and Jh√¢lr√¢p√¢·π≠an.29 With the latter it shares one striking peculiarity‚Äîthe superscribed and often highly ornamental k√¢·πá√¢s and m√¢tr√¢s. Our document is, however, not quite regular in this respect: P·πõish·π≠ham√¢tr√¢s and √¢‚Äìstrokes, marked by a horizontal line, occur likewise., Archaic is the form of ·π≠a which consists of a semi‚Äìcircle, inclining towards the right or placed horizontally with the round back upwards. In two cases, 1. 13 Bha·π≠·π≠a‚ÄìKshema≈õiva and 1. 14 Bha·π≠·π≠a‚ÄìSkanda, the top of the upper ·π≠a is flattened. The subscribed palatal √±a has also an archaicshape, differing only by the curves in the left‚Äìhand vertical from the form of the Gupta inscriptions. The older form of ya consisting of a loop and two verticals occurs 1. 6 and 11, in yena.

The language is good and pure Sanskrit, offering only a few irregularities in the spelling, which, however, are very common in the older inscriptions. Instead of the anusv√¢ra we have invariably ·πÖa before ≈õa, and also before sa, with one exception, where the dental na stands. For krituv√¢n the inscription has, 1. 4, kritav√¢n; for krit√¢≈õ, 1. 7, krit√¢≈õ; and for si·πÅha, 1. 1 and 5, si·πÖgha. No distinction is made between va and ba, a certain indication that then as now the letter va was always pronounced ba in Northern India. Above the inscription there are in the centre some irregular letters of later date which seem to read ≈ör√Æ‚ÄìIIall√¢dhi≈õvarebhya·∏•. Further towards the right stand five indistinct aksharas of the same alphabet in which the inscription is written, perhaps n√¢ratan√¢sya·∏• \‡•§\‡•§ and finally nearly in the corner above a diagram [r√¢?] ja≈õr√Æs√¢dhukena·∏• \‡•§\‡•§.

As regards the contents of the inscription, it offers (verse 22) a so‚Äìcalled Pra≈õasti,‚Äîa eulogy or panegyric, composed by Bha·π≠·π≠a Vasudeva, son of Bha·π≠·π≠a Skanda and grandson of Bha·π≠·π≠a Kshema≈õiva, and incised in the stone (verse 23) by the mason √é≈õvara·πá√¢ga, son of N√¢gadatta.

The Pra≈õasti records the dedication of a temple of ≈öiva (verse 20) by a princess, √é≈õvar√¢, who belonged to the royal race of Si·πÖghapura, for the spiritual welfare of her deceased husband. The latter, called ≈öri‚ÄìChandragupta, was (verse 19) the son of a king of J√¢landhara,‚Äîapparently himself not a reigning king, but either a younger son or possibly an elder son who died during his father’s lifetime. The greater part of the inscription (verses 2 18) is taken up by an account of the ancestors of the dedicatrix, and gives us the following pedigree of the king of Si·πÖghapura30, who, according to verse 2, belonged to the line of Yadu,‚Äìthe Y√¢davas of the lunar race,‚Äîwhich had ruled over the country “since the beginning of the Yuga.”

I. Senavarman (verse2)

II. √Çryavarman (v. 3)

III. Dattavarman (v. 4)

IV. Prad√Æptavarman (v. 5)

V. √é≈õvaravarman (v. 6)

VI. V·πõiddhivarman (v.7)

VII. Si·πÖghavarman (v. 8)

VIII. Jala[varman] (v. 9)

IX. Yaj√±avarman (v. 10)

X. √Çchalavarman Samaragha·πÖghala (vv. 11-12)

Kapilavardhana (v. 13)

XI. Div√¢karavarman (vv. 13-14)
Mah√Ægha·πÖghala

XII. Bh√¢skara [variman] md. Jay√¢val√Æ (v. 18)
Ripugha·πÖghala (vv. 15-17) 9

√é≈õvar√¢-md.-Chandragupta,
prince of J√¢landhara.

Though one or even several verses are devoted to each royal personage, not a single historical fact is mentioned regarding them. Only with respect to Jay√¢val√Æ the statement that “she obtained the title dev√Æ through her virtues,” permits us to infer that she was of comparatively speaking low extraction. As her father Kapilavardhana receives only the epithet ≈ör√≠ ’the illustrious,’ he probably was nothing more than a common Rajput. The fact that √é≈õvar√¢ was married to a scion of the royal family of J√¢landhara the modern Jallandhar in the Panj√¢b, makes it very probable that the district over which her ancestors ruled lay in the same province. Hence the Sai·πÖghapura r√°jya of our inscription may be safely identified with the kingdom of Sang-ho-pu-lo, i.e., Si·πÅhapura,31 described by IIiuen Tsiang32.”). This identification gives us perhaps a clue to the probable date of the inscription and to the period during which the twelve kings of Si·πÖghapura ruled. If the pal√¶ographical facts mentioned above are alone taken into consideration, the inscription will have to be placed between about 600 and 800 A.D. For the earliest of the dated cognate inscriptions was written in ≈ör√Æharshasa·πÅvat 48 or 654-55 A.D., and the latest in ≈ör√Æharshasa·πÅvat 153 or 759-60 A.D. It would, of course, be unsafe to assume that these dates are exactly the beginning and the end of the

periodduring which the alphabet of our inscription was in use, and it is only reasonable to allow a margin of about fifty years either way. Hiuen Tsiang’s remarks concerning the government of Si·πÖghapura make it, I think, likely that it was written near the remoter limit of this period He says ( loc. cit., p. 143) that, at the time of his visit, ‚Äúthe country had no king or fulers, but was in dependence on Ka≈õm√Ær.” As our inscription distinctly asserts that kings of the Yadu race ruled the realin of Si·πÖghapura since the beginning of the Yuga and enumerates those of eleven generations by name, its date probably falls before the Ka≈õm√Ærian conquest. For even if we assumed, though there is no foundation for such an assumption, that Si·πÖghapura again became free shortly after Hiuen Tsiang’s visit in 651 A.D., and if we assigned the inscription to the remotest limit, the end of the eighth century, its contents would clash with Hiuen Tsiang’s statement. For the eleven generations of kings enumerated we require at least 275 years, which we can in no way get, if we suppose the inscription to have been written after Hiuen Tsiang’s visit and after the hypothetical liberation of Si·πÖghapura from the Ka≈õm√Ærian yoke, cay between 650 and 1700 A.D. If we assume that it was incised before those two events, say about 600, the assertion that the Y√¢davas ruled Si·πÖghapura since the beginning of the Yuga, i.e., since time immemorial, and that eleven princes ruled it in a direct line of succession, offers no difficulties. The accession of Sonavarman will thus have to be placed in the beginning of the fourth century A.D.

In conclusion I may add that this inscription very forcibly inculcates the necessity of our abstaining from identifying every Chandragupta who may turn up in literary or epigraphic documents with the Maurya or the Gupta king of that name.

L. 5.

** ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§É‡•§**
‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§á‡§µ ‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§§‡§Ø‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡•ã ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡•• [‡•≠]
‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ú‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§∂‡•å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§∞‡§ø ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É[‡•§]
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ò‡•ã‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç ‡•• [‡•Æ]

L.6.

‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡•ã‡§≠‡•Ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡§æ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡§£‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§ú‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ú‡§≤‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡§≤‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§É‡•• [‡•Ø]
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§§‡§§‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§ú‡•Ä‡§≠‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡•§
‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‚Äì

L.7.

** ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ú‡§≤‡§¶‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•á‡§ï‡§æ X ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§∂ ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ñ‡§ø‡§®‡§É‡•• [[‡•ß‡•¶]]37**
‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¨‡§≠‡•Ç‡§µ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§ú‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§∞‡§ö‡§≤‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§ø‡•§
‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§≤‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•• [‡•ß‡•ß]
‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ‚Äì

L.8.

** ‡§∞‡§ò‡§ô‡•ç‡§ò‡§≤‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∞‡§£‡§∞‡•å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§É[‡•§]**
‡§Ö‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ó‡§£‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§∞‡§¶‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§É‡•• [‡•ß‡•®]
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§¨‡§≠‡•Ç‡§µ ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§§‡•Ä‡§∂‡§É[‡•§]
‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‚Äì

L.9.

** ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§§‡•á‡§ú‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ø‡§≠‡§µ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§£‡•• [‡•ß‡•©]**
‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§æ‡§£‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§ü‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§∞‡§ö‡§≤‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•§
‡§Ö‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¶‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡§¶‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§ò‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§≤‡§≠‡§ü‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡•• [‡•ß‡•™]
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‚Äå‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡§æ

L.10.

** ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§É‡•§**
‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§ò‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§µ‡§π‡§¶‡§æ‡§ú‡•å‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç‡•• [‡•ß‡•´]
‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ú‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§™‡§∞‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§£‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§É ‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡•á‡§É[ ‡•§]
‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§π‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§®‡§§‚Äì

L.11.

** ‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§™‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å‡•• [‡•ß‡•¨]**
‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ó‡§Æ‡§ó‡§®‡§ø ‡§∂‡•à‡§≤‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡•§
‡§Ü‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∂‡•å‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§æ ‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§É‡•• [‡•ß‡•≠]
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡§™‡§ø‡§≤‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‚Äì

L.12

** ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡•§**
‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•á‡§∂‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ú‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§≤‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§ï‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡•Ä ‡§ö‡•• [‡•ß‡•Æ]
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§ú‡§æ‡§≤‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•• [‡•ß‡•Ø]
‡§≠‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§ø ‡§ó‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‚Äì

L.13.

** ‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§æ ‡•§38**
‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡§§‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡•• [‡•®‡•¶]
‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§ß‡§∞‡§ú‡§≤‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡§ø‡§¶‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•• [‡•®‡•ß]
‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§Æ‚Äì

L.14.

** ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ú‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§¶‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡•§
‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡§∏‡•Å‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§è‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã [‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á]‡§∂‡§É‡•• [[‡•®‡•®]]39
‡§Ö‡§∂‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§ó‡•á‡§® ‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•Å‡§®‡§æ‡•§**
‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§∞‡•å‡§π‡•Ä‡§§‡§ï‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§®‡§É‡•• ‡§õ‡•• [[‡•®‡•©]]40

TRANSLATION.

O·πÅ.

  1. Obeisance to the supreme Lord,41who destroys the circle of births and assumes the three forms of Brahman, Vish·πáu, and Rudra for the sake of the creation, continuance, and dissolution of the universe !

  1. Among the kings, sprung from the race of Yadu, who govern the kingdom of Si·πÖghapura since (the beginning of) the (Kali) Yuga, arose in the course (of time) a royal sage, named the illustrious Senavarman.

  2. His son was an illustrious hing with the name √Çryavarman, who first after him (his father) proclaimed by his deeds the fact that he kept the vow of an √Çrya.

  3. The king, named the illustrious Dattavarman, who sccured safety, riches, victory, and destruction (respectively) to the fearful, to beggars, to his race and to his enemies, was his son.

  4. His son was a great protector of the earth, called the illustrious Prad√Æptavarman, a blazing fire for (that) multitude of moths, the armies of his roes, who were blinded by pride.

  5. His son, called the illustrious √é≈õvaravarman, became king through his great liberality, he who ruled, like Bhava, over a multitude of objects of existence (bhava).

  6. His son was he who was denominated the illustrious V·πõiddhivarman, a king whose good fortune was much increased, who, like the moon, removed torments42and gladdened the eyes (of men).

  1. His son was the illustrious Si·πÖghavarman, a lion‚Äìlike king who earned by (the strength of) his arms a reputation for bravery and whose power was seen (to be) above (that of) those having d√¢na (i.e., of merely liberal not heroic princes and of rutting elephants)43
  1. His son was he who is named the illustrious Jala, a prince whose peculiar action was the filling of the regions (with his fame), who removed the torments of his people, and who rained water (as it were) for (quenching) the forest‚Äìfire of the Kaliyuga.44

  1. His son was the king named the illustrious Yaj√±avarman, by whom the peacocks were ever made to cry aloud on account of the smoke‚Äìclouds (arising) from the sacrificial butter.

  2. His son was the illustrious royal sage called Achalavarman, who was constant in (following) the holy practices of the K·πõitayuga, because (his) virtues, firmness, and so forth, (were) the same (as those prevailing in the polden age);

  3. Who bore the second name Samaragha·πÖghala,45suitable (for him) on account of its meaning, (because he was) terrible in battle and his chest had been marked in countless fights by the points of elephants’ tusks.

13.His gon was the illustrious lord of kings, Div√¢karavarma≈Ñ, whose sun‚Äìlike nature (div√¢karat√¢) was shown by a characteristic (of his), the humbling of his enemies’46fiery courage (paratejobhibhava), just as the sun causes so pale all other lights (paratejobhibhuva);

  1. Whose famed appellation ’the Mah√Ægha·πÖghala’ warrior made his foes weaponless, when he nimbly strode over the battle(field) that was impassable on account of the elephants’ tusks.

  2. His younger brother was the protector of kings, called the illustrious Bh√¢skara, who (also) bore the name Ripugha·πÖghala, a charm ensuring victory in battle;

  3. Whose hand that was constantly occupied in giving away the wealth of hostile kingdoms won by (the strength of) his arms, (found) repose by resting for a moment on the backs of bending focs;

  4. By whom, sealing on foot mountain‚Äìfortresses, accessible (only) to birds, kings expert in fighting were attacked and made to pay a tribute of elephants.

  5. His queen, mistress of his life and his sole consort, was the illustrious Jay√¢val√Æ, the daughter of the illustrious Kapilavardhana, (a lady) who won the title of queen (devi) through her virtues.

  6. Her daughter was (a lady) faithful like S√¢vitr√Æ,” √é≈õvar√¢ by name, the wife of the illustrious Chandragupta, son of the king of J√¢landhara.

  7. When her husband had ascended to heaven from the shoulder of his elephant,47she caused to be built for his spiritual merit this temple of Bhava in consequence of a vow which was (made) in accordance with (the instructions of) her spiritual teacher.

  1. As long as the mountains, the oceans, the moon, the sun and the stars exist, so long may this location of the fame of illustrious Chandragupta endure.48, the latter portion of the verse might be translated,”)
  1. Bha·π≠·π≠a Vasudeva, the lord of Ayodhy√¢,49who owed his happy birth to Bha·π≠·π≠a Skanda, the son of Bha·π≠·π≠a Kshema≈õiva, composed this panegyric.
  1. By the mason √é≈õvara·πá√¢ga, an inhabitant of Rauh√Ætaka50 (and) son of N√¢gadatta, has it been incised in the stone.

III.‚ÄîA≈öOKA’S TWELFTH ROCK‚ÄìEDICT

ACCORDING TO THE SH√ÇHB√ÇZGARH√é VERSION,

By G. B√úHLER, PhD., LL.D., C.I.E.

The subjoined edition of the lately discovered twelfth edict of the Sh√¢hb√¢zgarhi series is based on (1), a heliotype facsimile taken from an impression; (2) a slightly mutilated paper impression taken by Captain ‘Deane, Assistant Commissioner of Yusafzai, and (3) a direct photograph of the right half of the inscription, taken from the rock.

The inscription is, incised in 9¬ºunequal lines on a granitic boulder, and is about 2 feet 6 inches broad and 9 feet 8 inches long. The rock appears to be full of large and small fissures, exfoliations, and hol√©s. Some of these seem to have existed before the inscription was engraved, as the mason has avoided them in cutting the letters. Thus the last two syllables of the word dhramamahamatra in 1.9, stand more than an inch apart from the preceding ones, and the impression clearly shows the traces of flaws in the intervening portion of the stone. But in most cases the fissures and holes are of later origin and have destroyed smaller or larger portions of the letters. This circumstance makes a certain proportion of the vowel sign≈õ anusv√¢ras and subscribed ra‚Äìk√¢ras doubtful. In a very few cases the consonants too are not clearly distinguishable.

The alphabet of the inscription is the so-called Baktro-P√¢li or North-Indian, which according to Sir A. Cunningham was current in Indian K√¢bul and in the Panj√¢b from the beginning of the historical, period to the third century A.D. The letters are mostly 1¬Ωto 2 inches high. Owing, to the want of perfectly readable impressions and trust worthy facsimiles of the inscriptions in this character, and specially of the edicts of A≈õoka, a good many minor details in the reading of these characters have still to be settled. Though this is not the place for the discussion of all the doubtful or disputed points, I must refer to a few of them in explanation of my transcript.

  1. I have in general adopted the new interpretations of some signs, e.g., of <MISSING_FIG href=”../books_images/U-IMG-1709370147S.png”/>and <MISSING_FIG href=”../books_images/U-IMG-1709370240S.png”/>which Dr. Bhagv√¢nl√¢l Indr√¢ji and Dr, Hoernle have given in their articles on the first rock-edict of the Sh√¢hb√¢zgarh√Æ version, and of the Suibih√¢r√¢ inscription, Indian Antiquary, vol. X, pp. 105 & 324, and vol. XI, p. 128.

  2. I am however not able to agree as yet with Dr. Bhagv√¢nl√¢l’s remark in the last article, that the short line slanting upwards, which is sometimes found on the left side of the lower end of consonants and a, denotes the long √¢. In our edict it occurs distinctly in the first sign of bahuvidha, 1.2, where the reading b√¢huvidha is impossible. It is further found in the va of devana·πÅ, 1.1, where the reading dev√¢na·πÅ is required. In a third word, ataprasha·∏çava·∏çhi, 1.8, it perhaps occurs in the initial letter, and the reading √¢ta is possible. But I do not dare to put these two lengths in the transcript, as none of the numerous other letters after which √¢ must have been read, such as ·∏ça in prasha·πÅ·∏çani, ·π≠ha in graha·π≠hani, show a similar contrivance. Moreover, neither Dr. Bhagw√¢nlal’s facsimile of the rock-edict nor the photograph of the Sh√¢hb√¢zgarh√Æ version which I owe to the kindness of Sir A. Cunningham, nor the facsimile and photograph of the M√¢nsahra version, which I have likewise received from him, confirm the assertion that the distinction between a and √¢ is clearly marked in the A≈õoka inscriptions. Hence I have noticed these slight peculiarities of the letters merely in the notes to the transcript.

  3. With respect to the spelling I have scrupulously adhered to the position of the letters in the original. I transliterate priyadra≈õi, dhramo, savra, though I have not the slightest doubt that the words were pronounced in the Panj√¢b, as elsewhere, priyadar≈õi, dharmo, and sarva. To everybody who is acquainted with manuscripts of works in the modern Pr√¢krits of India, or who has had to do with official correspondence in theso Pr√¢krits, the carelessness which the old inscriptions show with respect to the position of the letter ra will be nothing new or wonderful. A Hindu who is neither a Pandit nor a pupil of the Government schools, will write for sovar·πáa, sovra·πá or srova·πá, for sarva sometimes srava and sometimes savra, just as his fancy may direct.51 used in the transcript indicates that the letters are slightly injured, the sign [ ] that they are very much defaced but just recognisable.”) As long as the ra appears in the word, he is quite contented. He, of course, pronounces invariably dhar’m, sar’v,sovar’n, and so forth. There is, I think, no reason to suppose that A≈õoka’s Rajukas were better scholars than the Karkuns of the British Government offices before, the introduction of the European system of education, and I therefore believe that the abnormities in their spelling may be attributed to the same causes which operated in the case of the modern office writers. Still, in a transcript, it is as well to render the peculiarities of the text as accurately as possible.

TRANSCRIPT.

L. 1‚ÄîDe(va)na·πÅ (p)riyo (P)riyadra≈õi raya52savraprasha·πÅdani graha [tha] ni cha puje(ti) danena vividhaye cha pujay(e) [.] N[[o]]53ehu (tatha) [dajna[[·πÅ]]54va puja va.

L. 2‚Äîdevana·πÅ55 priyo m(a)√±ati yatha kiti [?] sa(la)va·∏çhi siy(a) savraprasha·πÅ·∏çana[[m]]56 [.] Salava·∏çhi tu bahuvidha57 [.] Tasa tu iyo mula ya(·πÅ)58 vach(a) guti [;]

L. 3‚Äîkiti [?] ataprasha·πÅ·∏çapuja (va) pa[rapa]sha[·πÅ]·∏çagarana59 va no s(i)ya [apra]‚Äìkaranasi60 [,]lahuka va siya ta(si ta)si prakara[·πá]e61 [.] Puje[ta]v[[a]]62 [e]va63 (chu) parapra (sha·πÅ) (.)

L. 4‚Äì[·∏ça tena tena prakara·πáena [.] Ev]a·πÅ64 kara·πÅta·πÅ [ata]prasha·πÅ·∏ça·πÅ vadheti

paraprasha·πÅ·∏çasa65 pi. cha upakaroti [.] Ta(da) a√±atha ka[[rata]]66 [[cha]]67 a(ta)pra[sha·πÅ·∏çam]

L. 5‚Äîchha·πáati parap(ra)sha·∏çasa68 cha apakaroti [.] Yo hi kochi69 ataprash (a)·∏ça·πÅ pujeti (para)p(ra)sh(a)·∏ç(a)70 [ga]rahati savr(a)71 atap (ra)sha·∏çabhativeva72kiti [?]

L. 6‚Äî(a)taprasha·πÅ·∏ça·πÅ dipaya(mi) ti [,] so eha puna tatha kara·πÅta·πÅ so cha puna tatha kar(a·πÅta·πÅ)73ba(·∏çha)tara (·πÅ)74upaha·πÅti atapra (sha)da·πÅ [.] So sayamo vo75s(a)dhu [,] kiti [?] a√±a·πÅ (a)√±asa dhramo76

L.7‚Äî≈õ(r)u·πáeyu77cha su(≈õ) rus(e)yu78cha ti, [.] Eva·πÅ (hi) d(e)vana·πÅ priyasa ichn [,] kiti [?] savraprasha·πÅ·∏ça bahu≈õruta cha [kala[·πáa]gama]79cha siy (a)su (.) Ye cha tatra tatra80

L.8‚Äîprasana tesha·πÅ81vatavo82[:] de(va)na·πÅ83pri[yo] n(a tatha da)na·πÅ va (pu)ja va m(a)√±ati ya(tha) kiti [?] salavadhi siya ti savraprasha·∏çana·πÅ bahuka cha[-]. Etaye a * *84

L.9‚Äîvapa·π≠a [[dhra]mahamatra]85 (i) * * yachhama (hama) tra86v(a)chabhumika a√±e cha nikay(a)87[.]Ima(·πÅ)88cha etisa (pha)la·πÅ ya·πÅ ataprasha·∏çava·∏çhi89

L.10‚Äîdhrama (sa) cha dipana90[.]

IN DEVAN√ÇGAR√é.
‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

1. ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§ø ‡§∞‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡§Ç‡§°‡§®‡§ø ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§†‡§®‡§ø ‡§ö ‡§™‡•Å‡§ú‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ö ‡§™‡•Å‡§ú‡§Ø‡•á‡•§‡§®‡•ã ‡§ö‡•Å ‡§§‡§• ‡§¶‡§®‡§Ç ‡§µ ‡§™‡•Å‡§ú ‡§µ

2. ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§û‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§• ‡§ï‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§≤‡§µ‡§¢‡§ø ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡§°‡§®‡§Ç ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§≤‡§µ‡§¢‡§ø ‡§§‡•Å ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß ‡•§ ‡§§‡§∏ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§∏‡•Å‡§≤ ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ö‡§ó‡•Å‡§§‡§ø ‡•§

** 3. ‡§ï‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡§Ç‡§°‡§™‡•Å‡§ú ‡§µ ‡§™‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡§Ç‡§°‡§ó‡§∞‡§® ‡§µ ‡§®‡•ã ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§∏‡§ø ‡§≤‡§π‡•Å‡§ï ‡§µ ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ø ‡§§‡§∏‡§ø ‡§§‡§∏‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡•á ‡•§ ‡§™‡•Å‡§ú‡•á‡§§‡§µ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§ö‡•Å ‡§™‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡§Ç-**

** 4. ‡§° ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡•á‡§® ‡•§ ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡§Ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡§Ç‡§°‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§¢‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡§Ç‡§°‡§∏ ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ö ‡§â‡§™‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶ ‡§Ö‡§û‡§•‡§ï‡§∞‡§§ ‡§ö ‡§Ö‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡§Ç‡§°‡§Ç**

** 5. ‡§õ‡§£‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡§Ç‡§°‡§∏ ‡§ö‡§Ö‡§™‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡§ø ‡•§‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§π‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ã‡§ö‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡§°‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§ú‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡§° ‡§ó‡§∞‡§π‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡§°‡§≠‡§§‡§ø‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡•§**

** 6. ‡§Ö‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡§Ç‡§°‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§ø‡§™‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ã ‡§ö ‡§™‡•Å‡§® ‡§§‡§• ‡§ï‡§∞‡§Ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ã ‡§ö ‡§™‡•Å‡§® ‡§§‡§• ‡§ï‡§∞‡§Ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§¢‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§â‡§™‡§π‡§Ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡§°‡§Ç ‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ã ‡§∏‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ã‡§µ‡•ã ‡§∏‡§ß‡•Å ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§û‡§Æ‡§û‡§∏ ‡§ß‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ã**

** 7. ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§£‡•á‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ö ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•á‡§Ø‡•Å ‡§ö ‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§π‡§ø ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§∏‡§á‡§õ ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡§Ç‡§°‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§ ‡§ö ‡§ï‡§≤‡§£‡§ó‡§Æ ‡§ö ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ø‡§∏‡•Å ‡•§‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ö ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞**

** 8. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§® ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§§‡§µ‡•ã ‡•§ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§® ‡§§‡§• ‡§¶‡§®‡§Ç ‡§µ ‡§™‡•Å‡§ú ‡§µ ‡§Æ‡§û‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§• ‡§ï‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§≤‡§µ‡§¢‡§ø ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ø ‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡§°‡§®‡§Ç‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§ï ‡§ö ‡•§ ‡§è‡§§‡§Ø‡•á ‡§Ö‚Äî‚Äî**

** 9. ‡§µ‡§™‡§ü ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§π‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§á‚Äî‚Äî‡§Ø‡§õ‡§Æ‡§π‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§ö‡§≠‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ‡§Ö‡§û‡•á ‡§ö ‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ø ‡•§ ‡§á‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§è‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§´‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡§°‡§µ‡§¢‡§ø**

** 10. ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§∏ ‡§ö ‡§¶‡§ø‡§™‡§®‡§æ ‡••**

TRANSLATION.

The Beloved of the gods, king Priyadra≈õi, honours men of allcreeds91 assembly or school. For as ra may be taken as equivalent to ar, prasha·∏ça may stand for parsha·∏ça, and this form differs from the Sanskrit original only by the shortening of the first a and by the lingualisation of the final da, both of which changes are required or sanctioned by the phonetic laws of the Pr√¢krit dialects. My rendering of the word by adherent of a creed, or creedis based on the assumption that in A≈õoka’s times it was free from the mala nota which adheres to it later. Itsinsport, I think, corresponded exactly to the English term ‘denomination and the German ‘Glaubensgenossenschaft. Owing to its ponderous length ’ denomination’ is not fit to be used in the translation of a document where prasha·∏ça recurs more than a dozen times.")both [ascetics] and householders92,by (showing them) liberality and by honouring them in various ways. But the Beloved of the gods thinks not so (much) of liberality and honour‚Äîas of what ?‚Äîthat an increase of essentials93may take place among men of all creeds. But the increase of essentials (may happen) in various ways. But this is its root, viz., guarding onc’s speech‚Äîhow so ?‚Äî“honouring one’s own creed and blaming other creeds shall not be in unimportant points, or, it shall be moderate with respect to this or that important point? But other creeds must even be honoured for this or that important point. Acting thus, one exalts one’s own creed and benefits also the other creeds. Acting differently, one hurts one’s own creed and injures the other creeds. For he who honours his own creed and blames all other creeds out of reverence for his own creed‚Äîhow so?‚Äî(thinking) “I promote (thereby the interests of) my own

creed”‚Äîhe, however, acting thus injures his own creed exceedingly. Hence self-restraint alone94 (is) commendable‚Äîhow so? " They shall hear each other’s law and love to hear it.95.’ For both in Sanskrit and in the Pr√¢krits the desiderative ≈õu≈õr√ªsh has almost lost its etymological meaning. In A≈õoka’s inscriptions, too, it is regularly used in the sense of ’to obey.’ The nominative dhramo stands for,dhrama·πÅ, as it is governed by the two verbs ≈õru·πácyu and su≈õruseyu. The same interchange of the two cases occure, as is well known, regularly in the modern Pr√¢krits, and occasionally in the Vedic dialects.”) For this is the desire of the Beloved of the gods‚Äîwhat ?‚Äî” that men of all creeds shall have heard much and possess holy doctrines.” And to those96 who adhere to this or that (faith) it must be said97. The Beloved of the gods thinks not so (much) of liberality and honour as of what ?‚Äîthat an increase of essentials “may take place among men of all creads; and a large one.” For this and are working the superintendents of the law, the superintendents of women, the vachabhumikas98, and other bodies. (of officials). And this is its result (viz.) the exaltation of one’s own creed and the promotion (of the interests) of the law.99

IV.‚ÄîAN INSCRIPTION FROM DABHOI.

By G. B√úHLER, Ph.D., LL.D, C.I.E.

On a large stone slab, 3 broad and 2‚Ä≤ 10‚Ä≥ long, which is fixed in the inner side-wall of the H√Æra Bh√¢gol√¢ gate at Dabhoi or Darbhavat√Æ, are found the remnants of a very large metrical Sanskrit inscription, originally consisting of 59,lines of neatly-incised N√¢gar√Æ characters which closely resemble those of the ancient Jaina palm-leaf MSS. The lower portion of the stone is broken in several places. The breaks have destroyed lines 44-46, and have more or less seriously injured the centre portions of lines 47-59. Never theless the lower portion, especially lines 52-59, is in a better condition than the upper one, which has suffered from the effects. of the weather or from rough treatment to such an extent that nowhere is an entire line readable. On the right hand, pieces containing from 20 to 35 letters have been almost entirely obliterated in each of the first 52 lines. The first five or six letters on the left are likewise gone nearly everywhere, and in the centre portions of lines 16-40 not much more can be made out with certainty than single words and letters here and there. Under these circumstances it would be a waste of time and paper to transcribe all the small fragments. I shall confine myself to a description of the contents of the document and to giving transcripts of those pieces where at least a whole p√¢da of a verse is readable. The materials on which I work, a photograph and a paper impression, have been furnished to me by Dr. J. Burgess.

The inscription belongs to the class of the Pra≈õastis or panegyrics, a large number of which have come to light during recent years. As has already been pointed out by Professor V. A. K√¢·π≠hv√¢te,100 it is the composition of Some≈õvaradeva, the well-known Purohita of the R√¢nakas of ·∏åholk√¢, who wrote the Kirtikaumud√Æ in honour of his spiritual client and master V√Æradhavala and of his friend the famous Jaina minister Vastup√¢la. The Pra≈õasti is dated (1. 59) Vikrama Sa·πÅvat 1311 Jyesh·π≠ha ≈öudi 15, Vudhadine, or May 14, 1253101, corresponding to 1253, the full moon of Jyaishyha fell on May 14th, 10 P.M., a Wednesday, in V.S. 1311 elapsed, or 1254 A.D., on June 2nd, 10 F.M., a Tuesday.”), and belongs therefore to a time when V√Æradhavala and Vastup√¢la had passed away.102 On the throne of the former sat his second son V√Æsaladeva, who in Vikrama Sa·πÅvat 1300 or 1302 extended his sway over the whole of Gujar√¢t.103 As might be expected, it is the latter to whom Some≈õvara devotes the greater portion of his poem, V√Æradhavala and his ancestors occupy a secondary place, and, Vastup√¢la is, it would seem, not even mentioned. The immediate cause which led to the composition of the Pra≈õasti, was the building or restoration of a temple of ≈öiva-Vaidyan√¢tha at Dabhoi-Darbhavat√Æ, ordered by V√Æsaladƒóva.

Turning to the details, it would seem that the first three verses contained a ma·πÖgala or invocation addressed to ≈öiva-Vaidyanatha.. A fragment of verse 2 says, “May glorious Vaidyan√¢tha himself with his eight bodies grant their desires to the creatures.” In verse 4 the description of V√Æsaladeva’s ancestors begins; for the end of p√°da 2 and p√°das 3-4 speak of “the line of the progeny of that (man), the good deeds of which (line) …. (cannot be described‚Äî) even by eloquent men.” As the name of the first ancestor is lost, and verse 5, too, is gone entirely, full certainty as to the point at which the genealogy begins is not obtainable. But verse 6 makes it probable’ that it included the name of the first Chaulukya of Gujar√¢t. For the fragroents of verse 6 point clearly to its identity with K√Ærtikaumud√Æ, II, 2‚Äî“Won over by the eminent qualities of this conqueror of his foes, the guardian goddess (≈öri) of the G√ªrjara princes became of her own choice his bride, just as (the goddess ≈öri became the bride) of (Vish·πáu), the foc of B√¢·πáa (at the churning of the ocean).” In the Kirtikaumud√Æ these lines refer to M√ªlar√¢ja, the founder of the Chaulukya dynasty of A·πáhilv√¢·∏ç. I do not believe that they can refer here to anybody else. For if they had been applied to Dhavala, the first member of the Vy√¢ghrapall√Æya or V√¢ghel√¢ branch of the Chaulukyas, known to us, Some≈õvara would be guilty of uttering a deliberate falschood. Dhavala was according to all accounts not even a minor chief of any consequence. The next verse 7 begins with the word yasmin and hence refers likewise to M√ªlar√¢ja. Its sense seems to be that the wives of his enemics tremble or fly into the jungles, “when he, an embodied stream of the sentiment of heroism, stands on the back of…..with the intention of fighting. In the lost verse 8 the poet seems to have turned to the V√¢ghel√¢s and, just as in the K√Ærtikaumud√Æ, to have begun with Ar·πáor√¢ja. This is evident from verse 9, “By whom, even the son of Dhavala, an imitator of K·πõish·πáa, this realm of famous G√ªrjara land was made free from thorns.” Here we have a new version of

*K√Ærtikaumud√Æ,*II, 63, ‚ÄúBy that good warrior who imitated K·πõish·πáa, even by the son of Dhavala, was begun the clearance of the kingdom from thorns.” The fragment of verse 10 informs us further that Ar·πáor√¢ja “slow on the battle-field Ranasi·πÅha who resembled R√¢va·πáa‚Äù‚Äîa deed which is not mentioned elsewhere. Verse 11 finally confirms the statement of Kirtikaumud√Æ, II, 66, according to which he himself met his death in battle. It says, “Now when his son valiant Lava·πáapras√¢da [was able to sustain]
the load of G√ªrjara land, he (Ar·πáor√¢ja) offered, his heart being averse to the world, a battle-sacrifice at which he gave his life as fee.”

Next follows the eulogy of Lava·πáapras√¢da, verses 12-24, which besides known events contains. Some now, historical facts. Verse 12 declares that owing to some deals of his, the particulars of which are lost, “the kingdom of the G√ªrjaras was even greater than that of R√¢ma.” Verse 13 mentions a fight near Vardham√¢na, the modern town of Va·∏çhv√¢·πá in north-eastern K√¢·π≠hi√¢v√¢·∏ç, with some unnamed powerful foes, regarding which the chronicles are silent. Verse 14‚Äî” By whom the chief of Na·∏ç√ªla was deeply wounded with his mighty swordy; owing to this (severe stroke), yon kings quake even to-day, just as the mountains at a thundor-clap”‚Äîis identical with Kirtikaumud√Æ, 11, 69, and reiterates the defeat of the ·π¨h√¢kur of N√¢n·∏çol in southern M√¢rv√¢·∏ç. Verses 15-17 refer to a victory over a Muhammadan king, whose name is not given.

  1. How many godlike kings are there not on earth? But even all of them became troubled by the mere mention of the king of the Turushkas. When that (Turushka king), excessively angry, approached in order to fight, [it was Lava·πáapras√¢da] who placed only . . .. . .. . .

  2. By whom (Lava·πáapras√¢da), the king of the Turushkas. . .. . .. . .who had spattered the earth with the blood flowing from the cut-off heads of numerous kings‚Äîwhen he came in front, with dry lips, full of doubt,‚Äîwas conquered at Stambha with his arm (strong) like a post (stambha) and terrible through the sword.”

17.. . .. . .. . .. . .. . .. . .. . .. . .. . .. . .. . .. . .. . .. . .. . .. .If he (Lava·πáapras√¢da) is a mortal, how is it that he conquered the lord of the Mlechchhas?”

This encounter of Lava·πáapras√¢da with a king of the Turushkas causes a difffculty, especially because Stambha104 is named as the place where it happened. In Lava·πáapras√¢da’s time fall three attacks of the Muhammadans on Gujar√¢t: (1) the unsuccessful expedition of Sh√¢habu’d-d√Æn Ghor√Æ in 1178 A.D.;, (2) the first expedition of Qu·π≠bu’d-d√Æn in 1194 A.D., during which A·πáhilv√¢·∏ç was sacked; (3) the second expedition of Qu·π≠bu’d-d√Æn in 1196, which was at first unsuccessful, but finally led to the temporary conquest of Gujar√¢t and to the temporary occupation of A·πáhilv√¢·∏ç by a Muhammadan garrison.105, pp. 160, 180-181. Regarding the duration of Lava·πáapras√¢da’s career we only know that he was the R√¢jyachind√¢k√¢ri or major domus of Bh√Æma II., who ruled over Gujar√¢t from Vikrama Sa·πÅvat 1235 or 1179 A.D., and that he was alive and took part in the war against Si·πÖghana of Devagiri which happened after the appointment of Vastup√¢la to the post of prime minister in Vikrama Sa·πÅvat 1276 or 1220 A.D. (K√Ærtikaumud√Æ, pp. xiv-xv; Indian Antiquary, vol. VI, p. 188), and ended with a treaty in Vikrama Sa·πÅvat 1288 (Bh√¢·πá·∏ç√¢rkar, Early History of the Dekhan, p. 84)”) It is very probable that he fought against the invaders on all three occasions. But I do not think that any of the engagements which then took

place can be referred to in our passage. Both according to the accounts of the Muhammadans and according to those of the Gujar√¢t√Æ chronicles and bards, the decisive battles were fought in southern Rajput√¢nd. On the other hand Stambha, the scene of the battle mentioned in our inscription, can be it seems to me, only Stambhapura or Stambhat√Ærtha, the modern Khambh√¢yat‚ÄîCambay,‚Äîwhich lies much further south. For Stambha is the regular abbreviation of these two names, made bh√Æmavat, and no other town has hitherto become known in Gujar√¢t from the name of which it could be derived. If we have then to look out for some other period during which Lava·πáapra≈õ√¢da may have gained his victory, the most probable. conjecture seems to me that it happened after the occupation of A·πáhilya·∏ç in 1196. Some time later the Muhammadans did suffer a defeat in Gujar√¢t and the province shook their yoke off.106 The details of these events are not given either by the Muhammadan or the Hindu authors; but our passage probably contains an allusion to them, and it may be that Lava·πáapras√¢da was the liberator of his country.

The fragments of verse 18 inform us that Lava·πáapras√¢das, a repository of medicine-like valour, cured [his country…. .] when the crowd of the princes of Dh√¢r√¢ of the Dekhan and of Maru, who resembled diseases [attacked it].

His success against the kings of M√¢lv√¢ and of the Dekhan are mentioned also in the K√Ærtikaumud√Æ, II, 74-75. As I have pointed out in the Indian Antiquary, vol. VI, page 188, note, the first mentioned foe is probably Subha·π≠avarman and the second si·πÖgha·πáa (1209-10‚Äî1247-48 A.D.), whose insctiptions record several expeditions against Gujar√¢t. The kings of Maru or M√¢rv√¢·∏ç, who are added here, may possibly be the four princes referred to, K√Ærtikaumu√Æ, IV; 55‚Äì65, who attacked Gujar√¢t at the
same time as Si·πÖgha·πáa’s army.

Verse 19 is purely laudatory: “He (Lava·πáapras√¢da) who raises his race, seems to me of greater fame than Yudhish·π≠hira, whose relatives were all destroyed, though their power to remove a ≈öalya is equal.”107 Verse 20 seems to have been of the same import. Verse 21 refers to the erection of a temple of Kum√¢ra near Va·∏çhv√¢·πá. “Who (Lava·πáapras√¢da) caused to be erected in the neighbourhood of Vardham√¢na, a (temple of) Kum√¢ra rivalling the ocean (in the possession of treasures) and surpassing the moon (in brilliancy).” The sense of the next three verses I am unable to make out from the scanty remnants. With verse 25 begins the praise of V√Æradhavala. Its complete restoration is easily possible, as it agrees literally with verse 27 of the Pra≈õasti in. Teja·∏•p√¢la’s temple at √Çbu.108 “From him sprang a son, who was the image of Da≈õaratha and Kakutstha (spelt kakustha), who swallowed like a mouthful the armies of hostile kings,‚ÄîV√Æradhavala. When the flood of his fame spread, the cleverness of faithless women,‚Äîwhose minds are distressed with the longing after enjoyments,‚Äîin the art of approaching (their lovers) was destroyed.”

Of the remaining verses referring to V√Æradhavala, 26‚Äì51, little more than single letters or words are legible, except in verse 45, where an unsuccessful combined attack of the lord of Dh√¢r√¢ and of the ruler of the Dekhan is mentioned. The portion of the Pra≈õasti which celebrates V√Æsaladeva’s great deeds and virtues, verses 52‚Äì108, is likewise in a very bad condition. The only political events traceable aro fights with the kings

of M√¢lv√¢ and of the Dekhan (L. 29, verse 58?) which his grant of V.S. 1317 mentions too, and a hitherto unknown expedition on which “V√Æsaladeva kept the hero’s vow on the shore of the Sindhu,” i.e., either of the ocean or of the Indus (L. 30, verse 59). In verse 77 and in those immediately preceding the manner in which V√Æsaladeva gained the throne of Gujar√¢t seems to have been described. But the name of the opponent whom he overcame has been lost. All that remains is: 77. “V√Æsal√¢ [madƒô. . . . . . . . .undergo] the fate of a moth in the fire of his valour.”

78.“Then that moon among princes, V√Æsaladeya, after obtaining sway over the world,”. . . . . . . . . .

A little further on, with verse 80, begins apparently the account of V√Æsaladeva’s building operations. We hear of the erection of one or several temples of Siva, (verses 81 and 91), of the restoration of a temple of the sun, called M√ªlasth√¢na (verse 92), of another” temple which resembled a peak of the mountain of. Hara,” i.e., of Kail√¢sa (verse 93), and that, “he who in form resembled Cupid renovated the pr√¢kara,” i.e., the enclosure, probably of some other temple. Verses 99‚Äî108 praise the king’s liberality. According to verse,100 he gave annually “a kalpalat√¢ of always increasing value; the cause of the wealth of the Br√¢hma·πáas.” Verse 102 says that “in his country the sound of the Vedas, uttered by untired Br√¢hma·πáas who were gladdened by fees given at great sacrifices, [ever] meets one’s ears.” The other verses are of a more general import. In the concluding portion of the poem, which opens with the words ita≈õ cha, Some≈õvara speaks of the official and architects connected with the building of the temple, of himself, of the writer and the engraver of the Pra≈õasti.

  1. In the.Pr√¢gv√¢·π≠a face109 was … ga, the son of illustrious Cha·πá·∏çasi·πÅha, who was appointed by the king on account of his confidence (in him),to the post (of guardian) of the fort of Vaidye≈õit·πõi.

  1. What description shall (I) give of that minister the flood of whose pure fame filled the carth, erected by whom, the excellent line of ramparts, free from interstices, dived into the abode of the gods.”

  2. There was a mason, called S√¢deva, a store of all good qualities; from him sprang V√¢madeva, famous for having built the temple of the Sun, called M√ªlasth√¢na. As his son was born he who is called Madana, a scion of (the race of) Vi≈õvakarman, the builder of the wall of (glorious) Vaidye≈õa, of the extensive temple, of the gates, of the wings and of the foundations.”110

  1. The son of √Çhl√¢dana, called Dev√¢ditya, who (became) the firm architect of Vaidye≈õit·πõi, is famous in the first rank of masons.

  2. Glorious Vaidyan√¢tha, worshipful sole protector of the world, I address a prayer to thee‚Äî“May God, through thy favour, that V√Æsaladeva, free from cares caused by focs, and united with his sons, be victorious during ten thousand Kalpas !”

  3. The chief domestic priest of the kings, born . . . who is called Some≈õvaradeva, made this panegyric, producing the great composition in half a watch of the night.

  4. And the excellent Br√¢hman Prahl√¢dana, the son of ≈öriy√¢manda (?), born in the gotra of famous Nandipura, wrote this panegyric.111

  1. By skilfulPadmasi·πÅha, foremost among masons,112 the son of the mason Sajjana, was this panegyric incised.‚ÄîSa·πÅvat 1311, on the 15th day of the bright half of Jyeshtha, a Wednesday. May it be well

TRANSCRIPT

L2.

‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢
‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø [‡§®‡§æ]-
‡§Æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•Å‡§≠‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§ø[‡§Æ‡§§‡§Ç] ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡•à‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø[[‡§®‡§æ‡§•‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•®]]113
‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø [‡§¶‡§ß‡§§‡•Å] ‡§ï‡§ø‡§≤ ‡§ï‡•á

‚Ä¢ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡•• ‡•©
‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ ‡§≠‡•Å ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢
‡§§‡§Ç‡§¶‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡•å‡•§
‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•à‡§∞‡§™‡§ø<MISSING_FIG href=”../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png”/> ‡§∞‡§ø<MISSING_FIG href=”../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png”/><MISSING_FIG href=”../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png”/>
<MISSING_FIG href=”../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png”/> <MISSING_FIG href=”../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png”/><MISSING_FIG href=”../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png”/> [‡§Æ] ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•Å‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É‡•• [[ ‡•™ ]]114

**‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ **

L4.

** ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ[‡§§‡•á‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§£] ‡§∞‡§ø[‡§™‡•ã‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ]
‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§∞‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞ [‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø] ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ú‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡•• ‡•¨115
‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡§∞‡§∏[‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ]‡§æ‡§π‡•á
[‡§Æ]‡§π‡•á‡§Ç[‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞] ‡§™‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§Æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡•§
‡§Ö‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£<MISSING_FIG href=”../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png”/><MISSING_FIG href=”../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png”/> ‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§ï<MISSING_FIG href=”../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png”/><MISSING_FIG href=”../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png”/> <MISSING_FIG href=”../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png”/><MISSING_FIG href=”../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png”/>

‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ø‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢‡§ó‡§Ç‡§≠‡•Ä‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡§ø ‡•• ‡•Æ116”)
‡§ß‡§µ‡§≤‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡•§

‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ó‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§∞‡§ß‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§Ç‡§ü‡§ï‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç‡•• ‡•Ø115
‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§£‡§Æ‡§ø‡§µ ‡§∞‡§£[‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç]‡§π‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π[‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø]‡§∞[‡§£] ‡§æ‡§Ç [‡§ó‡§£‡•á]

‡§®‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø
‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§É‡•• ‡•ß‡•ß117
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ã‡§£‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡§ø
