<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡•á-
‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§π‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§∞‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§¶‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä[‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ]‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡§ø‡•• ‡•ß‡•®118
‡§¶‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§É
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•á ‡§µ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•§
‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§´‡§≤‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç‡§ú‡§∞‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç‡§≠‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•à-
‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§ß‡§ø<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> ‡•• [‡•ß‡•©114
[‡§ú‡§ò‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡§Ç‡§°‡•á‡§® ‡§ó‡§æ‡§¢‡§Ç ‡§®‡§°‡•Å‡§≤] ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ï [ :‡•§ ] [‡§®‡§ø]**

L8.

**‡§∞‡•ç‡§ò‡§æ‡§§‡•á‡§®‡•á‡§µ ‡§§‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§Ç‡§™‡§Ç‡§§‡•á‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡§É‡•• ‡•ß‡•™115
‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§É ‡§ï‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç
‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ï[‡§•]‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•Å‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§ó‡§§‡•á ‡§Ω ‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•Å‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•á ‡§ß‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ï‡•á[‡§µ]‡§≤‡§Ç
<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/>‡§ï‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç‡•• ‡•ß‡•´

L9.

** ‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§¶‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ü<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> ‡§π<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> ‡§ú‡§É
‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§®‡§∞‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•å‡§≤‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ó‡§≤‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∑‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡•ã‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∂‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§ß‡§∞‡§É ‡§∂‡§Ç‡§ï‡§Ø‡§æ
‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡•É‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡§≠‡•Ä‡§∑‡§£‡§≠‡•Å‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç‡§≠‡•á‡§® [‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç]‡§≠‡•á ‡§ú‡§ø [‡§§‡§É ‡•• ‡•ß] ‡•¨
<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/>

<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/>**

L10.

** <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> ‡•§
<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> ‡§¶‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç‡§ï‡§•‡§Ç

‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ú‡•à‡§∞‡§ú‡•á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ú[‡§Ø]‡§®‡•ç ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§•‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§•‡§Ç‡•• ‡•ß‡•≠
‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§Æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§£‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§£‡•á
‡§∞‡•ã‡§ó‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø [‡§µ] ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> ‡§≤<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/>
<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•å‡§∑‡§ß [‡§®‡§ø]-**

L11.

** ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§ö‡§ø‡§ï‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•å

<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> ‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> ‡§ï‡§ß‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§∞‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§™‡§ø ‡§∂‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡§£‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•á
‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ß‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•É‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§¨‡§Ç‡§ß‡•ã‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§Ø‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§Ø-
‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡•á ‡§Æ‡•á‡•• ‡•ß‡•Ø119
‡§π‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/>

**‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡§ü‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§™‡§æ

‡§®‡§Ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§Ç<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/>[1]

‡§∏‡•Å [‡§§‚Äì ]**

L14.

** [‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä] ‡§π‡§∂‡§∞‡§•‡§ï‡§ï‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§É
[‡§™‡•ç‡§∞] ‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§µ‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§≤‡•ã ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡§ß‡§µ‡§≤‡§É
‡§Ø‡§∂‡§É‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø [‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡§æ‚Äì]**

[‡§Æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∏‡§∞‡§£‡§ï]‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∂‡§≤‡§§‡§æ‡•• ‡•®‡•´122
‡§§‡•á‚Äî ‚Äî‚Äî‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢

L23.

**‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢‡••[ ‡•™
‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/>

<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/>‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§™[‡§§‡§∏] ‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡•å‡•§
‡§ß‡•Ä‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•á‡§µ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§§‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç

‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> ‡§ß‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡••[[‡•™‡•´]]123

L 25.

**‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢

‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢‡••‡•´‡•ß<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/>‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡•ã‡§∏‡§≤‡•Ä ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ **

**‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ **

L 29.

‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢

**‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∏‡§≤‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ **
‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢

‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢

L 30.

‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢

<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/>‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ß‡•Å‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•á

‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∏‡§∏‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§è‡§µ ‡•• ‡•´‡•Ø114
‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢**

L 39.

‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢

‡§∏‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‚Äî -‡§ø ‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ

‡§Ü‡§ß‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ß‡§ø[‡§ó]‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É
‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§• ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∏‡§≤‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§É‡•§

‡§∏<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/>‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ [‡§∏‡•Å] ‡§ú‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ø- <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/>

L 41.

‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢
‡§Æ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§á‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§®<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/>‡••‡•≠‡•Ø
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§ú‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Æ‡•É‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ï‡§Æ‡•å‡§≤‡§ø-
‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å‡•§
‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Ç<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/>‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§-

L 42.

**<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/>
‡§¶‡•Å<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> ‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§≠‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡§ø ‡•• ‡•Æ‡•ß
‡§π‡•á ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§¶‡§Æ‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/>

[‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç] ‡§®‡•Ä‡§ö‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§ö‡§≤ [‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ] ‡§ï‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•á‡•§
<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω [‡§™‡§ø] ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§≤‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/>

<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/>[[‡••‡•Æ‡•®]]118

L 43.

<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> ‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•É‡§Ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡•§
‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> ‡§∞‡•à‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É
‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§™‡•Ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡•• ‡•Æ‡•©119
‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡§É ‡§™‡•Ä[‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ] ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡§Ç‡§ó‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç‡§≠‡§ï‡•Ä‡§≤‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡•Ä‡§µ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§§‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/>[[‡•• ‡•Æ‡•™ ]]127
‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢

‡§π‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§ñ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ø<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/>‡•§

L 49.

** <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> [ ‡•§ ]
‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç‡•• ‡•Ø‡•´
‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§µ‡§Ç‡•§
‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> **

‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§ï‡•É[‡§§‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™]‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§É<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ [ ‡•§ ]
‚Äî‚Äî ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§É‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢

L 50.

<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/>‡§ß‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§∞‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø‡•§
‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•à‡§∞‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•• ‡•Ø‡•Æ115
‡§®‡•Ç‡§®‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡§Ç <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/>

‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶ <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/>

L 51.

**
<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> ‡§ß‡§ø‡•• ‡•Ø‡•Ø118**

‡§Ø‡•á‡§® [‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™] ‡§≤‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ç‡•§
‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≤‡•Å‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§¶‡§Æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç‡•• ‡•ß‡•¶‡•¶115
‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç‡•§

‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡§£‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ç‡•• ‡•ß‡•¶‡•ß117
‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ø <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/>

L 52.

**
<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/>‡§Ø‡•á <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/>‡•§**

‡§Ö‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Å‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§®-
‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§£‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•á‡§Ω‡§µ‡§ø ‚Äî [[‡•• ‡•ß‡•¶‡•®]]118
[‡§ï‡§®‡§ï] ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§£‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø
‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§Æ‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§≤‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§µ‡§≤‡§ø‡§∞‡§™‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç
‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§® ‡§ú <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> [[‡•• ‡•ß‡•¶‡•©]]129

**<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> **

L 53.

<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≤‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§Ç‡•• ‡•ß‡•¶‡•™130
‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/>‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§Æ‡§µ‡§Ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§µ‡•á ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Ç‡•• ‡•ß‡•¶‡•´
‡§Ö‡§∏‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§π‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡•å‡§∞‡§µ‡§™‡§§‡§ø-
‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§¶‡•á <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> ‡§®‡•ã <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> ‡§ï‡§≤ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡§™‡•Å <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> ‡•§

L 54.

<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> ‡§™‡•á‡§§‡§É ‡§ñ‡•á‡§§‡§É ‡§∂‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§É ‡§∏‡•ã‡§™‡§ø ‡§®‡§π‡•Å ‡§µ-
‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§ò‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•á ‡§§‡§Æ‡§π‡§Æ‡§µ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•á ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§µ‡§∞‡§Ç‡•• ‡•ß‡•¶‡•¨131

**‡§µ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡§®‡•á ‡§∞[‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø]‡§Æ‡§∞‡•á‡§∂‡§Æ‡•à‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä-
‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§®‡§ó‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§ó‡§§‡•á ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•á
‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡§Ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡§ß‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø-
‡§¶‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡•• ‡•ß‡•¶‡•≠118
‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> **

L 55.

** ** <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> ‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§É ‡•§

**‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•à‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•à‡§É‡§∏‡•Å‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•à ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§Ø‡§§‡•Å‡•• ‡•ß‡•¶‡•Æ127 ‡§á‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ü‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•á <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> ** ‡§ó‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ö‡§Ç‡§°‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§µ‡•§
‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ã‡§£‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡•á‡§® ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ
‡§µ‡•à‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡§™‡§¶‡•á‡§Ω‡§ß‡§ø‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡•• ‡•ß‡•¶‡•Ø132
‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§®‡§æ ‡§∏‡§ö‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø
‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø[‡§™‡•Ç]

L 56.

** ‡§∞‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§≤‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•§**

‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§°‡•ç‡§°‡§Æ‡§∞‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞-
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§ó‡§æ‡§π‡§§ ‡§®‡§æ‡§ï‡§ø‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§Ç‡•• ‡•ß‡•ß‡•¶114
[‡§Ü] ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§∏‡§ï‡§≤‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§≠‡•Ç-
‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡•É[‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ]‡§Æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•Ç‡§ú‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§¶‡§®‡§∏‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø[‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï]

L 57.

** ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ] ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®‡§É
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•à‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∂‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§§‡§∏‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡•• ‡•ß‡•ß‡•ß133
‡§Ü‡§π‡§æ‡§¶‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§®[‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•ã] ‡§µ‡•à‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§∞‡§É‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ã ‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç‡•• ‡•ß‡•ß‡•®127
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡•à‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§æ‡§• ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§®‡•ç ‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡•à‡§ï‡§®‡§æ‡§•
‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§§‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§®‡§ø[‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‚Äì]**

L 58.

** ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§É
‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§Ø‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∏‡§≤‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§è‡§∑‡§É‡•• ‡•ß‡•ß‡•©134
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§æ[‡§Æ]** **<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622701S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709622384S.png"/> **
‡§∏‡§Ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§≠‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•ã‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§É‡•§
‡§ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ
‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¨‡§Ç‡§ß‡§É‡•§ ‡•ß‡•Ø‡•™119
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§®‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡§Ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§ó‡•ã[‡§§‡•ç‡§∞]‡§ú‡§É‡•§

L 59.

**‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§¶‡§®‡•ã‡§Ω‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ[‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç] ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§™‡•Å‡§Ç‡§ó‡§µ‡§É‡••‡•ß‡•ß‡•´135 **

‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π‡•á‡§® ‡§∂‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡•§

‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ä‡§£‡•á‡§® [‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶] ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•• ‡•ß‡•ß‡•¨

‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡•ß‡•©‡•ß‡•ß ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•á ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§† ‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡§ø ‡•ß‡•´ ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•á‡•• ‡§õ‡•• ‚Äî ‡••

‡§∂‡•Å [‡§≠‡§Ç] ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•Å‡•• ‡§õ‡••‡••

‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

V‚ÄîRATNAPUR STONE INSCRIPTION OFJAJALLADEVA, OF THE (CHEDI) YEAR 866.
BY PROF. F. KIELHOLN, Ph.D., C.H.E., G√ñTTINGEN.

This inscription is on a reddish-brown stone which was found at Ratnapur, in the Central Provinces, and is now in the N√¢gpur Museum.

The inscription consists of 31 lines. The writing originally ,covered a space of about 2‡•î2¬ΩÃã broad by 2‡•î 2Ãã high. At present, a small portion of the upper proper left corner and a large portion of the lower right corner of the stone are broken away, so that from 4 to 9 aksharas, are missing at the end of the first five lines, and from 2 to about 25 aksharas at the beginning of the last thirteen lines. Small portions of the stone appear to have broken away also at the upper right and lower left corners, and by the peeling off of the surface some aksharas have become illegible, especially in the last three lines of the inscription, as will appear from my transcript of the text.‚ÄîThe size of the letters generally varies from ¬Ω^(Ãã)to ‚Åµ/‚ÇàÃã, and is somewhat less in the five or six bottom lines. The characters are D√™van√¢gar√Æ. The language is Sanskrit, and, except for the introductory blessing and the date at the end, the inscription is in verse. The verses are numbered, and their total number is 34. The names of the composer, of the writer, and of the engraver appear to have been given in the concluding verses, but they are now illegible.‚ÄîIn respect of orthography we have to note the very frequent employment of the dental for the palatal sibilant (in saphar√Æ, line 1; sirasi, line 2; va·πÅs√™, line 4; visva, lines 4 and 16; satru, line 6; k√¥sam, line 7; s√¥bha·πÅ, line 9; srut√¢, line 13; saurya, lines 14 twice, 23, and 25; s√Æl√¢·πÅ≈õu, line 19; s√¥chi·∏•, line 19; S√µm√™svur√¥, line 20; *sir√¥,*line 23; as√™sham, line 24; s√¢sana·πÅ, line 28; s√¢svata·πÅ, line 28; s√¢stra, line 29; prasasti, lines 30 twice, and 31); the employment of the palatal for the dental sibilantsin tami≈õra, line 9, ≈õita·πÅ, line 19, and ≈õarasa·∏•, line 26; and the non-observance of the rules of Sa·πÅdhi in samabhavat ≈õr√Æ‚Äì, line 3, √¢s√Æt ≈õ√™sh√¢·πÅ≈õ = cha, line 6, and mitravat = ≈õriy√¢, line 20. The consonant b is denoted by the sign for v everywhere except in abdhi, line 18, where the proper sign for b has been employed.

The inscription refers itself to the reign of a prince J√¢jallad√™va of Ratnapura, a distant descendant of the Ch√™di ruler K√¥kalla; and it is dated in the year 866, expressed by decimal figures only, on the 9th day of the bright half of M√¢rga≈õ√Æraha, on Ravi or Sunday. And the inscription records (verses 27‚Äì31) certain religious benefactions,‚Äîthe establishment of a monastery for ascetics, the making of a garden and of a lake, probably also the foundation of, or the establishment of a temple at, J√¢jallapura, and the grant of the village of Sirul√Æ, and of Arjunak√¥·πáasara·πáa (?), &c., by the prince J√¢jallad√™va. Elsewhere I have tried to show that the epoch of the Ch√™di era is A.D. 218-49, and assuming the date of the present inscription to be recorded in that era, I

have found by Professor Jacobi’s tables that the 9th day of the bright fortnight of the month M√¢rga≈õ√Ærsha, 866, corresponds to the 8th November, A.D. 1114, which was a Sunday, as required. On that day, at sunrise, the 9th tithi of the bright half of the month was current, and it ended 19 h. 54 m. after mean sunrise.136

By way of introduction, the inscription gives the following account of the prince J√¢jallad√™ya and his ancestors:‚Äî

In the lunar race there was K√¢rtav√Ærya (v. 2), the ancestor of Haihaya, from whom were born the Haihayas (v. 3). In the race of these princes was born the Ch√™di ruler K√¥kalla, whose residence or country appears to be called Tritasaurya (v. 4). K√¥kalla had eighteen, sons, of whom the first born was ruler of Tripur√Æ, while the others became lords of ma·πá·∏çalas (v. 5). A descendant of one of these younger sons was Kali·πÖgar√¢ja, who left Tritasaurya and acquired Dakshi≈Üak√¥≈õala (v. 6), where he settled at Tu·πÅm√¢≈Üa (v. 7). His son was Kamalar√¢ja (v. 8), and his son agam, Ratnar√¢ja (v. 9) or Ratn√™≈õa,who ornamented Tu·πÅma·πáa with temples, gardens, &c. (v. 10), and founded Ratnapura (v. 11-12). He married N√¥nall√¢, a daughter of Vajj√ªka, the prince of the K√¥m√™ ma·πá·∏çala (v. 13), who bore to him a son, Prithv√Æd√™va or P·πõithv√Æ≈õa, who succeeded Ratnar√¢ja (v.14-16), and built temples at Tu·πÅm√¢na and a tank at Ratnapura (v. 17). He married R√¢jall√¢ (v. 18), who bore to him J√¢jallad√™va (v. 19). J√¢jalla was allied with the ruler of Ch√™di (v. 20), and honoured by the princes of Kanyakubja and. J√™j√¢bhuktika (v. 21); he defcated and captured in battle one S√¥m√™≈õvara (v. 22); and ho had either annual tribute paid or presents given to him by the chiefs of the ma·πá·∏çalas of… [Dakshina]‚Äìk√¥≈õala, Andhra, Khimid√Æ, Vair√¢gara, La√±jik√¢, Bh√¢·πáara, Talah√¢ri; Da·πá·∏çakapura, Nand√¢val√Æ, and Kukku·π≠a (v. 23).

I am not at present able to give a satisfactory account of the countries and places mentioned in the preceding. The name Tu·πÅm√¢·πáa we shall meet again in the two following inscriptions, where it denotes a country or district, not a town. Perhaps it may have been the original name of the “Jun√¢ Shahar,” which is mentioned as being close to Ratnapur in Arch√¶ological Survey of India Reports, vol. VII, p. 216. Vair√¢gara and La√±jik√° may be readily identified with Wairagarh and L√¢nji on the map, plate I, appended to vol. XVII of the Arch√¶ological Survey of India. The Talah√¢ri ma·πá·∏çala is mentioned in lines 6 and 20 of a Ratnapur inscription of [Ch√™di-] Sa·πÅvat 915, which has suffered in the most deplorable manner, since it was first drawn attention to by Sir R. Jenkins in the Asiatic Researches, vol. XV, p. 504. Both

Talah√¢ri and K√¥m√¥ occur in the inscription from R√¢j√Æm which has been edited in the same volume of the Asiatic Researches; and the name Komo is found, in ‘Komo Pass’ and ‘Komo Choki,’ on the maps, about 30 miles to the north of Ratnapur. A place, Kimedi or Khimide in Ganj√¢m, is mentioned in the Indian Antiquary, vol. XVI, p. 131; and as we there have the name Parl√¢‚ÄìKimedi, we may possibly have to read in the present inscription Andhra-Khimi·∏ç√Æ, not Andhra and Khimi·∏ç√Æ.

The prince of Kanyakubja akuded to in our inscription probably was Govindachandra (Indian Antiquary, vol. XV, p. 6); the prince of J√™j√¢bhuktika (or Bundelkhand sce Hultzsch in Zeitsch. Deutsch, Morg. Ges., vol XL, p. 49, note), the Chand√™lla king K√Ærtivarmad√™va (Indian Antiquary, vol. XVI, p. 202; and Arch√¶ological Survey of India, yol. XXI, page 85); and the ruler of Ch√™di, Ya≈õahkar·πáa or Gayakar·πáa of Tripur√Æ. S√¥m√©≈õvar√† I had thought of identifying with the prince of that name, the father of the Ch√¢hum√¢na prince Prithv√Ær√¢ja Arch√¶ological Survey of India, vol. XXI,p.174); but as that S√¥me≈õvara appears to have died in A.D. 1169 (Journal As. Soc. of Bengal, vol. LV, pt. I, p. 15), he could hardly have been defeated by J√¢jallad√™va before. A.D. 1114.

31.………………[[‡••33‡••]]145; and of the next verse.")……………….dhar√¥vu(bu)-dha·∏•prasa(≈õa)sti·πÅpr√¢pta- [svarvv√¢] s√¢·πÅv√¢sta…[nu]j√¥= likhat ‡••34‡••[Sa] ·πÅvat 866 M√¢rga su di 9 Ravau ‡•§[J√¢ja(?)153.`")-√™‚Äî?]

TRANSLATION.

√îm !

(Verse 1.)‚ÄîMay that √é≈õa grant prosperity !‚Äîheon whose head ….. is it the crescent portion [of the moon], abiding by the shore of the celestial river, the waters of which are augmented by the flood of the nectar fluid …………..?or is it, oh, acarp,………….thus gone to heaven……….!

(V. 2.)‚ÄîThis highest light dispelling darkness, having the lustre of the eye of the three worlds, which men call ‚Äòthe mine of nectar,‚Äô……… not the last, whence (there is).

the line of universal sovereignty of the regal order,‚Äîin his (the moon’s) primeval race there was born on earth the illustrious K√¢rtav√Ærya.

(V. 3.)‚ÄîOf hisrace, was Haihaya, from whom were born the Haihayas**……….**(?).

(V. 4.)‚Äî Inthe race of these Haihaya princes was born that ruler of Ch√™di, the illustrious K√¥kalla, an image of the god of love, whence all derived delight; by whom, (being) on earth, in order to measure his own fame, how much it might be, this**………..**of (?) Tritasaurya was sent up high into the universe.

(V. 5.)‚Äî He had eighteen sons, who destroyed the enemies as lions do elephants, (and) who increased**…….**The first-born son among them afterwards was ruler of Tripur√Æ, and he made the remaining brothers lords of ma·πá·∏çalas.

(V. 6.)‚ÄîThe race of one among these younger brothers in the course of time obtained an unequalled son, Kali·πÖgar√¢ja, a tree of prowess grown large by the water of the eyes of the wives of enemies; who, in order not to impoverish the treasury of Tritasaurya, abandoned the ancestral land and acquired by his two armsthis country Dakshi·πáak√¥≈õala.

(V. 7.)‚Äî Since Tu·πÅm√¢·πáa had been made a royal residence by his ancestors, therefore residing there, he increased his fortune, causing the destruction of his enemies.

(V. 8.)‚Äî As the cool-rayed (moon) from the oceanso was born here from him Kamalar√¢ja, lovely by his expanding spotless fame; through whom the lotus-group of the minds of men received exceeding lustre, (and) who dispelled, like blinding darkness, the hostile people.

(V. 9.)‚Äî As the ocean (produced) the Kaustubha for the decoration of the supporter of the earth (Vish·πáu), so he begat Ratnar√¢ja, who verily conquered the prowess of heroes, to be an ornament of princes.

(V. 10.)‚ÄîTu·πÅm√¢·πáa with its temples of the holy Va·πÖk√™≈õa and other (gods) and also (of) Ratn√™≈õvara and the rest, with a garden containing innumerable flowers and beautiful fruit, (and) a charming high mango grove, (and) crowded with palatial dwellings, decorated with charming beauty, was made by Ratn√™≈õa pleasant to the eyes, when viewed by the people.

(V. 11.)‚Äî This extensive glorious Ratnapura, which Ratn√™≈õvara built, has its fame listened to in (every) quarter; held by a great lord, it is like the city of (Kuv√™ra) the lord of riches; it is full of many-coloured sparkling jewels and hence like (the ocean) the abode of jewels; and since it is decorated with many temples, it looks like heaven, (with the many families of gods).

(V. 12.)‚Äî On all sides Ratnapura there says;If Ratnar√¢ja ordered me to be built on the earth, (and) if the foreman of the guild acquired fame, may the fame of these two proceed from me to the three worlds! (?).

(V. 13.)‚ÄîN√¥nall√¢, the famous daughter of Vajj√ªka, the prince of the K√¥m√¥ ma·πá·∏çala, was married by Ratnar√¢ja, together with the majesty of princes.

(V. 14.)‚ÄîFrom her was born P·πõithv√Æ≈õa, endowed with the qualities of righteousness and bravery. He led to heaven his kinsmen through his righteousness, and his enemies through his bravery in battle.

(V. 15.)‚ÄîWhen Ratnar√¢ja, who by his bravery and other (qualities) conquered the enemies in battle, had gone to heaven through his action (worthy) of heaven, his son P·πõithv√Æd√™va, the royal hero, became ruler of the earth after him. He was (really) a

god on earth (P·πõithv√Æ-d√™va), inasmuch as the frightened tribe of kings verily offered adoration to him, regarding him to be a guardian of the world in consequence of his many excellent qualities, among which lordly nature, bestowing of prosperity, and bravery were foremost.

(V. 16.)‚Äî And ruled over by P·πõithv√Æd√™va, the earth verily was Heaven (itself). And this marvel was strikingly manifest from the fact, that (the earth) everywhere was dwelled on by heroes, spread over with abundant fortune, (and) covered with hundred sacrifices; that it had a splendid great lord, and was (in consequence) unshaken; that the learned on it caused joyto everybody; that it was built over with extensive stuecoed buildings, (and) was without a second154; containing the splendid great lord (≈öiva) and Achyuta (Vish·πáu); containing the planet Meroury (Budha) which causes joy to the universe, and the moon, the habitation of nectar, which moves about in heaven.")

(V. 17.)‚Äî For the glory of religion (shrines of) P·πõithv√Æd√™v√™≈õvara and others (were established) at Tu·πÅ·πÅ√¢·πáa, and a tank resembling the ocean was built by him at Ratnapura.

(V.18.)‚Äî He married R√¢jall√¢, who by her loveliness shone like the moon, who was like Lakshm√Æ(the beloved of Achyuta) inasmuch as her love was unshaken, (and) like P√¢rvat√Æ by her beauty.

(V. 19.)‚ÄîAs Indra (begat) Jayanta on Aindr√Æ, (and) the ocean the moonin the beauty of heaven, so P·πõithv√Æd√™va on her begat the famous J√¢jalla.

(V. 20.)‚ÄîStrange (to relate), his fame, shining like the lustre of the cool-rayed (moon) in every direction, rendered a hundred women red (with affection), while it made this world white, and the eneimiess black. The illustrious J√¢jalla, who rises up a hero day by day on account of the abundance of his prowess, was by the ruler of Ch√™di, forming an alliance of princes (?)155**……….**friendship.

(V. 21.)‚Äî By the ruler of Kanyakubja (and) the prince of J√™j√¢bhuktika, considering him a hero on account of his prowess, he was like a friend honoured with fortune.

(V. 22.)‚ÄîHe who is possessed of even sevenfold fortune; and (by whom?) was seized in battle S√¥m√™≈õvara**……….** having slain an immense army (and) by whom was captured, and afterwards at his mother’s request released, the group156of counsellors and wives; ‚Äîtell me, have you seen or heard of such (another) prince on earth?

(V. 23.)‚ÄîTo whom verily the princely rulers of these ma·πá·∏çalas, (viz.)………… [Dakshi]·πáak√¥≈õala, Andhra, Khimi·∏çi, Vair√¢gara, La√±jik√¢, Bh√¢·πá√¢ra, Talah√¢ri, Da·πá·∏çakapura, Nand√¢val√Æ, Kukku·π≠a,‚Äîsome out of friendship, some to delight (him), gave**…….**fixed year by year.

(V. 24.)‚ÄîOf whom, endowed with majesty, the unique umbrella held over his head, while causing coolness to (his) people, strange (to ·πõelate), may well cause heartburning of enemies.

(V. 25.)‚Äî Nobility, bravery, depth**……….**he possesses; thus (his) expanding fame was proclaimed by the earth with the uplifted very splendid excellent arms‚Äîthe habitations of the gods.

(V. 26.)‚ÄîIs this that entirely bodiless god of love, who has not been seen by the eye of the three-eyed (≈öiva)? Is it Vaiku·πá·π≠ha**…….**with fortune? Is he, a Hero on

account of his heroism, the moon by his mighty splendour, the bestower of fortune (Kuv√™ra), dear to supplicants ? By the people, thus deliberating,157was he at last found out to be J√¢jallad√™va.

(V. 27.)‚ÄîThe glorious J√¢jallapura …………. [and an auspicious] monastery (ma·π≠ha) for ascetics; a mango grove with a garden; a pleasant lake, too, equal to the lake of heaven, which was caused to be made by the illustrious J√¢jalla, may that be, shining like fame,……..

(V. 28.)‚ÄîHis religious advisar (was) the illustrious Rudra≈õiva, who knew the authoritative doctrines of.…… pa, Dign√¢ga (?), and others, and knew his own and others‚Äôestablished truths.

(V. 29.)‚ÄîHis minister for peace and war also was Vigrahar√¢ja,…………

(V. 30.)‚ÄîThe prince J√¢jalla gave to the godthe excellent village of Sirul√Æ, to the monastery a group of p√¢·π≠al√¢trees, as a perpetual grant.

(V. 31.)‚Äî Arjunak√¥·πáasara·πáa (?) he.……………..

(V. 32.) The K√¢yastha, the illustrious**…….in the Sau·∏ça family……..** the leader of those whose counsel rivals the preceptor**…….illustrious…….who is anunequalled proficient in the essence of the ≈ö√¢stras………,**has composed the unequalledeulogy on J√¢jallad√™va.

(v. 33.)‚Äî**….**rbh√™≈õa has brought his spotless qualities into the eulogy, the excellent

(V.34.)‚Äî**…….the learned … dhara, the younger brother…..,**has written the eulogy which has obtained a dwelling in heaven.

The year 866; the 9th day of the bright half of M√¢rga[≈õ√Ærsha]; ona Sunday. J√¢ja**…….**(?).

** VI. ‚Äî MALHAR STONE INSCRIPTION OF JAJALLADEVA,**

OF THE (CHEDI) YEAR 919.

By Prof. F. KIELHORN, Ph.D., C.I.E., G√ñTTINGEN.

This inscription is on a black stone, now in the N√¢gpur Museum, where itappearsto have been brought from Malh√¢r in the Central Provinces.

The inscription consists of 28 lines. The writing covers a space of from 2’ 3¬Ω"to 2‚Ä≤ 4¬Ω ‚Ä≥ broad by 1‚Ä≤ 6¬Ω" high. At the upper proper right corner a small piece of the stone appears to have broken away, so that the first four aksharas of the first line are missing; otherwise the inscription is complete, and well preserved almost throughout. The size of the letters is¬Ω".‚ÄîThe characters are D√™van√¢gar√Æ.‚ÄîThe language is Sanskrit, and, except for the introductory blessing and the date at the end, the inscription is in verse. The verses are numbered, and their total number is 26. They were composed by Ratnasi·πÅha, son of M√¢m√™, of the V√¢stavya race; and the inscription was written by the Kshatriya Kum√¢rap√¢la, of the Sahasr√¢rjuna race, and engraved by the sculptor S√¢mpla (verses 23-26). In respect of orthography we have to note the employment of the dental for the palatal sibilant and vice vers√¢ in saurya, line 8, and vy√¢≈õakta, line 25; the use of the dental n instead of the anusv√¢ra in m√Æm√¢ns√¢, line 16, and anhri, line 26; the exceptional denotation of √±cha by the sign for ncha in bh√ªtin=cha,

line T3; and the non-observance of the rules of Sa·πÅdhi in √¢vahan ≈öubhra-, line 4.The consonant bis throughout denoted by the sign for v.

The inscription refers itself to the reign of a prince J√¢jallad√©va, a ruler of Tumm√¢·πáa, of the Ch√™di family; and it is dated, in figures only, in the year 919, which, taken as a year of the Ch√™di era, would correspond to A.D. 1167-1168. And it records the erection, at the town of Mall√¢la, of a temple of the god K√™d√¢ra (Ke., ≈öiva) by the Br√¢hman S√¥mar√¢ja, a younger son of Ga·πÖg√¢dhara, who in turn was theson of P·πõithv√Ædhara. In the introductory portion we are, told that the prince J√¢jallad√™va was preceded by his father P·πõickv√Æd√™va, who again was the son of the prince Ratnad√™va, the vanquisher of Ch√¥·∏ça and Ga·πÖga princes, of the lunar race (verses 4-7). And we are further informed that the Br√¢hman P·πõithvidhara had been settled at the village Kumbha·π≠√Æin ‘Madhyad√™≈õa; and that his son Ga·πÖg√¢dhara had come from there to the country Tumm√¢·πáa, and had been honoured by the prince Ratnad√™va with the gift of the village K√¥samb√Æ. (Verses 9-13.)

Mall√¢la most probably is the modern Malh√¢r (or Malar), where the inscription is stated to have been found. The other places I am unable to identify.

  8. l√¢n =cha ≈õriyam [ma]tv√¢ dharmm√™mation = adhad = vu(bu)dha·∏• ‡••20¬π‚Åπ145; and of the next verse.")‡••T√™na K√™d√¢ra-d√™vasya dh√¢ma Mall√¢la pattan√™dhimat√° k√¢rita·πÅramya·πÅsvaya≈õ√¥-r√¢≈õi-bh√¢suram‡••21‡••Urvv√Æm = √¢li·πÖgya p√¢rvva·πÅguru-

  9. jaghana-ghan-√¢≈õl√™sha-lav (b) dha-pram√¥d√¢m = √™tat-K√¢shth√¢-vadh√ªn√¢·πÅ dhvaja-bhuja-valanai·∏• ≈õl√™sha-daksha·πÅsamant√¢t‡•§ k√¢ma-vy√¢≈õa(sa) kta-ch√™t√¢iva vivu(bu)dha-pur√Æ-sundar√Æ·πá√¢·πÅsamaksh√™ tyakta-vr√Æ·∏ça·πÅnik√¢ma·πÅgagana-parisara·∏• ≈öri-

  10. mukha·πÅchumv(b)at = √Æva ‡••22‡••161K√¢≈õyap√Æy-√¢kshap√¢d√Æya-naya-siddh√¢nta-v√™din√¢‡•§vipaksha-v√¢di-si·πÅh√™na Ratnasi·πÅh√™na dh√Æmat√¢‡••23‡••145.")≈ör√Æ-R√¢ghav-√¢n(·πÅ)hri-kamal-√¢mv (b)udhar-√¢bhish√™ka-lav(b)dh-√¥data-pratata-≈õ√¢-

  11. kha-mah√Æruh√™·πáa ‡•§V√¢stavya-va·πÅ≈õa-kamal-√¢kara-bh√¢nun-√™ya·πÅ‡•§M√¢m√™-sut√™na rachit√¢ ruchir√¢pra≈õasti·∏•‡••24‡••114 Iya·πÅSahasr√¢rjjuna-va·πÅ≈õaj√™na kut√ªhal√¢t-ksha-triya-pu·πÖgav√™na ‡•§Kum√¢rap√¢-

  12. l√™na gun-√¢bhir√¢ma-r√¢m=√™va ramy√¢likhit√¢ pra≈õasti·∏•‡••25‡••119An√™ka-silpar-nirmm√¢·πáa-pay√¥dh√™·∏•p√¢ra-d·πõi≈õvan√¢‡•§utk√Ær·πá·πá√¢r√ªpak√¢r√™·πáa S√¢·πÅpul√™n=√™yam=√¢dar√¢t ‡••26‡••145.") Samvat 919[‡••*].

TRANSLATION.

√îm! √îm!

Adoration to ≈öiva!

(Verse 1.)‚Äî May that ≈öambhu always protect you !‚Äîhe who, wearing on his head, like water-lilies169,a mass of braided hair, (and) spreading around the lustre of a blazing lamp with the fire of his third eye which, as on a lamp-stand, is on his broad forehead, (and) covered with the streams of water of the high waves of the celestial river, possesses the beauty of an auspicious jar!

(V. 2.)‚ÄîMay that lovely trunk of Ga·πáapati for ever guard you!‚Äî which at daybreak, when lifted out of the waters of the celestial river into which it has been dipped, raised up and threatening, possesses a charm as if it were the stalk of the great lotus‚Äîthe circle of the universe!

(V. 3.)‚Äî Triumphant is that god with white rays, (the moon), born from the ocean, (who is) the root of great joy to the world, (and) possesses skill in removing the haughty reserve that closes (the hearts of) tremulous-cyed women; who covers the circle of the regions of the sky with a mass of drops trickling down from a multitude of streams of nectar; (who is) the mirror of the army of the king Love, (and) the friend of the night-lotuses.

(V. 4.)‚ÄîIn his race there was, beautiful (and) an habitation of Fortune, the protector of the earth, the illustrious Ratnad√™va; a fierce cloud to extinguish the

continuously raging flames of the spreading mighty fire of the prowess of Ch√¥·∏ç√±a and Ganga princes,170 (and) a blazing fire to consume the unique tree of the pride in their creeper-like long arms of all the hostile heroic rulers of the earth.

(V. 5.)‚Äî After him came his son Prithy√Æd√™va, a master of the whole extent of the terrestrial globe;, who to the mighty hostile lords of the earth was what Garu·∏ça is to the serpent-chiefs; whose two lotus-feet171were an object of worship for (princes) bent down with the weight of jasmine wreaths glittering with the great splendour of their crest-jewels; a high pleasure-mount for the glory of victory of his own arm; a tree for the creeping-plant fame, of excellent royalty.

(V. 6.)‚Äî From him was born the prinde J√¢jallad√™va; the leader of the princes who delight in keeping up the Ch√™di family; who by the pride of his two-massive arms annihilated the enemies; the ruler of Tumm√¢na, illumining like alamp his own spotless family, a unique treasury of excellent royalty, a sun of prowess who has acquired fortune by his heroism.

(V.7.)‚Äî I fancy that through fear, produced by the suspicion that they would have to give (them) to him, the ocean of milk, the husband of the rivers, kept (his) mass of jewels in the deep water agitated by the fear-inspiring (beasts) within it, and the sungod (his) horses, and the lord of the gods (Indra) his elephant, who enlivens rows of female bees with streams of rutting-juice, in the heavens rendered impassable by the waters of the celestial river.

(V. 8.)‚Äî In the reign of this prince, which follows the path of good government, is free from the contact of troubles, (and) causes joy to the people172.

(V. 9.)‚ÄîThere was in the glorious Madhyad√©≈õa, ornamented by the garland of the waves of the streams of water of the extended river of the gods, (and itself) as it were the necklace of the whole orb of the earth crowded with countries, a village named Kumbha·π≠√Æ, with pleasant broad lands, a dwelling-place of the best of the twice-born, which the creator had exerted himself to make the spotless counterpart of a portion of heaven.

(V. 10.)‚ÄîIn that (village) there was a twice-born named P·πõithv√Ædhara, in the g√¥tra of K·πõish·πÖ√¢tr√™ya, ornamented with the (three) auspicious pravaras, √Çtr√™ya the first, and after him the famous √Çrchan√¢na the second, (and) Sasy√¢v√¢sa173the third; whose pair of fect was covered with the lustre of the jewels which likesprouts were trembling on the heads of rows of protectors of the earth bowing down (before him).

(V. 11.)‚Äî From him there was born a son, that Ga·πÖg√¢dhara who, bearing on his head the beautiful title of ‚Äòking of the twice-born,‚Äôalways had knowledge as a third unique largeeye; (and) who, warding off the irresistible passion of love, secured for himself excellent welfare; (who) in a crowd of hostilo disputants resorted to (arguments) difficult to be met; (resembling ≈öiva Ga·πÖg√¢dhara, who, having on his

crest a spot beautified by the moon, possesses a large third eye; who annihilated the irresistible god of love, spreads excellent ashes over his body, and embraces Durg√¢).

(V. 12.) ‚ÄîThen that crest-jewel of the twice-born, who had acquired great fortune by the collection of his good qualities, inthe course of time came to the country Tumm√¢·πáa.

(V. 13.) ‚ÄîTo him the lord of the earth Ratnad√™va gave, after he had washed his lotus-feet, the villag√© of K√¥samb√Æ, (confirming his gift by the) pouring out (of) wat√©r.

(V. 14.) ‚Äî From the illustrious Ga·πÖg√¢dh√¢r√¢there was born, as a younger son, that illustrious S√¥mar√¢ja whose unique feet are an object of adoration for the people, causing great joy, free from blemishes, a treasury-house, √≥f numerous arts; who holds the position of king of the twice-born, is possessed of wide and abundant splendour inasmuch as be avoids the company of the dull, (and) is an ornament of the orb of the earth; (being) freed from its spot, a second moon (whose rays are an object of adoration for the world, which causes great joy, is the receptacle of growing digit≈°, bearsthe name of ‚Äòking of the twice-born;‚Äôwhich, united with miserable cold, is spreading its splendour far and wide, and is an ornament to the orb of the earth).

(V. 15.) ‚ÄîThat venerable person, who is a treasury of the pride of having no rival in the doctrine of K√¢≈õyapa and in the S√¢·πÅkhya, has completely mastered the two Mƒµm√¢·πÅs√¢s; (like ≈öiva) he is possessed of three eyes inasmuch as he has for his eye the teaching of Akshap√¢da. Hecrushed the great conceit of Ch√¢rv√¢ka, delighted the pitcher-born sage (Agastya) by drinking up the difficult-to-be-restrained Bauddha ocean, (and is) a god of death to the Digambaras.174

(V. 16.) ‚Äî At his house dexterous peacocks, delighted when they see the circle of the regions of the sky incessantly blackened by lines of smoke rising from groups of sacrificial fire-pits, which they mistake to be lines of black clouds moving about, dance again and again with spread-out wings, enlivened by the long-drawn sound of Vedic texts recited by the mouths of Br√¢hmans (which they mistake for thunder).

(V. 17.) ‚Äî Afraid as it were of having to give (their precious stones) to him, the mountain of gold keeps an impervious place, the ocean has itself guarded at the shores by thorny trees and by lions and other terrific beasts, (and) S√™sha even places his jewels in the multitude of his hoods, terrible with the sheets of flickering poison-flames ejected by the mouth with sharp fangs.

(V. 18.)‚Äî Him that lotus-born (Brahman) created, desirous as it were of seeing on the earth the most excellent collection of good qualities, after he had severally taken, beauty from the lord of Rati desiring to conquer the universe, gravity from the mountain of gold, depth from the ocean, nevor-ceasing175splendour from the thousand-rayed (sun, and) the lordly nature of (≈öiva) the destroyer of the god of love.

(V. 19.) ‚ÄîThe swan of his fame, having frequently again and again roamed about by the water on the shores of the seven oceans, unweariedly went to the abode of the gods, longing for the heavenly Ganges; (and) having eaten (there) tender lotus-fibres and pieces of lotus-stalks, it has, pining with excessive longing, rapturously come, to enjoy itself, to the lotus-grounds of the interior of the vessel-like egg of Brahman176.

(V. 20.)‚Äî Having reflected that the life of man is unsteady like a tuft of grass which moves when struck by the wind, and that fortune is fickle; he, the wise, set his mind on religion.

(V. 21.)‚Äî Possessed of intelligence, he caused to be built at the town of Mall√¢la a charming temple of the god K√™d√¢ra, resplendent like the accumulation of his own fame.

(V. 22.)‚Äî Having first embraced the earth, which derived pleasure from the close embrace of his heavy thighs, the surrounding sky, having as it were the heart filled with love, void of bashfulness within sight of the beautiful damsels of the city of the gods eagerly kisses, as if it were the face of, Fortune, this (temple) fit to be embraced on all sides by the encircling banner-like arms of the women of the regions.

(Verses 23 and 24.)‚Äî This pleasing eulogy has been composed by the son of M√¢m√™, the intelligent Ratnasimha, who knows the established truths of the doctrines of K√¢≈õyapa and of Akshap√¢da, (and is) a lion to opponent disputants; who owes his elevation, as a tree with wide-spread branches does its growth to showers from clouds, to the lotus-feet of the illustrious R√¢ghava177;(and who is) to the V√¢stavya race (what) the sun (is) to a group of lotuses.

(V. 25.)‚ÄîThis eulogy, charming like a woman who is pleasing by her good qualities, has been eagerly written by the excellent Kshatriya Kum√¢rap√¢la, born in the Sahasr√¢rju·πáa race.

(V. 26.)‚ÄîEngraved it has been with care by the sculptor S√¢mpula, who has seen the opposite bank of the ocean of various mechanical arts.

The year 919.

VII.‚Äî RATNAPUR INSCRIPTION OF PRITHVIDEVA,

OF THE (VIKRAMA) YEAR 1247 (?).

BY PROF. F. KIELHORN, Ph.D., C.I.E., G√ñTTINGEN.

This inscription is on a black stone, which was discovered within the fort of Ratnapur in the Central Provinces178,and is now in the N√¢gpur Museum.

The inscription consists of 24 lines. The writing originally covered a space of about 2¬¥ 5¬ΩÃã broad by 1¬¥ 1Ãã high; at present, a portion of the proper left side, all the way down, and the lower right corner of the stone, are broken away, so that altogether about ninety aksharas are missing. The stone evidently was less injured when Dr. R√¢jendral√¢l‚Äôs rubbing was taken. What remains of the inscription is well preserved.‚ÄîThe size of the letters is about¬≥/‚ÇàÃã .‚ÄîThe characters are D√™van√¢gar√Æ.‚ÄîThe language is Sanskrit, and, excepting the introductory blessing and the date at the end, the inscription is in verse. The verses are numbered, and their total number is 30. They were composed by D√™vagana, son of Ratnasi·πÅha; written by Kum√¢rap√¢la, or, as he is called here, KumƒÉrap√¢la; and engraved by S√¢mpula (verses 26-28).‚ÄîIn respect of orthography, we have to note the employment of the dental for the palatal sibilant in su·πá·∏ç√¢, line 2, saurya, line 6, Sach√Æ, line 10, s√¢≈õvat√™, line 18, and sikhara, line 19;

the use of the dental n instead of the anusv√°ra in’ avatansa·∏•, line 4; the employment of the upadhm√¢n√Æya in punpavantau, line 17; the exceptional denotation of √±cha by the sign for ncha in chanchar√Æka·∏•, line 11, kincha, line 13, and chakran=cha, line 23; and the non-observance of the rules of Sa·πÅdhi in dhavalam=vil√¥kya, line 12, and idam=vidagdh√¥, line 20. The consonant b is throughout denoted by the sign for v.

The inscription refers itself to the reign of a prince Prithv√éd√™va, son and successor of the Ch√™di prince [Ratnad√™va], the vanquisher of Ch√¥da and Ga·πÖga champions, who was the son and successor of a prince J√¢jallad√™va, of the lunar race (verses 4-6). And it records (in verse 24) the erection at the village of S√¢mb√¢, of a Siva‚Äìtemple by one D√™vagana, the glorification of whom and whose ancestors, wives, and children fills just half the number of verses of the inscription (verses 8-22). The great-grandfather of D√™vagana, Govinda, of the [V√¢stavya] race, had come from the Ch√¥di ma·πá·∏çala to Tumma·πáa, the country ruled over by the above-mentioned princes. G√¥vinda had two sons, M√¢m√™ and R√¢ghava; and M√¢m√™’s son again was Ratnasi·πÅha, he father of D√™vagana. This D√™vagana, the founder of the temple, himself composed, as we have seen above, this very inscription; and his father Ratnasi·πÅha is the author of the preceding Malh√¢r inscription, dated [Ch√™di-] Sa·πÅvat 919=A.D/1167-1168.

According to Dr. R√¢j√™ndral√¢l Mitra, the inscription is dated in [Vikrama-] Sa·πÅvat 1207=A. D. 1149-50. But, on the rubbing before me, the figures (scratched on the stone rather than properly engraved, and perhaps added some time after the inscription itself was engraved) look certainly more like 1247 than 1207. Besides, a comparison of the verses 3, 8, 12, 20, and 22 of the Malh√¢r inscription of [Ch√™di-] Sa·πÅvat 919=A.D. 1167-68 with the verses 3, 7, 8, 23, and 25 of the present Ratnapur inscription, as well as some minor resemblances, show that the author of this inscription, D√™vaga·πáa, had his father’s Malh√¢r inscription before him when he wrote his own composition. Taking further into consideration that this inscription, eulogizes five of the grandchildren of Ratnasi·πÅha, the composer of the Malh√¢r inscription, I feel certain that it has been composed considerably later than A.D. 1167-68=Vikrama-Sa·πÅvat 1225, and I think it probable that the figures at the end of it are really Vikrama-Sa·πÅvat 1217=A.D. 1189-90, and that these figures, by whom and whensoover added, furnish a true date for the prince Prithv√Æd√™va, in whose reign the inscription was composed. How well this date agrees with the other known dates of the earlier rulers of Ratnapur, may be seen from the following list of those rulers, which has been compiled from the three inscriptions here published, and from the R√¢j√Æm inscription of Jagap√¢la :‚Äî

(1.) Kali·πÖgar√¢ja.

(2.) Kamalar√¢ja.

(3.) Ratnar√¢ja (or Ratn√™≈õa).

(4) Prithv√Æsa (or Prithv√Æd√™va).

(5.) J√¢jalla (or J√¢jallad√™va); according to the first inscription here published, [Ch√™di-] Sa·πÅvat 866=A.D. 1114.

(6.) Ratnad√™va.

(7.) P·πõithv√Æd√™va; according to the R√¢j√Æm inscription, Kulachuri-sa·πÅvatsar√™ 896=A.D. 1145 ; and, according to Archaol. Survey of India, Volume XVII, Plate xx, Kulachuri-sa·πÅvatsara 910=A.D. 1158-59.

(8.) J√¢jallad√™va; according to the second inscription here published, [Ch√™di-] Sa·πÅvat 919=A.D. 1167-68.

(9.) Ratnad√™va; according to Archeol. Survey of India, Volume XVII, page 43, line 4 from the bottom, and Plate XX, Ch√™di-Sa·πÅvat 933=A.D. 1181-82.

(10.) P·πõithv√Æd√™va; according to the present inscription, [Vikrama] Sa·πÅvat 1247 (?)=A.D. 1189-90 (?)

  1. r=Gg√¥vinda≈õ-Ch√™di-mandal√¢t ‡•§ krit√Æ k√¢la-kram√™n-√¢sau d√™≈õan-Tumm√¢·πáam=√¢ga-ta·∏• \‡•§\‡•§ 8\‡•§\‡•§ Putras-tasya jan-√¢nur√¢ga-jaladhir-bh√ªbh·πõit-sabh√¢-bh√ªshan√¥ jy√¢y√¢n=pa·πá·∏çita-pundar√Æka-tara·πáir-Mm√†m√©‚Äôbhidh√¢no ‚Äôbhavat ‡•§ y√¥ dh√¢tr√Æ-tilak√¥ [[ni]]187<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1698747256CHANDA8.JPG"/>
  1. 1-√¢la·πák√¢ra-h√¢r-√¥pam√¥ vikhy√¢tas=Tripur√†ntak-aika-chara·πá-√¢mbh√¥j-aika-bh·πõi·πÖg√¥ bhuvi \‡•§\‡•§9\‡•§\‡•§118 Bhr√¢t√¢ ≈õr√Æ-R√¢ghav√¥ ‚Äômushya kan√Æy√¢n=gu·πáa-s√¢gara·∏• n√¢gar√¥ bhu-van-√¢bh√¥ga-bh√ªsh√¢ P√ªsh-√¥pam√¥ va(ba) bhau \‡•§\‡•§10\‡•§\‡•§145.") ≈ör√Æ-M√¢m√™-tanaya·∏• samasta-[jaga[t√Æ]]188^(<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1698747337CHANDA9.JPG"/>)
  1. r·πá·πána-k√Ær·πá·πáa-sphurat-kund-√™ndu-dyuti- k√Ærtti-santati -lat√¢-vy√¢sakta- di·πÖ-ma·πá·∏ça-pa·∏• ‡•§ r√¢jaty=unmada-v√¢di-v·πõinda-dalan√¥ l√Æl√¢-vih√¢ra·∏• ≈õriya·∏• ≈õ√Æl-√¢ch√•ra-vi[v√™]ka-pu·πáya-nilaya·∏• ≈õr√Æ-Ratnasi·πÅha·∏• kavi·∏• \‡•§\‡•§11\‡•§\‡•§118 Sa(≈õa)ch-√Æva Jish·πá√¥r=Ggirij=[√™[va]-]189

  1. mbh√¥r=Dugdh√¢v(b)dhi-putr-√Æva cha Chakrap√¢n√™·∏• ‡•§ s√¢dhv√Æ sad√¢ va(ba)ndhu-jan-√¢bhip√ªjy√¢ Rambh-√™ti n√¢m√¢‚Äôbhavad=asya patn√Æ \‡•§\‡•§12\‡•§\‡•§119 T√¢bhy√¢m-aj√¢yata jagat-traya-ghush·π≠a-k√Ærttir = √¢kha·πá·∏çit-√¢ri-vu(bu)dha-ma·πá·∏çala-cha·πá·∏ça-darppa·∏• ‡•§ Chand√Æ≈õa-ch√¢ru-charan-√¢mv(b)uja-chan (√±)char√Æka·∏• pra[j√±√¢]-pa<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1698747682CHANDA11.JPG"/>

  2. r=iha D√™vaga·πáas-tan√ªja·∏• \‡•§\‡•§13\‡•§\‡•§114 Etad-yasya jagad=ya≈õ√¥bhir=abhit√¥ ·∏çi·πá·∏ç√Æra-pi·πá·∏ça-prabhair=√¢kr√¢ntan=dhavalam(·πÅ)=vil√¥kya nikhila·πÅ g√¥p-√¢·πÖgan√¢-v√Ækshita·∏•‡•§ K√°-lind√Æ-hrada-K√¢lan√™mi-d√°lana-pr√¢rambha-v√Æt√¢daras=t√Ær√™ t√¢myati V√¢rir√†≈õi-tanay√¢-190

  1. tt√¥=pi j√¢ta-bhrama·∏• \‡•§\‡•§14\‡•§\‡•§146 P√Æy√ªsha-drava-s√¢ndra-vindu-vasatir=yasy=√¢sya v√¢k-chandrik√¢ vidvach-c·∏•akra-ckak√¥ra-cha√±chu-pu·π≠akair=√¢p√Æyam√¢n=√¢ni≈õam ‡•§kin(√±)ch-√¢ya[·πÅ] kara-pa√±jar√¥ khila-mila·πÖ-n√¢n√¢-digant-√¢rthin√¢·πÅ bk√ªy√¥ ‚Äôbh√Æsh≈£a-phala-prad√¢na-chatura[h] [sv√¢dh√Æ[na]–]191
