[y√¥] da·πá·∏ça-n√Ætau mata·∏•‡•§ chhand√¥‚Äôla·πÖk·πõiti-≈õav(b)da-manmatha-kal√¢-≈õ√¢str-√¢v-(b)ja-cha·πá·∏çadyuti≈õ=chakr√™ D√™vaga·πáa·∏• pra≈õastim=amal√¢[·πÅ]≈õr√Æ-Ratnasi·πÅh-√¢t·πõnaja·∏• \‡•§\‡•§26\‡•§\‡•§118 Ya·∏• k√¢vya-kairava-vik√¢≈õana-≈õ√Ætara≈õmir=udd√¢ma-vu(bu)ddhi-nilay√¥‚Äô196
  1. p√¢la-s√ªnu·∏• ‡•§ vidy√¢-vil√¢sa-vasatir-vvimal√¢·πÅ pra≈õasti·πÅ ≈õr√Æm√¢n-im√¢·πÅ Kuma-ra-p√¢la-vu(bu)dh√¥ lil√™kha \‡•§\‡•§27\‡•§\‡•§114 Pra≈õastir=iyam=utk√Ær·πá·πá√¢ ruchir=akshara-p√¢·πÅktibhi·∏• ‡•§ dh√Æmat√¢ s√ªtradh√¢r√™·πáa S√¢·πÅpul√™na man√¥ram√¢ \‡•§\‡•§ [28\‡•§\‡•§145; and of the next verse.")[]]197
  1. [D]√™va[ga]·πá√¢v=√™tau r√ªpak√¢ra-≈õir√¥man√Æ‡•§ chakratur-gha·π≠an√¢n-dh√¢mn√¥ Vi(bi)lvap√¢ni-pin√¢kinah \‡•§\‡•§29\‡•§\‡•§ Chandr√¢rkkau kira·πá-√•val√Æ-valayita·πÅ y√¢vad=vidhatt√¢√±198=jagad-di·πÖ-m√¢ta·πÖga-gha·π≠-√¥pav·πõi·πÅhita-dhar√¢-chakran(√±)=cha k√ª-

24.<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1698834014chanda24.JPG"/>nakshatra-prakar-√¥ru-h√¢ralatik√¢‚Äôla·πÖk√¢ra-s√¢ra·πÅ nabhas=tvat-k√Ærttir=Mmadan√¢ri-mandira-mish√¢t-t√¢yach-chira·πÅ nandatu \‡•§\‡•§30\‡•§\‡•§118 [[Sa·πÅvat 1247]?.]199, looks as if it had been put in the place of the figure 9, or as if that figure had been altered so as to assume the form of sa·πÅ.")

TRANSLATION.

√îm! √îm!

Adoration to ≈öiva!

(Verse 1)‚ÄîMay Rudra protect you ! ‚Äîhe who at the sexual enjoyment eagerly [thus] speaks to (P√¢rvat√Æ,) the daughter of the mountain: ‘How should that lord of serpents, who uses his eyes as ears, be able to see us? And [how should] this crescent moon [too, reduced to a state of infancy]…….!‚Äô

(V. 2.)‚Äî May Ganapati grant you prosperity! ‚Äîhe who has the surface of his unique frontal globes anointed with broad sheets of the powder of excellent red-lead; who with the dance of his trunk beautifies the [immense] pavilion of all the regions of heaven,…. play of uprooting groups of [trees]……!

(V. 3.)‚Äî [Triumphant] is the god with white rays, (the Moon), who covers the circle of the regions with a mass of rays flowing with streams of nectar; is beauteous as if he were the extensive mirror of the army of the king Love marching out to conquer the three worlds; ….. is the car-ornament of the gems of celestial damsels; (and) whose loveliness completely takes away the proud reserve of the hearts, (deep) like mountain caves, of haughty women.

(V. 4.)‚Äî In his race there was the protector of the earth J√¢jallad√™va, who, having by the pride of the group of his massive arms taken possession of the extent of the three worlds, was holding the position of (Indra,) the lord of the host of the gods, ….. the favourite husband of his wife, the earth, surrounded with the girdle of the… oceans; a unique jewel to ornament the world.

(V. 5.)‚Äî From him there was born a son, [the illustrious prince Ratnad√™va?], who was the fierce submarine fire of the unique ocean of the array of the difficult-to-be-subdued armies of the Ch√™di princes; who to the Ch√¥da and Ga·πÖga champions elated.

with [conceit] was, what R√¢hu is to the full orb of the moon, when he seizes and swallows it; (and) the marvellous might of whose heroism had no bounds on the orb of the earth.

(V. 6.)‚ÄîThen there came on this earth his son, the ruler of men, the illustrious Prithv√Æd√™va; the birth-place of increasing fame, white like the spreading lustre of the full moon, a sun from which is proceeding most intense brilliancy; … of excellent royalty; a gem which yields the desired objects to crowds of panegyrists from the (carious) quarters, come …..

(V. 7.)‚ÄîIn the reign of this very prince, which follows the path of good goverment, is free from the contact of troubles, (and) causes joy to the people.200‚Äî

(V. 8.)‚ÄîIn the course of time the learned G√¥vinda, the [moon of the] V√¢[stavya race, ?] came from the Ch√™di ma·πá·∏ç√°la to the country Tumm√¢·πáa.

(V. 9.)‚ÄîHe, had an elder son, named M√¢m√™, an ocean of the affection of the people, embellishing the assemblies of princes, to learned men what the sun’ is to lotuses; who, an ornantent of the earth, as it were a pearl-string to decorate [his]…. was famous the earth over as the unique bee of the unique lotus-feet of (≈öiva,) the destroyer of Tripura.

(V. 10.)‚ÄîHis younger brother was the illustrious R√¢ghava, an ocean of good qualities; clever, an ornament of the expanse of the earth, he was endowed with splendour like the sun.

(V. 11.)‚ÄîResplendent is the son of the illustrious M√¢m√™, the illustrious Ratna-si·πÅha, the poet; the creeper of whose brilliant expanding fame, shining like jasmine and like the moon, [spreading over] and covering the entire world, is entwined with the pavilion of the regions; who scattered crowds of crazed disputants, (an√¢ was) the pleasure garden of Fortune, (and) the home of virtuous conduct; discernment, and religious merit.

(V. 12.)‚ÄîHe had a virtuous wife, always an object of reverence for the kinsfolk, named Rambh√¢; who was (to him) what ≈öach√Æ is to Indra, what (P√¢rvat√Æ) the daughter of the mountain is to ≈öambhu, and what (Lakshm√Æ) the daughter of the ocean of milk is to (Vish·πáu), who holds the discus in his hand.

(V. 13.)‚ÄîFrom these two there was born here a son, D√™vaga·πáa, whose fame has been proclaimed in the three worlds; who has broken the excessive conceit of crowds of learned opponents; a bee (hovering) round the dear lotus-feet of (≈öiva) the husband of Chand√Æ, (and) a ‚Ä¶. of knowledge.

(V. 14.)‚Äî Having seen this whole world on all sides filled (and) whitened by his fame, shining like the foam of the sea, (Vish·πáu) even, [the beloved] of the daughter of the ocean, watched by the milk-maids, becomes confused; (and) having his attention withdrawn from the undertaking of destroying K√¢lan√™mi201in the waters of the K√¢lind√Æ, he stands motionless by the shore.

(V. 15.)‚Äî His words are always (eagerly received) by crowds of learned men, as the moonlight, the habitation of abundant drops of the nectar-liquid, is drunk by theround beaks of Chak√¥ra birds; and this cage-like hand of his, dexterous in giving plenti-

fully the wished-for fruits to all the supplicants of the various quarters, crowding together, holds in subjection the tree of paradise.

(V. 16.)‚ÄîWhat the moonlight is to the (moon) garlanded with cool rays, (and) the cluster of blossoms to the tree of the gods, that to him is his wife of virtuous conduct, Prabh√¢, who by her loveliness has surpassed the crowd of celestial women.

(V. 17.)‚Äî A second dear wife he has, named J√¢mh√¥, a habitation of graceful charms from the intensity of (his) boundless love a second home of (his) life.

(V. 18.)‚Äî Full of tlfe pride of having no rival in loveliness; being as it were the science of reviving on earth the god of love, even though he was wrathfully burnt by (≈öiva) who wears the moon on his crest;202a habitation of the unique pride of the excellencies of sterling beauty,‚Äî the dear one was more (to him) than life; she, having created whom the lotus-born (Brahman), filled with delight, obtained supreme happiness.

(V. 19.)‚Äî Resplendent on the earth is his son Jagatsi·πÅha, ‚Äòthe lion of the world,‚Äô who dispels the expanding darkness of ignorance, as a lion cleaves the frontal globes of elephants.

(V. 20.)‚ÄîThat (Skanda, the) son of the daughter of the mountain, is the enemy of T√¢raka; but this son of his, R√¢yarasi·πÅha, is the preserver of the whole body of relations.203

(V. 21.)‚ÄîThis virtuous daughter of his, Bh√îp√¢, untouched by the doings of the Kali-age, like the river of heaven, is purifying the three worlds.

(V. 22.)‚Äî(His) two (children) named V√¢lh√ª and the illustrious D√™vad√¢sa, united in mutual friendship, are shining, illumining the world like sun and moon in the sky.

(V. 23.)‚ÄîHaving reflected that this life of man is unsteady like a tuft of grass which trembles when shaken by the wind, and that fortune resembles the play of lightning flashing in the midst of terrific clouds, the exceedingly virtuous-minded (D√™vaga·πáa) put his faith in the eternal path of beatitude, which is a mighty blazing fire to burn the wood of this multitude of evils here.

(V. 24.)‚ÄîAt the village of S√¢mb√¢, D√™vaga·πáa built (to ≈öiva), the bearer of the Pin√¢ka, who has a Bilva-staff in his hand, a temple, resplendent like the extensive peaks of (Him√¢laya) the mountain of snow.

(V. 25.)‚ÄîFirst gratified, as it were, with the close embrace of the thighs of the earth, enjoyed by many princes, the surrounding sky, like a clever lover, accompanying his action with a smile of extreme love, eagerly within sight of the damsels of heaven kisses, as if it were the face of Fortune, this (temple) desirous of receiving204on all sides the heavy embrace of the bodies, trembling with the pangs of love, of the women of the regions.

(V. 26.)‚ÄîThe son of the illustrious Ratnasi·πÅha, D√™vaga·πáa, whose wealth of learning is purified by every traditional knowledge, (and) who possesses an excellent turn of mind for poetry; who has gone to the further shore of the ocean of the science of reasoning, (and) is esteemed as Bh·πõigu’s son in the administration of justice; who to the sciences of metrics, rhetorics, grammar, of love, and of the arts, is what the sun is to lotuses,‚Äî he has composed (this) spotless eulogy.

(V. 27.)‚ÄîThe son of [Avani-?]p√¢la, the illustrious learned Kumarap√¢la205,(who is) a moon in causing the lotus of poetry to open, a home of unlimited intelligence, (and) a habitation of the play of learning, has written this stainless eulogy.

(V. 28.)‚ÄîThis pleasing eulogy, charming with its rows of letters, has been engraved by the intelligent artisan S√¢mpula.

(V. 29.)‚Äî……and D√™vaga·πáa (?), these two crest-jewels of sculptors, have built the temple of (≈öiva) the bearer of the Pin√¢ka, who has a Bilva-staff in his hand.

(V. 30.)‚ÄîAs long as the moon and the sun keep the world enveloped in lines of rays; and the orb of the earth, supported by the array of the elephants of the regions, [is resting on the tortoise ?]; and the sky has for its excellent ornament the extended pearlstring of a mass of stars;‚Äîso long may thy fame prosper, in the guise of (this) home of the enemy of the god of love !

[[The year 1247]?]206

VIII. ‚Äî A R√ÇSIH·π¨RAK√õ·π¨A GRANT OF K·πöISH·πÜA II., DATED ≈öAKA 832.

BY E. HULTZSCH, PH.D.

The original of the subjoined grant was found at K√¢pa·∏çva·πáaj in Gujar√¢t. The document is inscribed on three copperplates with slightly raised rims, and is in good preservation. Each plate measures about 11¬Ω by 8¬Ω inches. The three plates are strung on two rings. The right-hand ring is circular and about ¬Ω" thick; measures about 3¬Ω" in diameter. The left-hand ring is of irregular shape and carries the oval scal, which measures 2¬≥/‚Çà by 3 inches and bears, in high relief, on a countersunk surface, a well-cut figure of Garu·∏ça, who is sitting on a rising lotus-flower and surmounted by two svastikas. As Garu·∏ça, the vehicle of Vish·πáu, is represented on the seal of the present grant, while all other R√¢sh·π≠rak√ª·π≠a grants hitherto published bear a figure of ≈öiva, it may be concluded that K·πõish·πáa II. who issued it was, unlike other members of his race, a Vaish·πáava. The language of the inscription is very incorrect Sanskrit. The numerous mistakes are not only due to the engraver, but also to the author of the text. Thus in verses 17 and 18, the metre proves that the composer of the inscription used the word ya≈õas in its Pr√¢k·πõit form ya≈õa.

The inscription opens with a short va·πÅ≈õ√¢vali, which has four verses in common with other R√¢sh·π≠rak√ª·π≠a grants207and mentions the following princes :‚Äî K·πõish·πáar√¢ja I. or ≈öubhatu·πÖga (verses 2, 3); his son Dhruvar√¢ja or Nirupama (verses 4, 5); his son Govindar√¢ja III. (verses 6 to 8); his son mah√¢r√¢ja Sha·πá·∏ça (verses 9, 10); his son ≈öubhatu·πÖga or Ak√¢lavarsha, i.e., Krish·πáa II. (verses 11, 12). Of Govinda III. the grant says that, though his father had several sons, he left the kingdom to him, as to a second R√¢ma, on account of his virtues (verse 7). From other inscriptions we know only one of Govinda’s younger brothers, viz., Indra III., the founder of the Gujar√¢t branch of the R√¢sh·π≠rak√ª·π≠as. The mah√¢r√¢ja Sha·πá·∏ça of the present grant is identical with the mah√¢r√¢ja ≈öarva or Amoghavarsha of other inscriptions. He is

here said to have destroyed his enemies and to have reconquered his kingdom, which had fallen off (verse 9). As we know from other inscriptions,208the enemies alluded to were rebellious members of his own family, probably Govinda IV. and his followers, whom he conquered with the help of his cousin Karka II. of Gujar√¢t.

After the pedigree of K·πõish·πáa II. the inscription gives the va·πÅ≈õ√¢vali of a vassal of his, the mah√¢s√¢manta Pracha·πá·∏ça, the son of Dhavalappa, who belonged to the race of Brahimavaka (verses 13 to 18). Further, the document records that Vallabhar√¢ja or Ak√¢lavarsha (ie., Krish·πáa II.) gave the village of Vy√¢ghr√¢sa or Vall√ªrik√¢ to the br√¢hma·πáa Brahmabhat·π≠a This villige formed one of 750 villages, which were designated by their chief town Harshapura, and among which Khetaka209; see Ind. Ant., vol. X, page 278; vol. XIV, p. 198.")and K√¢sadraha210are mentioned. To these 750 villages belonged the 84 villages of Karpa·π≠av√¢·πáijya, and to the latter the 10 villages of R√ªriddh√¢, in which the village granted was included; the inscription also mentions the names of seven villages which formed its boundaries211. East of Vagh√¢s lies Panthora called in the grant Pantho·∏ç√¢; in the south there is the Laruji M√ªs·∏çu·πÅ, probably the Araluvaka of the grant. North-west we have Abuvel, the Ap√ªvall√Æ of the grant, and north Ambach, corresponding to Amb√¢u√±cha.‚ÄîG. B√ºhler.")(lines 38 to 40). In verse 20, the 750 villages are stated to have belonged to the king himself, while in the ensuing prose-passage it is said that in these 750 villages a certain Chandragupta was the da·πá·∏çan√¢yaka of the mah√¢s√¢manta Pracha·πá·∏ça. It thus appears that Pracha·πá·∏ça held them as a feoff from K·πõish·πáa II. Perhaps Pracha·πá·∏ça‚Äôs father Dhavalappa had received them as a reward for his bravery and loyalty, which are praised in verse 17.

After the customary imprceatory verses there follows the signature of Akkuka or, as he is called in verse 18, Akkuva, the son of Dhavalappa and brother of Pracha·πá·∏ça The date of the grant was the ≈öaka year 832 (910-11 A.D.), on the full moon of Vai≈õ√¢kha.212The writer was the kulaputraka Ammaiyaka, the son of Nem√¢ditya.213The document ends with the signature of Chandragupta, who, as mentioned in line 34, was the da·πá·∏çan√¢yaka of the mah√°s√°nanta Pracha·πá·∏ça.

TEXT.

PLATE I.

1 ‡§ì‡§Ç [‡••] ‡§∏ ‡§µ‡•ã‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§ß‡§∏‡§æ ‡§ß‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡•§ ‡§π‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡§≤‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡•§ [‡•ß] ‡§Ü‡§∏‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å 2 ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø(‡§§‡§É) ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§É ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡•á[:] ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ214‡§á‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§É ‡•§ [‡•®] 3 ‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡§§‡•Å‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡•Å‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡§ó‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•É‡§π‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡•Ç‡§°215‡§∞‡•Å‡§π‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§ø‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§™‡§ø ‡§®‡§≠‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§ü‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ- 4. ‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ø‡•í‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Ç ‡•§ [‡•©] ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ú‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ß‡•Ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§É [‡•§] ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞-

5 ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§®‡§∞‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§£ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§µ ‡•§ [‡•™] ‡§∂‡§∂‡§ß‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§ø‡§≠‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Ø‚Äì 6 ‡§∂‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§® (T) ‡§ó‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§£‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§É216 [‡•ß] ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ó‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ß‡§∞‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§π‡•à‡§É ‡•§ [‡•´] ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡•Ç‚Äì 7 ‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡•á‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡§É ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡•Å‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§ß‡§É [!] ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞-‡§µ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø217 8 ‡§µ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§É ‡§ó‡•ã‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡§É ‡•§ [‡•¨] ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•ã‡§∂‡•Å‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡§ö‡§æ218‡§∞‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å- 9 ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§É ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡•Ä219‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§™‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§É ‡§∏‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ‡§§‡•ç [!] ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§ñ‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§§220‡§®‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ 10 ‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§°‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∑‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§ (:) ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡•Å221 ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡•§ [‡•≠]\‡•§ ‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§®‡§ø[:]‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡§Ç‡§≠‡•ã‡§ß‡§ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡•Å- 11 ‡§§‡§Ç ‡•§ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§£ ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ ‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø[:] ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ ‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§ø ‡•§ [‡•Æ] ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ222‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡•ã‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§ï‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§£‡§ó- 12 ‡§£‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§µ(:) ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§£‡§≤‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§Ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø223 ‡§∏‡§™‡§¶‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ü‡§ø‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ224 ‡§¶‡§¶‡§æ‡§π ‡•§ 13 ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ú‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø225 ‡§ö‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ß‡§æ‡§™226 ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§§‡§™‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø227 14 ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§§ ‡§µ‡§≤‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∑‡§Ç‡§°‡§É ‡•§ [‡•Ø] ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•ã [:] ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§Æ‡§£‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å- 15 ‡§ö‡§∞‡§£‡§≤‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç [‡•§] ‡§™‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§∞‡§ß‡•á228 ‡§®‡§ø‡§ó‡§°‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§®‡§µ‡§∞‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•á ‡•§ [‡•ß‡•¶] \‡•§ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π‡§≠‡•Ç‡§µ22916 ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§Ø‡§∂[‡§∏]: (‡•§) ‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡§§‡•Å‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•à230 ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•ã‡§™‡§∞‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ231 17 ‡§ó‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•á ‡•§[‡•ß‡•ß] ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§∏ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§π‡§ø ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•á‡§Ø‡•á232 ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø[‡§≠] - 18 ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡•§ ‡§®‡§ø‡§π‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§É (‡•§) ‡§ñ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ú‡•á‡§® ‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ö (‡§ï‡•É)

PLATE IIa.

19 ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£ ‡§á‡§µ ‡•§ [‡•ß‡•®] ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö‡§∞‡§£‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•É‡§∂‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§Ç233[‡•§] 20 ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•à234 ‡§∞‡§®‡§µ‡§∞‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡§ü‡•ç‡§†‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§ü‡§Ç ‡•• [‡•ß‡•©] ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ó‡§Ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‚Äì 21 ‡§Æ‡§≠‡§µ[‡§§‡•ç] ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡•Å‡§ô235‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§µ‡§°‡§ø‡§É ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§¨‡§≠‡•Ç‡§µ ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡§≤‡§®[:] ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¶‡•á‡§ó‡§°‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç [‡•§] ‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§®‡§∞‡•á‚Äì 22 ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§¶‡§≤‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§∂‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ò‡•á‡§®‡•á‡§µ236‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§ü‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ä‡§ï237‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§ï‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡•§ [‡•ß‡•™] 23 ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ö‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ö‡§∞‡§ñ‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§ø[:]‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§≠‡•Ç‡§≠‡•É‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§π‡§Ç‡§∏[:] ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§¶‡§ø‚Äì 24 ‡§®‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡§Ø‡•Ä ‡§ï(T)‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§æ‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§ø‡§µ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ238 ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡§™‡§ø ‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§Ç‡§ö‡§≤‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§æ‚Äì 25 ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á‡§®‡•ã‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§•‡§®‡§™‡§ü‡•Å239‡§®‡§æ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ç ‡•§ [‡•ß‡•´] ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡§ï‡§≤[T]‡§∞‡§ø‡§ú‡§®‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‚Äì 26 ‡§ß‡§µ‡§≤‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§§‡§∞‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§ß‡§µ‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡•ã ‡§ú‡§Ø‡§∏‡§∏‡•Ä240 ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡§µ‡§®‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø‡§ñ ‡•§ [‡•ß‡•¨] 27 ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ò‡•Ä‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Ø241‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§£ ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç242 ‡§Ø‡§∂‡•á‡§™‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡§æ [‡•§] ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ñ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ã243 ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡•Å ‡§Æ‚Äì 28 ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§≤‡§Ç ‡•§ [‡•ß‡•≠] ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ö‡§£‡•ç‡§° [:] ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•á ‡§Ø‡§∂‡§≤‡§Ç‡§™‡§ü‡§É[‡•§] ‡§Ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø ‡§ñ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‚Äì 29 ‡§§‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≤‡•ã ‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§ø ‡•§ [‡•ß‡•Æ] ‡§∏‡•á‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ß‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡•á‡§≤‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§§244‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡§ø (‡§§‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡§ø) ‡§®‡§æ [ ‡•§ ] ‡§®‡§ø‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø (T)

30 ‡§∂‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç (‡•§) ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ß‡•á245‡§Ø‡§∂‡§∏‡§æ ‡§ï‡•É‡§§246‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡•§ [‡•ß‡•Ø] ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§π‡§≤‡§≠‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§É247‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§π‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•ã‡§™-

31 [[‡§≤]‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç]248‡•§ ‡§≠‡•Å‡§Ç‡§ú‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§É‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§∂‡§§‡•ã‡§™‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§ [‡•®‡•¶] ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø-

32 ‡§≠‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¨‡§≤‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç (‡•§) ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß-

33 ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡§É ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡•á‡§ü‡§ï‡§π‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§£‡§§‡§§‡•ç(‡•§) ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ-

34 ‡§Ø‡§Ç … … … ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ó‡§§‡§™‡§Ç‡§ö‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡§æ‡§∂‡§¶‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ö‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ï‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å-

35 ‡§§‡•á (‡•§) ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§π‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡§∂‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§[‡§É]‡§™‡•å‡§§‡§ø[‡§ï]‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§ü‡§µ‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞(‡•§)‡§∂‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø-

PLATE IIb

36 ‡§ï‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§π‡§∞‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§ [:] ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ò‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§µ‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§∂‡§æ‡§™-

37 ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§É ‡§∏‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§[:] ‡§∏‡§ï‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡•É‡§£‡§ï‡•Ç‡§™‡§§‡§°‡§æ‡§ó‡•ã‡§™‡•á‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§≠‡•ã‡§ó‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó [:] ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É . ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§ò‡§æ‡§ü‡§®‡•ã -

38 ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§£‡§ï249‡§™‡§≤‡§∏‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§É (‡§∏‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á)‡•§ ‡§Ü‡§ò‡§æ‡§ü‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§ø250‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡§Ç‡§•‡•ã-

39 ‡§°‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§ö ‡•§ ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡•á‡§∞‡§°‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•Ä‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã ( ‡§Ö ) ‡§∞‡§≤‡•Å‡§µ‡§ï‡§Ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ö ‡•§‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§[:] ‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ-

40 ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§™‡•Ç‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•ã‡§ö‡•§ ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§§‡§É ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§â‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§É[‡•§] ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§ò‡§æ‡§ü‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§µ‡§≤‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ-

  1. ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§É ‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§ú‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§≠‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡§ó‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä251‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡•á252 ‡§µ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø-

42 ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø (‡•§) ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•å‡§¶‡§ï‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó253‡§µ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ö‡§∞‡§ï‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç254‡§•‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•á‡§£ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§É [‡•§] ‡§§‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Æ-

43 ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞255‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø [:] ‡§∏‡§¨‡•ç‡§¨‡•á‡§∞‡•á‡§µ‡§æ256‡§ó‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§Æ‡§≠‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•É‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¨‡•Å‡§™257‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•ã (‡§Ö) ‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø -.

44 ‡§Ø[‡•§] ‡§â‡§ï‡•ç‡§§ ‡§ö (‡•§) ‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•á‡§® ‡•§ ‡§∑‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•á‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§§‡§ø258‚Äù ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§É[!] ‡§Ü‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•á‡§§‡§æ ‡§ö‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§§‡§æ259

45‡§ö ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§®‡§∞‡§ï‡•á ‡§µ‡§∏‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ü‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å ‡§∂‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï ( : )‡§ï‡•ã‡§ü‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§®‡§É [‡•§], ‡§Æ‡§π‡§π‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§π‡§ø ‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø-

46 ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§π‡§∞‡§Ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡•á ‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ö ‡§®‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§™ (:) [1] ‡§Æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§† ‡§¶‡§æ-

47 ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•Å260‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Ø‡•ã‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§π261‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ ‡§®‡§∞‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§É‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§Ø‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ-

48 ‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø262‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§¶‡•Ä‡§§ ( : ) ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§µ263 ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§É ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç264‡§≠‡•Ç -

49 ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡§§‡•á ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§≠‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§É [‡•§ ] ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•á ‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ-

50 ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§π‡•Å‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ’ ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§ó‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É [ ‡•§] ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§É

PLATE III.

51 ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ ‡§´‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡§¶‡§≤‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•Å(:)‡§µ‡§ø-

52 ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§≤‡•Ä‡§≤‡§æ265‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§µ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡•§ ‡§∏‡§ï‡§≤‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶-

53 [‡§Æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§§‡§Ç]]266 [‡§ö] ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ267‡§® ‡§π‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§ú‡•à‡§É‡§™‡§∞‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡•á268‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§¶‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§π‡§∞‡•á-

54 ‡§§ ‡§µ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç [1] ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ï‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Ç‡§¨‡§æ ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•É‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§π ‡§™‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§ ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§ø269‡§ö-

55 ‡§ö ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§â‡§≠‡•å‡§§‡•ã ‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•å‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡•å‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•å‡•§ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞-

56 ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§Ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡•Ä270‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§® ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡§É ‡•§ ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø271‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•Å272‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç‡§Ø‡§É‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö

57 ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§Æ‡§π‡•Ä273‡§ö ‡§¶‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø274‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§ø‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•Å‡§™‡§Ç‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç275‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö276

58 ‡§® ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•ã ‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§µ277‡•§ ‡§ñ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§Ç‡§´‡§≤‡§Ç ‡•§ ‡§π‡§æ‡§¢‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑278 ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡•å-

59 ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ú‡§Ç‡§´‡§≤‡§Ç ‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§π‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§¶‡§¨‡•Å‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡§µ‡§∏-

60 ‡§®‡•ã‡§É‡§∂‡§ï‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡•Æ‡•©‡•® ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡§æ‡§≤‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§™‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç-

61 ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•ã‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§É [‡•§]‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§™‡•Å‡§ú‡§µ‡•á‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ø-

62 ‡§ï‡•á‡§® ‡§®‡•á‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡•á‡§®‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§‡§Ø‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•ã‡§®‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ-

63 ‡§£‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§ø‡§∏‡•Å‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡•• ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ö‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡••

TRANSLATION.

O·πÅ. ( Verse 1. ) May he( Vish·πáu ) protect you, from whose navel (rises) the lobusflower which Vedhas ( Brahman ) has made his abode, and may Hara (≈öiva) protect you, whose head is adorned by the lovely crescent of the moon !

  1. There was a lord of the earth (called) K·πõish·πáar√¢ja, who rosombled Mur√¢ri (K·πõish·πáa), and who like anovker incarnation of the god of justice,279 gave away immeasurable wealth.

  1. Even in summer the whole firmament had exactly the same appearance as during the rainy season, because the rays of the sun were obstructed on the sky by the dust, which was raised by the tall chargers of ≈öubhatu·πÖga.

  2. He was succeeded by his son, the illustrious Dhruvar√¢ja, who conquered all kings and resembled the morning sun( by ) his great majesty and his widespread prowess ( or heat ).

  3. His fame, which rosembles the rays of the moon, is sung in full by the Vidy√¢-dhara women, who dwell on the uppermost ridge of the mountain of the gods (Meru).

  4. He had ( a son ) called Govindar√¢ja, who was able to bear the burden of the earth, who resembled P√¢rtha ( Arjuna ), who, like Prithu; knew ( hereto distinguish between) good and bad qualities, who was the cause of unequalled sorrow to the wives of irresistible foes, and whose prowess was very widely known.

  5. Though there were several sons, this clover and handsome ( prince ), like another R√¢ma,‚Äìreceived on account of his superior virtues the kingdom, to which anointed kings paid homage, from the famous lord, his father Nirupama.

  6. He ruled righteously his whole kingdom together with the four oceans ( and thus ) filled the hearts of men with the highest joy.

PRASASTI FROM LAKKHA MANDAL AT MADH

<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1710153656EP-1.png"/>

<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1710153796EP-2.png"/>

JHƒÄNSI; CHANDEL INSCRIPTION OF SALLAKSHANAVARAM

<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1710153863EP-3.png"/>

Please dont Edit this page (Blank Page)

  1. His son was the illustrious peah√°rdja Sha·πá·∏ça, who was very brave, a mine280of all virtues, prouts and powerful. He quickly dispersed, surrounded and burnt the kings, like thorns, conquered by the strength of his arm his own kingdom which had fallen off, and made the earth subject to one’( royal ) paresol.

  1. In the jail of this sovereign, people incessantly heard the harsh clinking of the chains which were attached to the tender feet of the wives of his enemies.

  2. From this famous ( prince ) there sprang this ( present ) king called ≈öubha-tu·πÖga, the same whom people praise in song by his other name Ak√¢lavarsha.

  3. His deeds resembie those of K·πõish·πáa; for, laving killed his Poes, he bears the kingdom for the welfare of the ( four ) castes and the earth with his arm, like K·πõish·πáa.281

  1. Through his favour282great fortune came to the face of Brahmavaka; ( this fortune ) is incessantly and openly proclaimed by the great pats of later times.

  1. From this ocean-like race there arose the illustrious … Kumba·∏çi, and from him the illustrious Dega·∏çi, the destroyer of the pride of his enemies; the eternal fame which alone ( but ) without fear, obtained by destroying the elepants of many princes, pervaded the battle-fields, as that of a lion does the forests.

  2. As the sun from Ka≈õyapa, there sprang from him the fierce and illustrious R√¢jaha·πÅsa, whose far-reaching and hard hands ( or hot rhys ) overcame all kings ( or mountaing ) and who was rising daily; he who, liko Partha ( Arju·πÖa ), knew how to destroy his foes, led fickle fortune, who was wandering somewhere else, again to his own beautiful temple of ≈öambhu ( ≈öiva283 )

  1. Like ( ·∏§anumat ) the son of the wind, there was born the illustrious Dhaval-appa, who conquered all his enemies, whose name was well-known, and who whitened the world with his fame.

  2. Becoming ( as it were ) a lion and being desirous of fame, he quickly killed the enemy and restored to his master the province, which ( this unnamed enemy ) had taken.

  3. From him came Pracha·πá·∏ça, who was eager for fame in war, and the spotless Akkuva, who is renowned on earth by his sword.

  4. Sella-Vidyadhara284also, whose hands were as graceful as the selu ( plant ), adorned his race with fame by killing his enemies in battle.

  1. The illustrious Vallabhar√¢ja Ak√¢lavarsha possesses soven hundred and fifty villages, which are designated by ( their chief-town ) ≈öri-Harshapura.

( Line 31.) He informs all who shall come (to this village) :‚Äî gracious princes, great vassals, ministers, commanders of the army, heads of districts and great men,‚Äî

( L. 33.) ‚ÄúBe it known to you that, while in these seven hundred and fifty (villages) of Khetaka, Harshapura, and K√¢sadraha, the illustrious Chandragupta was the dandandyaka of the mahds√°manta Pracha·πá·∏ça, who has obtained tho five mah√°≈õabdas, I gave as a donation the village of Vy√¢ghrasa, which is included in the ten (villages) of

R√ªriddh√¢, which belong to the eighty-four (villages) of Karpa·π≠av√¢·πáijya, which are included in the seven hundred and fifty (villages) of ≈öri-Harshapura, together with its rows of trees, together with (the right to) punishment and (the right of fining those who commit) the ten offences, up t√≥ its boundaries, together with its timber, grass, wells and tanks, together with its enjoyments and shares, together with its gold, defined by its four boundaries, together with its pacture and straw;‚Äì the boundaries are (here) written: on the east, the village of Panho·∏ç√¢andVitkh√¢ralli; on the south, the village of Kera·∏çavalli and the village of Araluvaka;on the west, ‘N√¢v√¢lika and Ap√ªvalli; on the north, the village of Amb√¢√º√±cha ;‚Äì the village of Wall√ªrik√¢, thus defined by its four boundaries, to the br√°hma·πáa Brahmabha·π≠i who is the son of Vavva, lives at Bha·π≠·π≠a (!), belongs to the Bharadv√¢ja-gotra and studies the Vaji-Madhya·πÅdina (≈õ√°kh√°), aftc. having b√•thed, with a libation of water, in order (to enable the donee to perform) the bali, charuky and vaikvadeva. Therefore, all future rulers shall preserve and assent to the charitable gift which was given by us, without obstructing us."

(L. 44.) And the saint Vy√¢sa has said:‚Äì [ Here follow twelve of the customary imprecatory verses which it is unnecessary to translate. ]

(L. 59). This is the signature of the illustrious Akkuka, the son of the illustrious Dhavalappa. Saka-samvat 832, on Mah√°-vai≈õ√°khi, (i.e.) on the full-moon in the bright half of Vai≈õ√°kha, (the above-mentioned village) was given, with the exception of previous gifts to iemples and to Br√¢hmanas. This edict was written by the noble (kulaputraka) Ammaiyaka, the son of Nem√¢ditya. What syllable in this (document) is too few or too many, all that is valid; for even a man who resembles Vysa is liable to make mistakes. This is the signature of the illustrious Chandragupta.

IX. - TWO CAVE-INSCRIPTIONS FROM THE TRI≈öIRAPALLI ROCK.

By E. HULTZSCH, PH.D.,

EPIGRAPHIST TO THE ARCHEOLOGICAL SURVEY, SOUTHERN INDIA.

The subjoined inscriptions are engraved on two pillars in a rock-cut cave not far from the summit of the well-known rock at Trisir√¢ palli (Trichin√¢palli). They are both somewhat worn. The left pillar was covered by a modern wall, which the temple authorities temporarily removed at the request of the Collector, W. A. Willock, O.S. Each of the two pillars bears four Sanskrit verses. Besides, the lower part of the left pillar bears a few unintelligible Sanskrit words and a much defaced inscription in old Tamil characters.

The two inscriptions record that a king Gu·πáabhara, who bore the birudas‚Äì Puru-shottama, ≈öatrumalla and Satyasa·πÅdha, constructed a temple of ≈öiva on the top of the mountain and placed in it a linga and a statue of himself. Each of the two pillars mentions the river K√¢v√Ær√Æ, i.e. the K√¢veri, on whose banks Tri≈õir√¢palli is situated,

______________________

Compare the village of Aralu√§m in the Il√¢o grant of Dadda II., Ind. Ant. vol. XIII, p. 117.

and refers to the Chola country. ‘On’the left pillar the K√¢v√Ær√Æ is called the beloved of the Pallava’; this means in prose that a Pallava Ring ruled over the country along the banks of the K√¢ter√Æriver. This allusion and the fact, that the characters of the two pillax inscriptions remind us of those of the Pallava inscriptions at M√¢malla-puram and K√¢√±ch√Æp∆∞ram, make is very probable that Gu·πáabhara was a Pallava prince who ruled over the Chala country..

A. - PILLAR TO THE LEFT.

TEXT.

[1] ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∏‡§≤‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ-

[2] ‡§Æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ß‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§É

[3] ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø [‡§ó‡•Å] ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑285‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§ø[[‡•§√ó]]286‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ç-

[4] ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•É‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§Ç‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§π‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ó‡§ø-

[5] [‡§∞‡•å]‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§≤‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å-

[6] ‡§µ‡§æ‡§£‡§æ ‡§®‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• [‡•ß] ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§≠‡§∞‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§≤‡§ø-

[7] ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•á‡§® ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§®‡§ø ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç [‡•§*] ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§§‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø-

[8] ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• [‡•®*]‡§ö‡•ã‡§≤‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡•à‡§≤‡•ã

[9] ‡§Æ‡•å‡§≤‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§Æ‡§£‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø[‡•§] ‡§π‡§∞‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§Ç-

[10] ‡§ú‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§µ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡••[‡•©*]. ‡§∂‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ[‡§ñ] ‡§∞‡•á-

[11] ‡§£‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≠‡•å‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä [‡•§] ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ-

[12] ‡§Ø‡•Ä ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡§æ ‡§§‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä ‡•• [‡•™ *] ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡•É[‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø] ‡§ö‡§≤‡§æ [‡§∏]-

TRANSLATION.

(Verse 1.) Being afraid that the god who is fond of rivers (≈öiva), having perceived the K√¢v√Ær√Æ, whose waters please the cye, who wears a garland of gardens, and who possesses lovely qualities, might fall in love (with her), the daughter of the mountain (P√¢rvati), has, I think, left her father’s family and resides permanently on this mountain, calling this river the beloved of the Pallava (king).287

(2.) While the king called Gu·πáabhara is a worshipper of the li·πÖga, let the knowledge which has turned back from hostile (vipaksha) conduct, be spread for a long timein the world by this li·πÖgal288, in which lingin meansthe subject of a proposition, linga the predicate of a proposition and vipaksha an instance on the opposite side.").288, in which lingin meansthe subject of a proposition, linga the predicate of a proposition and vipaksha an instance on the opposite side.")

(3.) This mountain resembles the diadem of the Cho·∏∑a province, this temple ofHara (≈öiva) its chief jewel, and the splendour of ≈öa·πÅkara (≈öiva) its splendour.

(4.) By the stone-chisel a material body of ≈öatyasa√±dh√¢289was executed, andby the same an eternal body of his fame was produced.

B. ‚Äî PILLAR TO THE RXGHT.

TEXT.

[1] ‡§∂‡•à‡§≤‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á

[2]. ‡§∂‡•à‡§≤‡•Ä‡§§‡§®‡•Å‡§Ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§≠‡§∞‡•ã‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§≠‡§∞‡•ã ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ø [‡•§]

[11] ‡§¶‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡§π‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ[‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á] ‡§ó‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡§µ‡§®291-

[15] ‘‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§É ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•í‡§Æ‡§ö [‡§≤‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø] ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ- 1

6] ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• [ 8 *]

TRANSLATION.

( Verse 1.) When king Gu·πáabhara placed a stone-figure in the wonderful stone-temple on the top of the best of mountains, he made in this way292Sth√¢≈Üu ( ≈öiva ) stationary293 one whose name was true to its meaning.’")and became himself stationary ( i.e., immortal ) in the worlds together with him.

( 2 ) King ≈öatrumalla built on this mountain a temple of Giri≈õa ( ≈öiva ), the husband of the daughter of the king of mountains, in order to make the name Giri≈õa ( i.e., the mountain-dweller) true to its meaning.

(3.) After Hara ( ≈öiva ) had graciously asked him : ‚ÄúHow could I standing in a temple on earth, view the great power of the Cholas or the river K√¢v√Ær√Æ?"‚Äì king Gu·πáabhara, who resembled Manu in his manner of ruling, assigned to him this mountain-temple which touches the clouds.

( 4. ) Thus having joyfully placed on the top ( of the mountain ) & matchless stonefigure of Hara ( ≈öiva ), which he caused to be executed, that Purushottama; who bore ≈öiva fixed in his mind, made the loftiness of the mountain fruitful.

X ‚Äì BAD√ÖUN STONE INSCRIPTION OF LAKHANAPALA.

BY PROFESSOR F. KIELHORN, PH.D., C.I.E.; G√ñTTINGEN.

This inscription was found in August 1887, in the rains of the south gate of the old fort of Bad√¢yn294 and described as “),^()the chief town of the Badaun District of the North-Western Pro-vinces, whence it has been removed to the Lucknow Museum,

The writing covers a space of about 3 feet broad by 1 foot, 6 inches high, but the inscription is not complete now.All along the top, on the proper left side all the way down, and at the left side of the bottom, portions of the stanƒô are broken away. But the aksharas which in consequence are missing on the left side are few, and can in almost every case be casily supplied; and at the top probably only one or two lines are lost, containing little more than the customary blessings and verses in honour of some deity, in the present casc, probably ≈öiva; and the introductory historical portion of the inscription, at any rate, appears to be complete. Nor does anything of importanco scem to have been lost in the concluding lines, in the verses which cither refer to the composer of the inscription or express the usual wish that the temple, the erection of which is recorded here, may last for ever. Excepting about half a dozen aksharas at the beginning of the last dine, what remains of the inscription is well preserved, and may be read with certainty.

The average size of the letters varies from ¬æ” to ¬æ" and is somewhat less in the four or five bottom lines. The characters are Devan√¢gari of about the 12th or 13th century A.D., and the inseription was engraved by the two artizans G√¥ge and Jilhe ( line 23 ). The language is Sansk·πõit, and excepting what possibly is a date, at the beginning of line 23, the inscription is in verse throughout. The verscs were, it appears, composed by the poet Govindachandra, who is described as the youngest of the five sons of Ga·πÖg√¢dhara ( himself the son of the sage S√¥m√™svara, a resident of √Çh√¢dega·∏çha ) and his wife S√ºlh√¢, a daughter of the learned Para≈õurama ( lines 21-22 ). The inscription is remarkably free from minor errors, and in respect of orthography I therefore have only to note that ba is represented by the sign for va everywhere except in the word √°rabdha in line 23.

The inscription possibly, at the beginning of line 23, contains a date which at present, unfortunately, I am unable to make out from the impression submitted to me. Certain it is that it refers itself to the reign of a prince, Lakha·πáap√¢la, and that it records the erection of a ≈öiva-temple at the place, it may be presumed, where the inscription was discovered, and which is called here Vod√¢may√ªt√¢ ( lines 1 and 11). And from these two points of view the inscription may be conveniently divided into two portions, the first of which, extending to near the end of line 7, gives the genealogy of Lakha·πáap√¢la, while the second part, comprising about lines 8‚Äì20, has reference to the founder of the temple and his spiritual predecessors. Of this latter portion it is sufficient to give

an abstract of the contents; regarding the prince Lakha·πáap√¢la and his ancestors, the writer of the inscription expresses himself as follows:‚Äî

(L. 1). ‚Äú*[Here295*] where the rising of the whole assemblage of evils is far removed by the floods of water of the river of heaven,296[there is] the town Vod√¢may√ªt√¢, ornamenting the land named Pa√±ch√¢la, (and) protected by the arms of all the famous princes born in the Rashtrakta family. Radiant with, prosperity, inasmuch as its enemies were feeble and the excellent well-disposed persons in it many, ornamented with the best of horses, (and) surrounded by trees resembling the trees, of paradise, pleasing with its lofty.spotless [tentples] (and) a seat of law-abiding people, this beautiful (town) with its collections of excellencies shone like the city of Indra, radiant with the wealth of very many excellent flowers of mand√°ra297trees, ornamented with the best of Gandharvas, (and) surrounded by samt√°na and kalpa trees, pleasing with, its lofty pure [habitations] of the gods, (and) the seat of the assembly of the immortals."

(L. 2). “There, there was first, endowed with endless excellencies, the lord of men, Chandra, who by the terror of his sword terrified the host of the enemies; whose son Vigrahap√¢ladova protected the carth, well known among adversarics (and) munificent towards supplicants. His son, known by the name of Bhuvanap√¢la, (was) certainly, manifested as it were to the eyes, the law incarnate; when, after having protected the earth, he had gone to heaven, his son Gop√¢ladeva guarded (the earth), and when he, the remover of the distress of the people, had assumed the reign, the castes, delighting in their several duties, attained to happiness.”

(L. 3). ‚ÄúAfterwards his son Tribhuvana protected the earth, humbling the multitude ofenemies (and in consequence) endowed with fame. When (this) his brother by the deeree of fate had gone to heaven, then the same land was ruled over by the prince Madanap√¢la, in consequence of whose distinguished prowess there never was any talk of IIamb√Æra’s298coming to the banks of the river of the gods. Afterwards his younger brother, who destroyed hundred thousands of proud adversaries (and who was) munificent (and) compassionate, protected the earth, bearing on earth the excellent name of the illustrious Devap√¢la, a recital of whose deeds might secure victory even to-day."

(L. 5). ‚Äú (Then) his son became king, installed in the place of his father as the illustrious Bh√Æmap√¢la, who defeated the difficult-to-be-conquered hostile herocs (and) whose excellent body was spotless like gold, a born ruler, causing welfare, devoted to the gods and to Br√¢hmmans. Then there came, to protect the carth, his son, known the world over as the illustrious S√ªrap√¢la, (who among princes was) what Indra is in the assembly of the gods, what the moon is in the assembly of the stars, what (Indra’s elephant) Air√¢va·πáa is among the choicest of elephants, (and) what the lion is among the wild beasts. IIis son was Amritap√¢la, who, endowed with prowess, frightened all enemies by the sharp sword of his hand, who was devoted to the twice-born, the elders,’ and the gods, attached to every science, (and) the preceptor as it were of all whose. weapons deal out stern punishment.‚Äù

(L. 7). ‚Äú May his younger brother, the prince Lakha·πáapala, who has succeeded him, remain here billions of ages!‚Äì he, whose munificence i boundless, (and) the multitudes of whose missile weapons, resembling the scorching rays of the sun, drink streams of blood from the bodies of distinguished enemies !"

Put into the form of a tabular statement, the genealogy here furnished to us is as follows:‚Äî

<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-169874820100000000.png"/>

Beyond these names, and the statement that these princes belonged to the Rash·π≠rak√ª·π≠a clan (which appears to connect them with the R√¢th√¥r rulers of Kanauj), and that the town Vodamay√ªt√¢ was ruled over by them, we learn nothing of historical importance from the inscription. Nor have I been able to gather any certain information about these rulers from other inscriptions, or from the historical works which I have consulted. Most of the names, of course, do occur elsewhere, but the only name ending in pala, distinctly connected with the town of Bad√¢un, is that of Mah√Æp√¢la, “the Tomar Raja of Dehli, who,” according to Sir A. Cunningham,‚Å∂ ‚Äúis said to have built the great fort on which part of the city now stands," as well as a temple, on the site of which the Muhammadans built the present J√¢m√Æ’ Masjid; and Mah√Æp√¢la’s name does not occur here. The reference to Hambira (or the Hamb√Æras), in line 4, appears clearly to point to the invasions of the Muhammadans.

After the above historical introduction, the inscription goes on to relate that therewas once a Saiva ascetic, called Varma≈õiva, whose home was Anahilap√¢»õaka, and who, after destroying by the efficacy of his mantras an idol which had been set up by Bauddhas in Dakshi≈Ü√¢patha, and after giving other proofs of his piety and superhuman power in Ka≈õm√Ær, on his wanderings also came to Vod√†may√ªt√†, where, by Devap√†la’s minister Rulh√¢, he was appointed head of a matha or monastery of the town (lines 8-12). In this office he appears to have been succeeded by another holy and renowned personage, named M√ªrtiga·πáa, who became the spiritual adviser of the prince S√ªrap√¢ladeva (lines 13-15). M√ªrtigana’s place, again, was taken, during the reign of Am·πõitap√¢la, by his pupil √é≈õ√¢na≈õiva, who is described as born in Gauda, as belonging to the Vatsabh√¢rgava gotra, with the five pravaras Bh√¢rgava, Chyavana, √Çpnav√¢na, Aurva, and Jamadagni, and as the eldest son of the twice-born

______________________

Arch√¶ol. Survey of India, vol. XI, p. 1.-A prince ‘Dep√¢l,’ with the date A.D. 1256, and a prince ‘Lakhan Pal, with the date A.D. 1330, are mentioned, ib., vol. XX, pp. 18 and 14.

Vas√¢va·πáa, a resident of Si·πÅhapall√Æin the Hariy√¢na country. This √é≈õ√¢na≈õiva, per-suaded of the vanity of worldly affairs, founded the temple of ≈öiva at which this inscription must be supposed to have been put up originally, and endowed it with (the revenues of) a place called Bh√•danaulik√¢(lines 16-21). This portion of the inscription closes with a verse (line 21) which appears to intimate that the minister Rulh√¢, mentioned above, was succeed√™d in office by Lakshm√Ædhara √¢nd Jagatp√¢la, who were as devout workshippers of ≈öiva as their predecessor.

Of the places and districts, which, besides Vod√¢may√ªt√†; are mentioned in the inscription, Anahilap√¢taka is the well-known Anhilw√•·∏ça in Western India, and Hariy√¢·πáa the modern Hari√¢na, described in the Imperial Gazetteer as a tract of country in the Iliss√¢r District of the Panj√¢b. The places Si·πÅhapall√Æ (l. 16), Bhada-·πáaulik√¢, and √Çh√¢degadha (1. 21) I am unable to identify.

TEXT.299

L. 1. [sva·∏•si]ndh300-√ªdaka-p√ªra-d√ªra-gamit-√¢≈õ√™sh-√¢gha-sa·πÅgh-√¥day√™‡•§ prakhy√¢t-√¢khila-R√¢shtrak√ª·π≠a-kulaja-kshm√¢p√¢la-d√¥·∏•-p√¢lit√¢ Pa·πÅch√¢l-√¢bhidha-d√™≈õa-bh√ªsha·πáa- Kar√Æ V√¥d√¢may√ªt√¢ pur√Æ‡••Ma·πÅd√¢r√¢tiva(ba)hu-prak·πõish·π≠a-sumana·∏•-sampatti-sa·πÅ-[≈õ]√¥bhit√¢ ga·πÅdharvv-√¥·π≠tama-bh√ªshit√¢ pariv·πõit√¢ sa·πÅt√¢nakalpadrumai·∏•‡•§ atyuchch-√¢mala-d√™va-[ma·πÅ ?]

  1. n√¢ramy√¢ sudharmm-√¢≈õray√¥y√¢ r√™j√™ gu·πáa-sa·πÅchayair=iva pur√ÆPaurandar√Æ sundar√ÆT√∫tr¬≥301=√¢dit√¥=bhavad=ananta-gu·πá√¥nar√™ndra≈õ-Chandra·∏• sva- kha·∏çga-bhaya-bh√Æshita-vairi-[v·πõi]nda·∏• ‡•§prathyarthishu praka·π≠it√¥=rthishu yasya d√¢t√¢ ksh√¥·πá√Æ·πÅ raraksha suta-Vigrahap√¢lad√™va·∏• ‡••Tasy-√¢[[tma]]302-
  1.   1. s-Tribhuvan√¥ bhuvana·πÅraraksha ‡••Sva-bhr√¢tari svar=upay√¢tavati sva-daiv√¢t= s-aiv-√¢vanir=Madanap√¢la-n·πõip√™·πáa bhukt√¢‡•§yat-paurush√¢t=pravarata·∏• surasindhu-t√Æra-Hamv√Æ (mb√Æ) ra-sa·πÅgama-kath√¢ na kad√¢chid-√¢s√Æt ‡••Tasy-√¢nuj√¥ dalita-d·πõipta-vipaksha-laksh√¥ d√¢t√° day√¢lur=avan√Æm-avati sma pa≈õch√¢t [‡•§*]

  1. tara-bhaktits vasumat√Ægahan-√¢sya h√Æk√Ærttanai·∏• ‡•§ kim-apara·πÅ graha·πÅshu naganyat√™ katishu sarva-dhana·πÅdvijas√¢t-k·πõita·πÅ‡••N322=√¢m√Æ s√™vy√¢ vishama-vishay√¢ dush·π≠a-h√¢l√¢hal-abh√¢va(ba)ddha·πÅka·πÅ·π≠h√™ chiram=api dhana·πÅ pr√¢·πáina·πÅ n=√¢nuy√¢ti I sa·πÅs√•r√¥=ya·πÅ sarasa-kadal√Æ-da·πÅda-vach=ch=√¢py-as√¢ras=tasm√¢d= dh√™ya·πÅsakalam=apara·πÅ dharma-t√¥=nyad=viditv√¢‡•• Pr√¢323
  1. da √™sha Bharatasya pur√™ hy-ak√¢ri y√™ n√¢ma tu·πÅgima-gun√™na jagaj=jig√¢ya‡•§yad-r√¢ma·πá√Æyakan=anuttamam=√¢kalayya Kail√¢sa-v√¢sa-vimukh√¥vasat-√Æha ≈öa·πÅbhu·∏• IIAn√¢rata119- prabhram√™·πáa bh·∫©n√¥324khinn√¥=si vi≈õr√¢mya muh√ªrttam=atra ‡••it=√Æva sa·πÅ-√±√¢m=anusa·πÅdadh√¢na≈õ=chalat-pat√¢k√¢-chchhalat√¥ vibh√¢vi(ti) ‡••≈öiv√¢layam325and of the next verse.")yihirm√¢pyapratish·π≠h√¢ [[s-cha ?]]326
  1. dh√¢nata·∏•‡•§ pr√¢yachchhad=√és√¢na≈õiva·∏•≈õ√¢sana·πÅBhada·πáaulik√¢·πÅ R√ª·∏çh√¢Rulh√¢bhi[dham]pr√¢pya≈öiva-bhakti-lat√¢ hiy√¢‡•§Lakshm√Ædhara-Jagatp√¢la-bhavanai·∏• s=aivavarddhit√¢‡••√Ç h√¢·∏ç√™gadha118uttam√™ samabhavat=s√ªri·∏• sa S√¥m√©≈õvar√¥yat-p√ªj√¢-param√¢va(ba) [bh√ªvu]r=akhil√† l√¥k√¢·∏•sad√† n√¢gar√¢·∏• ‡•§tasy= √¢s√™sha-g[u]≈Ü√¢<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1698746019b.PNG"/>[Ga]·πÅg√¢dhara·∏•pa·πÅ·∏çit√¥vidy-√¢d√¢na-rata·∏• pa‚Äì327
  1. graha-bhay√¢d-y√¥n=aikshata kshatriy√¢n‡•• Tasmai114dadau Para≈õurama-vu(bu)dha·∏•sva-putri[·πÅ] S√ªlh-Abhidh√¢·πÅGirisut√¢m=iva Parvvat√™≈õa·∏• ‡•§tasy√¢·πÅ= va(ba)bh√ªvasuta-pa·πÅchatay√Ækanish·π≠h√¥ G√¥vi·πÅdacha·πÅdra-vivu(bu)dha·∏• ≈õruti-≈õ√¢stra-nish·π≠ha·∏• ‡••Sur√¢-lay-328√¢r√¢[ma]<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1698747065c.PNG"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1698747112d.PNG"/>[pra*][≈õa]stim-√™t√¢m-akar√¥t=kav-i≈õvara·∏• [‡••*]

23 ‚Äì ‚Äì ‚Äì ‚Äì ‚Äì ‚Äì ‚Äì‡••329Utk√Ær·πá·πá330=√™ya·πÅvar·πá·πáa-viny√¢sa-vidbhy√¢·πÅG√¥g√™-J√Ælh√™-n√¢mak√¢bhy√¢·πÅ-ubh√¢bhy√¢·πÅ‡•§yad-var·πá·πá-√¢ly√¥ bh√¢·πÅti p√¢sh√¢·πáa-pa·π≠·π≠√™ j√¢t√Æ-pushp-√¢rabdha-p√ªj-√¥pam√¢n√¢·∏• ‡••Y√•vad310")= Ga·πÅg√• sut√¢Bh√¢[n√¥] r=y√¢vad-bh√¢nu-[ni[≈õ√¢]]331……………[pra]≈õa[sti*]……

XI. ‚ÄìTHE MADHUBAN COPPER-PLATE OF HARSHA,

DATED SAMVAT 25.

BY G. B√úHLER, Ph.D., LL.D., C.I.E.

The subjoined edition of Harsha’s lately found grant has been prepared from two paper impressions and an ink print which have been made and furnished to me by Dr. J. Burgess. The plate was discovered in January 1888, by a cultivator whose phoughshare struck against it in a field near Madhuban, a village in parga·πáa Nath√ªpur of tehs√Æl Sagr√Æ, thirty-two Miles NE. from √Çzamga·πõh, in the North-Western Provinces. It was obtained by Dr. A. F√ºhrer from the Collector of √Çzamgarh, and is now in the Lucknow Museum.

The inscription is incised on a single copper-plate measuring 20 inches by 131, and which weighs 83 tbs, but has no ring or seal. The letters are cut neatly and deeply, so that even in those places where the surface has suffered or the plate is uneven, they have not been quite destroyed or blurred, and the reverse of the impressions shows them distinctly. The alphabet is of the Central Indian type which appears on Dr. Bhagv√¢nl√¢l’s inscriptions from Nepal, Nos. 3‚Äì15, the K√¢mavana, Jh√¢lr√•p√¢tan, Lakkh√¢Ma·πá·∏çal and other inscriptions, as well as on the Horiuzi palm-leaves and the Nepalese Cambridge MS. No. 1019.332 The characters resemble those of the later epigraphic documents named, especially Dr. Bhagv√¢nl√¢l’s No. 15, and those of the MSS., more closely than the earlier inscriptions which are known to fall within or immediately after Harsha’s reign. Only
a few letters, like ka and the subscribed √±a, show more ancient forms than the palmleaves. As rega·πõds ka, the curve of the left-hand limb does not join with the upward stroke on the left of the central vertical line. The subscribed √±a has in sam√°j√±√°payati (1. 10) the older form, which occurs in the Lakkh√¢Mandal Pra≈õasti, in r√°j√±i (1. 12) and ƒëj√±√° (1. 15), the form used in the MSS. and Nepal No. 15, differing only slightly in the position. On the other hand a good many signs like tha, ≈õa, ha and the numerals for 20, 5 and 6 show somewhat later or more developed forms than those of the documents quoted. The letter-numerals 5 and 6 resemble exactly the figures of the Cambridge MS. No. 1702, the sign for 20 comes closest to that of the Cambridge MS. No. 1461.333Peculiar is a small excrescence on the left-hand of da, caused by the letter having been made with two strokes, the triangular form of the subscribed va, and the slope in the bottom-lines of the letters pa, ma, ya, va, la, sa, and sha, which however is not constant. These latter mostly show acute angles, but occasionally nearly right angles.

The inscription is most important for pal√¶ographical purposes, and its careful study may be recommended to those scholars who still believe that the epigraphie documents give a clear view of the gradual development of the Indian alphabets. If this ≈ö√¢sana is compared letter for letter with Dr. Bhagv√†nl√†l’s No. 15, it will appear that the latter, which was incised 128 years later, shows a number of more archaic forms. If the Madhuban grant had been accessible when I wrote my pal√¶ographic essay on the Iloriuzi palm-leaves334, it would have been much easier to prove that everywhere in India the epigraphic alphabets are in many details retrograde and lag behind the literary ones,

and to demonstrate more forcibly the great antiquity of the Japanese and of the oldest Nepalesc MSS.

The language of the edict is on the whole good Sanskrit, and there are very few clerical mistakes. As regards the spelling, no distinction is made between ba and va, no doubt because in the seventh century the pronunciation of the two letters was the same, just as at present. I samvi·∏çita·πÅ (1. 10) and samvet (1. 18) the letter m remains unchanged before va, which practice is, though against grammar, very common in the inscriptions of the fourth and later centuries, and due to the pronunciation that in this point too agreed with the modern one. Ungrammatical or, unidiomatic forms and words occur exclusively in the technical portion of the grant. Among them may be noted ku·πá·∏ç√°dh√°n√≠vaishayika (1. 8) for ku·πádh√¢dh√°n√≠vishay√¢nta·∏•p√°ti, bhuktaka·∏• (1. 10) for bhukta·∏•, sarvaparihritapari≈à√°ra·∏• (1. 11) for parik·πõitasarvaparih√°ra·∏•, ¬∫samak√¢l√≠na·∏• (1. 11) for ‘samak√¢lika·∏•. Very interesting is the incorrect form pram√¢t√¢ra, which twice (1. 9 and 1. 17) occurs in the middle of a compound. It can only be explained as caused by the influence of the vernacular language which must have had then as now forms in t√¢r, spelt t√°ra, such as kart√¢r, instead of the Sanskrit words ending in t·πõi.

The historical information which the inscription furnishes, is throughout most interesting. Great IIarsha is known as one of the most eminent kings of India. His life and the lives of his immediate predecessors have been described by B√¢·πáa and by Hiuen Tsiang. It is therefore most important to sec, if what he says about himself and his family agrees with the accounts in the ≈ör√Æharshacharita and in the Si-yu-ki. The result of the comparison is on the whole favourable, especially for B√¢≈Üa. But we obtain some valuable additions to the facts already known. The genealogy of Harsha’s family‚Äìthe Vai≈õyas of Sth√¢·πávi≈õvara335 prove him to have been a Kshatriya. I also agree with his identification of Harska’s family with the modern Bais R√¢jputs. I would add that according to Dr. Kielhorn’s MS. B., Pata√±jali on P√¢·πáini, IV, 1, 170, (vol. II, p. 369, Kielhorn) mentions a country called Vaisa, an inhabitant of which is named Vai≈õya. Dr. Kielhora prints, according to the majority of his MSS. Nai≈õa and Nai≈õya. Though this proceeding is undoubtedly correct, yet it by no means follows that the roading of the majority of the MSS. is the original one, for na and va are very similar in the ancient alphabet and the writers or correctors might casily make a mistake in the case of a nume which does not occur in other literary works. Hence it is not impossible that the Mah√¢bh√¢shya has preserved the ancient name of the Bais nobles. The fact that the capital of Harsha’s ancestors was Sth√¢·πávisvara‚ÄìTh√¢·πáesar, is fully proved by B√¢·πáa’s statements.")‚Äìstands now as follows:‚Äî

<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1698823726e.PNG"/>

The names of the first three kings and those of their queens are new. Both Iliuen
Tsiang and B√¢·πáa omit them, the latter mentioning in their stead the remote founder of the family Pushpabh√πti or, as the correct spelling of the name probably was, Pushyabh√ªti336.336 They seem however to have stood on Mr. Fle√™t’s Sonpat scal of Harsha, on the

facsimile of which (1. 5) the end of the name of Prabh√¢karavardhana‚Äôs mother is visible in the words . . . . nagupt√¢d√™vy√¢m utpanna·∏•.337 it appears that he has made out the names of the second and third kings and of the third queen.")As all three receive the simple title mah√¢r√¢ja, it follows that their power was not great, and it is even doubtful if they were independent. For in the fourth, fifth, sixth and later centuries of our era the title mah√¢r√¢ja was commonly given to great vassals, as the Valabh√Æ and numerous other inscriptions prove. The position of the fourth ruler, Prabh√¢karavardhana, was of course different. As he is called paramabha·π≠·π≠√¢raka and mah√¢r√¢dhir√¢ja, he must have been an independent sovereign and a man of some consequence. He no doubt owed his prosperity to his own valour. B√¢·πáa mentions his successful wars against his northern neighbours, the king of Gandh√¢ata and the H√ªnas in the Him√¢layas, against the king of Sindh in the west, and against the rulers on his southern frontier, the G√ªrjaras, i.e., those of Bh√Ænm√¢l in R√¢jput√¢n√¢, the L√¢·π≠as, i.e., the G√ªrjaras of Bharoch, who no doubt assisted their northern clansmen, and against the king of M√¢lava338, where the foes of Prabh√¢karavardhana are briefly enumerated and in a somewhat different order.").The same author gives also a number of other data which prove that Prabh√¢karavardhana‚Äôs wars did not lead to permanent conquests of the countries or tribes which he combated and may have vanquished. Thus he tells us that shortly before his death the king sent his eldest son ‚Äúinto the north-country in order to exterminate the H√ªnas.339‚Äù Again, we hear340that immediately after Prabh√¢karavardhana‚Äôs death the king of M√¢lava was powerful enough to destroy the kingdom of the Maukhari Grahavarman, the son-in-law of the ruler, of Sth√¢·πáv√Æ≈õvara, and to slay him, as well as that he intended to attack Th√¢·πáe≈õar. That does not look as if M√¢lava had suffered much at the hands of its foe. Another remark which B√¢·πáa makes on the same occasion warns us against forming too high an opinion of the extent of Prabh√¢karavardhana‚Äôs kingdom. He says that after Grahavarman‚Äôs death, his wife R√¢jya≈õr√Æ was thrown into prison at Kanyakubja, and lay there in fetters. Hence Kanyakubja seems to have been the independent state which Grahavarman governed and the kingdom of Sth√¢·πáv√Æ≈õvara which Prabh√¢karavardhana held, cannot have extended far eastwards. It seems probable that his possessions did not go beyond the limits of the kingdom of Th√¢·πáe≈õar which Hiuen Tsiang describes (Beal‚Äôs Si-yu-ki, vol. I, p. 183ff), and which, as Sir A. Cunningham (Ancient Geography, p. 328ff) suggests, probably included portions of the Southern Panj√¢b and of Eastern R√¢jput√¢n√¢. A state, the circuit of which amounted to 7000 li or 1200 miles, might exercise a considerable influencc, keep its neighbours in fear, and afford to a very talented king the means for greater conquests; but its ruler cannot have been a chakravartin.

The further description of Prabh√¢karavardhana in our grant is obviously

conventional. The same expressions occur also on the As√Ærga·∏çh seal of the Maukhari ≈öarvavarman, and apply there to the first king Harivarman. The only other statement which possesses a historical value is the assertion that Prabh√¢karavardhana was ‚Äúa most devout worshipper of the Sun.‚Äù B√¢·πáa, too, says of him (in the ≈ö·πõ√Æharshacharita p. 274)‚Äî‚Äú And owing to his natural disposition this prince became a worshipper of the Sun.‚Äù He goes on describing at length the king’s daily devotions, adding that the recitation of the √Ådityah·πõidaya‚Äîa still much-used stotra‚Äîformed part of them. The name of Prabh√¢karavardhana‚Äôs queen is likewise known from B√¢·πáa‚Äôs poem. In the latter she is however called Ya≈õovat√Æ, not Ya≈õomat√Æ.341This vacillation in two contemporaneous sources is another instance showing how little the Hindus care about the form of a name provided the sense remains the same.

Prabh√¢karavardhana‚Äôs eldest son R√¢jyavardhana ruled, as B√¢·πáa and Hiuen Tsiang tell us, for a short time only. Soon after his father’s death he set out in order to punish the king of M√¢lava and to avenge the destruction of Grahavarman. He was successful, defeated and slew his foe. But before he returned home, he followed an invitation of the king of Gau·∏ça (≈ör√Æh√¢rshacharita) or Kar·πáa-Suvar·πáa (Si-yu-ki),‚Äînamed, according to one MS. of the ≈ör√Æharshacharita, Narendragupta and according to the Si-yu-ki ≈öa≈õ√¢·πÖka,‚Äîwho treacherously killed him, because he feared his military ability.342 The grant in the main confirms these statements. The verse inserted, 11. 6-7, declares that after defeating various kings, Devagupta and others, R√¢jyavardhana ‚Äúgave up his life in the mansion of his foe owing to his adherence to a promise.‚Äù Assuming the correctness of B√¢·πáa‚Äôs account (≈ör√Æharshacharita, pp. 393-394), according to which the expedition against M√¢lava followed immediately after Prabh√¢karavardhana‚Äôs death and R√¢jyavardhana was slain some months343later, it may be suggested that Devagupta was the name of the M√¢lava king. The latter certainly was the chief foe, and the conquest of his kingdom is attested by the further statement of B√¢·πáa that Bha·πá·∏çin, who had accompanied R√¢jyavardhana, brought the booty from M√¢lava to Harsha when the latter had reached the territory of Kum√¢ra-Bh√¢skaravarman on his expedition of revenge against the king of Gau·∏ça.344 Asserts. B√¢·πáa, 298, states plainly that he was the son of queen Ya≈õovat√Æ‚Äôs brother, who at the age of eight years became the attendant of the two princes, ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§µ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ã‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§Æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç . . . ‡§≠‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ö‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç. Dr. Hall has already pointed out that Hiuen Tsiang‚Äôs account of the part which Bha·πá·∏çin played in setting Harsha on the throne does not agree with B√¢·πáa‚Äôs narrative. It is no doubt inexact.")I may add that the word M√¢lava need not refer here or in the other passages of the ≈ör√Æharshacharita to the M√¢lava in Central India. There was another M√¢lava in the Panj√¢b, much nearer to Th√¢ne≈õar, which may be meant.

Another statement of the grant which possesses some interest is that R√¢jyavardhana was a Saugata or Buddhist (1. 6). If B√¢·πáa, himself a Br√¢hma·πá, does not

mention it, there is no reason for wondering at his reticence. But it is certainly curious that the fact‚Äîfor such it must be considered‚Äîescaped the notice of Hiuen Tsiang, who is so anxious to record every point in favour of his faith and who occasionally, it would seem, exaggerates its influence in India. Suchan exaggeration of the Chinese pilgrim is laid bare by the only direct statement concerning Harsha which the grant contains. Harsha calls himself a most devout worshipper of Mahe≈õvara or ≈öiva, ‚Äúwho like Mahe≈õvara is compassionate towards all created beings.‚Äù It agrees with this assertion that the emblem on the So·πápat seat is a reclining Nandi. Huen Tsiang, on the other hand, tries to make out tha Harsha was a Buddhist or full of faith in Buddha from the beginning. He tells us an obviously fictitious story describing how Harsha was prevented from mounting the throne and induced to take the title kum√¢ra by a Bodhisattva, who miraculously appeared to him in return for his worship345

In the gencalogical portion of the grant Harsha says nothing more about himself, and to our regret thereby sets an example which few Indian princes have imitated. But indirectly we learn something more about him from his edict. First, the wording of the verse in II. 16-17, and the reverential manner in which the grant in 1. 13 speaks of ‚Äúthe feet‚Äù of the elder brother, prove that Harsha really felt the strong attachment and great regard for R√¢jyavardhana of which B√¢·πáa speaks very fre‚Äìquently. Otherwise he would not treat him here with almost greater reverence than
his parents. Secondly, we learn from the edict that Harsha really was a poet. The second admonitory verse, Il. 16-17, gives us a maxim proclaimed by Harsha. Its wording proves beyond a doubt that the king superintended the drafting of the grant, and that this verse at least is his own composition. The fact that the first admonitory verse contains the same sentiments which are usually given in such passages, but in its form differs from all the known parallel passages, makes it probable that it likewise belongs to him. Under these circumstances I feel inclined to ascribe to him also the verse on R√¢jyavardhana. Instanees in which kings took a part in the composition of their inscriptions are not common. No. 15 of Dr. Bhagv√¢nl√¢l‚Äôs Nep√¢l series, where five verses are stated to be ‚Äúthe clever king‚Äôs own composition,‚Äù proves, however, that such things did occur. In the case of Harsha it is not astonishing that he took an interest in such matters, as we still possess three plays which go under his name and probably, in part at least, proceeded from his pen. The third piece of information, a confirmation of Hiuen Tsiang‚Äôs account, of his military career, is furnished by the particulars regarding the donation. The object of the grant is to transfer the village of Somaku·πá·∏çik√¢ situated in the vishaya of Ku·πá·∏çadh√¢n√Æ, and in the bhukti of ≈ör√¢vast√Æ, to two learned Br√¢hmans, the S√°maved√Æ Bha·π≠·π≠a V√¢tasv√¢min of the S√¢var·πái gotra and the ·πöigved√Æ Bha·π≠·π≠a ≈öivadevasv√¢min of the Vish·πáuv·πõiddha gotra. The village had formerly been enjoyed on the strength of a forged ≈õ√¢sana by one V√¢marathya, from whom it is now taken after destroying the old plate. The latter point is of some interest, as it shows that the rules of the Sm·πõitis which settle the punishment for forgers of royal edicts, were not unnecessary, and that ancient forgeries existed. As the village granted by Harsha was situated in the bhukti of ≈ör√¢vast√Æ, it is evident that he had conquered at the time a very considerable portion of Northern and Central India. The d√ªtaka,

or officer charged with the execution of the grant, was the Mah√¢s√¢manta-mah√¢r√¢ja Skandagupta who held the office of pram√¢t·πõi. This personage is probably the same Skandagupta who, according to B√¢·πáa346,was ‚Äúthe master of the elephant‚Äù at the death of R√¢jyavardhana and addressed to his prince the well-known speech full of political wisdom and historical allusions. The order to engrave the inscription was given by the chief of the mah√¢ks·∏•apa·π≠alika‚Äôs office, or the great keeper of the records, s√¢manta-mah√¢r√¢ja √é≈õvaragupta, and it was barried out by one Gurjara, whose name no doubt is derived from his caste.347

The date of the grant, Sar·πÉvat 25, M√¢rga≈õ√Ærsha vadi 6, clearly refers to the ≈ör√Æharsha era. Since the discovery of Mr. Bendall’s inscrintion348of A·πÅ≈õuvarman, dated Sa·πÅvat 34, it is not doubtful that the era began in 606 A.D. Our date consequently corresponds to November-December 631 or, if the years are taken as elapsed, to 632 A.D. I am unable to offer any suggestion regarding the situation of Pinthik√¢, where Hersha‚Äôs camp of victory which included elephants, horses and boats, was located at the time when the edict was issued.

TRANSCRIPT.

L. 1. ‡§ì349‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•å‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•É‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§£‡•Ä‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ã

L. 2. ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•ã‡§¶‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ-‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§¶‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ-

L. 3. ‡§∏‡•á‡§®‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§É‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ-‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§®‡§Æ‡§Ø ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§è‡§ï‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§• ‡§á‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§π‡§∞‡§É

L. 4. ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§Ø-‡§∂‡§É‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡§ï‡§≤‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡§Æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§≤‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•Ä‡§§-

L. 5.‡§ß‡§®‡§¶‡§µ‡§∞‡•Å‡§£‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§§‡•á‡§ú‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§•‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§£‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§£‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡§ø-‡§∂‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ã‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç

L. 6. ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ã‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§∏‡•å‡§ó‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ó‡§§ ‡§á‡§µ ‡§™‡§∞‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•à‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø-‡§µ‡§π‡§®‡§É ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ß‡§ø ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡§æ‡§ú‡§ø‡§® ‡§á‡§µ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§æ -

I. 7. ‡§¶‡§Ø‡§É

‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡§∂‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É [ ‡•§ ]
‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§ñ‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Ç
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•á ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡•á‡§® ‡§Ø‡§É [[‡•• ]]350‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ú -

L. 8. ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§π‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§á‡§µ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡•Ä ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‚Äì‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§π‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§≠‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•å ‡§ï‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ‡§ï‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á

L. 9. ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç351‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§¶‡•å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‚Äì‡§Ø‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡§ü‡§ö‡§æ‡§ü‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ú‡§®‡§™‡§¶‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ-

L. 10352. ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§™‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ‡§ï‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ï‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡•Ç‡§ü‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ï ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ-

L. 11. ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§π‡•É‡§§‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•É‡§§‡§™‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡•å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡§É ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä‡§®‡•ã

L. 12. ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ-
‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ã‡§Æ‡§§‡•Ä‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É

L. 13. ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•É‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ã‡§≠‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§π‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§ø‡§∏-
‡§ó‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ã‡§Ç‡§ó‡§∏‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø-

L. 14. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§µ‡•É‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§∏‡§ó‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ö‡§∏‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø

L. 15. ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ú‡§®‡§™‡§¶‡•à‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§£‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§≠‡•ã‡§ó‡§ï‡§∞‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§Ö‡§®‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•á‡§µ‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡•ã‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø-

L. 16. ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ö ‡••

‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡§∞‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§Æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ã‡§¶‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Ç [ ‡•§ ]

‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§°‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§≤‡§ø‡§≤‡§ö‡§Ç‡§ö‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§´‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ø‡§∂‡§É‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡•§

‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£

L. 17. ‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§®‡•á‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç [ ‡•§ ]

‡§π‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§£‡•à‡§§‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§Ç353 ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡••

‡§¶‡•Ç‡§§‡§ï‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§™‡§ü‡§≤‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø -

L. 18. ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡•®‡•¶ + ‡•´ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡§∂‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§µ‡§¶‡§ø ‡•¨

TRANSLATION.

O·πÅ Hail ! His son who meditated on his (father’s) feet (was he who was) born from the illustrious queen Apsaras, a most devout worshipper of the Sun, the great king, the illustrious Adityavardhana. His son who meditated on his (father’s) feet (was he who was) born from the illustrious queen Mah√¢senagupt√¢, he whose fame passed beyond the four oceans, he whose sovereign power was employed in settling (the system of) castes and orders, who like (the deity) with the single-wheeled chariot355removed the torments of his subjects, a most devout worshipper of the Sun, the supreme lord and supreme king of great kings, the illustrious Prabh√¢karavardhana. His son who meditated on his
