He in a wonderful manner brought about both these things by his fame (which is imperishable and bright); the whole earth is bright with the whiteness of white mortar (filled as it is with has bright fame).‚Äô

[‡§®‡•ã]‚Åµ‚Å¥‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§Ç
[‡§∏‡§Ç]‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§ß‡•É‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ[‡§∏‡•Å]‡§∏‡•Å‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äå‡••-‚Åµ‚Åµ-688 [37].
20.
‡§ï‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∑‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®‡•Å‚Åµ‚Å∂‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•É‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§§‡§É‡§ï‡•É‡§§ -
‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•à‡§É‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ç‡§≠‡•ã‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§É\‡•§
‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§ó‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§Ç‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡•Ä‡§É
‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ú‡§≤‡§ß‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•à(‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡•à)‡§≤‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§°‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡••‚Äî[38].
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§æ(‡§∂‡§æ)‡§∞‡§¶‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§ø[[‡§ñ]]689‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø(‡§∂‡§ø)‡§ñ‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§®(‡§£‡•ç‡§£) ‡§®‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑[[‡§§‡•ç‡§∞^(x)]]690‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ-
‡§û‡•ç‡§ö [‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑] ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§Æ‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡§•(‡§®)‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§•‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§•‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§É ‡•§
21.
‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç‡§≠‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ (‡§∂‡§æ) ‡§§‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§π‡§ø‡§®‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡§ø(‡§∂‡§ø)‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø(‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§ø)‡§µ‡§ø(‡§¨‡§ø)‡§Æ‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ(‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§æ)‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡§§‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•á
‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§Æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ(‡§∂‡•ç‡§Æ) ‡§µ‡•à‡§ï‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§†‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§É‡••‚Åµ‚Åπ–[39).
‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∏(‡§∂)‡§∏‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ[‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø]‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡•Ä ‡•§ ‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•Ä ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‚Å∂‚Å∞‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§™‡§§‡•á‡§É‡••‚Å∂¬π310.")-[40].
‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§ó‡§∏‡•á‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡•Å‡§Ç‡§ß‡§§‡•Ä‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡•§
22.
‡§µ(‡§¨)‡§≠‡•å ‡§Æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§≤‡§∏‡§æ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§® ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É ‡§ï‡§•‡§Ç‡§ö‡§® ‡••‚Å∂¬≤- [41 \‡•§.
‡§∏‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•Ä‡§®‡§∞‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡•á‡§É ‡§∏(‡§∂)‡§ö‡•Ä‡§µ‡§∏‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç (‡§§‡§Ç)
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§ ‡§™‡•Ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§ø‡§µ [[‡§ß‡§Ç ]]691‡§ó‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äå ‡••‚Å∂‚Å¥127- [42].

……………………………………………………………………..
**54.**This is a mere conjecture; the original has ‡§§or ‡§§‡§Ç, altered to some akshara or other which is not clear in the impressions; the first akshara, ‡§∏‡§Ç, of the following line also is indistinct.‚ÄîDh·πõitar√¢sh·π≠ra, the nephew of Bh√Æshma and father of the Kauravas, had for his wife G√¢ndh√¢r√Æ, the sister of ≈öakuni; Yudhish·π≠hira, the eldest of the P√¢·πá·∏çavas, was the son of Dharma; Dro·πáa was the teacher of the Kauravas and P√¢·πá·∏çavas, und Kar·πáa an ally of the Kauravas. I therefore should translate the verse, in the first instance, as follows :–’ Having for his beloved G√¢ndh√¢r√Æ,who was fond of the voice of the joyful ≈öakuni,‚Äîstupefied when he heard the speeches, which gave no pleasuro to his ear, of Bh√Æshma and Dro·πáa,‚Äînot hostile to the son of Dharma, even when he saw his own race destroyed by him,‚Äî(the prince) who was (both) a good friend (and) an enemy, came to be Dh·πõit√¢rish·π≠ra.‚Äô This wonder is explained when we take the last line to mean, that the prince, surrounded by good friends and free from enemies, firmly established his government ; and then understand the preceding lines to say, that he had for his wife a G√¢ndh√¢ra,princess (?) who was fond of the song of merry birds,‚Äîthat he was stupefied when he heard the omiuous cries of ravens, which did not please his ears,‚Äîand that he did not act contrary to law, even when the existence of his family was at stake.
56. Originally ‡•¶‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®‡§ø‡•¶, altered to ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®‡•Å.‚ÄîCompare Monier Williaws, Dictionary, under ‡§∏‡§ó‡§∞and ‡§≠‡§ó‡•Ä‡§∞‡§•.
59. Metre, Sragdhar√¢.‚ÄîIf the verse, as given above, is correct,‚Äîand I do not see how it could be read differently,‚Äîit is badly constructed, mainly, because in the second line we expect the relative ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç, instead of the demonstrative ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‚Äå.The meaning of the verse Itake to be: ‚ÄòHeerected this dwelling, praised by all, of Vaiku·πá·π≠ha, the enemy of ethe Asuras from which tho charioteer of the sun, to save the wheels, turns awayhis chariot, because with its sharp spires, shining like the autumnal moon, it pierees the Zodiac; and the golden dome of which always causes it to be taken for the sun, kissing with its orb the peaks of the mountain of snow.‚Äô‚ÄîCompare verse 50, below.
**60.**On the best of my impressions this word is quite distinct, and I take it to be the nameof the queen, who in this verse iscompared with the river Narmad√¢. Compare Amarako≈õa, ‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§æ.
**62.**Metre Va·πÉ≈õastha.‚ÄîIndirectly the princess is compared with Anas√ªy√¢, Aruadhat√Æ, Damayant√Æ, and Mad√¢las√¢.Compare the similar verse 26, above.

‡§Ö‡§∂‡•ã‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶[‡§≠‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ]‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§™‡•Ç‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§∞‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡•§ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•ã ‡§π‡§£‡§ø‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡•á ‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§∏ ‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•ã‡§É ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‚Å∂‚Åµ‡§®‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§É‡••‚Å∂‚Å∂144 ; and of the next verse.") [43].
23.
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ [‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‚Å∂‚Å∑- ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§ø?]‡§§‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•É‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ñ‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§É ‡•§ ‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§∂‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§£‡§Ç‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡•á‡§®‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‚Äå ‡•• - [44].
‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•ã‡§∂‡§≤‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§Ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§§‡§æ -
‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π‡§≤‡§™‡§§‡•á ‡§≤‡§µ‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ(‡§¨) ‡§π‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äå\‡•§
‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç‡§µ‡§ø[‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ]‡§™‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç‡§§‡§≤‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§¶‡§®‡•á ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äå‡•§‚Å∂‚Å∏692
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§ó‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‚Å∂‚Åπ693‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§É‡••‚Å∑‚Å∞-694 [45]
24.
‡§ï‡§æ ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡•Ä‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‚Å∑¬π695‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§æ‡§¢‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§¢‡§µ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡•á‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡•Ä[I^(x)]
‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§É‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡§ú‡§Ø‡§ø‡§®‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡•à‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡•á ‡§∏‡§ú‡§≤‡§®‡§Ø‡§®‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ã‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ (‡§¨)‡§≠‡•Ç‡§µ‡•Å‡§É ‡••‚Å∑¬≤-696 [46].
‡§ï‡§æ ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§∂‡§∂‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ã‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ(‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ)‡§≤‡§æ
25.
‡§∏‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§É‡§ï‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§π‡§Ç‡§µ‡•Å(‡§¨‡•Å)‡§ß‡•à‡§ï‡§∏‡•Å‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§É‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ß‡§Ç‡§ó‡§™‡•É‡§•‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§™‡§§‡•á‡§É\‡•§
‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ(‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ)‡§Æ‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ó‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•å‡§§‡•Å‡§ï‡§æ
‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§ß‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø(‡§∂‡§ø)‡§ñ‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç ‡••‚Å∑¬≥697 ‚Äî\47).
‡§Æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§§‡§Æ‡§Ø ‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç‡§ó‡§Ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§¶‡§∂‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç(‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç)‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ü‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡•§
‡§§‡§¶‡§µ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§§‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ß‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§∞‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ß‡§Ç‡§ó‡•á‡§®‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∏‡§ø(‡§∂‡§ø)‡§§‡§Ç ‡••[‚Å∑‚Å¥698- [48\‡•§.
26.
‡§µ‡•á‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ (‡§∂‡•ç‡§Æ) ‡§®‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ (‡§∂‡•ç‡§Æ) ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡§§‡•á ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∂‡§™‡§æ‡§∏(‡§∂‡§Ç)‡§π‡§∞‡•ã‡§π‡§∞‡§É‡••‚Å∑‚Åµ-[ 49].
‡§§‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏(‡§∂)‡§∞‡§¶‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•Å (‡§∂‡•Å)‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø(‡§∂‡§ø)‡§ñ‡§∞‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ß‡§Ç‡§™‡•É‡§•‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§≠‡•Å‡§ú‡§æ
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ(‡§∏‡§æ)‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§¶‡§∂‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§Ç(‡§∂‡§Ç)‡§≠‡•ã‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∑‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§ß‡•å‡§§‡§ï‡§≤‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Ç (‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç)\‡•§
27.‡§Æ‡•á‡§∞‡•ã‡§É ‡§∏‡•É‡§Ç (‡§∂‡•É‡§Ç)‡§ó‡§Æ‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡•á‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•ã‡§∞‡•Å‡§£‡§É ‡••‚Å∑‚Å∂699–[50).
‡§≠‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡•Ç‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§∏(‡§∂)‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§É \‡•§

……………………………………………………

65 Read ‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Ä‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ. ‚ÄòWorshipping Vish·πáu (the joy of Ya≈õod√¢), the purenamed one engaged in battle; born, an object of joy, in a fierce race, that destroyer of enemies was the bestof men (Krish·πáa),‚Äîwho, worshipping Ya≈õod√¢and Nanda, brought about the destruction of (the fiend) P√ªtan√¢, and who, born in the V·πõish·πái race, annihilated the enemy Ka·πÅsa.‚Äô‚Äî Compare, e.g., V√¢savadatt√¢, p. 12 and p. 150.
67. About the aksharas in these brackets I am very doubtful. In the impressions, the first of them looks somewhat like ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä, i.e.,‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Äthe second like ‡§Æ, and the third like ‡§ß‡§ø; but the third akshara appears certainly to have been altered, and probably also the first. ‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§∂‡§ø‡§™‡•Åalso means‚Äò gold and food and clothing; ‚Äòcompare, e.g.,V√¢savadatt√¢, p.11, and Damayantikath√¢, p.22.
75. Metre,≈öloka(Anush·π≠ubh). ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§§ ishere, as elsewhere, used in the sense of ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§É

‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ã‡§∞‡§£‡§∞‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞ ‡••‚Å∑‚Å∑-700-[51].
‡§ú‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§ü‡•ã [‡§µ]‚Å∑‚Å∏701‡§ü‡•ã‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§π‡§æ‡§ü‡§ï‡§ï‡•ã‡§ü‡•Ä‡§∞‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡•§
‡§Ö‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡§æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏(‡§∂)‡§§‡§∏‡•ã(‡§∂‡•ã) ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§®‡•• ‚Äî(52]. \‡•§
‡§∑‡§ü‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ[‡§≠‡§ø]‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‚Å∑‚Åπ702 ‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•Å (‡§∂‡•Å)‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∏(‡§∂)‡§π‡§Ø‡§æ- `
28.
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ(‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ)‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§∑‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ã‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ã‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§§‡•á ‡§ß‡§®‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡•á‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É
‡§∏‡•å‡§ß‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ç‡§ü‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§ü‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ(‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ)‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§æ‡§É‡••‚Å∏‚Å∞– [53].
‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞ (‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞)‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•Å ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞(‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞)‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å‡•§ ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§™‡§∞‡•ã‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‚Äå ‡••‚Å∏¬π ‚Äî( 54].
‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§µ‡•Å(‡§¨‡•Å)‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø(‡§∂‡§ø)‡§∞‡§∏(‡§∂)‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç
29.
‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∏(‡§∂)‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏(‡§∂)‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ß‡§Ç‡§ó‡§™‡•É‡§•‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§≤‡•ã‡§ö‡§®‡§É ‡§∏ ‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§ú(‡§û‡•ç‡§ú)‡§™‡§®‡•ç‚Äå703‡§ú‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§µ‡•Ä -
‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡§∏‡§≤‡§ø‡§≤‡•á ‡§ï‡§≤‡•á‡§µ‡§∞‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§¶‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡••‚Å∏¬≥-704 [55]
‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡§æ (‡§∂‡§æ)‡§∏‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§æ (‡§∂‡§æ) ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∏‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§ß‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡•Å(‡§¨‡•Å)[‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•å] ‡•§
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ã‡§ß‡§∞‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§∏‡§ø ‡§µ‡•á‡§ß‡§∏‡•ã‡§µ ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ú‡§ó‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•Ä‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡§æ ‡••‚Å∏‚Å¥705- [56].

**30.
‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∏(‡§∂)‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¶‡§®‡§É ‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä ‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ú‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡•ã‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§µ(‡§¨) ‡§≤‡•ã‡§µ(‡§¨)‡§≤‡§≠‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡•• ‚Äî[57].
‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®‡•Å‡§É‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®‡•É‡§§‡§ó‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§≠ [‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø] ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§ø ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç‡§°‡§ø‡§∞‡§®‡§ò‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§É‡•§
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§∞‡§Æ‡§£‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§∂‡•Ç(‡§∏‡•Ç)‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•Ä ‡§§‡•á‡§®‡•á‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞[‡§ö‡§®‡§æ] ‡§≠[‡§§‡§•‡§æ]‡§≤‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∂‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡§É ‡••‚Å∏‚Åµ–706[58].
31.
‡§® ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§É‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§ø‡§π‡§® ‡§∏‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§∂‡•Ä‡§≤‡•ã‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ(‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ)‡§≤‡§ß‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡•§
‡§Ø‡§∂‡§É‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§™‡§¶‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∂(‡§∏): ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§∂(‡§∏)‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡§É ‡••‚Å∏‚Å∂707— [89].
‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡•§
‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø(‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø)‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ [‡§≠‡§ø]‡§ß‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§ß‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ(‡§∏‡§æ)‡§¶‡§É708‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§•‡§®‡§æ‡§•‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡••‚Å∏‚Å∏-677- [60].

‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•É‡§•‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∏‡§™‡•É‡§•‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ß‡§∞‡§®‡§ó‡§∞‡§®‡§ó‡§æ ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•à-
‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ø‡§£‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§£‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§¶‡§®‡§É ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§§‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø(‡§∂‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø): \‡•§**

……………………………………………………………………….

80. Metre, ≈ö√¢rd√ªlavikri·∏çita, Thesix occupations of Br√¢hmans are ‡§Ö‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§®, ‡§Ö‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§®, ‡§Ø‡§ú‡§®, ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡§®, ‡§¶‡§æ‡§® and ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π, i.e. stndy, teaching, offering snorifices, conducting them for others, giving and accepting gifts.The palaces, high like the peaks of the Knil√¢sa, which the king erected for certain holy Br√¢hmans, are the same buildings which elsewhere are called brahmapuri; seeIndian Antigquary, vol. XV, p. 44, note130.
81. Metre, ≈öloka (Anush·π≠ubh),‚ÄîNorth of the Him√¢laya is the country of eternal heatitude; hre the Br√¢hmassselected by the king had found south of the Him√¢laya a place where all their wishes were fulfilled. ‚Äò

**‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞(‡§¶‡•ç‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞)‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§°‡§≠‡§æ‡§Ç‡§°‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§•‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§£‡§µ‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§É
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ (‡§∏‡§æ)‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡•á‡§∑ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§§‡•Å ‡§®‡§∞‡§™‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡•à‡§≤‡§æ‡§∏‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡§É ‡••‚Å∏‚Åπ-161-[61].
‡§≤‡§ø‡§™‡§ø[‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ\‡•§‡§®‡§µ‡§ø[‡§ß‡§ø^(x)]‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§®‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§®‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§∏‡§æ (‡§∂‡§æ)‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡•§
‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π‡•á‡§®‡•á‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§∏‡§æ(‡§∂‡§æ)‡§≤‡§ø[[‡§®‡•ã]]709‡••‚Åπ¬π-325.")-[62].
- ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§§(‡§§‡•ç‚Äå) ‡•ß‡•¶‡•´‡•Ø‚Åπ¬≤‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ñ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§∞-
38.
‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ [‡§π]‡§ï‡•á‚Åπ¬≥ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä[‡§ß‡§Ç]‚Åπ‚Å¥‡§ó‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§§‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏(‡§∂)‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ ‡••
‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§ñ‡§æ‡§§‡•ã‡§∂‡§Æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•É‡§£‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç710 ‡§™‡§¶‡•à-
‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡•å‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ó‡§∞‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ó‡§≠‡§Ç[‡§ó‡•Å]‡§∞‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•à‡§É‡•§
‡§¶‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ -
‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§≤‡•á‡§ñ‡§ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§Æ‡§≤‡•à‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡•à‡§É‡§¨‡•Å‡§≠‡•Ç‡§ú‡§æ‡••‚Åπ‚Å∂–[63].
34.
‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§Ø‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§∏‡•ã (‡§∂‡•ã) ‡§§‡§ï‡§ø‡§∞‡§£‡•ã‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ã
‡§ó‡•å‡§°‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø711‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§É‡•§ ,
‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•ã ‡§ú‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø (‡§¨‡§ø) [‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞ ] ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ‡§É
‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§µ‡•Å(‡§¨‡•Å)‡§ß‡§ø‡§µ‡§Ç(‡§¨‡§Ç)‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§π‡§§‡§§‡§Æ‡•ã‡§∞‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§É‚Åπ‚Å∏‡•• –[64].

‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‚Äå ‡•ß‡•ß‡•≠‡•©‡§µ‡•à‡§∏‡§æ(‡§∂‡§æ)‡§ñ ‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡§ø ‡•© ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡••**

V.
STONE INSCRIPTION OF KOKKALA, OF THE YEAR 1058.

The slab which bears this inscription is said to have been found about fifty yearsago at the temple of Vaidyan√¢tha, at Khajur√¢ho; and is now built into the side wall of the entrance porch of the temple of Vi≈õvan√¢tha at the same place. Tho inscription has been mentioned several times in the volumes of the Archaeological Survey of India, and a photo-lithograph of it, which, though useless for editing, shows well the style.

…………………………………………………………………….
92 This figure is quite distinct, and it is neither 1019 nor 1056.
93 Inthe two impressions supplied to me by Dr. Burgess, the two aksharas ‡§¨‡§æ and ‡§ï‡•á are quite distinct, and the consonant of the akshara stunding between tho two is ‡§π‡•Å; but this ¬• appears to have been preceded by the sign for e(not i) which, sofar as I can make out, has been struck out again.
94 This akshara can only be read ‡§ò‡§Ç or ‡§¨‡§Ç, and the following akshara is quite clearly ‡§ó.
96 Metre, ≈ö√¢rd√ªlavikr√é·∏çita ; and of the noxt verse. ‚ÄòThe prince Jayavarmadeva who with the letters of his fame inscribed the walls of the regions, the mountain-like great princes of which had been uprooted (by him, and which had been) smoothedby the steps of (his) furious elephants, (and) washed with the streams of the tears of the trembling wives of (his) enemies, perishing when they met (him) in battle,‚Äîthis princehas written again this enlogy with clear letters‚Äô ;‚Äîi.e., the prince Jayavarmadeva caused the inscription, which may be supposed to hate become damaged or illegible, to bere-engraved.

98. In Cunningham’s Archeol, Survey of India, Vol.XXI,p. 68, it is stated that the inscription had originally been written in irregular (K√Ær·πáa) letters, and that it was ro-written in letters of thekumvda form, or in ‚Äòlotus-like or beautiful characters‚Äô, My text and translationof the proceding verseshow that the inscription does not coutain the word K√Ær·πáaat all; nordoes the present verse say anything about kumuda characters. For the verse simply says, that Jayap√¢la, the Gau·∏ça, the K√¢yastha of the ruling prince. Jayavammadeva, honoured by the learned, acquainted with the various arts, and familiar with poetry,
&e.,with his hands moving forward wrote these letters, as the moon, reating on the body of ≈öiva, containig digits, and the friend of the ocean, &e., with her spreading rays, touches the lotus-flowers.

of the letters and the general state of preservation of this record, is given by Sir A.Cunningham in Archaoi. Survey of India, vol. XXI, plate xix.

The inscription consists of 22 lines. The writing covers a space of about 8‚Äô 8‚Äùbroad by 2‚Äô 2‚Äù high. Down to line14, it is on the whole well preserved. From line15 to 21, on thoe proper right side, a large piece of the surfacoe of the stone has gone,causing the completce.loss of about 80 aksharas; and a few aksharas have gone in otherplaces, as will appear from my trans√©cript of the text. T‚Äòhe size of the letters is from ¬æ‚Äú to ^(7/8)". The characters are Na√¢dgari√Æ. The language is Sanskrit, and, except for the introductory Om·πÅ namah·∏• S≈öiva√¢yaSivdya, the words kim·πÅ vahuna√¢in line 8, and the date at the end, the inscription is in, v√©rse. As regards orthography, 5 b has throughout been denoted by the sign for v; the palatal sibilant has been employed for thoe dental sibilant in vikas≈õat and bha√¢s≈õvat, line 1, S≈õamkalpa, line 8 3, and ajas≈õram·πÅ, line 17; and the dental for the palatal sibilant in sayya, line 17, and vahusrutam·πÅ, line 21; the dental nasalrfor the lingual or palatal nasal in jirna, line 8, idrikshena, line 15, and kanchana, line 19; y for j in sphuryat, line 1, and jatayutam, line 5; the conjunct jv for for jjv‚Äòin milajvdld, line 1, and ujvala, lincs 10 and 22.Besides, a consonant has been doubled before y or r in proddyat, linc 1, rajjyd, line 15, chittra, lines 7 and 9, vichittra, line 17, pattre, linc 16, and yattra, line 21. And regarding the language and style in general, I may add that the inscription is in every way, inferior to the two other large Khajurhho inscriptions, aud that some of its verses do not admit of a proper construction. The inscription does not record the naine of the composer, nor the names of the writer and engraver.
The inscription is dated, in lino 22, on the full-moon day of the month Karttikaof the year 1058 (expressed by decimal figures only), which, as a year of the Vikrama era, corresponds 19 A.D. 1000-1001. And it records, in lines 19-21, the erection of a temple in honour of (Siva) Vaidyanatha and of a set of buildings for pious Brahmans, by oneKokkala or Kokkalla, the younger brother of Sekkala or Sekkalla, both of whom were sons of Jayadeva, the son of Mahata, who again was the son of Yasobala or Atiyasobala, of the Grahapati family. These personages would appear to have becn small chiefs or nobles dwelling at Khajuraho, and all the inscription says about them, is that Kokkala founded a town, and that Yasobala was settled at the townof Padmavati¬≤712Other members of the same family or clan are mentioned in the following inscriptions. So much will be clear from a perusal of. this inscription that the Kokkala or Kokkalla, mentioned here, has nothing to do with Kokalla, the Chedi ruler of Tripurt.

Text¬π713

L1. ‡•ê‡§®‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•• ¬≤714‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø(‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú)‡§§‡•ç‡§´‡§æ(‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡§æ)‡§∞‡§´‡§£‡§æ‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ‡§™‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§∂(‡§∏)‡§°‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡§ü‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§Ç ‡•§¬≥715 ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ñ(‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ)
‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø(‡§§‡§ø)‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§∏‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø(‡§ö‡§ø)‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•ã‡§≤‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡•ã‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§≤‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤‡§¨‡•ç‡§¨‡§æ(‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ) ‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§≤‡•Ä‡§™‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§ï‡•§
‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á ‡§∏‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¶‚Äì

**2. ‡§∞‡§µ‡•à‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§æ‡§•‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø(‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç) ‡§ú‡§ü‡§æ‡§Æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§≤‡§Ç ‡•• ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡§µ‡§®‚Å¥‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•à‡§É‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç‡§≠‡•É‡§∂‡§Ç‡•§‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§ö‡§®‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§ (‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç) ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡••(‡•§) ‡§ï‡§£‡•ç‡§†‡•á‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡•Ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡•ã‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§É
3. ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç‚Åµ ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ(‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ)‡§µ‡§ø(‡§ß‡§ø)‡§π‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡§æ‡§ö‡§∞‡§ß‡§∞‡§É ‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§µ‡§É ‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§É ‡•• ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ã ‡§µ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏ [:^(x)] ‡§∂‡§Ç(‡§∏‡§Ç)‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§Ç‡•§ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞(‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞)‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡•à‡§ï‡§Ç‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§§‡§≠‡§ú‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§§‡§Ç(?) ‡§ö‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§ø‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‚Å∂‡§µ‡•Å(‡§¨‡•Å)‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ-
4. ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡§Ç‡•• ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•à‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•à‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§™‡§§‡•á‡§É(?) ‡§∏(‡§∂)‚Å∑‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§Æ‡§É‡•• ‚Å∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ï‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•à‡§É‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•à‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•Ä-
5. ‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§ ‡§ß‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§™‡•ç‡§ï‡•ã‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∞‡§ï‡•ã‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§ü‡§ø‡§§‡§™‡§†‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ü‡§æ (‡§ü‡•ã) ‡§™‡§ï‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ [:^(x)]‚Åπ‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Å‡§ü‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§ü‡§ú- ‡§ü‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Ç(‡§ú‡•Ç)‡§ü‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Ç‡••¬π‚Å∞‡§Ü‡§∏‡•Ä‡§¶‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•à‡§∞‡§æ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§≤‡•á ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§™‡•á‡§® ‡§≠‡•Ç-
6. ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•á‡§® ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡••(‡•§ )‡§ï‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡•Ä‡§π ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ (‡§µ‡•á) ‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡•É‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ(‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ)‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§™‡§†‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ[‡§£^(x)]‡§™‡§ü‡•Å‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡•å‡§ß‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§™‡§§‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ò‡§®‡§™‡§•‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§æ ‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ-
7. ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∑‡§™‡§æ‡§ñ‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ä‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§∂‡§ø‡§ñ‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§µ(‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨)‡§∞‡§æ ‡••(I) ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§≤‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ(‡§ö)‡§≤‡§∂‡•É‡§Ç‡§ó‡§∏‡§Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø(‡§®‡§ø)‡§≠‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§≠‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§¶‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§ö‡§®‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä ‡•• ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å(‡§ñ‡•Å)‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ã‡§¶‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã

  1. [‡§¶‡§Ç] ‡§§‡§Ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§®(‡§∞‡•ç‡§£)‡§ï‡§†‡•ã‡§∞‡§µ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å(‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞?)‡§Æ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§¶‡§∞‡§æ‡§≠‡§Ç, ‡§®‡§≠‡§É‡••(‡•§) ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡§ü‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§¶‡•É‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ[‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å]‡§§[ ‡§Ø‡•Å] ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å(‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å)‡§§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§É‡•• ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç [‡§µ(‡§¨)‡§π‡•Å]‡§®‡§æ‡•§ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç¬π¬π ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç- ‡§µ(‡§¨)‡§ï -
  2. ‚Äî ‚Äî¬π¬≤‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§É [I^(x)] ‡§ï‡•ã‡§ü‡§ø‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•ã‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§®‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§§‡§ø‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ã‡§µ(‡§¨)‡§≤‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç(‡§Æ‡§æ)‡§®‡•ç‚Äå‡••¬π¬≥ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡§≠‡•Å‡§ú‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§§‡§æ[‡§™‡•ç‡§§]‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§§‡§∞‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§É[‡•§^(x)] ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§≠‡§Ç‡§ó‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡§ï‡§ü‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∂‡§∞‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ [‡§§‡•ç‡§§] ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞-
    10 ‚Äî ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§∂‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§É‡•• ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§∂‡§∂‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§ï‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ (‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ)‡§≤‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§≤‡§ú‡§≤‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ(‡§¨)‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§°‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡••(‡•§)‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§™‡§ø ‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ(‡§Æ‡§æ)‡§ö‡§≤‡•á(‡§≤)‡§∂‡•É‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡•Å‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ï‡§∞‡•á‡§∂[ ‡§§‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞ ] ‡§§‡•Å‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•Ä ‡§∏ ‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ã‡§µ(‡§¨)‡§≤‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø -
  3. [: ‡•• ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ]‡§¶‡§≠‡•Ç‡§¶‡§≠‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§‡§æ‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡§µ (‡§¨)‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•Å‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•ã ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡•É(‡§§‡•ç‡§∞)‡§µ‡§ó(‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó)‡§´‡§≤‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≤‡§≤‡§µ‡•ç‡§ß(‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß) ‡§∏‡•å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡••(‡•§) ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø-‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§ï[‡§•‡§æ ]‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ó‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®[‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø]‡§Æ‡•ã‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§ú‡§®‡§É ‡§ï‡§ø‡§≤ [‡§Æ‡§æ] ‡§π‡•É‡§ü‡§æ [‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø]:‡•• ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ú‡§É¬π‚Å¥‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï-
  4. ‚Äî ‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡§∏‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡••(‡•§) ¬π‚Åµ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•É‡§§‡§ó‡§≠‡•Ä‡§∞‡§ø‡§Æ[‡§Ø‡§æ]‡§µ‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø(‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø)‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‚Äî ‚Äî‚Äî[‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å]‡§∞‡•Å‡§ó‡§≠‡•Ä‡§∞ [‡§∞‡§æ]‡§∂‡§ø‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ï‡•É‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§Ø‡§¶‡•á[‡§µ‡§®‡§æ]‡§Æ‡§æ‡•• ‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ¬π‚Å∂‡§∂‡•Ä‡§§‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Ä -
  5. [‡§π‡§ø‡§§^(x)] ‡§´‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•å ‡§ö ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ã ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ ‡§§‡§§‡•ã ‡§ú‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡§≤‡§É[I^(x)] ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡§∞‡§£‡§ø‡§É‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡•Ä[:^(x)] ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ó‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•à‡§ï‡§µ‡§∏‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä ‡§ß‡§®‡•à‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø[‡§§‡§É‡••^(x)]¬π‚Å∑
  6. [‡§∏^(x)]‡§π‡•Ä‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø¬π‚Å∏‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§™‡•É‡§•‡•Å‡§ï‡§ï‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ(‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ) ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ó‡•á¬π‚Åπ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ(‡§Æ‡§æ)‡§®‡§É ‡§ï‡§ü‡•Å‡§ï‡§™‡§ü‡§µ- ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ã‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§£‡•á ‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó[‡§≤‡•ç‡§Æ][1^(x)] [‡§∏)]‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•å‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§ü‡§ø‡§§[‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ]‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡§É‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•Å -
  7. ‚Äî [‡§µ?]‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡§π‡§ø‡§§ ‚Äî ‚Äî‚Äî[‡§∏‡•á? ]¬≤‚Å∞‡§ï‡§≤‡•ã‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‚Äå‡•• ¬≤¬π‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§π‡•ã‡§∞‡§ó‡§≠‡•Ä‡§∞‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡§≤‡§ß‡•á‡§É ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•á ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø[‡§§‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§¶‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§®(‡§£)?]‡§Æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§≠‡•Å‡§ú‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡§§‡§®‡•Å‡§Ç [‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ?]‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ã‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∏‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§Æ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ [ ‡§ï‡•Å]‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ-**

…………………………………………………………………………………………………….

  1. Originally ‡§µ‡§®‡•á.
    5.These three aksharas and the word ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§Éat the end,of the preceding line are quite clear in the impressions, butthey give no sense. One expects something like ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§É‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§É.
  2. These aksharas, too, are quite distinct;I would suggest ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ.
  3. This correction is not absolutely necessary,because the word is spelt both ‡§∂‡§∞‡•ç‡§µand ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ; and the verse evidently containsa play on the word ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ.
    8.Metre, Sragdhar√¢.
    9.This sign of visarga is not absolutely necessary.
    10.Metre, ≈ö√¢rd√ªlavikr√Æ·∏çita, and of the two next verses.
  4. Metre, √Çry√¢.
  5. This akshara lookslike ‡§Æ‡•á..
  6. Metre, Vasantatilak√¢; and of the next three verses,
  7. This verse contains five P√¢das insteadof four.
  8. The akshara actually given here are quite clear but Iam unable to make out any connected sense.
  9. Metre,≈ö√¢rd√ªlavikr√Æ·∏çita.
  10. The aksharas within these brackets are entirely gone.
  11. Metre, Sragdhar√¢.
  12. Reade ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§ó‡•á.
  13. Of this akshara only the upper portion is visible.
  14. Metre, ≈ö√¢rd√ªlavikr√Æ·∏çita.

16 ‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§É‡••¬≤¬≤‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ú‡•ã‡§™‡§ø[‡§∏‡•å‡§Ç]‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ [‡§¶‡•å]‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‚Äå‡•§ ‡§Ø‡•å‡§µ‡§®‡•á‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§É‡•§ (‡••) ‡§Ø‡§É¬≤¬≥‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§¶‡§¶‡§æ-

    • ~ ~+ ~ ~~‚Äú –~–~- 7 - - – ‡§®‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§µ‡§∏‡§®‡§∂‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡§∏ (‡§∂)‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡•§ ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ(‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ)‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç(‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç) ‡§∏ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§ï‡•ã‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ [‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã] ‡§≠‡§µ‡§µ‡§¶‡§ø‡§π‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§∞‡§É¬≤‚Å¥‡§ï‡•Ä -
  2. ‡•Ø. ‚Äî [‡§®‡•ç‡§ß]‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡•• ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡§Æ¬≤‚Åµ~ ‡•´, ‚Äî- VU <‚Äú - ‡•´ -’- > ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•ã‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ñ‡§∞‡§ø‡§∂‡•É‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡•Å‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§Ç‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∑‡§£‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§≤‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§ó‡•ã‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ö‡•ã‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡§≤‡§É‡••‡§§‡•á¬≤‚Å∂ -
  3. ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å‡§π‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§ö‡§≤‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≤‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§ï‡•Ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞[‡§ï‡§æ?] - ¬´~ oO - - - ~ ~ - ~ - ‡§µ‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø(‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø) ‡§ó‡§π‡§®‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§ï‡§Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§ö(‡§û‡•ç‡§ö)‡§®‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ï‡§≤‡§∏ [‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ] ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ö‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§≠‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡•à‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§æ‡§•‡§™‡•ç‡§∞-
  4. ‡§≠‡•ã[:‡••^(x)] [‡§Ø]‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø¬≤‚Å∑‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ[‡§∞‡•á]‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§æ‡§§‡§§‡§Æ‡§ø‡§µ ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡•ã ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ- = - – - ~ ‚Äî [‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç] ‡§ó‡§ó‡§® ‡§á‡§µ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§°‡•ç‡§°‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§ó[‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ]‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø[‡§≠‡§æ‡§§‡§ø] \‡•§ ‡§Ø[‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ]‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ‡•à‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§æ‡§•‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡§µ‡§≠‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§ï‡§Ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§ø‡§µ
  5. >- ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§∞‡§£‡•Ä‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡•• ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞¬≤‚Å∏‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§æ - UU ~ ‡•¶ ~ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§π‡•Å‡§§‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ(‡§¨)‡§π‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å(‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å)‡§§‡§Ç‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡•É‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§Æ‡§®‡§ò‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç‡••¬≤‚Åπ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§ï‡§∏‡•á‡§ï‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Ø‡•ã‡§≤‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∂‡§ñ-
  6. ~ < < ‡§™‡•ã‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§ó‡§£‡§æ ‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡•ã‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ(‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ)‡§≤‡§æ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§≤‡§æ‡§≤‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡§µ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§π‡•Ä[‡§≠‡•É ]‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§æ‡§®‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§™‡§Æ‡§ø‡§µ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞(‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞)‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§°‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§π‡§§‡§ø‡•• ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‚Äå ‡•ß‡•¶‡•´‡•Æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡§≤‡•á‡§®[‡••^(x)]

TRANSLATION.

Om!

Adoration to ≈öiva !

(Line1.) I adore the adorable coil of matted hair carried by the beautiful. Vaidyan√¢tha, (which is) irradiated by the expanding terrible hoods of a multitude of hissing broad serpents ;¬≥‚Å∞marked with the half-moon which is excessively shining, more brilliantly than the sun; (and) yellowish, when in contact with theline of flames of the fire issuing forth from his tremulous eye.
(2.) May that ≈öa·πÅkara who takes away all disease (and) supports the movable and immovable, protect you!‚Äîhe, whose dwelling-place isthe cemetery, who holds mighty sway over goblins, who applies ashes to his body to decorate it, who delights in the destruction of the world, (and) on whose neck there is a deadly poison,‚Äî(but) who, although thus inauspicious, remains the auspicious (≈öiva)!
(3.) Adoration be always to that ≈öarva, who causes all (gods) to be comprehended in (his) one (person) !‚Äîhe, whom those acquainted with the end of the Veda call ≈öiva, the desire of the mind, while people of true knowledge call him the one supreme

…………………………………………………………………………..

22 Metre ≈öloka (Anush·π≠ubh).
23Metre, ≈öragdhar√¢.

24 This word, which is quite clear in the original, appearsto be used for ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§É

25 Metre, P·πõithv√Æ.

26 Metre, ≈ö√¢rd√ªlavikr√Æ·∏çita.

27 Metre, ≈öragdhar√¢.

28 Metre, Rathoddhat√¢.

29Metre, ≈ö√¢rd√ªlavikr√Æ·∏çita.

30 The original has ‡§´‡§£‡§æ‚Äòthe hood of a serpent,‚Äô but one expects a word meaning ‚Äòa serpent‚Äô; compare, e.g. line 1 of the grant of V√¢kpatir√¢ja, in Indian Antiquary, vol. XIV, p.160.

Brahman, the indestructible, ageless, immortal, others the verily auspicious Buddha, (and) others again the spotless V√¢mana, the triumphant (Jina). !

(4.) People overcome with severe distress (brought about) by violent fever (sent) by the great Indra (?) or by Vishn·πáu, (and) those seized again and again by goblins and by evilspirits that show themselves day hby day, (and) those afflicted with leprosy, which displays its fierce maight by sore thumbs and fore-arms, (all) these are freed from evil when they set eyes on thy clearly shown uncouth twisted tresses of hair.

(5.) There was on the sutrface of the cearth a matchless (ftown), decorated with lofty palaces, which is recorded fto have been founded here between the golden Aand silver ages by some ruler of the earth, a lord of the people, who wasof Brahman‚Äôs race, (a town which is) read of in histories (?) (and) called Padma√¢vatt√Æ by people versed in the Purii√¢nas.

(6.) This most excellent (town) named Padmi√¢vati√Æ, built in an unprecedented manner, was crowded with lofty rows of streets of palaces, in which tall horses were curvetting: with its shining white high-topped walls, which grazed the clouds, it irradiated the sky; (and) it was full of bright palatial dwellipngs that resembled the peaks of the snowy mountain.

(7.)Tell us, need we praise that (town) in which the dust raised up by the pounding of the hoofs of galloping tall horses made the sky, covered (as it were) with ‚Äúan old worn-out cloth, look like the belly of a tortoise, while the ground in a wonderful manner was furnished with a coating of mud by the rain emitted from the checks of many infuriated formidable celephants ? What need we say more ?

(8.)In that (dtown) there was born. . . . . of (?) the Grahapati family . . . . .undefiled, the famous illustrious Atiyas≈õobala, bowed down to by pceople who excelled by first-rate qualities; who by his own arm acquired wondrous fame ; supported, like excellent trees, the families of friends and dependants; (and) threw down the forces of enemices . . . . . . by striking with arrows which wore the glances fond of his knitted brows (?).

Hewho built tanks full of water, in which the lotuses shone with the loveliness of the spreading rays of the bright-lustred moon, and temples high like the peaks of the Himf√¢laya, he, successful like Indra, was called Ya≈õobala.

(11.)From him was born (ason) named Ma√¢hat·π≠a, who honoured the whole body of relatives, who, by (attaining) the difficult-to-be-obtainced fruit of the three objects of life716,in a blameless manner secured for himself happiness, (and) who indeed delighted the people by his high-mindedness which was proclaimed by tales in praise of his good fame.

(12.)His son was the illustrious Jayadeva, a performer of good deeds, whose actions were able to remove . . . . fear and dishonour from his own and from all people. . . . . .(?).

(13.) From him, who by his loveliness wasthe moon, and, as regards the attainment of the objects of men‚Äôs desires, a tree of paradise, there was born, as the light proceeds from the lord of the day, a son (named) Sekkala, who was learned, a sun of unparalleled majesty, famous, foremost among the good, the sole habitation of truth, liberality, and bravery, self-confident, (and) endowed with wealth.

On account of his manliness not to be insulted with fame which spread tothe ends of the broad regions, in munificence like Kar·πáa, and not conversant with hurtful or deceitful speech, the illustrious Sekkala at once showed his greatness both by his benevolence and in battle, was difficult of approach for the host of enemies, and. . . . . . . (?).

[The next versealso refers to Sekkala (whose name is spelt here-Sekkalla), who appears to be described as a boat for crossing the ocean ofroyal government. But the verse is incomplete, and I am unable to derive from the words actually remaining any connected meaning.]

(16.) His younger brother, too, endowed with beauty, propriety of conduct, generosity,and activity, and already in youth of noble conduct, is famous as the illustrious Kokkalla.

He who on worthy recipients incessantly bestowed . . . . . . . . . food, hundreds of excellent dresses, horses, couches, and seats, dwelling-places accompanied by umbrellas and shoes, aud great donations of grain, that was here the illustrious Kokkala, a youth (?). . . ..engaged in works of piety.

Kokkala caused to be built a wonderful town which,. . . . . .furnished with big archways of great value, (and) with dwellings high like mountain-peaks, (and) with highly decorated lofty shining great gates, resembled the city of Indra.

(19.) Desirous of crossing the deep ocean . . . . . , he caused to be erected this (temple, high like ?) the spotless great peaks of the mountain of snow, the lofty golden dome of which, becauseit is in contact with the fierce splendour of the sun, became aspotless canopy for the glorious lord Vaidyan√¢tha.

[The next verse, which is incomplete, appears to describe certain buildings close to the temple, which Kokkala erected for pious Br√¢hmans].

Here he settled a faultless very learned crowd of twice-born who knew the Vedas. . . . . ..(and) delighted in the six duties (enjoined on Br√¢hamans).

(21.)The creeper of his good fame, the sprouts of which are shining with prosperity produced by the sprinkling of his boundless discernment, (and) . . . . . . which nourishes (like groups of birds) crowds of twice-born, (and) is beautified, as by flowers, by good conduct, rising above the lines of princes (as above mountains), ascends from the wide round basin of the earth up into the universe, as if it were an arbour.
The year 1058, on the full-moon day of Karttika. By the illustrious Kokkala.

THREE INSCRIPTIONS FROM IMAGES IN THE JAINA TEMPLES.

VI.

This incomplete inscription is in a single line, 5^(¬º‚Äù)long. The size of the letters isabout ^(5/8‚Äù).The characters are Nagari, and the language is Sanskrit. The inscription contains merely the words: ‚ÄúThe Sresh·π≠hin, the illustrious P√¢·πáidhara, in the Grahapati family.‚Äù

The Grahapati family, mentioned here and in the two following inscriptions, is also mentioned in line 8 of the preceding inscription of Kokkala, No. V.

Text.

¬π717 [‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞*]‡§π‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§ß‡§∞ [‡••*]

VII

This is another inscription ina single line, 2‚Äô lotg.n The size of the letto ers is about 3‚Äô.¬Ω".The characters are Na √¢gari, and the language is Sanskr ·πõit. The inscriptioncontains the words: ‚ÄúOm ! In the Grahapati family, the Sreshthin PAnidhara;≈öreshthin P√¢·πádharahig s sons, the Sreshthin ≈öreshthinTrivikrama, and √ÇAlhan ·πáa, (and) Lakshmi √Ædhara;‚Äù and the date ‚Äúthe year 1208 5 (which, as a year of the Vikrama era, corresponds to A.D. 11 47-48), the 5th day of the dark half of (the month) Ma √¢gha.‚Äù

Text.

‡§ì‡§Ç¬≤718 ‡•• ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§ß‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§§‡§ø(‡§§‡§ø)(‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø)‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§£‡•§ ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§ß‡§∞‡•• ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‚Äå ‡•ß‡•®‡•¶‡•´‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ò ‡§µ‡§¶‡§ø‡•´‡••

VIII. .

** **This inscription¬≥719is on the base of a Jaina imagoe and is in a single line, divided into two parts by a boss: the first part is 1‚Äô 7¬º‚Äù and the second 1‚Äô 5¬Ω‚Äù long. The size of the, letters is about 3/8‚Äù. The characters areNa√°gari, and the language is Sanskrit.

The inscription is dated in the year 1215 (which, as a year of tho Vikrama era, corresponds to A.D. 1157-58), on the 5th day of the bright half of (the month) Ma √¢gha, in the prosperous reign of victory of the illustrious Madanavarmadeva. And it records that the statue on which the inscription is, was caused to be set up by the Sa √°dhu 88110, S√¢lhethe son of Pa√¢hilla, who was the son of the Sreshthin≈öreshthin Dedu,√ªof the Grahapati family; and adds that the sons of Sa√¢lhe, Maha√¢gan·πáa, Mahi√Æchandra, Sirichandra, Jinachandra, Udayachandra, and the rest, always bow down to Sambhavana √¢tha. The name of the artizan was Ra √¢madeva. The name Pa √¢hilla we have met before, in inscription No. III.

TEXT.

‡§ì^(4720)‡•• ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‚Äå ‡•ß‡•®‡•ß‡•´ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ò ‡§∏‡•Å‡§¶‡§ø ‡•´ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡§®‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§Ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡§®‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§Ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡•• ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§Ç‡§Æ‡•á ‡§∏‡•á(‡§∂‡•á) ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§¶‡•Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§¶‡•Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§É‡•§‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§¢‡•á‡§¶‡•Ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§É‡•§ ‡§™‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡§∞‡•Å‡§π‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§∏‡§æ‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡•á [‡§§‡•á]‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§Ç (‡§Ø‡§Ç) ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡•• ‡•• ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§É ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§ó‡§£‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•§ ‡§∏‡§ø[‡§∞‡§ø] ‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•§ ‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•§‡§â‡§¶‡§Ø‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§§‡§ø‚Åµ721‡•§ ‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡§æ‡§•‡§Ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‚Å∂722 ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡•• ‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§ó[‡§≤‡§Ç] ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä[:*] ‡•• ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ[:*]‡••

XX.‚ÄîTHE TWO INSCRIPTIONS OF THE VAILLABHATTASVAMIN TEMPLE

AT GWALIOR.

Bx E. HULTZSCH, PH.D.; BANGALORE.

The two subjoined inscriptions¬π723are engraved on a small monolittic temple, which is situated on a turn of the road leading up to the Gwalior Fort.The temple was described by General Cunningham, according to whom it is now called the Chaturbhuja Temple.¬≤724Thefirst inscription, which is engraved over the front door of the temple, seems to have hitherto remained unnoticed.A rough transcript and translation of the second inscription, which is found inside the temple on the left wall¬≥725was published by Dr. R√¢jendral√¢la Mitra.‚Å¥726 My transcripts of the two inscriptions were made from mechanical copies taken during a visit to Gwalior in 1885.
The first inscription consists of 27 Sanskrit verses and must have been composed by an ingenious pa·πá·∏çit, who was well versed in ala·πÅk√¢ra, His extravagant hyperboles will appear startling and amusing even to one accustomed to the usual k√¢vya style. We learn from the inscription that the Vish·πáu temple containing it was built by a certain Alla, the son of V√¢√Øllabha·π≠·π≠a and grandson of N√¢gar√¢bha·π≠·π≠a, and that it was consecrated in the year982 (in words). N√¢garabha·π≠·π≠a belonged to the Varj√¢ra family and had, immigrated from √Çnandapura in L√¢·π≠ama·πá·∏çala, i.e. Va·∏çnagar in Gujar√¢t. V√¢√Øllabha·π≠·π≠a had been chief of the boundaries (mary√¢d√¢-dhurya) or margrave in the service of (king) R√¢madeva (verse7). Alla succeeded his father in office (v. 11), and ’ was appointed to the guardianship of Gop√¢dri, i.e. of the Gwalior Fort, by (king) ≈ör√Æmad-√Çdivar√¢ha (v. 22).
The second inscription is written in incorrect Sanskrit prose and dated in the year 983 (in words and figures), at ≈ör√Æ-Gopagiri (i.e. the Gwalior Fort) and during the reign of the parame≈õvara Bhojadeva. Alla is here directly called the guardian of the fort (ko·π≠·π≠ap√¢la) of Gopagiri. The inscription records four donations to two temples, which had been built by Alla, the son of V√¢√Øllabha·π≠·π≠a, The donee of the first grant was the Navadurg√¢ Temple situated beyond the V·πõi≈õchik√¢l√¢ river; this is probably another name of the river Subanrikh5727 (Suvar·πáarekh√¢ ?) at Gwalior. The two donees of the three remaining grants were the same Navadurg√¢ Temple and ‚Äúthe Vish·πáu temple called V√¢√Øllabha·π≠·π≠a-sv√¢min, which Alla had likewise caused to be built on the descent of the road of the illustrious Bhojadeva.‚Äù By this we have to understand the temple, at which both inscriptions are found. It had evidently received its name in commemoration of V√¢√Øllabha·π≠·π≠a, the father of its founder. The four donations were made by the inhabitants of ‚Äòthe place‚Äù (sth√¢na), i.e. the ancient town of Gwalior, which lies on the eastern side of tho fort. They consisted of a piece of land for a flower-garden, two fields, a monthly supply of lamp-oil to be made by the guild of oil-millers, and a monthly supply of flower-garlands to be made by the guild of the gardeners,

who dwelt on the top of the Gwalior Fort (≈ör√Æ-Gopagiri-talopari). The inscription mentions several other localities, which I am unable to identify, viz. Ch√ª·∏ç√¢pallik√¢, Jayapur√¢ka, ≈ör√Æ-Sarve≈õvarapura, ≈ör√Ævatsasv√¢mipura, Chachchik√¢ha·π≠·π≠ik√¢ and Nimb√¢dityaha·π≠·π≠ik√¢. It deserves to be noted, that at the time of the inscription the measure of length was ‚Äúroyal yards‚Äù (p√¢rame≈õvar√Æya-hasta) and that of capacity‚Äúdro·πáas according to the measure of Gwalior ‚Äù (Gopagir√Æya-m√¢pyena).
The first inspription mentions two kings, viz. R√¢madeva, the contemporary of V√¢√Øllabha·π≠·π≠a, and ≈ör√Æmad-√Çdivar√¢ha, the contemporary of Alla. At the time of the second inscription the ruler of Gwalior was the parame≈õvara Bhojadeva.Another inscription of a parame≈õvara Bhojadeva was discoveredby General Cunningham at Deogarh.Its date, Sa·πÅvat 919 and ≈öaka 784, led General Cunningham to suppose that the date of the second Gwalior inscription, Sa·πÅvat 933, has to be referred to the Vikrama era, Referring the date of an inscription at Peheva, Sa·πÅvat276, to the era of ≈ör√Æharsha, General Cunningham further identified the parame≈õvara Bhojadeva of the Deogarh inscription and of the second Gwalior inscription with the parame≈õvara Bhojadeva, the son of the parame≈õvara R√¢mabhadradeva.‚Å∑This supposition is corroborated by the first Gwalior inscription, as theR√¢madevawhom it mentions as a contemporary of V√¢√Øllabha·π≠·π≠a, seems to be identical with the R√¢mabhadradeva of the Peheva inscription. ≈ör√Æmad-√Çdivar√¢ha in the first Gwalior inscription I take to, be a biruda of Bhojadeva himself. Thus we have the following names and dates:‚Äî

1. Parame≈õvara R√¢mabhadradeva (Peheva inscription) or R√¢madeva (Gwalior inscription No. 1).
2. His son, parame≈õvara Bhojadeva (Deogarh, Gwalior No. 2, and Peheva) or≈ör√Æmad-√Çdivar√¢ha (Gwalior No. 1). Dates: A.D. 862 (Deogarh), 875 (Gwalior No. 1), 876 (Gwalior No. 2), and 882 (Peheva).

As lately shown by Mr. Fleet, tho mah√¢r√¢ja Bhojadeva, son of the mah√¢r√¢ja R√¢mabhadradeva, who is mentioned in two copper-plate grants from Mahodaya, is distinct from the above-mentioned parame≈õvara Bhojadeva.^(8)Another identification of General Cunningham‚Äôs is also uncertain, as Kalha·πáa‚Äôs R√¢jatara·πÅgi·πái(V. 151) does not seem to mention a king Bhoja, but a king of the Bhojas (Bhoj√¢dhir√¢ja), as a contemporary of ≈öa·πÅkaravarman of Ka≈õm√Ær.^(9)

^(————————————————————————–)
^(6) Ibid. vol. X, p. 101.

^(7) Jour. As. Soc, Beng. vol. XXXIII, p. 229; Cunningham’s Archaeol. Survey of India, vol. II, p. 224; vol. 1X, pp. 84 and 102. The inscription reads: paramabhat {araka-maharajdhiraja-paramesvara-Sri-Ramabhadra-deva-padanudhyata-paramabhataraka-maharadhiraja-paramesvara-sri-Bhojadeva-padanam-abhipravardhamana-kalyana-vijaya-rjye-samvatsara-Satadvaye shatsaplatyadhike vaisakhamasa-Suklapaksha-saptamyamsamvat 276 vaisakha Sudi 7.The apparent breaks in the facsimile (Jowr. As. Suc. Beng. vol. XXXII) arive from the overlapping parts not having been properly pasted together.

8 Ind. Ant. vol. XV, p.110. From Professor Kielhorn‚Äôs introduction to the Siyadoni, inscription (infra) it appears that the paramesvara Bhojadeva of the Deogarh, Gwalior, and Peheva inscriptions was a kingof Mahodaya or Kanyakubja the Qannaujof Firdausi?, and the modern Kanauj; and that ,his successor, the paramesvara Mahendrapala-deva was ruling in A.D. 903. Among the coins which are mentioned in the Styadoni inscription, is the Srimad-adivaraha-dramma. This coin was √©vidently named after Srimad-Adivarah a, the biruda of Bhojadeva. General Cunningham, in Aroh. Survey of India, vol. I, p. 329, identifies it with a base silver coin, which beara on the obverse a representation of the boar incarnation ard on the reverse tho legend Srimad-Adivardha , The ovin is engraved in Marsden’s Numismata Orientalia, pl. liii, No. mccxix. It is frequently met with ia Northern India :‚ÄîConf. Cunningham’s Arch, Surrey of India, vol, VI, p. 137, apd loc.cit.

^(9) The rending adopted by Mr. Fleet, ‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•á ‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•á, is confirmed by my Kasmir MS. The DeccanCollege MS. reads: ‡§≠‡•É-‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•á ‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•á

FIRST INSCRIPTION

TEXT.

(L. 1.) ‡§ì‡§Ç[‡••^(x)] ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ú‡§≤‡•å‡§ò‡•ã ‡§ò‡§®‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∞‡§®‡§ø‡§≠‡•ã ‡§ú‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®728‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§ó‡§ó‡§®‡§§‡§≤‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç‡•§‡§ö‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø729‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•ã‡§ú‡§ó‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ã‡§≠‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡•ã‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§∏‡§ø ‡§∏ ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§ú‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡§É ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∑‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡•• [‡•ß^(x)] ‡§Ö‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§≤‡§æ‡§ü‡§Æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§≤‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡•ã ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‚Äå‡•§ ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§≠‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡•• [‡•®^(x)] ‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§§‡§®‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§ø ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡§ú‡§®‡§ö‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã730‡•§ ‡§® ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ß‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§π‡§®‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡•á‡§®‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç‡•• [‡•©^(x)] `

(2.) ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø731‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•à‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‚Äå‡•§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§™‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•å ‡§® ‡§ï‡§¶‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§ï‡•å732‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•å‡•• [‡•™^(x)] ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§ø‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§¶‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¶‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡§ó‡§æ‡§ß‡§§‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡•§‡§ú‡§ø‡§ó‡§Ç733 ‡§∏‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§∂‡§É‡§™‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ß‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§ ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§∞‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•à‡§É‡•• [‡•´^(x)] ‡§ß‡§®‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡§ø ‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ã‡§™‡§ø ‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§É‡•§ ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§ø ‡§® ‡§ú‡§°‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡•ã‡§ï‡•ã‡§™‡§ø ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§É‡•§ [‡•¨^(x)] ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§ô‡•ç‡§ò‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§ü‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡•• [‡•≠^(x)] ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§µ‡§π‡•Å‡§®‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡§•‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•à‡§É‡•§

(3.) ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§ò‡§ü‡§ï‡•ã‡§µ‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ‡§™‡§ø ‡§® ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§ø734‡•• [‡•Æ^(x)] ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§Ç‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ó‡§ú‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§∂‡§≠‡•Å‡§É ‡§∂‡§ö‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§•‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§•‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∂‡•Ä‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ç‡•§ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡•ã‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ï‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•ã‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ú‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ç‡•• [‡•Ø^(x)]‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ó‡§§‡§Æ‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ã‡§π‡§ú‡§æ‡§≤‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§É ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•à‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§π‡•É‡§§‡§ñ‡§≤‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡•ã‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§É‡§∏‡§ï‡§≤‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∂‡§≤‡•ã ‡§¨‡§≠‡•Ç‡§µ ‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡•• [‡•ß‡•¶^(x)] ‡§® ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§≠‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‚Äå¬π‚Å∑‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§∂‡§π‡•ã‡§®‡•ã‡§π‡•á ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§≤‡•Å‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§® ‡•• [‡•ß‡•ß^(x)] ‡§¶‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ ‡§§‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡•• [‡•ß‡•®^(x)]

(4.) ‡§π‡§∞ ‡§á‡§µ‡§µ‡•É‡§∑‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡•ã‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡§æ‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§≠‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§®‡•á‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§§‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§§‡§É‡•• [‡•ß‡•©^(x)] ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§∏‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡•Ç‡§®‡§Ç‡•§ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•ã‡§≠‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§π‡§ø ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ñ‡§≤‡•Å ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡••[‡•ß‡•™^(x)] ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡§∞‡§ï‡§≤‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡•à‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡•ã‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡•§ ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡§µ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ã‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§≤‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡•Å‡§π‡•É‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§¶‡§É‡•• [‡•ß‡•´^(x)] ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•ã‡§¶‡§Ø‡•á‡§™‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡§Ç‡•§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§∂‡§É ‡§ï‡§ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡•• [‡•ß‡•¨^(x)] ‡§Ö‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§Ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•å‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•Å‡•§

(5.) ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§® ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§ï‡§≤‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•• [‡•ß‡•≠^(x)] ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§∏‡§ø ‡§® ‡§∞‡•ã‡§∑‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§Ø‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡•ç‡§® ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•Å ‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•Å‡§∑‡•à‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ‡§≤‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§® ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡•• [‡•ß‡•Æ^(x)] ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡•á ‡§ö ‡§≤‡•ã‡§≠‡•ã ‡§® ‡§ï‡§¶‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§ß‡§®‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§∑‡•Å‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§ï‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§® ‡§µ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡•Å‡•• [‡•ß‡•Ø^(x)] ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§π‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§®‡•ã ‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§É735‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Ç ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§∂‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ó‡§æ‡§ß‡§™‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ã ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§≠‡•ã‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§É‡•§ ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§µ ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡•• [‡•®‡•¶^(x)]

(6.) ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§§‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§• ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•å‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§®‡§∂‡§§‡•à‡§É ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§®‡•Å‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç‡•• [‡•®‡•ß^(x)] ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•á‡§£ ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§ø‡§ó‡•Ä‡§∑‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§µ‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ã ‡§ó‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§®‡•á‡•• [‡•®‡•®^(x)]‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡•Å‡§ï‡§¶‡•Å‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§µ‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™ ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ‡§ü‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§®‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡•§ ‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ó‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§ú‡§æ ‡§ó‡•å‡§∞‡•ã ‡••[‡•®‡•©^(x)] ‡§ó‡•ã‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡§ú‡§æ ‡§∏‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§®‡§ï‡§§‡§®‡§Ø‡•á‡§∏‡§ü‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡•ã‡§¢‡§æ [;‡•§^(x) ] ‡§µ‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø736‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡§æ ‡•• [‡•®‡•™^(x) ] ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§£‡•á ‡§Ø -

…………………………………………………………………………………….

1 7 Read ‡•¶‡§Æ‡•É‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‚Äå.

(7.)‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ú‡§Ç‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡§∞‡•ã‡§∞‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§´‡§≤‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§É‡§Ç737‡•§ ‡§ü‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ã‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§ø‡§µ ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡•à‡§∞‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∂‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•ã‡§∞‡§ø‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∞‡§Ç‡•• [‡•®‡•´^(x)] ‡§¶‡§ß‡§§‡§ø ‡§ú‡§≤‡§Æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§∞‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡•ã‡§¢‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•§ ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ñ‡§∞‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡•á‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•á‡§Ø‡§∏‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§ò‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ó‡§Ø‡§§‡•Å ‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§ø ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ã‡§¶‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡•• [‡•®‡•¨^(x)]‡•• ‡§®‡§µ‡§∏‡•Å ‡§∂‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ738‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ç738 ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡•á‡•§ ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§∂‡§ø‡§≤‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•á‡•• [‡•®‡•≠^(x)]‡••

TRANSLATION.

O·πÅ. (Verse 1.) May that Vish·πáu destroy your sins, having seen whose foot, when he was going to stride (the three worlds), the horses of the sun did not pacethe lofty sky for along time, as they seemed to be afraid, that, vying with theGa·πÖg√¢, theflood of the waters of the Yamun√¢, which resembles dense darkness, or that the ridgeof theVindhya (mountain) had risen again, in order to obstruct their path in the heavenly sphere!
(Vv. 2 & 3.) There was a virtuous youth, N√¢garabha·π≠·π≠a of the Varj√¢ra family, who had come from √Çnandapura, the ornament of the lovely L√¢·π≠ama·πá·∏çala. He begat a son, V√¢√Øllabha·π≠·π≠a by name, who excited the admiration of the people, as he was constant in battle (yudhish·π≠hira), but did not conclude a true friendship with low people (nakula), (while Yudhish·π≠hira was a true friend of his younger brother Nakula).
(4.) As a grammarian hepossessed an intimate knowledge of the explanatory rules, &c.; but the results of deeds in former births (karman) or of tricks (upadh√¢) never gave him trouble.¬≤¬≤
(5.) The milk-ocean, which has a deep-white colour, which fills all quarters and which is unfathomable, loudly challenged with its waves the high sea of his fame, trying (in vain) to equal (itsheight).
(6.) He was liberal (or Kuvera), but not inattentive (or not Varu·πáa);¬≤¬≥a de- stroyer of all snakes (or Garu·∏ça), but not ugly (or bird-shaped); a mine of jewels (or the ocean), but not stupid (orcold); and without sorrow (or an a≈õoka tree), but not impassioned (or red).
(7.) While, in the service of the illustrious R√¢madeva, he never transgressed his duty of chief of the boundaries, he, like his ancestors, proclaimed his spotless name in battles ( for which he had to transgress the boundaries of the realm).
(8.) Why say more ?.His virtues cannot even be told by people like myself; for even from the occan a pot cannot receive more water than its measure.
(9.) As Vish·πáu (look) Lakshm√Æ, as ≈öiva (took) the mountain-daughter and as Indra (took) ≈öach√Æ, thus he took for his wife the virtuous and noble Jajj√¢, the daughter of K√¢sarak√Æya-Vish·πáu.
(10.) These two had a son (called) Alla, to whom the net of conceit and delusion had ceased to be attached, whose only aim was, that his deeds might be (worthy of)
…………………………………………………….
23 Pakshe, the two words karman and upadh√¢have to be taken in their grammatical meaning, ‚Äú passive voice‚Äô and ‚Äúpenultimate letter.‚Äù I do not know to which paribh√¢sh√¢the author alludes.

23 Professor Kielhorn has favoured me with the following explanation of the words dhanadopi na pramatto : ‚ÄúIwould compare V√¢savadatt√¢, p. 111: dhanaden√¢pi prachetas√¢. At least na pramatta isthe same asprachetas, and Ishould almost think, that the anthor of the inscription remembered the quotation from V√¢savadatt√¢:‚ÄîDhanada (Kuvera) is not prachetas (Varu·πáa), hence pramatta ; V√¢illabha·π≠·π≠a is not pramatta, hence prachetas (attentive).‚Äù

the K·πõita (age) ; who possessed a gracious appearance, who avoided the intercourse with the wicked and who was skilled in all arts.
(11.) He (continued) to bear the burden (of his father‚Äôs office), not because he was desirous of worldly (power), (but) because he could not bear to hear it said, that a son had never becn up to his father‚Äôs affairs.
(12.) As the milk-occan by the rutting-juice (of elephants), he-was continually purified by the water (poured out) at donations, and as Praj√¢pati-by the lotus (that rose from Vish·πáu‚Äôs navel), he was embraced by the goddess of prosperity.
(13.) He constantly took care of meritorious gifts, as ≈öiva of his bull; he avoided the touch of sin, as the sun the touch of the evening; and he stepped on the crowd of his enemies, as Vish·πáu on the flapping wings of his bird (Garu·∏ça).
(14.) It is indeed wonderful that he has remained free from covetousness, although‚Äô his mind is always observed to be attached to the highest truth (or apparently : to the property of others).
(15.) Although he avoided the wives of others, took delight only in virtue and was satisfied with his ownwives, he constantly and by all means desired the pleasure (or apparently : the wives) of his friends.
(16.) Having perceived the lotus-face of this man, the moon is even now waning a little in every moment, because even ‚Äòat her riseshe is unable to free (herself) from spo·π≠s (while he is spotless).
(17.) He gave alternatives, when he had to furnish a commentary, but made no distinction between the recipients of his gifts, and turned away from another‚Äôs wife, but not from battle.
(18.) He stuck to his word, but not to anger, was covered with (the fame of) victories, but not in the slightest with the sins of the Kali (age), and was slow (when he was afraid) to sin, but not in the affairs of the king.
(19.) He was desirous of acquiring spiritual merit, but never of another‚Äôs property of any kind, and made no distinction between his friends, but knew how to judge the degree of intelligence (of others).
(20.) Curiously enough, he who led the conduct of those whose minds appear refined to mental observation, openly carricd on robbery of all kinds, without meeting the blame of the world; for he robbed the beggar of his poverty, the enemy of his prosperity, woman of her heart, Cupid of his beauty, and the unfathomable ocean of its depth.
(21.) Even if the Creator had bestowed a thousand ears on the king of serpents, would then the latter be able to hear the floods of virtues of that man and to enumerate them with his hundreds of mouths ?
(22.) Having observed his virtues, the illustrious √Çdivar√¢ha and who wished to conquer the three worlds, appointedshim to the guardianship of Gop√¢dri.
(Vv. 23 to 25.) This great and passionless man, who had married Vavv√¢, the daughter of Kanhuka and mother of (his) favourite daughterSoma·π≠√¢, further Gogg√¢, the daughter of Bha·π≠·π≠a, then Gaur√Æ, the daughter of Mah√¢deva, Sill√¢, the daughter of Govardhana, and √ésa·π≠√¢, the daughter of Nannaka, built, for the increase of the spiritual merit of Vavv√¢, &c., and of himself, this temple of Vish·πáu, which is an even path to beatitude, a great ship for crossing the ocean of existences, the seed of the tree

INSCRIPTIONS OF VAILLABHATTASVAMIN TEMPLE AT GWALIOR.

of spiritual merit, which bears endless fruit¬≤‚Å¥, the permanent abode of the goddess of prosperity and, so to say, a receptacle of (his) fame, cutby the chisel, and marked with the syllables of (his) name.
(26.) As long as the oceanswill contain unfathomable water and as long as this lofty mountain will bear on its head a mass of peaks, which touch the clouds, so long may this beautiful temple¬≤‚Åµ stand on earth and cover the two worlds (with its fame).
(27.) In the year ninehundred and thirty-two, in Vai≈õ√¢kha, (a statue of) Vish·πáu was reverently placed in this lovely temple, which consists of a single piece of rock.

                     SECOND INSCRIPTION.

TEXT.

(L.1.) ‡§ì‡§Ç‡§®‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡•á‡•• ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡§∂‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å‡§®‡§µ‡§∏‡•Å ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§∂739‡§¶‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ò‡§∂‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Ç ‡•Ø‡•©‡•© ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ò‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡§ø ‡•® ‡§Ö‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§π‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ó‡•ã‡§™‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡•å‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡•§
(2) ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡•ã‡§ú‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•á ‡§§‡§¶‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡•É‡§§740‡§ï‡•ã‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§™‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§Ö‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡•É‡§§741‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡•É‡§§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§µ‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï (‡•§)‡§á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•Å‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï (‡•§) ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ ‡§∏‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ -
(3)‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡•§ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§æ‡§á‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§µ‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡§∞‡§ï‡•Ç‡§≤‡•á ‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§∂‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§µ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡§®‡§æ-
(4)‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡•Ç‡§°‡§æ742‡§™‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§π‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ñ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§Ç‡§¶‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§ò‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§£‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∂‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•®‡•≠‡•¶ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§743‡§∞‡•á‡§£

(5) ‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∂‡§§‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§á‡§∏‡•ç‡§§ ‡•ß‡•Æ‡•≠ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§µ‡§æ‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§π‡§®‡§ø744‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç [‡••^(x)] ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§Ω‡§®‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§µ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•á
(6.)‡§´‡§æ‡§≤‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§®‡§µ‡§π‡•Å‡§≤‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§¶‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡•ã‡§ú‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•á ‡§Ö‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§á‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü[ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§æ]‡§Ø‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§§‡§•‡•ã -
(7.)‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ‡§ø‡§§‡§®‡§µ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§ö ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ú‡§Ø‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ò‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•á‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡§æ\‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•á[‚Å∑745 ]
(8.)‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§°‡§æ‡§ï‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§¶‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§ï‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§Æ‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡•ã746‡§™‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ -
(9.)‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§£ ‡§è‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂ [‡•§^(x)] ‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡§™‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡§æ‡§ò‡§æ‡§ü‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§£‡§®‡§°‡§°‡§æ‡§ï‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§ü‡§É
(10.) ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§® ‡§¶‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§ï‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§ï‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§™‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§ü‡§É ‡§§‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§ï‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∞‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡§§‡§É ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ
(11.) ‡§≤‡§ò‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§ö [‡•§^(x)] ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§ò‡§æ‡§ü‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§π‡§®‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç‡••‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§µ

(12.) ‡§â‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ‡§ø‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡§§‡•à‡§≤‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡•à‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ï ‡§≠‡•ã‡§∂‡§æ‡§ï‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï (‡•§) ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡§µ -
(13.) ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§ß‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§ï‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡•ã‡§ï‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡•à‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡§π-
(14.) ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§ï‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§æ‡§ï‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ò‡§æ‡§ï ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•Ç‡§ï‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡§ñ‡•ã‡§π‡§°‡§æ‡§ï‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§ö‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§π‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§π‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡•à‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ -
(15.) ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§¶‡•á‡§â‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§ú‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§ü‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡•Ç‡§ï‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§ú‡§Æ‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§ï ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ü‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§ú‡§Æ‡•ç‡§µ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡•§ ‡§è‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø -
(16.) ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•à‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ã‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡•Å‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡§®‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡§®‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•à‡§≤‡§™‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§™‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§®‡•Ä -
(17.) ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡•• ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§ó‡•ã‡§™‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§≤‡•ã‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡§π‡§∞ ‡§ó‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡•Ç‡§ï
(18.) ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡•Ç‡§ï‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§ú‡§æ‡§∏‡•á‡§ï ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§≤‡§æ‡§ï‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§∏‡§ø‡§π‡•Ç‚Åπ747‡§ï ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§ú‡§Æ‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§∏‡§π‡§°‡§æ‡§ï ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡§ß‡§∞‡§ø ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§®‡§∂‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡§µ‡§æ748-
(19.) ‡§â‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§µ‡•á‡§â‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø[‡§ü‡§æ]‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡§£‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§™‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï749‡§π‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ -
(20.) ‡§≤‡§æ‡§É ‡§™ (‡§æ)‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡§§‡•ç‚Äå ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§∂‡§§‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡•´‡•¶ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø750‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§®‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ [‡••^(x)] ‡§è‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§â‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ‡§ø -
(21.) ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ü‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç [‡••^(x)] ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§•‡§®‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á‡§∞‡§™‡§ø ‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡••‡§Ø‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§ñ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã
(22.) ‡§π‡§∞‡•á‡§§ ‡§µ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç [‡•§^(x)] ‡§∏ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•É‡§≠‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§π ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§¶‡§§‡•á¬π‚Å¥‡•• ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§≠‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§≠‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•§
(23.) ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ ‡§´‡§≤‡§Ç ‡•• *‡••¬π‚Åµ751

TRANSLATION.

O·πÅ. Adoration to Vish·πáu! In the year nine hundred and thirty-three, on the second day of the bright (half) of M√¢gha,‚ÄîSa·πÅ[ vat] 933, M√¢gha ≈õudi2‚Äîto-day, here at ≈ör√Æ-Gopagiri, while the parame≈õvara ≈ör√Æ-Bhojadeva was the ruler, while the guardian of the fort (ko·π≠·π≠ap√¢la) Alla commanded this (Gopagiri), while Tattaka commanded the army (and) while the merchant Vavviy√¢ka, the trader Ichchhuv√¢√©ka, and the other (members) of the board (? v√¢ra) of the Savviy√¢kas were administering the city, the whole town gave to the temple of the nine Durg√¢s, viz. of Rudra, Rudr√¢·πá√Æ, P√ªr·πá√¢≈õ√¢, &c., which Alla, the son of V√¢illabha·π≠·π≠a, had caused to be built on the further bank of the‚Äò V·πõi≈õchik√¢l√¢river, a piece of land belonging to the village of Ch√ª·∏ç√¢pallik√¢, which was its (viz,the town‚Äôs) property, two hundred and seventy royal hastas‚Äîhasta 270‚Äîin length (and) one hundred and eighty-seven hastas‚Äîhasta 187‚Äîin breadth, for a flower-garden, on an auspicious day.

(Ll. 5‚Äî-11.) And this same town gave in this same year, on the first day of the dark half of Ph√¢lguna, to the Vish·πáu temple called V√¢√Øllabha·π≠·π≠a-sv√¢min, which Alla had likewise caused to be built on the descent of the road of ≈ör√Æ-Bhojadeva, and to the above mentioned temple of the nine Durg√¢s, for the performance of worship, the field cultivated¬π‚Å∂by Dallaka, the son of Sa·πÖga·∏çaka, in the chief grain-land (?m√ªl√¢v√¢pa) of the common¬π‚Å∑called Vy√¢ghrake·πá·∏çik√¢, in the villageof Jayapur√¢ka, which was its (viz. the town‚Äôs) property, and on the north of this same field, the field cultivated by Memm√¢ka, the son of the Kshatriya Devavarman¬π‚Å∏the seed required for which two (fields) is eleven dro·πáas of barley according to the measure of Gopagiri;¬π‚Åπ‚Äîthe boundaries of these two fields are: on the east, the field cultivated by Na√º·∏ç√¢ka; on the south, a piece of rock¬≤‚Å∞ ;on the west, near the field of Dallaka, a piece of rock, and near the field of Memm√¢ka, a water-channel,¬≤¬πwhich leads to the north and runs round the ficld; on the north, a road and a small piece of rock ;‚Äîthe two fields, thus defined by their four boundaries, on an auspicious day.
(11‚Äî17.) And in this same year, on the ninth day of the dark half of Ph√¢lguna, (the town) gave to the two above-mentioned temples a perpetual endowment¬≤¬≤to the effect that, in order (to provide) oil for the lamps, the chiefs of the oil-millers, who dwell in ≈ör√Æ-Sarve≈õvarapura, (viz.) Sarvasv√¢ka, the son of Bhochch√¢ka, Jy√¢≈õakti, the son of M√¢dhava, S√¢hulla, the son of ≈öivadhari, and Gagg√Æka, the son of Sa·πÖg√¢ka; the chiefs of the oil-millers, who dwell in ≈ör√Ævatsasv√¢mipura, (viz.) Si·πÖgh√¢ka, the son of Ku·πá·∏ç√¢ka, and Khoha·∏ç√¢ka, the son of Vall√ºka; the chiefs of the oil-millers, who dwell in Chachchik√¢ha·π≠·π≠ik√¢ and Nimb√¢dityaha·π≠·π≠ik√¢, (viz.)
