^(16)The participle vahita is derived from Hindi bahnd, ‚Äúto plough‚Äù
¬π‚Å∑ Har, ‚Äúa village-common, the cultivated space immediately round a village."’‚ÄîBate’s Hindee Dictionary.
^(18) To judge from their names, tho trader Ichehhuavaka (1. 2) and the oil-miller Jyusakti (1. 13) also belonged to the Kahatriya caste. The law-books permit a Kahatriya, and oven a Brahmana, to adopt the livelihood of a Vaidya, if they are unable to gain their subsistence by fulfilling the duties of their own castus; see tho passages on the so called addharma or Apatkalpa, i.ethe rules for times of distress : Gautama, VII ; Manu, X, 81 f.; Yajiavalkya, III35 ff.
^(19) Compare Khetaka-manena vrihi-dvi-pithaka-vapam Kotilaka-kshetram, ‚Äú the field of Kotilaka, the seedrequired for which is two pithakas of paddy according to the measure of Khetaka ‚Äù (Ind. Ant., vol. XV, p. 340, line 46), and bhumir yatra vdu….sardha-sdrdha-sapta, ‚Äú piece of land, the seed required for which is seven and a half dronas‚Äù (ibid, vol. XVI, p. 208).
20 Pdhdje is perhaps a Sanskritised form of Hindi pakdd, ‚Äú mountain, bill, rock‚Äù (Platts).
^(21)Vahaka seems to be connected with Hindi baha, ‚Äúa water-channel ;"‚Äîsee Grierson’s Bihar Peasant Life, p. 211.
^(22)With akshayanimika(linos 16 and 20) compare akhayaniviin the Nasik, Kanheriaud Junnar Inscriptions in Dr. Burgens’s Archaol. Sur. Westn. Ind., vols. IV and V.
¬≤¬≥ Kolhuka is the same as Hindi kolhu, ‚Äúan oil-mill ;"‚Äîsee Grierson, u. s. p. 46.
^(24) With mallika-mahara compare tailika-mahattaka(lines 12, 13and 14) and mahar, ‚Äúa chief‚Äù (Bate).

for (the requirements of) worship, fifty garlands‚Äîm√¢l√¢50‚Äî of such market flowers as are available at the particular season.
(20‚Äî23.) These aboveementioned gifts were made by the above mentioned town, &o., from their property for as long a time as the moon, the sun and the earth exist. Nobody shall cause obstruction (to the present owners). For (Vy√¢sa has said) : [Here follow two of the usual minatoryverses].

XXI.‚ÄîSIYADONI STONE INSCRIPTION.
By PROFESSORF. KIELIIORN, Ph.D., C.I.E.; G√∂TTINGEN.

In the Journal, Beng. As. Soc., vol. XXXI, pp. 6-7, Dr. F. E. Hall had occasion to mention ‚Äúa huge inscriptiop,‚Äù existing in some part of the State of Gw√¢lior, a transcript of which, by a native, had been made over to him by Colonel (now General Sir) Alexander Cunningham. From the apparently very imperfect copy supplied to him, Dr. Hall was able to report that the inscription in the opening lines mentioned a king Mahendrap√¢la. Near where he is spoken of, was the date 960. Next came Bhoja, and then Mahendrap√¢la again, with the date 964, Further on Kshitip√¢la was mentioned; and, after him, Devap√¢la, the date 1005 being closeby. These dates, according to Dr. Hall, were not sufficiently particularized for one to certify their era by calculation. Besides, the kings of the record were stated by Dr. Tall to have beon memorialized as having granted land and other things, by way of local donaries, in ten several years, ranging from 960 to 1025. According to Sir A. Cunningham,¬π752‚Äô the actual site of the inscription was then unknown ; and it has remained so for twenty-five years afterwards.^(2753 has been referred to by Dr. Hornle, in the Centenary Review, Beng. As, Soc., part Il, p. 208; and by Mr. Fleet, in the Indian Antiquary, vol. XV, p. 108, note 18, andvol. XVI, p. 178, who has pointed out the desirability of rediscovering aud publishing the inscription."))
In 1887, Dr. Burgess, when in the Lalitpur district of the North-Western Provinces, learnt that there was a large inscription at ‚ÄòS√Æro·πá Khurd,‚Äô about ten miles WNW. of the town of Lalitpur, Long. 78¬∞ 23‚Äô E., Lat. 24¬∞ 50‚Äô N. (Indian Atlas, quarter-sheet 70, NW.) And tho inscription was found on the east, of the village at which it had been reported to be,‚Äîand which in the inscription itself is called S√Æya·∏ço·πá√Æ,‚Äîon the bank of tho Kher√¢r stream, in the precincts of o Jaina temple of ≈ö√¢ntin√¢tha, where it had been recently set up by a Bania. It turned out to be the huge inscription mentioned by Dr. Hall; and I now edit it from impressions supplied to me by Dr. Burgess.
The inscription consists of forty-six lines; and the writing covers a space of about 5‚Äô 2¬Ω‚Äù broad by 3‚Äô 4‚Äù high. Of the first two and the last two lines large portions of the writing have either gone altogether or become illegible, by the flaking off of the edges of the stone; and from the same cause some aksharas have become illegible in lines 39-44. But the preservation of lines 8-38, is perfect almost throughout, so ‚Äúthat here the actual reading of the stone hardly admits of any doubt whatever. The size of the letters is about ¬Ω. The characters are N√¢gar√Æ of about the eleventh century; down

to line 89, they are regularly and beautifully formed and skilfully engraved. The execution of lines 40-46 is some what inferior to the rest, and the difference in appearance is rendered more marked by the imperfect state of preservation of these concluding lines. The language of the inscription must be described as Sanskrit. Unless there was a date in any part of the concluding lines which is now illegible, the inscription itself is not dated; but it contains ten dates, some of which‚Äô are historically important, while one is sufficiently particularized to ascertain from it the era employed, by calculation, as will be shown below.
The inscription consists of two parts, The first and by far the larger portion extends to about the middle of line 39; it is in prose, and records a large number of donations made at different times, from the (Vikrama) year 960 down to the. (Vikrama) year 1025, and nearly every one of them by private individuals, in favour of various Brhamanical deities, at S√Æya·∏ço·πá√Æ. The second part, which is almost entirely in verse, comprises the remaining portion up to the end, and records the erection of a temple of
Mur√¢ri (Vish·πáu).

THEFIRST PART

To treat fully of the language of the first part, would require almost a separate treatise. The author or authors, though intending to write Sansk·πõit, had a very meagreknowledge of the grammar of that language; they were evidently influenced by, and have freely employed words, phrases, and constructions of, their vernacular.
As regards orthography, bhas throughout been denoted by the sign for v; and the dental sibilant has often been employed for the palatal.¬≥754The sign of the jihv√¢m√ªl√Æya occurs twenty-two times, almost exclusively in the phrases ‡§Ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•çand ‡§Ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•ã‡§™‡§ø. The sign of the upadhm√¢n√Æya has becn correctly employed six times (e.g., in ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‚Äì‡§™‡§∞‡•¶, line 5, and ‡§≠‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‚Äì‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§®, line 13); but it has also been wrongly inserted three times (in ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ü‚Äì‡§™‡§∞‡§ø ‡•¶, line 18,line 28, and ¬∞ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§≤‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‚Äì‡§™‡§∞‡§ø ‡•¶, line 29), and probably erroneously omitted twice (in¬∫‡§≠‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‚Äì‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§®, line 25, and otf ‡§∞‡•á‡§≠‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ, linc 35). Of individual words, the numera ‡§§‡§øhas throughout been spelt ‡§§‡•É(in ‡§§‡•É‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó,Gut, lines 24, 29, 30, and ‡§§‡•É‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§® ‡•¶, lines 25 and 27); ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§® throughout ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‚Å¥755 (e.g., in lines 3, 6, 8, etc.) ; ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä‡§® throughout ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§® (e.g., in lincs 3, 6, 20, etc.); and similarly we have ‡§≠‡•ã‡§ó‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡§æ in line 38, for ‡§≠‡•ã‡§ó‡§æ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ, In line 8, we twice have ‡§Ö‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§® for ‡§Ü‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§®; throughout, frequently, ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ, apparently for ‡§Ü‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ (e.g., in lines 7, 8, etc.) ; and similarly a short vowel has been employed instead of a long one, and vice vers√¢, occasionally in other words. For ‡§µ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•Äwe have wet ‡§∑‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•Ätwice in linc 17, and perhaps also in some of the compound numerals; for ‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•Ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï (line 15), ‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï in lines 25 and 26; for ‡§µ‡•à‡§ñ‡§æ‡§®‡§∞, ‡§µ‡•à‡§ñ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞in line 12. Through the influence of the vernacular, we havo ‡§µ‡§£‡§ø‡§ï throughout for ‡§µ‡§£‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‚Äå; ‡§≠‡•Ä‡§§‡•Ä in line 24 for ‡§≠‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø (lines 18 and 26) ; ‡§∏‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§ß‡§∞ in line 39 for ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ß‡§∞ (linc 37); ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§™‡§æ‡§≤ and ‡§ï‡§≤‡§™‡§æ‡§≤ in lines. 9 and 19, for ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§™‡§æ‡§≤ ;etc.

The rules of sa·πÅdhihave been persistently neglected ; and as a specimen of an extraordinary sa·πÅdhi I may point out ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§≠‡§ø], for ‡•¶‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§≠‡§ø[:], for, i.e,¬∞ **‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§è‡§≠‡§ø‡§É,**i.e,¬∞ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§è‡§≠‡§ø‡§É, in line 85.

As regards the treatment of nouns in general, case-terminations have often been altogether omitted; sometimes wrong cases have beenemployed, masculine words treated as if they were neuter, and masculine or neuter forms of adjectives and pronouns used with reference to feminine nouns, etc. Thus, to give a few examples, instead of the wellknown phrase ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§•‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡§ø, we read fifteen times ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§•‡§®‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡§ø (e.g., in lines 8, 9, 16) ; and similarly ‡•¶‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡§ø, lines 13and 20; ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§•‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡§ø, line 17; ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§•‡§®‡§æ‡§ñ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡§ø, lines 6 and 15; and ‡§ñ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ ‡§¶‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡§ø, line 39. In line 3we find ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§§, qualifying ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø, which is separated from it by other inflected words ; in line 4 ‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ‡§£ (for ‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ‡§£‡•ã) ‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§: ; in linc 39 ‡§∏‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§ß‡§∞ (for ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ß‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø) ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø; in line16 ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§≤‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§§ (for ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§≤‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä) ‡§â‡§µ‡§ü‡§ï‡§∏‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•å^(5756.)The words ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞, ‡§Ü‡§ò‡§æ‡§ü, ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶, ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó, ‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§ are used as neuters in lines 34; 7, 12, 13, etc.; 6; 24, 29, 30; 26. In line 9 we have the Nominative ‡§∏ ‡§ö ‡§∏ ‡§ö for the Instrumental ‡§§‡•á‡§®‡§§‡•á‡§® ; in line 34 the Accusative ¬∞ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç for the Nominative ‡•¶‡§∏‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§æ; in lines 32, 33, 38, 14, 22, ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø and ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äå for the feminine forms ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É and ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äå or ‡§Ü‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äå. The final visarga of certain case-terminations has complctely disappeared, e.g, in ‚Äû¬∞ ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§ï‡•à, lines 6, 15, 16, ctc., and in “‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•ã, lines 20, 25, 31^(6757.)
An extraordinary construction of the cardinal numerals, which I have already pointed out in other inscriptions, is illustrated by ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡•à‡§ï‡§Ç, line 20, ‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§ï‡§Ç, line 28, ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•à‡§ï‡§Ç and ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•à‡§ï‡§Ç, line 37, ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§•‡•Ä‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•å, line 16, and ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•å‚Äòtwo houses,‚Äô line 24. And, speaking of numerals, attention may be drawn here to the three different expressions ‡§Æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§ï‡•àin line 6, ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§ï‡•á in lines 15, 16, 18, and ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§ï‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ï‡•àor ‡§ï‡•àin lines 10, 27, 30; and to the strange ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§®‡§µ‡§∏‡§§ (i.e.,‡§®‡§µ‡§∂‡§§, for ‡§®‡§µ‡§∏‡•Å); meant to denote ‚Äònine hundred years,‚Äô in lines 2, 5, 8, and 11.
The number of finite verhal forms employed is, as might have been expected in a record of the Middle Ages, small; and among them, I need point out only ‡§≤‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø, used in a passive sense, in lines G, 10, 15, etc. Among the verbal derivatives, there occur thewrong Gerunds ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø, line 6; ‡§â‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ, line 17, ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æline 25 (for ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ, lines 9, 10, 19), ‡§è‡§ï‡§Æ‡§§‡•Ä‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ, lines 29, 80, and 33, and ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø, line 38; with the last of which may be compared the primary nouns ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§™‡§® in lines 11 and 87, and ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡§® in line 38. And anomalously used is the Gerund ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ in the phrase ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æin line 26, apparently meaning before all the people assembled.
Of frequent occurrence is ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§ï, which thirteen times may be considered a secondary suffix conveying a possessive sense or expressing the meaning of a Genitive case; e.g., in ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ø‡§°‡•ã‡§£‡§ø‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§Æ‡§£‡§™‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç, line 6, ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§µ‡•Ä‡§•‡•Ä, line 12, ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•Ç‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ, line 32, and ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ, line 9=(‡§µ‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ, line24); while twice it is, exceptionally, like an independent word, construed with a preceding Genitive,in‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§Ç, line 9, and ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§π‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§∞‡§ø, line19.
Under the head of compounds, I may point out the violation of an elementary rule of grammar, in ‡§Æ‡§π‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•ã‡§Éline 8,‡§Æ‡§π‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•ã, line 20, ‡§Æ‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•ã‡•¶7 ¬∞ ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•ã‡§É in line 25 and 28, ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•ãand ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•ã in lines 11, 29, 31, and 33; the use of phrases like fea ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø, line 6, for ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§Ç (actually used in lines 6, 10, and 28), and ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ç, line 20, or ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø, lines 29 and 37, instead of ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ç (line 45); and the employment of the Nominative cases in passages such as ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§ú‡•á‡§ú‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§≠‡§≤‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ

‡§ú‡•ã‡§ó‡•Ç‡§ï‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç, line 29 (and similarly in lines 7, 19, 20, 27, and 81), where; in proper
Sansk·πõit, the formation of a Dvandva compound would have been resorted to.
Moreover, the first part of the inscription contains a considerable number of words which either do not occur in Sansk·πõit literature at all,which the dictionary furnishes no appropriate meaning; and some of which undoubtedly were taken from the vernacular. These words I give in the following alphabetical, list, in which I also include some words which appear to be proper names of places or localities, but about the actual meaning of which I cannot be certain :‚Äî

** ‡§Ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§®‡•Ä‡§Æ‡•Ä** in linc 6, and ‡§Ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§®‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ in lines 7, 9, 21, etc..=‡§Ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§®‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø ‚Äòa perpetual endowment.‚Äô

** ‡§Ö‡§™‡§∏‡§∞‡§ï** in ‡§Ö‡§™‡§∏‡§∞‡§ï‡§∏‡§π‡§ø‡§§ in lines 7,17, 24, and ‡§Ö‡§™‡§∏‡§∞‡§ï‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§£‡§∏‡§π‡§ø‡§§, lines 32 and 33, said of houses, etc.; compare the Hind√Æ ‡§ì‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§æ‚Äòa porch, portico, peristyle, vestibule,‚Äô Ma√¢·π≠h√Æ‡§ì‡§∏‡§∞‡•Ä.

** ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ** in lines 7, 8, etc., apparently for ‡§Ü‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ, derived from ‡§Ü‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏ ‚Äòdwelling, residence.

** ‡§Ü‡§π‡§æ‡§°**in ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Ü‡§π‡§æ‡§°‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§¶‡§∏‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§ï‡•Ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç in line 80; perhaps a place where stone-cutters work, a quarry (?).

** ‡§â‡§µ‡§ü‡§ï** in line 25, and in ‡§â‡§µ‡§ü‡§ï‡§∏‡§π‡§ø‡§§, lines 12, 13, 16, etc., said of houses, etc.; compare the Mar√¢·π≠h√Æ‡§ì‡§ü‡§æthe little wall or raised edge which runs along the brink of the raisod mass on which the house stands,‚Äô and ‡§ì‡§ü‡•Ä, ‚Äòa veranda, porch, vestibule.‚Äô

** ‡§ï‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï** in ‡§ï‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§µ‡•Ä‡§•‡•Ä, linc 16 ; compare the Hind√Æ‡§ï‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞ and the Mar√¢·π≠h√Æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞ or‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞ ‚Äòa brazier,‚Äô (‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞).

** ‡§ï‡§Ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§ò‡•Ç‡§ü** in line 15.

** ‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï** three times in linc 10 ; compare the Hind√Æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ç‚Äòa certain tribe whose occupation it is to fry corn, prepare sweetmeats, etc., & sugar-boiler.‚Äô

** ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ã‡§™‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ**, qualifying ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§•‡•Ä, in lines 27, 85, and 38.

** ‡§ï‡•å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï** in lino 2; and in lines 19 and 30, both times compounded with a proper
name; denoting perhaps an office.

** ‡§ñ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æin‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§•‡§®‡§æ‡§ñ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ**, lines 6, 10, 15, and ‡§ñ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ, line 39; compare the Hind√Æ ‡§ñ‡§∏‡§∞
‚Äòdamages, loss, injury, fraud.‚Äô

** ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§ï** in line 15, probably for ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡§™‡§§‡§ø.

** ‡§ò‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ï**in line 28, and ‡§ò‡§æ‡§£‡§ï in line 31; compare the Mar√¢·π≠h√Æ ‡§ò‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‚Äò an oil-mill.‚Äô

** ‡§ö‡•Ç‡§Ç‡§Ü** or ‡§ö‡•Ç‡§Ç‡§Ü‡§Çin ‡§ö‡•Ç‡§Ü‡§Ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§•‡•Ä and ‡§ö‡•Å‡§Ç‡§Ü‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ß‡•Ä, lines 13and 14,

** ‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ** in ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ, lines 7 and 88,

** ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ**in lines 8, 21, and 24.

** ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡§ø** in line 85, for ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•Ä, probably a kind of building; see Indian Antiquary, vol.
XIV, p. 161, note 27.

** ‡§§‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä** in-line 9, and ‡§§‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø in line 20, perhaps aparticular measure of spirituous liquor.

** ‡§§‡§ø‡§£‡§∞‡§æ**10 ‡§§‡§ø‡§ñ‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§•‡•Ä, line 35.

** ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∑‡•ç‡§†** in ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§∑‡•ç‡§†, line 14, ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•á‡§∏‡§ï, line 32, and ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•á‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ï‡§Ç, line 38; compare ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡•ã‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ï ‚Äòa gate-chamber,‚Äô in the Index of the Divy√¢vad√¢na.

** ‡§®‡•á‡§Æ‡§ï** in ‡§®‡•á‡§Æ‡§ï‡§µ‡§£‡§ø‡§ï, lines $, 11, 16, etc., and ‡§®‡•á‡§Æ‡§ï‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§£‡§ø‡§ï, line 87; perhaps equiva. lent to the Hind√Æ and Mar√¢·π≠h√Æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ï‚Äòsalt.‚Äô

‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤ in lines 2, 18, 29, 30, 36; an office, apparently similar to the Mar√¢·π≠h√Æ ‡§™‡§Ç‡§öor
‡§™‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§à‡§§‡§ÉCompare Ind. Ant., vol. XI, p. 221, 1. 21, and p. 242, 1. 9; also vol. XII, p. 195, note.
‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§ï in ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§ï, line 19.
‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ in,line 26, and ‡§™‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ in lines 28 and 31; probably = ‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø=‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§•.
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï in line 12.
‡§≠‡§∞‡§£ in ‡§≠‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø, line 80 ; perhaps ‚Äòa load‚Äô (of stores).
‡§Æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§™‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ in lines 6, 19, 29, 80, 45; evidently some public or official building of the town. Compare Ind. Ant., vol. XIV, p. 10, second col., line 5; and Journ. Beng. As. Soc., vol. XXX, p. 332, last line.
‡§Æ‡§π‡§∞ in ‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡§π‡§∞, line 26; compare ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ïin ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ï, line 19; and the Hindi‡§Æ‡§π‡§∞ ‚Äòa chief.‚Äù Compare Dr. Hultzsch, ante, p. 161, note 24.
‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ in line 6.
‡§∏‡•Å‡§≤‡§æ‡§á‡§§‡§£ in line 11.
‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó or ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§æ in ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡•á‡§ï‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ, line 0, ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡•à‡§ï‡§Ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡•à‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø, line 20, and ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§∞‡§ø, line 21.
‡§∞‡§∏‡•ã‡§ï‡•á in line 24.
‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ã‡§™‡§ï in line 10, and ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ã‡§µ‡§ï in linc 26; perhaps ‚Äòthe twentieth part of‚Äô or a name of a particular coin. We may compare ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ã‡§™‡§ï‡§æ, which several times occurs in a copperplate inscription of the Lucknow Musoum.
‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§æ in lines 18 and 20; equivalent to ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§•‡§®‡§æ or ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ò‡•ç‡§®.
‡§µ‡§∑‡§Ø‡§£ in line 38, compounded with a proper name, and denoting perhaps a trade.
‡§∏‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§ï‡•Ç‡§ü in linc 30, = ‡§∂‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§ï‡•Å‡§ü‡•ç‡§üin verse 101 of the Sasbah√ªinscription, Ind. Ant., vol. XV, p. 40, 40stone-cutter.‚Äô
‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•ã‡§≤‡•Ä‡§™‡§æ‡§§ or ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•ã‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§§ in lines 12,16, 21, 28, ‡•¶(‡•¶., and in ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•ã‡§≤‡•Ä‡§™‡§æ‡§§ and

‡§π‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü ‚Äòa market‚Äô in ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü, line 15, ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§π‡§ü, line 35, ‡§¶‡•ã‡§∏‡§ø‡§π‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü, lines 12, 16, 20, 21, 29,
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§π‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü, line 18, and ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§π‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü, lines 45 and 46; (also in ‡§π‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§∞‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ, lines 12,14, ete.)
As regards the contents, the first part of the inscription is divided, by means of ornamental full-stops, into twenty-seven scctions; and it records as many donations, made at different times, and almost all of them by traders and artizans, for providing the usual materials of worship of Vish·πáu and other deities, at the town of S√Æya·∏ço·πá√Æ. The inscription, in fact, is a collective public copy of a series of deeds; and the occasional remarks that a certain portion was written by the kara·πáika, or writer of legal documents, Sarvahari, the son of Bhochuka (line 4), another by Rachchh√¢ka, the son of Sarvahari (line 34), another by Sv√¢mikum√¢ra, another son of Sarvahari (line 36), and another again by the kara·πáika Dh√Æravarman, the son of Sv√¢mikum√¢ra (line 39), were copicd with the rest from the original deeds, and must not be taken to refer to the inscription itself. There are some, I believe, minor points in several of the deeds here presented to us, which, owing at least in part tothe ungrammatical state of the language and to the employment of obscure expressions, I do not fully understand. But the general import of tho various donations is clear enough, and may be seen from the following statement, from which I omit, as of no interest, all reference to the boundaries of buildings which in the original are given with scrupulous care.Any

remarks of historical importance or of more general interestwhich may be incidentally furnished by these deeds,‚Äîconsidering the great length of the inscription, they are disappointingly few,‚Äîwill be treated of below.

Abstract of the contents of the first part of the inscription (lines 1‚Äî39).

From the above abstract it will appear that most of the donations recorded here were made in favour of the god Vish·πáu, under the names of Vish·πáu-bha·π≠·π≠√¢raka, N√¢r√¢yana-bha·π≠·π≠√¢raka, V√¢manasv√¢mideva, and Ohakrasv√¢mideva. The same divinity I understand to be denoted by the name Tribhuvanasv√¢mideva. But besides him, we find among the donees also Umamahesgvara, clearly a form of the god ≈öiva, and Bh√¢√Ølasv√¢mideva, a namo which in a fragmentary inscription from Bhilsa, mentioned by Dr. Hall in the Journ. Beng. As. Soc., vol. XXXI, p. 112, is distinctly given as a designation of Ravi, ‚Äò the Sun.‚Äô‚Äô
In connection with the objects of donation, attention may be drawn to the various names of coins mentioned in the inscription, which are as follows: Dramma, line 29;

Pa√±chiyaka-dramma, lines 6 and 37; Vigrahap√¢la-dramma, line 30; Vigrakup√¢l√Æya-dramma, line 24; Vigrahap√¢lasatka-dramma, line 9; and Vigrahatu·πÖg√Æya-dramma, line 90; ≈ör√Æmad√¢divar√¢ha, line 19, and ≈ör√Æmad√¢divar√¢ha-drayma, line 37; Var√¢hakaya-vi·πÅsopaka (?), line 10, and Vigraha-dramma-visovaka, line 26; and Kapardaka, linc 20; to which may be added here at once, from the second part of the inscription, K√¢ki·πá√Æ and Var√¢·π≠ak√¢, in line 45.
Among the donors, the only personage of importance is Undabhata, who is described here (in line 5) as mah√¢pr√¢lih√¢ra, samadhigat√¢seshamah√¢≈õabda, and Mah√¢s√¢mani√¢hipati, and who clearly is the Mah√¢s√¢mant√¢hipatiUndabha·π≠a, mentioned, with the date 960, in two short inscriptions at Terahi, a village about twenty-seven miles NW. of S√Æya·∏ço·πá√Æ. I have shown elsewhere^(8)that the date of the Terahi inscriptions must be referrod to the Vikrama era, and this alone would prove that the date assigned toUndabhata‚Äôs donation in the present inscription, the year 964, and together with it all the other dates, aro recorded in the same era. But cven irrespectively of the Terahi inscriptions, the date of the donation No. 18, in which the 5th of the dark half of the month Vai≈õ√¢kha of the year 994 is coupled with a sa·πÅkr√¢nti or entrance of the sun into a sign of the zodiac, contains sufficient data to enable us to prove that the era which we are here concerned with is the Vikrama era, that the years mentioned are southern Vikrama years, and that the arrangement of the lunar fortnights follewed was the am√¢nta or southern arrangement. For, taking the figures 994 to denote the southern, Vikrama year 994 expired, the 6th of the dark half of Vai≈õ√¢kha, by the am√¢nta scheme of the lunar fortnights, corresponds to Sunday, 22nd April, A.D. 938, when the 5th of th√© of the dark half ended about 17h. 45m. after mean sunrise, and whea, about 14h. Giz. after mean sunrise, the sun did enter into the zodiacal sign of V·πõisha, exactly as required by the details of the date.‚Åπ‚ÄôAccordingly, the donations spoken of in the inscription were made between A.D. 903-4 and 968-9.
From the introductory remarks to the donations Nos. 11, 21, 23, and 27 (lines 18, 29, 80, and 36) we learn that the town of S√Æya·∏ço·πá√Æ, in the year 969= A.D. 912-13, was held by (or, as the inscription expresses it, was in the enjoyment of) the Mah√¢r√¢j√¢dhir√¢ja, the illustrious Dhurbha·π≠a; and in the years 1005=A.D. 948-49, 1008= A.D. 951-52, and 1025=A.D. 968-69, by the Mah√¢r√¢j√¢dhir√¢jaNishkala·πÖka. A third personage, described, so far as one can sec, as samadhigat√¢≈õeshamah√¢≈õabda and Mah√¢s√¢mant√¢dhipati, who appears to have held a position similar to that of Dh√ªrdbha·π≠a and Nishkala·πÖka, was mentioned, with the date 960=A.D. 903-4, in line 2, but his name is

bhaya or Nirbhayanarendra, and that R√¢ja≈õekhara in some passages of his plays now illegible. Under these nobles, the affairs of the town would seem to have been managed by an assembly of five called pa√±chakula, and by a committee of two, appointed from time to time by the town. The Mah√¢r√¢j√¢dhir√¢jasthemselveswere subordinate to, and derived their authority from, the paramount lords of the country, of whom the inscription mentions :‚Äî
Inline 1, with the date 96(0=A.D. 903-4, the [ Pa·πõamabha·π≠·π≠√¢raka] Mah√¢raj√¢dhir√¢jas, and Parame≈õvara, the illustrious Mahendrap√¢ladeva¬π‚Å∞[meditating, in all probability, on the fect of the Paramabha·π≠·π≠√¢raka, Mah√¢r√¢jadhir√¢jas, and Parame≈õvara, the illustrious Bhojadeva];
In line 4, with the date 964=A.D. 907-8, again, the same P. M. and P. the illustrious Mahendrap√¢ladeva, meditating on the fect of the P. M. and P. the illustrious Bhojadeva; and
In line 28, with the date ‚Äò1005=A.D. 948-49, the P. M. and P. the illustrious Devap√¢la, meditating on the feet of the P. M and P. the illustrious Kshitip√¢ladeva.
We are nowhere in the inscription distinctly told what was the name of the country over which these particular sovercigns held sway, or of their capital; but as the inscription, in line 40, speaks of a ruler of Mahoday√¢ who granted a town to certain Br√¢hma·πás descendants of whom lived at S√Æya·∏ço·πá√Æ, we shall not be wrong in assuming that Bhojadeva, Mahendrap√¢ladeva, Kshitip√¢ladeva and Devap√¢la were kings of Mahoday√¢, better known as Kanyakubj√¢ (or Kanauj).
The main importance of our inscription then linesin this, that it furnishes, together with certain dates, the names of two pairs of kings of Kanyakubj√¢,‚Äî

Bhoja; succeeded by
Mahendrap√¢la, who was ruling in A.D. 903-4 and 907-8 ; and
Kshitip√¢la; succeeded by
Devap√¢la, who was ruling in A.D. 948-49.

Of theso, I do not hesitate to identify Bhoja with the Bhojadeva of the Deoga·∏çi, Gw√¢lior, and Peheva inscription¬π¬πof A.D, 862, 876, and 882.
As regards Kshitip√¢la, there is nothing in our inscription to show that he was the immediate successor of Mahendrap√¢la; but I shall try to prove that such was the caseand that Kshitip√¢la, in fact, was the son of Mahendrap√¢la.
In an article on the date of the poet R√¢ja≈õekhara¬π¬≤Mr, Fleet has put together cortain facts concerning that poet which had been already drawn attention to by Professor Pischel¬π¬≥and which amount to this, that one or more of the poect‚Äôs plays were acted, at Mahoday√¢or Kanyakubj√¢, before a king Mah√Æp√¢la, a son of a king Nir-

¬π‚Å∞ In the original, the first syllable is illegible, but there cannot be the slightest doubt about the correctedof the above name ; nor is it, in my opinion, at all doubtful that the name of the sovereign on whose feet Mahendrap√¢la was meditating, was Bhojadeva. And these two sovereignare clearly the same Bhojadeva and Mahendrapala who are mentioned in the second deed, in line 4; so that the inscription speaks of only ove Bhojadeva, and of only oneMahendrapaladeva.

I may draw attention hore to the somewhat unusual phrase mahi-pravardhamana-kalydna-vijayarajye, which the Siyadoniinscription has in common with, at any rate, the Deogadh inscription, and with the Asni inscription which will be mentioned below.
