7. ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ
‡§ú‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ß‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ö‡§Ø‡§®‡§ö‡§Ø‡§®‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§Æ‡§æ ‡•• ‡•™ ‡••954
‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•Ä ‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡§Æ‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§ñ‡§Ç‡§°‡§ø‡§∑‡•Ä‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•à‡§ß‡§ø‡§∑‡•Ä‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü
‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§Æ‡•à‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø-
8. ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§®‡•Å ‡§Æ‡§π[‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•á] ‡§§‡§∏‡§æ [ ‡§∏‡§Ç ] ‡§ó‡§∏‡•Ä‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü ‡••
‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ [‡§µ‡§ø]‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã[‡§§‡§ø]‡§∑‡•Ä‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞[‡§ï‡•É] ‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•á-‡§Ø‡§ø‡§∑‡•Ä‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø-
‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•Ä‡§É‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¨‡•ã‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§ø‡§∑‡•Ä‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ö‡•Å‡§∞‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§Æ‡§≤‡§æ -‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ã‡§ï‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§ø‡§∑‡•Ä‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü ‡•• ‡•´ ‡••955
‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ-**

9. ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡•ã‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§§‡§∞‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ç[‡§µ‡•à]‡§ú‡§Ø‡§Ç[‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ç]‡§ú‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä-
‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã[‡§ï]‡§≤‡§ø‡§§[‡§ï]‡§≤‡§ø‡§Æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ ‡••
‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡•ã‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§§‡§∞‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•à‡§ú-

L.10 ‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ç[‡§ú]‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä-.
‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ[‡§≤‡§Ø‡§Ç]‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø‡§§ [‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø‡§Æ‡§≤‡§æ] ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ[‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å] ‡§§‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ‡••‡•¨‡••956
‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡§É ‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§¶‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ‡§æ
‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡§É

11. ‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§¶‡§æ[‡§¶‡•á]‡§µ‡§µ‡§ø[‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ] ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ‡§æ ‡•§
‡§∏‡§æ‡•í[‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ç]‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ[‡§µ]‡§É‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§π‡§∞‡§ø[‡§™]‡§¶‡§æ‡§¶‡•á[‡§µ]‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ‡§æ
‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡§É ‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§¶‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ã-

12. ‡§Æ‡§æ [‡••] ‡•≠ [‡•• ]
‡§è‡§ò‡§Ç‡§§‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•Å ‚Äî ‡§®‡•Å ‚Äî‚Äî[‡§Æ]‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç [‡§Ø‡§æ] ‚Äî ‚Äî‡•ã ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ ‚Äî‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‚Äî
‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§µ‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß[‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∑‡§§‡§ø] ‡§™‚Äî‡§ø‚Äî‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡§æ‡§∑‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡••
‡§™‡•Å‡§Ç‡§∏‡§É ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§¶‡•Å‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï-

13. ‡§≤‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§§[‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å]‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ
‡§∂‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§∂‡•å ‚Äî‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§´‡§≤‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™[‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•Å]‡§§‡•á‚Äî ‚Äî‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡••‡•Æ‡••957
‚Äî‡§ó‡•Ä‡§∏‡•Ä‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‚Äî‡§ø ‚Äî‡•á ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§ï‡§≤‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§Ç‡§∏‡§ø‡§∑‡•ã‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∂‡•Ä‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü

14. ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡•ã‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü ‡§ö ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‚Äî‡§Ç ‡§§‚Äî‡§ø‡§Ç ‚Äî‡•ã‚Äî‡§ø‡§∑‡•Ä‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü ‡••
‚Äî‡§æ‡§∏‡•ã‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‚Äî‡§æ‡§∞‚Äî ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‚Äî‚Äî‡§∏‡§¢‡§®‚Äî‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ó‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§∑‡•Ä‡§ü‡§æ‚Äî‡§ø‡§∑‡•ã‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü
‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§∏‡•ã‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡•É‡§∑‡•Ä‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•Ä‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡•Ä

15. ‡§§‡•á ‡••‡•Ø‡••
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ò[‡§µ] ‡§ö‡•à‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡§æ[‡§¶‡§ø]‡§®‡§æ ‡•§
[‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§µ ] ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•á‡§Ø‡§Ç [‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ] ‡§≤‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡••‡•ß‡•¶‡••384
‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Ø‡§ó‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§É‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø‡§Æ‡§≤‡§¶‡§≤‡§®‡•á‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§°‡§É‡§ï‡•É-

16. ‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡•á-
‡§∑‡•ç‡§∑‡§°‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§§‡§ø[‡§∏‡•Å‡§§] ‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∑‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡••
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ó‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç‡§•‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ
‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ -

17. ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø ‚Äî‚Äî[‡§®‡§ø]‡§™‡•Å[‡§£‡•ã] ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•Ä‡§£‡§É ‡•• [‡•ß‡•ß ‡••]
‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®‡•Å‡§É ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§®‡§∞‡§µ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ã‡§¶‡§∞‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ-
‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§£‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§π‡§∞‡§ö‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç‡§≠‡•Ä‡§ú‡§≠‡•É‡§Ç‡§ó‡•ã‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§≤‡§Ç ‡•§

18. ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ‡§¶‡§ø‡§¶[‡§Æ‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‚Äî‡§ø‚Äî‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§Ç
‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§É‡§ï‡§≤‡§Ø‡§§ ‡§§‡§¶‡§ø‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡•• [ ‡•ß‡•® ‡•• ]
‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•á ‡§ú‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•É‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§µ‡§¶‡§µ‡§®‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡•á-

19. ‡§ò‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ã‡§≠‡•Ç-
‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§ó‡§£‡§®‡§ø‡§≤‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•Å‡§É ‡••

**__________________________

‚ÅπMetre of verses11-13, Sragdhara. Read ‡§ï‡•É‡§£‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§∑‡•ç‡§∑‡§°‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É; ‡•¶‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•¶is doubtful.**

‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§É ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§™‡§Ç‡§ö‡§Æ‡§æ[‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ] ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∑‡§ø‡§≤‡§É
‡§∂‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§ø-

L.20. ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‡•• [‡•ß‡•© ‡••]¬π‚Å∞958

** ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§∞‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§¶‡§æ ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§æ‡§π‡§§‡•á
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§≤‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∑‡•á‡§£ ‡§™‡§Ç‡§®‡§ó‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡•á‡§® ‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•Ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§ ‡•§
**

** 21. ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§≠‡•Ä‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§´‡§≤‡§¶‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ[‡§Æ]‡§£‡§ø‡§É ‡§∂‡•ã‡§≠‡§§‡•á
‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§ñ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§É ‡•• [‡•ß‡•™]¬π¬π959
‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•á ‡§Æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§™‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡•ã‡§¢‡§∞‡§ø ‡§∞‡§æ-**

** 22.
‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡••
‡§∞‡§£‡•Ä‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•Ä‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•á ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡•• [‡•ß‡•´ ‡••]¬π¬≤960
‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§°‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ó‡•Å‡§π‡§æ‡§Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•á‡§¶‡•É‡§¢‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§Ç
‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç‡§≠‡•ã‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã -**

** 23. ‡§ó‡§™‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§µ‡§æ ‡§§‡§Æ‡§É‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡••
‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡§Ç
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡§π‡§Ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ú‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä ‡•§ [‡•ß‡•¨ ‡••] ^(13863)
24. ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡§£‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§¨‡•ã‡§ú‡§¶‡•á‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø \‡•§
‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≤‡•á‡§ñ‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ó‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡•• [ ‡•ß‡•≠ ‡•• ]¬π‚Å¥961
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à ‡§®‡§Æ‡§É [ ‡•• ]**

TRANSLATION. ¬π‚Åµ962

Verse 10. By the famous ascetic R√°ghavachaitanya, a Vedantist, has this string of jewel-likepraise been offered to Jv√°l√°mukhi.

  1. (There was) a learned Dr√°vida of the Atreya gotra, Krishnabhatta, a destroyer of the impurity of the Kali age, a teacher of the six Dar≈õanas, who was honoured by the sons of kings and who had bathed on (the completion of) Soma sacrifices. From him was born a leader of wise men, called V√°gi≈õvara, a composer of works, who had completely mastered the M√Æm√°ms·∫£, was clever in (the exposition of) the Smritis *…..*and was learned in sacrificial lore.

  2. His son Krishnabhatta, a brother to the wives of others, a master of all sciences, a composer of poetry, a bee on the lotus of the feet of Harihara ( filled ) with excessive (devotion), an inhabitant of Kasi, came and copied with broad ….. most excellent hymn on the greatness of Jv√•l√¢mukh√Æ; take notice of this (poem that is) most important for (the attainment of ) enjoyments and liberation.¬π‚Å∂963 with excessive ( devotion), ’ is not idiomatic.")

  1. In the race of the (lord of this country) to whom long life may be granted arose king Meghachandra. From him sprang the illustrious king Karmachandra,the abode of a multitude of virtues, a moon for (that) assemblage of lotuses, virtuous men. From him was born king Sams√¢rachandra, anointed in the fifth year (of the Lokak√°la); after conquering all his enemies, he presents the earth to those who know the meaning of the Vedas and of the S√°stras964 assemblage of lotuses, virtuous men,’ is most objectionable. For the poet really means to say that the king causes good men to prosper, just as the moon causes the lotus flowers to open, and he ought to have said satkumuchchandra·∏•, or satkumudachandra·∏•. The affix vat which makes the simile to halt, has probably been added only because the poet did not know how to satisfy the requirements of the metre.The same causehas also induced him to use the incorrect form vijitna.").

  1. Victorious is that best among princes, king Samsarachandra, whose fame, resplendent like snow or a string of pearls, pervades the three worlds in the guise of the snowy mountains, of the lord of snakes, and of the moon,‚Äîhe whose form shines as the Chint√°manithat grants the desired rewards to the virtuous.

  2. While the chamberlain (prat√≠h√°ra) Ra≈Üi who has conquered hosts of foes, the noble son of the chamberlain (prat√≠h√°ra) Vira, carries the burden of the government, thy fame, O king, protects the earth.

  3. Victorious be the fame of the illustrious S√¢hi Mahammada, that most excellent sorceress who sees the supreme light called majesty, after having most firmly fixed the tortoise-seat in the cave called Brahman’s egg, after having shorn the locks of darkness, even using the milk-ocean during her devotions as the knee-cloth, and after having conquered the dark matter.

  4. Through pure fondness for divineGanapati, out of devotion for the K√¢mboja Delha, this hymn has been caused to be written by the mason S√ºgika.¬π‚Å∏965

Of S√ªryadhvaja, the pupil of famous Karmadhvaja, adoration to Jv√¢l√¢mukhi!

XXV.-TWO CHANDELLA INSCRIPTIONS.

BY PROFESSOR F. KIELHORN, PH.D., C.I.E., G√ñTTINGEN.

I.

MAU STONE INSCRIPTION OF MADANAVARMADEVA.

THE stone which bears this inscription was discovered in 1813 by Lieutenant William Price, at the foot of a rocky hill in the vicinity of the town of Mau, in the Jhansi District of the North-Western Provinces, where “the natives were accustomed to sharpen their knives and talwars upon it.” Lieutenant Price presented it to the Asiatic Society of Bengal, and it is now in the India Museum at Calcutta. He published a transcript and translation966of the inscription in the Asiatic Researches, vol. XII, pages 357-374.

The inscription, so far as I can judge from the impression, consists of 29 lines. The writing covers a space of about 4’ 01/2" broad by 3’ 1" high, and a considerable portion of it is greatly damaged. Thus, the last line is almost completely effaced, and portions of about half the number of lines are either gone altogether or have become illegible, as will be seen from my transcript of the text. Fortunately, however, the names of the royal personages mentioned in the inscription are all well preserved, so that in all probability little of historical importance has been lost. The size of the letters is about 7/8". The characters are N√¢gariof about the twelfth century, similar in style to those of the inscriptions from Ajaygadh and Mahoba, of which photo-lithographs are given in Cunningham’s Archeological Survey of India, vol. XXI, plates xv and xxi-xxiii; and all that need be said about them here, is that in this particular alphabet it is sometimes difficult to distinguish between the signs for g, n and m. The language is Sanskrit, and, so far as the inscription is legiblƒó, it is in verse throughout. The names of the composer and of the engraver may have been given in the concluding lines, but they are no longer legible. As regards orthography, b is denoted by the sign for v everywhere except in Kanyakubjam, line3, abdher, line 14, abbhramlihair and abbhrabhr√°nti, line 18, babh√∫ru·∏• (?) and bibhrad, line 21, and bbh√ªyas√Æ,line25; the dental n is used instead of the anusv√°ra in subhr√°nsu, line 10, vansa, lines 11 (twice), 19 (?) and 23, mim√¢nsaka, line 11, and yaj√±√¢nsa, line 19; and ujvala occurs for ujjvala, in lines 13 and 15 (but not in line 16).

The inscription, in its present state, contains no date, but as it clearly is of the time of the (Chandella) king Madanavarman,¬≤967 it must be referred to about the middle of the twelfth century A. D. Its proper object is to record the erection of a temple of Vishnu, the building of a tank near the village of Deddu, and the execution of some other work of piety, by one of the king’s ministers whose name appears to have been Gadadhara (verses 46-48); and by way of introduction the inscription (in verses 3-16) gives a list of the (Chandella) kings from Dhanga to Madanavarman, and (in verses 17-15) an account of the family of the ministers of these kings, to which Gad√¢dhara belonged.

The line of kings here presented to us, together with few remarks of historical importance, is as follows:-

(1.) Dhanga,¬≥968defeated the king of Kanyakubja (v. 8).
(2.) His son Ga·πá·∏çadeva (v. 4).
(3.) His son Vidyadharadeva (v. 5).
(4.) His son Vijayap√¢la (v. 6).
(5.) His son Kirtivarmadeva (vv. 7-8).
(6.) His son Sallaksha·πáavarmadeva (vv. 9-10); evidently carried on a war in the country of Antarvedi (vv. 38-39).
(7.) his son Jayavarmadeva (v. 11); succeeded by
(8.) Prithvivarman, the younger brother of (6) Sallakshanavarman,(vv. 12-13).
(9.) His son Madanavarman defeated the kings of Chedi and M√¢lava, and made the king of Kasi keep on friendly terms (vv. 14-16).

As regards the line of ministers, it suffices here to state that in the family of Gautama Akshap√¢da, the reputed founder of the Ny√¢ya system of philosophy, there was born Prabhasa, the prime minister of the kings Dhanga and Ganda ( vv. 18-22 ). His son was Sivan√°ga, the minister of Vidyadhara ( vv. 23-24 ) ; and from him sprang Mahipala, the minister of Vijayapala (vv. 25-26). Mahipala had two sons, Ananta and Yogesvara, of whom Ananta was minister under Kirtivarman and Sallakshana-varman (vv. 27-39). Ananta had two wives and several sons, of whom one, probably Gadadhara, was appointed Pratih√°ra by Jayavarman (v. 40), and prime minister by Prithvivarman (v. 41), a post which he continued to hold under Madanavarman (v. 42).In this account of the ministers all the names of the kings are repeated.in the same order in which they are given in the earlier part of the inscription.

Of the localities mentioned in the inscription the country of Antarvedi (in verse 38) is the Doab or district between the Gang√¢ and Yamun√¢ rivers; and the village of Deddu (in verse 47 ) must have been near where the inscription bas been found. Prabh√¢sa, mentioned by way of comparison in verse 20, is a famous place of pilgrimage on the west coast, at Ver√¢wal Pa·π≠·π≠an in K√¢·π≠hi√¢w√¢·∏ç.

**TEXT.**¬π969

L.1.<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1699783339Screenshothh.png"/>¬≤970

<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1699781703Screenshotkk.png"/>

‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§ß‡§¶‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ ‡•§

‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§≤‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§ï‡§π‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á -

<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1699783762Screenshotgg.png"/>^(3971‚Äî[1].)

^( <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1699784030Screenshothhh.png"/>4972)
2.
<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1699784219hj.png"/>‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§≤‡•Ä[‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç]
[‡§≠‡§Ç] ‡§ó‡§ø‡§É‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø[‡§∏‡•ç‡§§]‡§≤ [‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä]‡§ï‡•Å‡§ö‡§ï‡§≤[‡§∂]‡§§‡§ü‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ß‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡•§
‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•Å ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§¶‡§≤‡§ø‡§™‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∂‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠‡•á
‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§•‡•á‡§®‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§§‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø[‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø] ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞[‡§∂]‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡••‚Åµ378-[2].

<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1699785511Screenshot(50"/>.png)[‡§®‡§æ]‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§®‡§∞‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§É [‡•§]

3.<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1699785375Screenshotd.png"/> [‡§®‡§ø]‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤[‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§Ç] ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•Å‡§ú‡§Ç ‡§®‡§∞‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞[‡§≠‡•Å] ‡§µ‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•à‡§É ‡••‚Å∂385- [3].
‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§ï‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•Ç[‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞] ‡§¶‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§ñ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§®‡§™‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡•§

‡§ó‡§£‡•ç‡§°973‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•ã ‡§Ω‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞ [‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ] ‡§µ‡§®‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§É ‡••‚Å∏974.") -[4].
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§®‡§∞‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡•å‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ[‡§®‡•ç‡§§]‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡§¶‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡§É ‡•§
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ß‡§∞‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§É ………..[‡§µ‡§æ] ‡§∏‡§µ‡•ã ‡§ú‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á ‡••‚Åπ543 - [5].
‡§Ö‡§ú‡§®‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§Ø‡§™‡§æ-

L.4 [‡§≤]‡§É‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§≤‡§É[‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠] ‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§™‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§É‡§∏‡•Å‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§É‡•§
‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§®‡§ø‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§£‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§É ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø [‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§≠‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§É ?] ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§£‡§ø‚Äî‚Äî U‚Äî‚Äî U¬Ø :‡••¬π‚Å∞385[6]
‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§ó‡•ã‡§§‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§É ‡•§
[‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø][‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§Ç‡§§‡§Ç?]- ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§á[‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞?] ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ω‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§É‡••¬π¬π975- [7].

** ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á**

5. ‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡§É[‡§ï‡§ø]‡§≤ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡§ø[‡§≠‡§ø]‡§É‡§∑‡§°‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•à‡§É
‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§£ ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•Å‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§Æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç¬π¬≤385 ‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§
‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§É ‡§ï‡§£‡•ç‡§ü‡§ï‡•å‡§ò‡•ã ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø‡§Æ‡§≤[‡§æ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§®‡§µ‡•á ?] ‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡§Ç
[‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ] ‡§∏‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§ö‡§æ‡§ú‡§≤‡§ß‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡§∞‡§Ç [‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡§æ‡§∞] ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§π‡•à‡§µ ‡••¬π¬≥584- [8].
[‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ] ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§≠‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‚Äî

6. [‡§∏]‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§Ω[‡§≠‡•Ç] ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•Å‡§É [1]
‡§ß‡•å‡§∞‡•á‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§∂‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ (‡§¨)‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•Å‡§É ‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§É
‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö ‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§µ‡§ø‡§ü‡§™‡•Ä ‡§®‡§ø‡§É[‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§Ø]‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡••¬π‚Å¥976- [9].
‡§Ø‡•á[‡§®‡§æ]‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡§ï‡•Å[‡§≤‡§ú]‡§®‡•á ‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∞[‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ]
[‡§∏‡§æ] ‡§ï‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ ‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ[‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø]
‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‚Äî

7. ‡§®[‡§ï] ‡§Æ‡§£‡§ø‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§®‡•á‡§™‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ -
‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§¶‡§∏‡§ø ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡•ã‡§™‡§≤‡§®‡•ç‡§≠‡§É‡••¬π‚Åµ378‚Äì [10].
[‡§î‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø] ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§Ø‡§∂‡•å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü ‡§§‡§®‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§ú‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§É ‡•§
‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡§™‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§¶‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡§æ ‡§á‡§µ [‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§?] :- ‡§® ‡§π‡•á‡§ú‡•Å‡§É ‡••¬π‚Å∂374‚Äî[11].
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∏‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ã‡§£‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§•‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ã‡§¶‡§∞‡•ã‡§µ -

8. ‡§∞‡§ú‡§É ‡•§
‡§Ö‡§• ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§É ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ß‡•å ‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡••¬π‚Å∑611‚Äì [12].
‡§Ö‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡•ã ‡§≠‡•É‡§∂‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§π‡•á
‡§ú‡§ø‡§ò‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§Ω‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§µ‡§¶‡§• ‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç ‡•§
‡§™‡§∞‡§æ [‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ]‡§™‡§ø ‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§™‡§∞‡§§‡§æ
** ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§®‡•á ‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•à‡§∞‡§ø‡§π ‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ ‡••¬π‚Å∏977‚Äì [13].**

** ‡§Ö‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§¶‡§®‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ω‡§• ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§**

9. ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ú‡§µ (‡§¨) ‡§≤‡§Æ‡§µ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø [‡§Æ‡•á]‡§®‡•á ‡§Ω‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§§‡§µ (‡§¨) ‡§≤‡§≠‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§ï‡§•‡§æ ‡§ú‡§®‡•à‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ø‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡••¬π‚Åπ978[14].
‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡§ö‡•à‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡§≠‡§∞‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç
‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•å‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§§‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§É ‡•§
‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡•å‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§É ‡§∏ ‡§ö ‡§∏‡§™‡§¶‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡§µ‡•á‡§∂ -
‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§µ‡§®‡§ø‡§≠‡•Å‡§ú‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ö ‡§≠‡•á‡§ú‡•Å‡§É ‡••¬≤‚Å∞979 ‚Äì [15].

L. 10. ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•á‡§ó‡§µ‡§≤‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡§ó‡§ñ‡•Å‡§∞‡§™‡•Å‡§ü‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§£‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§µ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ã‡§É
‡§∏‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ã‡§Ø‡•à‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§ø ‡§≠‡•É‡§∂‡§Ç ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§∂‡•Å980‡§ó‡•å‡§∞‡§Ç‡•§
‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ú‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§¨‡•ã‡§§‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ω [‡§≠‡•Ç]-
‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§≠‡§É‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡§≠‡§µ‡§∏‡§≠‡§æ‡§Æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§™‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§∂‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ ‡•• ‚Äì[16].
‡§Ö‡§• ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§§‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡•§
‡§Ö‡§≠‡§µ -
11. ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§∂‡§É981‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡§Ω‡§ß‡•Å‡§®‡§æ ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‡•• ¬≤¬≥544[17] .
‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•É‡§ú‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ω‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ -
‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§∂‡•á982‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡•å‡§§‡§Æ‡§É ‡•§
‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§∏‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ø‡§£‡§æ983‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§ü‡§ø‡§§‡•á ‡§≠‡§æ‡§≤‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡•á‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§®‡§æ
‡§∞‡•ã‡§∑‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§¶‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•å ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡•á ‡§™‡§¶‡§§‡§≤‡•á ‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç. ‡•• ¬≤‚Å∂984- [18].
‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§¶ -
12. ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§É‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ω‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§™‡§æ‡§¶ ‡§á‡§π ‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§® ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§™‡§¶‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§É ‡••¬≤‚Å∑985‚Äì [19].
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§¶‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§™‡§É‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§µ‡§∏‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ -
** ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å [‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à] ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•å‡§ò‡§∏‡§¶‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡•Ä‡§É ‡•§
‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§®‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡§æ‡§É
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Æ‡§ø‡§µ ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•Å‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Ø‡§∏‡•á ‡••¬≤‚Å∏986- [20].**

13. ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡•ã‡§™‡§ß‡§æ‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ä‡§£‡•ã ‡§ß‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•á‡§® ‡§ó‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•á‡§®987‡§ö ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§É ‡•§
‡§®‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•á ‡§ó‡§π‡§®‡•á ‡§∏‡•Å‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§Ω‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡••¬≥‚Å∞609 ‚Äì [21].
‡§∏‡•Å‡§¶‡•É‡§¢‡§§‡§∞‡§µ‡•Å ( ‡§¨ )‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§É‡§∏‡§Æ‡•á‡§ß‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•Å (‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•Å) ‡§∏‡•á‡§ï‡•á‡§® ‡•§
‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§∞‡•Å‡§∞‡§≠‡§µ‡§¶‡§®‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡§´‡§≤‡§¶‡§É ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡••¬≥¬π611-[22].
‡§µ‡•Å(‡§¨‡•Å) ‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§µ (‡§¨) ‡§π‡•Å‡§®‡§æ ‡§ß‡§ø‡§∑‡§£‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡§™‡•ã‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø (‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§ö)‡§≤‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ã‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡§¶‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§É ‡•§
‡§Ü‡§ú‡•å‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§π‡•á‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø-

14. ‡§∑‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ ‡••¬≥¬≤374 - [23].
‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ã‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§•‡§Æ‡§ø‡§µ ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§§‡•á -
‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§è‡§ï‡§É ‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ò‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§ö‡§ø‡§µ‡§™‡§¶[‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§Ø] ‡§® ‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡§Ç ‡•§
‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ß‡§∞‡§®‡§∞‡§™‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§∞‡§¶‡•Ä -
‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡•ã‡§∂‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§§ ‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡••¬≥¬≥602- [24] .
‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ ‡§ú‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•Å‡§≠‡§ó‡•ã
‡§Æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§≠‡§µ‡§¶ -

15 ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø(‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§ò) ‡§≤‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§É ‡•§

** ‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡•à‡§É[‡§∏‡•Å] ‡§´‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡•à-**

‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§®‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‡•• ‚Äì [25].
‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§≠‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§Ø‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§®‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ß‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∏‡§ö‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§¨‡§≠‡•Ç‡§µ ‡§®‡§ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡••988‚Äì[26].
‡§∏‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§ï‡§ß‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•ã‡§ó‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§µ‡§™‡•Å‡§É ‡§õ‚Äì

L.16. ‡§§‡•Ä‡•§

‡§ú‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á ‡§Ω‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ω‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§É‡••989 ; and of the next verse. “)‚Äì [27].
‡§Ö‡§≠‡•Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡•Å‡§ú‡§É‡•§
‡§∏ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡§∏‡•å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø …… ‡§ß‡§®[‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§]: ‡••‚Äì[28].
‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ(‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ)‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡§Ç
‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§É ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ[‡§∞]‡§£‡•Ä‡•§
‡§∂‡•å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§π‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§£‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§∏‡§§‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®‡•É‡§§‡§æ
‡§Ω‡§®‚Äì

17. ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§É ‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡§Æ‡§§‡•á‡§É ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡••‚Äì990[29].
‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á ‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡§ø ‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•Ç‡§¢‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á
‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø[‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•á‡§§‡§æ?] ‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•Å [‡§™‡•Å‡§∞?] ‡§µ (‡§¨)‡§≤‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ ‡§è‡§ï‡§ñ‡§ó‡•ã‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡•§
‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•á‡§§‡§æ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ[‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ ‡•¶‡•¶‡•¶‡•¶ [‡§∂]: ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡•à‡§ï[‡§ß‡•Å]‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É
‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§® ‡§∏‡•ã‡§≠‡•Ç‡§¶‡§≠‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§‡§∏‡§ö‡§ø‡§µ‡§É ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•á‡§ñ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡••991‚Äì [30].
‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‚Äì

18. ‡§ö‡§ø‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•à‡§∞‡§≠‡§ø‡§ú‡§®‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ[‡§∂‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø]‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‚Äì
‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§® ‡§§[‡§¶‡§æ] ‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Å‡§ü‡§Ç ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§§‡•É‡§µ‡§∞‡•á ‡§Ω‡§®‡•Å‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡§ø [‡§ß‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø]‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•Å‡§É
‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏[‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö]‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•à‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ[‡§ú‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§§‡§Ç[?]‡••]992‚Äì [31].
‚Äì ‚Äì‚Äì[‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞] ‡§µ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§π‡•à‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§π‡•à‚Äì
‡§∞‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§∂‡§ø‡§ñ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‚Äì

19. ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‚Äì ‚Äì ‚Äì‡§§‡§≤‡•ã ‚Äì [‡§™‡§ø?] ‡§Æ[‡§ò]‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø993‚Äì ‚Äì[‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•á]
‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•á ‡§π‡§ø ‡§ó‡§£‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø[‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§¶‡•ã‡•ß]‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡•• ‚Äì [32].
‡§Ü[‡§∏]‡§µ ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§∂‡§ú‡§æ994‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§π‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
‡§Ö‡§®‡§∏‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ω‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡•á‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ………………….. ‡••‚Äì[99533].
‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ö ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§æ‡•§
‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§≤‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‚Äì

20. ………………………………..‡••996. “)‚Äì[34]
…………………………[‡§®] ‡§Æ‡§®‡§ö‡§Ç‡•§
‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ[‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å]‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ø‡§µ‡••‚Äì[99735].

‚Äì ‚Äì: ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ [‡§Æ] ‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•å‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã
‡§µ‡§ø[‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑]‡§π‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§∂‡•å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡§∞‡§ø‡§Æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ(‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ)‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‚Äì‚Äì<MISSING_FIG href=”../books_images/U-IMG-1699438295Screenshot2023-11-08154058.png”/>‡•§
‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì<MISSING_FIG href="#"/><MISSING_FIG href="#"/>‚Äì [‡§ó‡§¶‡§æ] ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ã ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡§É
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞-

L.21 ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö[‡§¨‡§≠‡•Ç‡§µ‡•Å ? ]:‚Äî‡•§<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1699438503Screenshot2023-11-08154446.png"/> ‡••‚Äî998[36].
<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1699438563Screenshot2023-11-08154548.png"/>[‡§µ‡§ø?]‡§≠‡•Å‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ[‡§ó‡§æ]‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡•Å‡§ú‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§™‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø [‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç?]‡•§
‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§Ω[‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§ß ?] <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1699438687Screenshot2023-11-08154735.png"/>‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§ö‡§ø‡§∂‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§®‡•ã‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å‡••‚Äì[99937].
‡§Ö‡§• ‡§∏‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ[‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•Å?] ……………‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡•á……

22. ……………‡••‚Äî1000[38].
<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1699438846Screenshot2023-11-08155033.png"/>
‡§∂‡•å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•ã‡§É ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡•§
‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ï‡§£‡•ç‡§ü‡§ï‡§∂‡•ã‡§ß‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§®‡§™‡§¶‡•á ‡§Ω‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§Ø‡§Ç
‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§ß‡•á ‡§ö ‡§µ‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§∞‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ã‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö ‡••‚Äî[100139].
‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§¶‡§∂<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1699439030Screenshot2023-11-08154019.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1699439030Screenshot2023-11-08154019.png"/>‚Äî ‡§≠‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡§≤‡§æ[‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É]:
‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§ò‡•ã ‡§Ω‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1699439030Screenshot2023-11-08154019.png"/>

23.
<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1699439030Screenshot2023-11-08154019.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1699439030Screenshot2023-11-08154019.png"/>[‡§™‡§∞ ] ‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞(‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞) ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏ ‡§ú‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§æ-
‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§É‡••‚Äì1002[40].
‡§Æ‡•å‡§≤‡§É ‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§∂‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ1003‡§∂‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ
‡§µ‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡§≤‡•ç‡§≠‡§É ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡§ó‡§∞‡§•‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§π‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§É ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ[‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞]:‡•§
[‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§ó‡•Ç‡§¢‡•ã?]‡§Ω‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•á‚Äì

24.
<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1699439030Screenshot2023-11-08154019.png"/>‚Äî [‡§®‡•Å‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É]
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§™‡•É‡§•‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§æ ‡§§‡§¶‡§®‡•Å ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡••‚Äî1004[41].
‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§∞‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•à‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§§ ‡§®‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡§ß‡•Ä‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•ã‡§Ω‡§• ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç
‡§∏‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø[‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§ø‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞]‡§¶‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§®‡•Å ‡§ö ‡§Æ‡§¶‡§®‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ã‡§£‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ω‡§Ø‡§Ç‡•§
‡§∑‡§æ‡§°‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•à‡§É [‡§∏]‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•à‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§∞‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ-
‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§£ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§®‡•Å‡§§ ‡§µ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§§[‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç]‡••‚Äî[42].

**25.‚Äî ‚Äî ‚Äî<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1699439030Screenshot2023-11-08154019.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1699439030Screenshot2023-11-08154019.png"/> ‚Äî‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•å‡§ò‡•à‡§∞‡§™‡§ø
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§ó‡§¶‡§æ‡§ß‡§∞ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç(‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç) ‡§§‡•á ‡§ú‡§®‡•ã‡§Ω‡§Ø‡§Ç [‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç?]‡•§
‡§ó‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§£ ‡§™‡§Ø‡•ã‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§Ç<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1699439030Screenshot2023-11-08154019.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1699439030Screenshot2023-11-08154019.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1699439030Screenshot2023-11-08154019.png"/>‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1699439030Screenshot2023-11-08154019.png"/>‚Äî‚Äî [‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•å]
‡§µ‡•Å[‡§¨‡•Å] ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§É‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§Ç<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1699439030Screenshot2023-11-08154019.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1699439030Screenshot2023-11-08154019.png"/><MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1699439030Screenshot2023-11-08154019.png"/>‚Äî[‡§ï‡•á‡§®‡•ã]‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•Ä‡••‚Äî1005[43].
‡§ï‡§≤‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ[‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø]‡§ß‡§Ø‡•á
‡§Æ [‡§π‡•Ä‡§≠‡•Ç]‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ ‡§µ‡§∏‡•Å ‡§∏‡§ï‡§≤‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ã[‡§™‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ø‡•á?]‡•§ **

L.26.<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1699528646Screenshot2023-11-09164520.png"/> [‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ] ‡§£‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•à‡§É
‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç‡§ó‡§§ ‡§á‡§µ ‡§∏ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§®‡•á ‡§ñ‡§≤‡•Å ‡§ú‡§®‡•à‡§É‡••‚Äî1006[44].
‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§É‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ß‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ß‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶[‡§Ø‡•ã] ‡§Ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§Ø‡§ø‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§µ [‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ] ‡§§‡§§‡•ã ‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç‡••‚Äì[100745].
‡§á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ö‡•Å‡§∞[‡§∏‡•Å]‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§§‡•á‡§®
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡•ã‡§Ω‡§Ø‡§Ç <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1699528796Screenshot2023-11-09164925.png"/>‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•§

‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1699528858Screenshot2023-11-09165043.png"/>

  1. <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1699528906Screenshot2023-11-09165132.png"/>‡§Ø‡§£‡•ã ‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø-
    ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ã ‡§Ω‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∏‡•Å ‡§π‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§™‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø ‡••‚Äì1008[46].
    ‡§ï‡§ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•à[‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ]‡§∏‡•Å‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§æ-
    [‡§π‡•á]‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ö‡•Å‡§∞‡§™‡•É‡§•‡•Å‡§∂‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ(‡§¨)‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø[‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§°‡§æ]‡§ó‡§É‡•§
    ‡§ï‡•Ç‡§≤‡•á‡§Ω‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø [‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã]‡§™‡§≤‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§∞‡§ö‡§®‡§æ<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1699529145Screenshot2023-11-09165530.png"/>
    <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1699529187Screenshot2023-11-09165559.png"/>‡••‚Äî584[47]

28.<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1699529275Screenshot2023-11-09165720.png"/>‡§£‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•á‡•§
‡§ò‡§ü‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§¶‡§ó‡•ç‡§µ(‡§ó‡•ç‡§¨)‡§ï‡•á‡§® ‡§µ (‡§¨) ‡§µ‡•ã<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1699529353Screenshot2023-11-09165851.png"/>[‡§∞]‡§£‡§É‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§á[‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å]‡§ó‡•å‡§∞‡§®‡•Ä‡§∞‡§É ‡••‚Äì1009[48]
[‡§ï‡•á] ‡§°‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ[1010‡§Æ]……………..‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∏[‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø]‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•á [‡§ö]‡•§
‡§ï‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§ú‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡§§‡§Ø‡•á ………..[‡§∏‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§≤‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•Ä] ‡••‚Äî1011[49]

29……………………………………..

**TRANSLATION.1012 **

(Verse 1 ) .‚Äî [May Vish·πáu guard you, who,] though possessed of a divine body which is marked by the ≈örivatsa1013, or is vet wholly unperceived; [who], though the one cause of final liberation, holds the world fast in the snares of illusion; [and who … ……..]!

(2)‚Äî May the undulating lines of paint……….. protect you,which,from the round breasts of the impassioned Lakshmi transferred unto the rock-like chest of ≈öridhara, are like a beautiful eulogy, set down by the god of love in clear characters, & record of ecstatic amorous dalliance !

(Verse 3).‚Äî……….. a king1014 family. “) named who, having defeated on the battle-field the king of Kanyakubja [who had subdued ?] all princes, obtained exalted sovereignty.

(4).‚ÄîFrom him sprang Ga·πá·∏çadeva, a ruler of the earth in the four quarters, expert in annihilating enemies whose massive arms were terrible through the itching of pride. .,

(5).‚ÄîFrom him was born, [like?] Indra………the illustrious Vidy√¢dharadeva, whose beautiful lotus-feet took rest on the diadems of all kings without exception.

(6).‚Äî As the good son of that king was born Vijayap√¢la, eminent by widespread fame (and) purifying by virtuous conduct; who exterminated all the wicked (and) gladdened all good men; who put an end to the Kali age,…… the earth…….

(7).‚Äî As his son was born K√Ærtivarmadeva, whose pure fame was sung in the three worlds; who, as it were, was Virtue, descended here……to destroy the sin of theKali age (?)….

(8).‚Äî Who indeed vanquished the host of enemies, together with all the six internal enemies1015; who day by day rendered more prosperous the seven constituent parts of the kingdom1016, together with virtue; who extirpated the multitude of thorns in the world, together with the strife induced by the impurity of the Kali age; and who made his command reach the borders of the sea, together verily with his widespread fame.

(9).‚ÄîHis son was the lord,the illustrious king Sallakshanavarmadeva,who always kept the enemies awake by the weight of his prowess;….. a leader of those versed in sacred lore, a kinsman of the virtuous, a store of arts, an abode of good conduct, and a tree of paradise to all suppliants for support.

(10).‚Äî Who, by taking away the riches of enemies and bestowing them on all (his) people of good family, far removed that wretched misery,…… and whose……. to fortune; (and) in (whose) assembly there was not perceived any difference whatever between the kings doing homage to him and his other dependants, from the similarity of their garments, glittering with quantities of gold and jewels.

(11).‚Äî As his son was born Jayavarmadeva, a dwelling‚Äîplace of generosity, truth, policy, and heroism; by the rising sun of whose majesty princes, like lamps……..were deprived of their lustre.

(12).‚ÄîThen the king Prithvivarman,the co-uterine younger brother of the illus trious king Sallaksha·πáavarman, bore, equal to the task, the burden of the hereditary government.

(13).‚Äî Who, hating the ill-behaved (and) greatly delighting in worthy people, desirous of taking lawful wealth (and) then exponding it according to prescript on sacred objects, carefully protecting all beings and wholly intent on securing propriety of conduct, thus practised here‚Äîa noble art‚Äîthe conduct of the golden age.

(14):‚ÄîFrom him was then born the protector of the earth Madanavarman, whose

valour is famous in the three worlds; having witnessed the strength of whose arm people have credited as true the tale of Bhima’s marvellous strength1017.

(Verse 15).‚Äî Before whose name even, ever quickly flees the Chedi king, vanquished in fierce fight; (and) through dread of whom the king of K√¢si always passes his time in friendly behaviour; by whom morcover that ruler of M√¢lava, full of arrogance, was quickly exterminated, while other monarchis, paying homage to him, have enjoyed supreme comfort.

(16).‚Äî From the seed, consisting in the pearls bright like the white-fayed (moon) from the heads of the elephants of his focs, which he ropeatedly sowed on the field of battle, ploughed by the hoofs of impetuously charging horses (and) irrigated by the streams of ‘blood gushing forth from the throats of enemies, there has grown up the creeping plant of (his) fame; that, sprinkled by him with the water (poured out) at donations, has overspread the bower which is the assembly-house1018of (Brahman), sprung from the lotus.

(17).‚Äî Now then will be detailed the venerable lineage of the great ministers of pure conduct, who bore the burden of the government of these kings.

(18).‚ÄîThe son of the creator of the universe, to be honoured by all the worlds, (was) Angiras: in his lineage was born the holy sage Gautama, a store of knowledge; who in the course of disputation, when Sambhu disguised as a M√Æm√¢msaka showed the eye. on his forehead, enraged, at once displayed an eye in the sole of his foot1019.

(19).‚ÄîThat Akshap√¢da,‚Äîfor whom in this world is he not an object of veneration, he who, able to expand the Ny√¢ya doctrine, confuted false reasoning and then estab, lished the supreme greatness of the Lord ?

(20).‚Äî In the thriving family of that abode of the might of fierce penance therc was born in the course of time the wise Prabh√¢sa, the one resting-place of religious merit, the seat of a crowd of excellencies; whom, graced as he was by the brilliant play of overpowering eloquence, virtuous men respectfully went to see, as (people visit) the holy place PrƒÅbhƒÅsa1020,for their welfare.

(21).‚Äî A leader of those who are free from all deceit, (and) highly expert in the abstruse conduct of politics, he, having been (duly) tried, was appointed chief of all the ministers by Dhanga and king Ga·πá·∏ça.

(22).‚Äî(And) the trce of government which had struck very firm roots, when it was made to grow by being sprinkled with the water of his policy, always bore to those two kings the fruit of the three objects of life1021.

(23).‚Äî From him was born the virtuous ≈öivan√¢ga, in understanding and wide sacred knowledge like Dhishana1022;who filled the extent of the regions with his fame, bright like the moon-light, (and) whose might could not be endured by the hosts of enemies in battle.

(24).‚Äî How is it at all possible (duly) to applaud the excellencies of that wise one, who, as soon as he had assumed the post of minister, alone, hy his excellent conduct, gradually made the government of the king Vidy√¢dhara one to which all

the rulers of the earth were rendered for ever tributary, so that it surpassed all others on earth ?

(Verse 25). ‚ÄîAs the moon, grateful to the eyes of mankind, (arose) from the pure sea of milk, so sprang from him Mahƒ´p√¢la, with pleasing brilliant qualities; who fulfilled the purport of his word by truth, that of his understanding by actions which bore good fruit, and that of his wealth by pious and beneficial deeds.

(26).‚ÄîSustaining, to its full extent, the weighty burden of the important affairs of the king Vijayap√¢la, he, in whom valour was united with a blameless policy, became the standard of comparison among good ministers.

(27).‚Äî From him was born, able to bear the weight of the world (and) endowed with endless excellencies, the wise Ananta, the one home of goodness, whose body always was resplendent from virtuous enjoyment.

(28).‚ÄîWhose younger brother was Yoge≈õvara, the seat of numerous excellencies, as (Lakshma·πáa,) the son of Sumitr√¢, was of R√¢ma. devoted

(29).‚Äî (Birth in) this most noble family which hatl risen higher and higher, Br√¢hma≈Üical rank most illustrious, study of the Vedas,spotless sacred knowledge, wealth shared with the learned, heroism always difficult to be withstood in battles, (and) everywhere pleasing but sincere speech,‚Äîwhat is there in which this noble-minded virtuously inclined Ananta did not surpass the world?

(30).‚Äî(Being the king’s) councillor in the very high office of counselling, (the very)’ heart (of the king) in secret confidential matters, constantly [a leader of horses and] elephants among enemies, a superintendent of the forces of the town (?),an unrivalled protector of property,a vanquisher of adversaries,………..the sole chief of all heroes, ‚Äîin what affair was he not the approved minister of the king K√Ærtivarman?

(31).‚ÄîWhen a king has for his guide a minister of noble birth, endowed with understanding, uprightness and similar qualities, then there is clearly nothing so high that it would be difficult for him to attain to. No wonder, then, that the lord K√Ærtivarman by his fame and good acts and prosperity surpassed the son of Dharma1023” (even), when that best of guides was governing the carth.

(32).‚ÄîBy the volumes of smoke of the sacrificial fires which touched the clouds (and) caused all peacocks, by whom they were mistaken for clouds, to dance,……Maghavan………a share of the sacrifice……..1024

(33).‚Äî [His wife was a lady] named √Çsarv√†, born in an illustrious family, venerable for her virtuous conduct, as Anas√ªy√¢ (was) of the sage Atri, (34). And he had also another wife, sprung from a noble race, [who by] patience, good character, uprightness….

(35).‚Äî[She bore to him ?]……..a faultless [son], named Vatsa, like the elevated Sunetra1025," seated in the assembly of the gods (?).

(36)……… of clear understanding (and) pure conduct, a mine of benevolence, and Vishnu, removing faults,…… bravery, dignity, piety,……… Gad√¢dhara, a store of excellencies, V√¢mana, fond of the good, and Pradyumna were [his other sons (?)]……

(Verse 37).‚Äî……..through (his) liking for distinguished qualities, having been properly tried, all were appointed by the king Sallaksha·πáavarman……….. in offices suitable to wise, upright, and valiant men.

(38).‚ÄîThen [the lord] Sallaksha·πáavarman…………. again, in the country of Antarvedi ………..

(39).‚Äî…….. utterly defeated by the excess of his heroism, were made to prostrate themselves at the feet of his master; having cleared the country of thorns (and) dissipated the fears of the subjects,he1026in an unparalleled manner increased their treasure and power.

(40).‚ÄîWhen the venerable Ananta, having abandoned his body in the waters of [the river of] the gods and of the daughter of the Sun1027, had attained ……….to supreme union with Brahman,he, considered the chastiser of the enemies (and) famous for his greatness, was cagerly appointed by the king Jayavarman, near his own person, in the office of Pratih√°ra.

(41).‚ÄîAnd (being) a hereditary servant, born in a noble lineage, upright, of clear intellect, versed in sciences, tried by practice, eloquent, clever, resolute, expert in mounting elephants, horses and chariots, skilled in archery, [secret in council,] endowed with affection and other excellent qualities, (and)……… he subsequently was appointed chief of the ministers by the illustrious king P·πõithvƒ´varman.

(42). Then sustaining the high office of minister, possessed of keen intelligence, he made the government of that king prosper in all its constituent parts, and so he did afterwards that of the king Madana.Having gradually reduced all princes to the state of dependency by applying the six expedients1028and so forth, each in due season, he made (the king’s) sovereignty over the earth characterized by a single umbrella.

(43).‚Äî……….able,……endowed with manifold multitudes of excellencies,illustrious, not haughty, spoken of by people as GadƒÅdhara1029 incarnate(?), . by his depth the ocean, by his understanding surpassing the preceptor [of the gods (?)],‚Äî who [is there that has attained to] greater elevation?

(44).‚ÄîHe has his wife for the procreation of children and his sacred knowledge for the practice of good conduct; the Vedas serve him for the welfare of the earth, and his wealth he has for the benefit of all people. Inclined as his mind is to…….. people in consequence of his conduct indeed believe that with him the Kali age has come to an end (?)

(45).‚ÄîSince he has got for his sons ≈öridhara, Vidy√¢dhara, and the rest, who by their excellent qualities surpass all people, he takes the lead of all family men.

(46).‚ÄîAlways anxious to engage in pious and beneficial acts and other good deeds, ho caused this edifice to be erected, endowed with ……in it there is here the god [N√°r√¢ya·πáa (?)]; for the wealth of the great is employed in acts of piety.

(47).‚ÄîMoreover, with his exceedingly pure wealth, he caused carefully to be built on the boundary of the village of Deddu, a tank, charming with its masonry of many

broad stones; (and) on the banks, not liable to be broken, with a mass of other stones,

(Verse 48).‚Äî……..a collection of hewn stones, by in the place, he caused to be made, built with collection of hewn stones………….the water of which is pale like the moon.

(49).‚ÄîKendi by name (?) …………. and in the proximity of the village by wise one for the benefit of the people…….a tank of good water.

II.

BATESVAR STONE INSCRIPTION OF PARAMARDIDEVA;
OF THE VIKRAMA YEAR 2252.

The stone which bears this inscription1030is said to have been found1031 in an ancient mound at Ba·π≠e≈õvar, a town in the Agra District of the North-Western Provinces, on the right bank of the Jumna, 35 miles south-east of Agra1032;and it is now in the Lucknow Museum. The stone is broken right through from top to bottom; but, the break being fairly clean, the aksharas, which in consequence are gone, are few, and can, with one or two exceptions, be readily supplied. Besides this, the upper proper left corner of the stone is broken away, causing the nearly complete loss of 23 aksharas at the end. of the first, and of eight aksharas at the end of the second line.

The inscription consists of 24 lines. The writing covers a space of about 2’ broad by 1’ 8" high, and, with the exceptions already noted, it is fairly well preserved, so that everything of importance may be read with certainty. But the engraving being rather shallow and the surface of the stone somewhat worn, it is occasionally difficult, and in several places impossible, to trace the superscript letters in the impressions. The size of the letters is between " and “.The characters are N√¢gar√Æ, resembling those of the Mahoba inscriptions, of which photo-lithographs are given in Cunningham’s Arch√¶ological Survey of India,vol. XXI, plates xxii and xxiii.The language is Sanskrit, and, with the exception of the introductory om om namo bhagavate V√°sudev√°ya and the concluding √©rir-astu, the inscription is in verse throughout.It was composed by Devadhara, a son of Gad√¢dhara, who was minister of peace and war of Paramardideva and a son of Lakshmidhara, of the Gau·∏ça lincage; written by Dharmadhara, a younger brother of Devadhara; and engraved by Mah√¢r√¢ja (?), the son of Somar√¢ja (verses 30-32).As regards orthography, bis denoted by the sign for v everywhere except in udbabh√∫vur, line 10, babh√∫va, lines 13, 14, 16, 20 and 22, and bibhartti, line 24; the dental sibila·πát is fifteen times used for the palatal sibilant (e.g., in Saure≈õ, line 1, vindsa, line 6, &c.), and the palatal for the dental in saro, line 11, √°≈õ√≠d, line 14, and sachiveshu, line 21; before sibilants and the dental n is employed instead of anusv√°ra, in the interior of simple words in van≈õas, line 2, pay√°nsi, line 9, hanso-vatansita¬∫, line 11, hansas, l·ªãne 14, pum√°nsam, line 21, (but not in avata·πÅsa·∏•, line 2), and, exceptionally, at the end

of a word in niramku≈õan-≈üa√±cha¬∫, line 9, adhikan-harin·µí, line 10, and vidy√°val√°n-sa, line 22. Besides, ujjvala is, as usual, spelt ujvala in lines 14 and 18.In respect of lexicography, it may be noted that the word vibha·πÖgi apparently is used in the sense of bha·πÖgi, in line 12.

The proper object of the inscription is, to record (in verses 25-29) that Sallaksha·πáa, the minister of the king Paramardideva,built a temple of Vish·πáu,and a temple of ≈öiva at which the inscription was put up; and that this second temple was completed by Purushottama,the son of Sallaksha·πáa and his successor in the office of minister, after the death of his father. And by way of introduction the inscription (in verses 3-13) gives the genealogy of the king,and (in verses 14-24) that of his ministers. All we learn regarding the former is, that from Atri’s eye sprang the moon, and from the moon the ChƒÅndr√¢treya princes; that one of them was Madanavarman, whose son was Ya≈õovarman, whose son again was the ruling prince Paramardideva. The lineage of the ministers, on the other hand,is as follows:in the gotra of Vasish·π≠ha there was Lakshmƒ´dhara; his son was Vatsar√¢ja,and his son again L√¢ha·∏ça; L√¢ha·∏ça had for his wife PrabhƒÅ, who bore to him Sallaksha·πáa, whose son was Purushottama. Of these, L√¢hada was chief minister of Madanavarman, while Sallaksha·πáa and Purushottama held the same position under Paramardideva. It may be noted that in the account of the ministers the name of the prince Ya≈õovarman is omitted.

The inscription is dated (in verse 34), in words only, in the Vikrama year counted by the wings (2), the faces of ≈öiva (5), and the √Çdityas (12), i.e., in the Vikrama year 1252, on the 5th lunar day of the bright half of A√©vina, on a Sunday. The possible” European equivalents for Vikrama 1252, √Ç≈õvina ≈õukla 5, would be:‚Äî

for the northern current year,‚ÄîWednesday, 21st September, A.D. 1194;
for the northern expired or southern current year, Sundays‚Äî10th September,
A.D. 1195, when the fifth tithi of the bright half ended 14 hours 14 minutes after mean sunrise ;

for the southern expirod year,‚ÄîSaturday, 28th September, A.D. 1196.

The true date accordingly is Sunday, 10th September, A.D. 1195, and the Vikrama year mentioned in the inscription must be taken to be the northern expired, or, possibly, the southern current year.

‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡§ø[‡§∞‡§æ‡§•] ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç1038 ‡•• - [6].

6. ‡§Ö‡§ï‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§≠[‡§™‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡•á] ‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§≤‡§ø‡§Æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡§É ‡§ï‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡§¶‡§É ‡•§
‡§Ø‡•Å‡§µ‡•á‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§∏ (‡§∂) ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§ø1039[‡§≠‡•à‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö‡§æ]“‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§ø ‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ [‡§®‡•Ç*] ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Ä1037 ‡••” -[ 7 ] .
‡§Ö‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§ ‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ã‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§§‡§§‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§á‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§µ‡•Å‡§ß‡•á‡§É1040" ‡•§

7.‡§Ø‡•ã‡§≠‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§ó‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§Æ[‡§π‡•á‡§≤]‡§∞‡§∂‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§Æ‡§£‡§ø‡§É1041 .") ‡••"- [8].
‡§ï‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§ó‡§π‡§ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ß‡§µ‡§≤‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡•§
‡§ï‡•á‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ú‡§æ[‡§§‡§æ ‡§µ]‡§§ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§™‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ ‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ñ‡§æ1042 ‡••"‚Äî[8].
‡§Ü‡§∏‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ã ‡§®

8. ‡§¨‡§®‡§∞‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•å‡§≤‡§ø‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§ü‡§≤‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡•Ä‡§†‡§É ‡•§
‡§Ö‡§ñ‡§¨‡§ó‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§ö‡§ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•[‡§¶‡•Ä]‡§à‡§™‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§à‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§É ‡•• -[10].
‡§™‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø [‡§§]‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ï‡§•‡•à‡§µ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡•§
‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡§™‡§ø ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç1041 .") ‡••"- [11].

9. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ö‡§≤‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§ï‡•Å‡§≠‡§æ[[]‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§§‡§ß‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§™‡•Å[[]: ‡•§
‡§ï‡§µ‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ø (‡§∂‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø) ‡§§‡•Ä‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ ‡§™‡§ø‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§™[‡§Ø‡§æ]‡§®‡•ç‡§∏‡§ø1043" ‡§§‡•ã‡§Ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•á1044 (‡§∂‡•á): ‡••"- [12].
‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§¶‡§π‡§®‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§Ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø1045 “

10. ‡§∏‡§™‡§®‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§∏‡•Å‡•§

[‡§â[‡§¶‡•ç]]1046‡§≠‡•Ç‡§µ‡•Å‡§∞‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï[‡§®‡•ç‡§π]‡§∞‡§ø‡§Æ‡§£‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ(‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ï‡•ã‡§Æ‡§≤‡§§‡•É‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§É1047‡••- [13].
‡§Ö‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∏‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ó‡•ã[‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç*] ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•à‡§ï‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡•§
‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•Å(‡§∂‡•Å) ‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡§Ø‡•ã -

**L. 11. ‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ ‡§Æ‡•å‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•å‡§ò‡§æ‡§É ‡••‚Äî[104814] .
‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡§∏‡§æ (‡§∂‡§æ)‡§∏‡•ç‡§≤‡§Æ (‡§∏) ‡§∞‡•ã‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§∏‡•ã‡§µ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§≠‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§É‡•§1049‚Äî [15].
‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§ß‡§∞‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø‡§§[‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ] ‡§¶‡§∏‡•Ä (‡§∂‡•Ä) ‡§§‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø (‡§∂‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø) ‡§∏‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞(‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞) ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§Æ‡•å‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç ‡••635 **

12. ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§∏ (‡§∂) ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§≤‡•á‡§ñ‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Å[‡§ü‡§æ]‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡§∞‡§£‡§É‡•§
‡§¶‡§ø‡§ó‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡•Ä‡§®‡§™‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ß‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§∏[[‡§µ‡•á]]1050 ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø [‡§®‡•ç‡§§ ‡••[] ‚Äî]1048[16].
[‡§Ö] ‡§≤‡§≠‡§§ ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡§™‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§Ø‡§∏‡§¶‡§®‡§Æ‡•á-

**13. ‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§°‡§ø‡§ú‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§É‡•§
‡§ú‡§≤‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ [‡§ó‡§≠‡•Ä‡§∞]: ‡§∂‡•á‡§≤‡§µ‡§°‡•á‡§Ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§∏‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§¨[‡§≠‡•Ç]‡§µ ‡••1051‚Äî[17].
‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≤‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§ó‡§£‡§µ [ ‡§§‡§¨ ‡§Æ‡§ø*] ‡§µ‡•ã‡§¶‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ã‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•ã‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•Å (‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•Å ) ‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ‡•§
‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡§°‡§ø‡§ú‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ **

**14. ‡§¨‡§≠‡•Ç‡§µ ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§É‡••‚Äî[105218].
‡§Ü‡§∂‡•Ä (‡§∏‡•Ä) ‡§¶‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§Ö‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ß‡•Å‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ú‡•ã‚Äù ‡§≤‡§æ‡§á‡§°‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡•Å[‡§™‡•ã‡§∑] ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≤‡§µ‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§∞‡•á[‡§Æ‡•á] [‡§ö*] ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡••‚Äî1053 [10]. **
‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§ñ (‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ) ‡§≤-

15. ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§¶‡§®‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§É‡•§
‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á[‡§µ?] ‡§ú‡§ø‡§ó‡•Ä‡§∑‡•Å‡§É ‡§™‡§Ç‡§ö‡§µ‡§æ‡§£ ‡§á‡§µ ‡§∏‡•Ä (‡§∂‡•Ä) ‡§§‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§ñ‡§Ç‡••‚Äî[105420].
‡§ï‡•Å‡§ü‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨ (‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨) ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•å‡§¢‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ã‡§¶‡§®‡•á ‡§™[‡§ü‡•Ä*]‡§Ø‡§∏‡•Ä‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§∞‡§ø‡§ú‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ ‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§Ø‡§µ-

16. ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§≠‡§æ‡••‚Äî1055[21].
‡§§‡§§‡•ã ‡§¨‡§≠‡•Ç‡§µ ‡§π‡§ø‡§ú‡§∞‡§æ [‡§á]‡§Æ‡§ö‡§É ‡§∏‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§¨‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö[‡§≠‡•Ç]‡§ö‡§ø[‡§®‡•á]‡§µ‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§É ‡§ö‡•ã‡§∑‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≤‡•á‡§®‡••‚Äî1056[22].
‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‚Äî[‡§∞‡§Æ]‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ú‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç
‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞-

17. ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§≠‡•Ç‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡•É‡§¢‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•å‡§¢‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ã[‡§¶‡•ã]‡§¶‡§Ø‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ(‡§°‡§æ)‡§≤‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§Ç‡§ó‡§∏‡§æ(‡§∂‡§æ) ‡§µ‡§ï‡§ü‡•Å‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡•É‡§∂‡§æ‡§Ç
‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞(‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞)‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§∏‡§∞[‡§∏‡§ø]‡§ï[‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ]\‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§≠‡§µ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§§‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç [‡••‚Äî[1057. “)23].
‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡§®-

18.‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ ‡§≠‡§ú‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§¶‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç
‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§É‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ï‡§Ç‡§ü‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§ø‡§®‡•ã ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•á‡§ï‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø‡§¶‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•ã‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ(‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ) ‡§≤‡§Ç
‡§µ‡•à‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§É ‡§∏ ‡§® ‡§ï‡§¶‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§π‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§ß‡•Ä-

L.19. ‡§∞‡•á ‡••‚Äî[24].
[‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ]‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§®‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡•É‡§∏(‡§∂)‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§™‡§¶‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡••‚Äî1058. “)[25].
‡§Ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ø[‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö] ‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡§Æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ[‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø]‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§Æ‡•å‡§≤‡•á‡§É‡•§
‡§® ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•Å ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§¶‡•á-

20. ‡§µ‡§É ‡§ï‡•à‡§≤‡§æ‡§∏‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§É‡••‚Äî[105926].
‡§¨‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§µ (‡§¨) ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§¨‡§≠‡•Ç‡§µ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡•§
‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö ‡§®‡§Ç‡§¶‡§ï‡•ã‡§≠‡•Ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§∏[‡§§]‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡••‚Äî [27].
‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡§Æ‡§π‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö-

21. ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§∂‡•Å‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§®‡§Ø‡§§ ‡§∂(‡§∏) ‡§ö‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡§ø ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ ‡§π‡§ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø1060‡••‚Äî1061[28].
‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•Å (‡§∂‡•Å)‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞(‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞)‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•á [‡§µ‡§π*]‡§∞‡§ø‡§£[:]‡•§
‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§®‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§¶‡§Æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§π‡§Ç‡§∏‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡§ø-

22.
‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡••1062. “)‚Äî [29].
[‡§ó‡•å] ‡§°‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•á‡§ï‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ó‡§¶‡§æ‡§ß‡§∞‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§ß‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§®‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡•§
‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§∏1063‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞[‡§π]‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡§ö‡§ø‡§µ‡•ã ‡§¨‡§≠‡•Ç‡§µ ‡••‚Äî1064[30].
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§ß‡§∞‡§É ‡§ï‡§µ‡•Ä-

23. ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏ (‡§∂)‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•§
‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ú‡•ã‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ß‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§∞‡§É ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡•Ç‡§π‡§≤‡§æ‡§π‡§æ(‡§π‡§æ)‡§≤‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§≤‡•á‡§ñ‡•• ‚Äî1065[31].
‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ö‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§∂‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
….[‡§ß‡•Ä]‡§∞‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§É ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡••‚Äî1066. “)[32].
‡§∂‡§Ç-

24. ‡§≠‡•Å‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§¨‡§ø‡§≠‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§ü‡§æ‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ‡§™‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§≠‡•Å[‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§]‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•§
‡§™‡§æ[‡§•‡•ã]‡§ß‡§ø‡§ú‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§ö ‡§ï‡•å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§≠‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡••‚Äî1065[33].
‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑[‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ]‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§µ[‡§§‡•ç‡§∏]‡§∞‡•á‡•§
‡§Ü‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§∂‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§∞‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§∞‡•á‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§É‡••[‚Äî[34].]144. “)
‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å [‡••*]

TRANSLATION.

**Om! Om ! Adoration to the holy V√°sudeva ! **

(Verse 1).‚Äî Victorious are the arms of ≈öauri1067,the trees which yield the four objects of life1068, s every hair on which [becomes] erect (with pleasure) at the close embrace of Lakshmƒ´.

(2).‚Äî May he who holds the discus in his hand1069, protect [you], he who under the pretence of ………………….. touched the breasts of the daughter of the ocean !

(Verse 3).‚ÄîFrom the eye‚Äîlotus of Atri was born the god1070 (who is) the ornament of the beloved husband of the daughter of the lord of mountains. From him [spiang] this race [which]……has shone with its bright fame, as if (decorated) with pearls.

(4).‚ÄîIn it there were born, of pleasing conduct, the [Ch√¢ndr√¢treya] princes, who by their powerful massive arms have crushed the hosts of enemies.

(5).‚ÄîAmong them appeared the lord of the earth Madanavarman, who with his flashing sword scattered (his) adversaries (and) whose vigour became known by his onslaught on hostile kings, elated with pride; (resembling) the great Indra ‘who cut off the wings of the mountains with his thunderbolt (and) whose might became famous by his killing (the demon) Vala.

(6).‚ÄîThe wives of his enemies,‚Äîstanding sighing in their palaces, addressing in pitiful terms their favourite parrots, looking, their sight dimmed by streams of tears, at the young ones of their pet antelopes, what did they not do when, afraid of him, they were about to depart for the forest, (and) when their minds had no hope ever to return?

(7).‚Äî In battle his sword, applied by him to the broad frontal globes, covered with red lead, of the elephants of adversaries, (and) darkened by the bees1071 (which stuck to it), was by his enemies seen moving rapidly to their own destruction, like RƒÅhu1072,coming in contact with the new(ly risen) sun.

(8).‚Äî As the moon, the crest-jewel of Mahe≈õvara, (arose) from the ocean, so was born from him Ya≈õpvarman, who was an ornament of great rulers, causing oy to the people.

(9).‚Äî Whose fame, spreading in the three worlds with the loveliness of the jasmine and the moon, made the hair (of men) appear white, and thus caused the unprecedented. notion that people, before they had attained to old age, had, alas! turned grey.

(10).‚Äî From him has sprung Paramardideva whose foot-stool is pale-red with the lustre of the crest-jewels of kings bowing down (before him,and) who crushes the pride in their arms of crowds of antagonists, filled with no mean conceit.

(11.)‚Äî How could one even mention mutual conflict in the reign of this (king), who has brought about the union of both fortune and eloquence (in his own person) ?

(12).‚Äî When he marched out to conquer the regions, the clouds of dust raised by the hoofs of his horses, suffering from intense heat as it were because they had devoured the rays of the sun, swallowed the water of the sea.

(13).‚Äî Although the fire of his prowess spreads, unchecked, over the habitations of his rivals, there have yet on all sides sprung up in abundance tender blades of grass dark-green like emeralds.-

(14).‚Äî Now there is, well known in the three worlds, the family of Vasish·π≠ha, the unique receptacle of good acts, in which were born sages of pure conduct, as heaps of pearls (are found) in the occan.

(15).‚Äî Among these, there was in the course of time Lakshmidhara, a swan sporting in the lake of all sciences, who ornamented the lotus-feet of the husband of ≈öiv√¢; an ocean of the pearls of good qualities rivalling the brilliantly shining sun.

(16).‚ÄîThe lines of smoke of whose bright sacrificial fires, with their numerous clearly visible undulating lines, assumed the beautiful appearance of braids of hair (put) playfully on the big breasts of the women of the quarters.

(Verse 17).‚Äî From him took his origin the chief of the twice‚Äîborn Vatsar√¢ja, an unique receptacle of good conduct, a home of propriety; who was deep like the ocean, reputed for his firmness like a mountain, and, like the enemy of Mura,” the resort of fortune.

(18).‚Äî Endowed as he was with a crowd of spotless excelencies and delighted at the elevation of friends, his righteous wealth became an object of enjoyment for pure twice-born people, just as the faultless beauty of the lotus, which has many clean fibres and blooms at the rising of the sun, is enjoyed by white birds.

(19). He had a son, named L√¢ha·∏ça, a swan in the sea of sacred lore, who nurtured the play of graceful utterance and dwelt, as in lakes, in the minds of good men.

(20).‚Äî Him, whose person was beautified by (his acquaintance with) the arts, the king Madana placed at the head of his counsellors, just as the god of love does the cool-rayed (moon), when about to subdue the three worlds.

(21).‚ÄîThat king of the twice-born had (for his wife), dear to his heart, Prabha, (a lady) dexterous in bringing into full bloom the family-lotus.

(22).‚ÄîFrom her sprang the king of the twice-born” in human form, Sallaksha·πáa, a receptacle of pleasing conduct; through whom, free from stains, Paramardideva has become a lord of the earth with three eyes.

(23).‚Äî Having placed on whose arms the whole [burden] of government, the illustrious lord of the earth, the brave Paramardin, a cause of excessive joy to those whose eyes are like the eyes of frightened young deer and who were filled with boundless love, always let his mind delight in the playful art of ornamenting (their bodies).

(24).‚Äî Being the abode of the play of fortune, smiling with joy at the elevation of friends, having laid seditious people quite low, being endowed with excellent qualities (and) the one remover of the distress of the people, it was quite clear in the three worlds that he shared the properties of the day-lotus, which is the abode of the play of Lakshm√Æ, blooms at the rising of the sun, is quite free from thorns, has many fibres (and) cools in an unsurpassed manner the heat of people; but he differed (from the day-lotus) in this that he was never averse from the supreme lord of the twice-born.

(25). He erected a temple of Vishnu, containing (an image of) Hari, which with its top always touches his own middle stride.

(26).‚ÄîAnd he also caused this crystal-white habitation of the moon-crested (≈öiva) to be built, residing in which the god has never turned his thoughts to dwelling on Kailasa.

(27).‚ÄîFrom him sprang (a son), named Purushottama,” whose fame has taken possession of the sky, whose appearance is recognized to be beautiful, and whose crowd of excellencies causes rejoicing;

______________________________

i.e., Vishnu, the husband of Lakshmi, the goddess of fortuno.

i.e., the moon; and, accordingly, his master Paramardidera becomes the lord with three eyes,

i.e., ≈öiva, on earth, Sallakabapa being the third eye of the king.

i.e., ≈öiva, in the case of Sallakshans; and the moon, ip the case of the day‚Äîlotus.

i.e., the sky

Purushottama is one of the names of Vish·πáu; and some of the terms of the original verse are so chosen as to be applicable also to that deity; for sudarfans and nandaka are the names of Vishnu‚Äî Krishna’s disons and sword, aud p√Æt√¢m‚Äî tara would denote his yellow garment, Vishnu himself being called Pitambara, ‘dressed in yellow clothes.”

(Verse 28).‚Äîwhom, old in conduct that deserves to be glorified in the three worlds, though still a youth, the king Paramardin has appointed to be chief of his ministers.; for that which makes a man valued in the world, is his qualities.

(29).‚Äî He, pure in his conduct, has completed this praiseworthy work of his parent who roams about in Brahman’s world1073,which had been left incomplete.‚Äî

(30).‚Äî ƒΩakshmidhara, the unique ornament of the Gau·∏ça family, had a son named Gad√¢dhara, a supreme chief of poets; who, first among the learned, was the great minister of peace and war of Paramardideva.

(31).‚Äî His son, the chief of poets, Devadhara, has composed this unequalled eulogy; and his younger brother, the steadfast Dharmadhara, the young poet, has eagerly written it.

(32).‚Äî……… son of Somar√¢ja, the steadfast Mah√¢r√¢ja (?), who rouses the admiration of all artizans, has engraved it.‚Äî

(33).‚Äî As long as ≈öambhu wears his tresses of matted hair and the light which has risen from the ocean1074,and Vish·πáu his breast (?) and the Kaustubha jewel, so long may the fame (of the founders) and (their) work endure!

(34).‚Äî In the year of Vikrama, counted by the wings (2), the faces1075 of the three-eyed (≈öiva) (5), and the √Çdityas (12), on the fifth (lunar day) of the bright half of √Ç≈õvina, on the day of the lord of the day1076.

May fortuno attend!

XXVI.‚ÄîJHANSI STONE INSCRIPTION OF SALLAKSHANASIMHA (?).

**BY PROFESSOR F. KIELHORN, PH.D., C.I.E., G√ñTTINGEN. **

The stone which bears this inscription was found, in July 1887, in the walls of the ruined Fort of Jh√¢ns√Æ, in the North‚Äî Western Provinces, and is now in the Lucknow Museum. It measures about 3‚Ä≤ 1‚Ä≥ by 1‚Ä≤ 7‚Ä≥, and contains fragments of 32 lines of writing disposed on the stone as may be seen from the photo-lithograph. The original inscription must have been a very large one; for not only did it contain more than 32 lines, but the actually remaining portions of the lines 21‚Äî24 enable us also to infer that each line, in its complete state, held about 90 aksharas, and measured at least 4’ 6” in length. The existing writing is on the whole well preserved. The size of the letters is between 7/8and 1”.The characters are N√¢garƒ´of about the twelfth century. The language is Sanskrit; and, what remains of the inscription, is in verse.The inscription was written and engraved very carefully; and in respect of orthography it is only necessary to state that b is throughout denoted by the sign for v, and that the dental sibilant is occasionally employed for the palatal.

The inscription is in so fragmentary a state that I fail to perceive the object for which it was composed, and am unable to derive from it any connected sense; and, accordingly, I can do little more than point out the proper names which occur in it.

In line 2 the inscription speaks of the river of the gods, the Ganges, as the resting-place of Kany√¢kubja; from which I would infer that this record has reference to the

rulers of KanyƒÅkubja themselves, or to certain chiefs who owed allegiance to them. According to line 4, the moon begat a son named Jayanta. Lines 5 and 6 appear to mention two chiefs-Sidhuka and M√¢maka (?)‚Äî of whom the elder one became king. Other chiefs, who kept the Bhillas (line 7) in order, are spoken of in the following lines which appear to record the building of a tank, the establishment of a grove-called (line 8) KanhapƒÅdi (?),-and the erection of a temple, and contain the name of the village Dugdhakupya (line 10). In line 15 three chiefs appear to be spoken of, the second of whom is called Lakkhata and the third Raja·∏•p√¢la. Line 18 records that somebody married two wives who somehow or other are brought in connection with the Chaulukya family, and one of whom bore the name R√¢jaladevi. In line 20 we meet with the prince Kirtivarman who is protected from somebody (the Chedi king Kar·πáa (?)); and line 21 speaks of three kings, one of whom appears to be again Kƒ´rtivarman. Line 23 mentions the son of the illustrious Satyavatƒ´, who perhaps defeated a certain Ga·πáapƒÅla (?), and did something to the rule of Uday√¢ditya, the lord of Avanti. Line 25 perhaps contains the name Nrisimha, and line 26 that of the illustrious Hira or Hir√¢msu; and line 27 mentions, in a manner as if he had been living at the time, the illustrious Sallaksha·πáasimha, who probably was engaged in fight with the troops of the Yavanas (line 30) or Muhammadans.

Other inscriptions may yet be discovered which will throw light on this one: for the present, I can only say that, of the princes mentioned here, Kƒ´rtivarman probably is the Chandella1077 ‘king of that name, the contemporary of the Chedi king Kar·πáadeva; and UdayƒÅditya the ruler of M√¢lava, who is spoken of in two Chedi inscriptions of the period; but that I see no cogent reason for identifying Sallaksha·πáasimha with the Chandella king Sallaksha·πáavarman, or for assigning this inscription to the Chandella rulers.

TEXT.
