  1. ………………………(‡§ö)1088 ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§µ‡§¶‡§®‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å(‡§≠‡§ø)‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§µ‡§™‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡•• (‡§ö)1089 ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞(‡§µ‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø) ‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§µ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ç……….

  1. …………………….. ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•• [[‡§∏?]]1088 [‡§∏‡•É?]‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á[‡§µ‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞?]‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§Ç‡§µ[‡§®?] ‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ï‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ã‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§ß‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•ç[‡•ß]…………..

  2. “‡§ï‡•Ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§®1087‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•à‡§É‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§™‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡•Ä‡§≤‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§ï‡§™‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡•à‡§É‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ[‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡•à‡§É]‡§π‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ[‡§¶?] ………………

  3. ……………………. “‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ1088‡§∏‡•Å‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∞‡•ã‡§π‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡§É‡•§ [‡§ï‡•Å]‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä ‡§á‡§§‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§≤‡•ã‡§ö‡§®‡§™‡§•‡•ã‡§ö‡•Ä‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ[‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ]‡§∏‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ[‡§≤‡•ã]……….

  4. [‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ1037]‡•§ ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•á (‡§≤‡•à?) ‡§¨‡§Ç‡§µ‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§ï‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§É‡§™‡§¶‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ö‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç………

  5. ………………..[[‡§µ‡§æ]]1088‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§É‡•• “‡§Ö‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä(‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä) ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Æ‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ç(‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•Ç)‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø‡§∞‡•å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§É ‡§ï ‡§®‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§É‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§∂‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ……

………………………‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø1088 (‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø): ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ö‡•Å‡§∞‡§§‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§ñ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∏‡§ü‡•Ä‡§∏‡•å ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§É ‡§Ü‡§™‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•å‡§¢‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§ø ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡§ø ‡§∞‡§ú‡§É‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ [‡§§‡•É‡•ß]………

  1. ……………. “‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç1088 ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø (‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø) ‡§∞‡§§‡§≤‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•å‡§ï‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‡•§‡§™‡•å‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§ñ‡§≤‡§¶‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡§ó‡§∞‡§Æ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§∞‡•á(‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ?)……..

  2. ……………….. ‚Äú‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§µ1088 (‡§ú) ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡§ø‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§É‡•§ ‡§¨‡•Å(‡§¨‡•Å)‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§É‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§≤‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ß‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§¶‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡§∏ ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§É…………

  3. ………………… “[‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ç1088] ‡§ß‡§µ‡§≤‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡§ø‡§≠‡•Å‡§ú‡§¨‡•å‡§≤‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§≤‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§µ‡§π ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§£‡•à‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö……….

  4. ……………….. “[‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø1088 ‡§∏‡•à]‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§•‡§£‡•á[‡§µ] ‡§ú‡§Ø‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•Ä‡§¶‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•• “‡§∏‡•å(‡§∂‡•å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§Ç‡§ö‡§§‡§®‡•Å…….

  5. ………………….[[‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•ç‡§£]]1089‡§Æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§ß‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§ï‡§≤‡§ù‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§ö‡•Ç‡§°‡§æ‡§Æ‡§£‡•á‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§®‡•É[‡§™‡§§‡§ø] ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ(‡§µ‡§æ) ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø……..

L. 24. [‡§™‡•ç‡§∞]‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§µ‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡•• ‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ1090 ‡§ï‡•É‡§∞‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•å(‡§∂‡•å)‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡§¶‡•É[‡§∂‡•ã ‡§®‡•å]‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§ñ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡§™‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø

<MISSING_FIG href=”../books_images/U-IMG-1700746849Screenshot2023-11-23191009.png”/>

  1. ‚Äî‚Äî U[‡§Æ ? ]‡§¶‡§µ‡§®‡§ø‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡•Ä ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π‡•ã ‡§®‡•É‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π‡§É ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§§‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§∂‡§ø‡§∞‡§É‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å ………..

  2. …………[‡§∂‡•Å]‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§π‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§≠‡•Ç‡§É‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§π‡•Ä‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•Å[‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ ?] …………….

  3. ………………‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§É1091 ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§£[‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π] ‡§è‡§µ ‡§ú‡§®‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡•Ä‡§§‡•Ä‡§≠‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§≠‡•É‡§∂‡§Ç ………………….

  1. …………….[..[‡§£]‡•Ä ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É]1087 ‡§∂‡§ñ‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø[‡§®‡§Ø‡§ø]‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ………

  2. ………………….[[‡§ï]‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ã‡§ó‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§É]1092‡•• ‡§∂‡•å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ1093 ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞[‡§•‡§ø]………………..

………………………….‡§Ø‡§µ‡§®‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡§ó‡§∏‡•à‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§∞‡§ø1094……………………

  1. ……………………………..‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞………………………

  2. ……………………………………‡§Æ‡•å ‡§∞‡§£1095……………….

———–

XXVII.- A CHANDELLA INSCRIPTION FROM MAHOBA.

BY E. HULTZSCH, PH.D.

The stone, which bears the subjoined inscription, was discovered by General Cunningham in 1865 at Mahob√¢1096.¬π Having been lost sight of for some time1097,it turned up again in the All√¢h√¢b√¢d Museum, where General Cunningham saw it in 18721098. His volume published in 1885 contains a facsimile of the inscription1099. In the same year, I took an impression of it at All√¢h√¢b√¢d, and published a transcript with a short abstract in German after my return to Europe1100. The original stone is now preserved in the Lakhnau Museum.

The stone, which bears the inscription, is broken both on the right hand and at the bottom. The preserved part ends with the first syllables of the 29th verse of a genealo- gical account of the Chandella dynasty. Of the preceding 28 verses, not a single one is complete, and one (13) is entirely lost. But even the few existent fragments contain some important data for the history of the Chandellas.

The inscription opens with an invocation of ≈öiva. Verse 5 ends with the words:-‘From this beloved of the night (i.e., the moon) there sprang a race beloved by all,’ and the next two verses seem to have treated of the kings of the lunar race. Among these there was NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa (v. 8). Only three syllables remain of the next verse.

Verse 10 begins as follows:- Then there was that king, Jej√† by name, after whom Jej√†bhukti was (named), just as this earth (prÃ•ithivi) after PrÃ•ithu. His younger brother, called Vij√† ……‘The two brothers Jej√¢ and Vij√¢ are identical with Jeji√†ka and Vijj√†ka, who are mentioned in another fragmentary inscription1101. Professor Kielhorn has further identified both pairs of names with Jaya≈õakti and Vijaya≈õakti1102’ or VijayƒÅ1103, the sons of V√¢kpati. According to verse 10 of the present inscription, Jej√† (or Jeji√†ka) gave his name to Jej√¢bhukti (also called Jej√¢bhuk·π≠ƒ´ka1104 or Jejakabhukti1105), ’the dominion of Jej√¢ (or Jej√¢ka).’ This old name of Bundelkhand, the country which was ruled over by the Chandellas, is the original of the vernacular form Jaj√¢h√ªt√Æ or Jaj√¢hoti1106,” just as the modern Tirhut is derived from Tirabhukti1107.

The purport of the mutilated verses 11 to 16 cannot be ascertained. Verse 17 is almost complete and runs as follows: There appeared a blessing for the earth, called the illustrious Dha·πÖga, who caused the destruction of his enemies and who, by the strength of his arms, equalled even the powerful Hamvira, who had proved a heavy burden for the earth.’ Hamv√Æra or Hamb√Æra is a further corruption of Hammira, the Sanskritized form of which appears on the coins of the Path√¢n kings of Delhi1108 as a contemporary of Samgr√¢mar√¢ja (A. D. 1003 to 1028), is probably meant for Mahm√ªd of Ghazna.")." Professor Kielhorn has published three inscriptions of Dha·πága1109," which are dated in Samvat 1011, 1055 and 1059, or A. D. 954, 998 and 1002. The third inscription was composed after Dhanga’s death, which it mentions. Accordingly the Hambira or Amir, who is stated to have been Dhanga’s contemporary, seems to be identical either with Sabuktagin (A. D. 977 to 997) or with his son Mahmud of Ghazna, whose first two expeditions to India fell in A. D. 1000 and 1001. Firishta1110reports that Jayap√¢la, the king of Lahore, was, on the occasion of his second defeat by Sabuktag√Æn, supported with troops and money by the king of Kala√±jara. As K√•la√±jara, after Yasovarman who conquered it1111,seems to have been the capital of the Chandellas1112, the Chandella kings Dha·πága, Devavarman, and Madanavarman, bear the title of Kala√±jarddhipati or ’lord of Kalafijura.")," it is not improbable that this remark refers to Dhanga, and that Hambira has to be identified with

Sabuktag√Æn, and not with Ma·∏•m≈´d of Ghazna. That Dhanga was far from victorious, is indirectly confirmed by the subjoined inscription, which says only that he equalled,’ but not that he conquered, Hambira.

Verse 18 is again mutilated. Verse 19 describes Dhanga’s son and successor Ganda: From him (viz., Dha·πÖga) there sprang an ornament of the earth, called the illustrious Ga·πá·∏ça, an unrivalled hero, who bore all the parts of the earth on his on his armas, and the fierce fire of whose wrath ……’ General Cunningham has satisfactorily identified Ganda with Nand√¢, king of K√¢la√±jara, who, according to the Mu·∏•ammadan historians, was twice attacked by Ma·∏•mad of Ghazna in A. D. 1021 and 10231113.

Verse 20 is incomplete. Verse 21 gives the name of Ga·πá·∏ça’s son and successor : From him (viz., Ga·πá·∏ça) there sprang that king Vidy√¢dhara, who gathered the flowers of the fame of his enemies Verse 22 probably refers to the same Vidy√¢dhara :- Bhojadeva, together with Kalachuri-chandra (i.e., the moon of the Kalachuris), worshipped, full of fear, like a pupil, (this) master of warfare, who had caused the destruction of the king of Kanyakubja, and who was lying on a couch. As the three Chandella kings Ganda, Vidy√¢dhara, and Vijayap√¢la must have reigned between Samvat 10551114and Samvat 1107, the date of the grant of Devavarman1115," or A. D. 998 and 1050,- Bhojadeva’ seems to be identical with Bhojadeva of Dh√¢r√¢, for whom we have the two dates A. D. 1021 and 10421116.‘The moon of the Kalachuris refers to one of the Kalachuri kings of Chedi, perhaps Kokalla II1117." The king of Kany√¢kubja’ cannot be identified at present, as we know nothing of the kings of Kanauj between A. D. 9481118 and 10971119.

Verse 23 contains the name of Vidyadhara’s successor :- There was (a king) called Vijayap√¢la, whose conquest of the world was stopped (only) by the ocean 25 As we learn from. verse 24, he was a contemporary of G√¢ngeyadeva of Chedi, who was reigning about A.D. 10301120:- When G√¢·πÖgeyadeva, who had conquered the world, perceived before him (this) terrible one the lotus of his heart closed the knot (i.e., the flower ?) of pride in battle.’

The inscription omits mentioning Devavarman, whose grant is dated in Sa·πÅvat 1107 or A. D. 10501121. Verse 25 mentions the reign of his brother K√Ærtivarman, whose inscription is dated in Samvat 1154 or A. D. 10981122:- From him (i.e., Vijayap√¢la) there sprang the illustrious Kirtiva[rman], (who was endowed) with all the virtues of Bharata Verse 26 records that Kirtivarman conquered Lakshmi- kar·πáa:- Just as Purushottama (Vish·πáu), having produced the nectar by churning with the mountain (Mandara) (the rolling (milk) ocean1123," whose high waves had swal- lowed many mountains, obtained (the goddess) Lakshmi together with the elephants (of the eight regions),-he (viz., K√Ærtivarman), having acquired fame by crushing with his strong arm the haughty Lakshmikar·πáa, whose armies had destroyed many

princes, obtained splendour in this world together with elephants.’ Lakshmikar·πáa is identical with Karna of Chedi1124," whose defeat at the hands of Kirtivarman is related in the prologue of Krishnami≈õra’s Prabodhachandrodaya. This drama was acted before K√Ærtivarman at the command of his general, a Br√¢hma·πáa named Gopala, who had just vanquished Kar·πáa and again placed Kirtivarman on the throne1125. Karna is three times mentioned in the prologue:‚Äî

1. In a Sansk·πõit verse, the importance of which was first recognized and its bearing explained by General Cunningham1126:He (viz., Gop√¢la), having overcome the strong Kar·πáa, caused the rise of the illustrious king K√Ærtivarman, just as discrimination, having overcome strong delusion, gives rise to knowledge.

2. A passage in Sansk·πõit prose1127" says of Gopala that he ‘strove to re-establish the sway over the earth of the kings of the lunar race, which (sway) had been uprooted by the lord of Chodi, who was as terrible as the fire at the end of the world to the multi- tudo of all princes.’ Here the expression the lord of Chedi’ refers to Kar·πáa and the kings of the lunar raco’ to the Chandellas.

3. A lengthy Pr√¢krit passage1128 is as follows:- q√µ√¢merat ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§Æ‡§•‡§®‡•á‡§®‡•á‡§µ ‡§ö‡•Ä‡§∞‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§Ø‡§≤‡§ï‡•ã‡§É ‡••")," which need not be translated in full, says that Gopala, ‘having crushed the ocean-like army of Kar·πáa, obtained the splendour of victory in battle, just as Madhumathana (Vishnu), having churned the milk-ocean, obtained (the goddess) Lakshm√Æ.

It is a curious coincidence that, in the passage just quoted, the army of Kar·πáa is compared to the milk-ocean, just as in verse 26 of the subjoined inscription, and Gopala to Madhumathana (Vish·πáu), just as there Kirtivarman is compared to Purushottama (Vishnu); and it appears very probable that the composer of the inscription knew the Prabodhachandrodaya and borrowed from it his description of K√Ærtivarman’s victory over Karna. The reign of Kirtivarman and, together with it, the date of K·πõishnami≈õra, the author of the Prabodhachandrodaya, is limited by A. D. 10501121and A. D. 1116, the date of Jayavarman’s inscription1129.

According to Bilhana’s Vikram√¢nkadevacharita (sarga i, verses 102 f.) K√Ærtivarman’s contemporary Karna of D√¢hala or D√¢h√¢la (i.e., Chedi) was defeated by the Western Ch√¢lukya king √Çhavamalla II. (about 1042 to about 1068 A. D.). In another part of his poem (sarga xviii, verse 93), Bilha·πáa calls Karna, whose court he visited, ’the death to the lord of the K√¢la√±jara mountain’ (K√¢la√±jaragiripati), i.e., to the Chandella king. This expression, if contrasted with the repeated statement that K√Ærtivarman and his general Gop√¢la completely defeated Karna, illustrates the necessity of hearing the other party before drawing historical conclusions from an Oriental record.

If an inscription of one king asserts that he conquered another, it scarcely proves more than that the two were contemporaries.

The mutilated verses 27 and 28 seem to have continued the description of the reign of Kƒ´rtivarman. Verse 29 begins :‚Äî His son, of wonderful …. was ……..The remainder of the inscription is lost.

TEXT.

2.‡§®‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§µ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§Æ‡•å‡§≤‡§ø‡§∂‡§∏‡§ø‡§®‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§ñ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§É‡••[‡•®*] ‡§è‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ1131…..

  1. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§≤‡§É‡•§ ‡§™‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§∑‡•à‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§§‡•à‡§∞‡§π‡§∞‡§π‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø1132 …

4.‡§µ‡§§‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ã ‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ú‡§®‡§ø ‡§∞‡§ú‡§®‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§≠‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É‡••[‡•´] ‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§ø‡§∞‡•á ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ò‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ1133…

  1. ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•ã‡§ß‡§ø‡§Ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç‡§ó‡§∞‡§Ç‡§ó‡§£‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ‡§É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡•ú‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§É‡•• [‡•≠] ‡§Ü‡§∏‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å [‡§ó‡•Å1134]……..‡••

6.‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§É ‡•• [‡•Ø*] ‡§ú‡•á‡§ú‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§• ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏ ‡§¨‡§≠‡•Ç‡§µ ‡§ú‡•á‡§ú‡§æ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡•ã‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ ‡§Ø‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ø‡§µ‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡•§ ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§®‡•Å‡§ú1135….

  1. ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§µ‡•• [‡•ß‡•ß*] ‡§π‡§§‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∑‡•á‡§£ ‡§ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ú‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§ø‡§µ‡§≤‡§≠‡§ø‡§ó‡§§‡•á‡§µ ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Å‡§ü‡§∞‡§£‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú861…..

  2. ‡§¨‡§≠‡•Ç‡§µ ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§°‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡§£‡•á ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ó‡§≤‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó[‡§™‡•Å]‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§µ‡§ñ‡•Å‡§∞‡§§‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§ú‡§É‡•§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§•‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§∏‡§∞‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•á[‡§∞‡•Å1136]….

  1. ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§µ‡•á‡§≤‡§æ‡§™‡§Ø‡•ã‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§§‡§ü‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡•• [‡•ß‡•´] ‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ñ‡§µ‡•É‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•à‡§∞‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§®‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§Æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø[‡§§‡•à1137]…….
  1. ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡•à‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ß‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§≤‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡•§ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ú‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§π‡§Ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•• [‡•ß‡•≠*] ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§É1138…….
  1. ‡§∞‡•Å‡§π‡§π‡•Ä‡§™‡§ú‡§Ø‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§≠‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§°‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡••[‡•ß‡•Æ] ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§≠‡•Ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§ú‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§§‡§æ‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ñ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§É‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ó‡§£‡•ç‡§° ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§®‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡§É‡•§‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ï‡•ã‡§™‡§∂‡§ø‡§ñ‡§ø1139….

12.‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§µ‡•à‡§É1140‚Äù‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡§®‡•Å ‡§§‡§∞‡§≤‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§≤‡•Ä‡§≤‡§æ‡§¶‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§ß‡§∞‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§™‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§ø‡§®‡§§‡§∞‡•Å‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§ñ‡•à‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡§π‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§É‡••[‡•®‡•¶*] ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∏‡•å ‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§É ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§∞‡•ã‡§≠‡•Ç‡§π‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ã ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞[‡§§‡§ø1141]……..

L.13.‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§≠‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§≠‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∏‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•å‡§¢‡§≠‡•Ä‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§≠‡§æ‡§ú‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§π‡§ï‡§≤‡§ö‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ú‡§µ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Ä‡§ú‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§É‡••[‡•®‡•®*] ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§µ‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡§§‡§ï‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§Ø‡§™‡§æ‡§≤1142 ‡§á[‡§§‡§ø]….."

14.‡§µ‡§π‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§≠‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§π‡§§ ‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§É‡§∏‡•ã‡§™‡§ø ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§£‡§ó‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§•‡§ø ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§É ‡•• [‡•®‡•™] ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§≠‡•Ç‡§µ ‡§≠‡§∞‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•á‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ1143[‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ] ………..

  1. ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§ï‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡§≤‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡•à ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§π‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§ö‡§≤‡§Æ‡§π‡§∏‡§æ ‡§¶‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§∂‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø ‡§á‡§π ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§Ç‡§≤‡•á‡§≠‡•á‡§™‡§∞‡§É [‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•ã[‡§§‡•ç‡§§]\‡§Æ‡§É1144‡•• ‡•®‡•¨*]
  1. ‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§ø‡§∞‡§£‡•à‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ß‡§®‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§è‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§ß‡•á ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡§É‡•• [‡•®‡•≠*] ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§§‡§ñ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§≤‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ï‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§æ ‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§™‡§§‡§Ø‡•á1145[T]
  1. ‡§ó‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡•ã1146‡§É‡•• [‡•®‡•Æ*] ‡§Ü‡§∏‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡§®‡§Ø‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§§1147………

XXVIII.‚Äî THE UDEPUR PRASASTI OF THE KINGS OF MALVA.

BY G. B√úHLER, PH.D., LL.D., C.I.E.

When last year the preparation of my notes on the historical portion of Padma- gupta’s Navas√°has√°nkacharita1148(discovered by Professor Zachariae) turned my attention to the history of M√¢lv√†, I came across some remarks by Dr. F. E. Hall1149’ on a “much’ mutilated” inedited inscription which he had seen at Udepur (Gwalior). Though some of Dr. Hall’s statements regarding its contents rather puzzled me, they yet showed very clearly that the document must give a fuller pedigree of the Param√¢ras of M√•lva than any other known inscription, and that it must besides contain interesting historical information. Convinced of its value, I asked the Editor kindly to secure a copy for me. He directed Dr. F√ºhrer, who was in the Jhansi District, to obtain it, and the latter sent me, in May last, two excellent impressions, one on thick and one on thin paper. It is on these materials that the subjoined edition is based.

The inscription is a fragment, incised on a stone slab about 28 inches by 27, which at present is lying in the court-yard of the great temple of ≈öiva at Udepur. It contains 24 lines of deeply and well-cut rather ornamental N√¢gar√Æ characters, which closely resemble those found in the other Param√¢ra inscriptions of the eleventh century A.D. To judge from the appearance of the impression, the slab seems to be entire, and the remaining portion of the inscription probably was engraved on a second slab, which perhaps may still be found among the numerous inscribed stones in and about the temple1150. The portion now published is on the whole in a fair state of preservation. For, though a good many letters, especially in lines 3, 4, 6, 8, 20, 21, 23 and 24, have suffered severely from rough treatment, it is in the majority of cases possible to recognise their outlines, when one has restored the text conjecturally and knows what they ought to be. The language of the inscription is Sansk·πõit, and, with the exception of the

short invocation in line 1, throughout metrical. It shows a few grammatical mistakes such as kha·∏çgam √∫rddhik·πõitam yen√† (line 16) instead of kha·∏çga √∫rdhv√≠k·πõito yena and frequent faulty ·π£ubstitutions of sa for ≈õa. Once in vi≈õrast√°·πÅgo (line 23) ≈õa has been put for sa. Va throughout does duty for ba, as is the case in most medieval inscriptions from M√¢lv√¢ and Gujar√¢t. A mistake in versification occurs in line 1, where the word √°lav√°le has been treated like a compound and √°la belongs to the first P√•da of the verse, while the second begins with v√°le. No really good poet makes the pause fall in the mid·∏çle of a simple word. There are also other passages which indicate that the author was not a poet of the first rank, but, as the Hindus woul·∏ç say, a madhyama kavi.

The state of the inscription makes it impossible to arrive at full certainty regarding its object. But it certainly contains a Pra≈õasti. As Pra≈õastis mostly record the erection or restoration of temples, and as the opening verses are addressed to ≈öiva, Parvati and Ganesa, it may be conjectured that it originally belonged to a ≈öaiva temple, which was built either by Uday√¢ditya, the last pri·πáce named in the fragment, or by one of his immediate successors.

However that may be, the value of the Pra≈õasti remains very great, as it is the only document which gives an apparently complete enumeration of the earlier Param√¢ra rulers of M√¢lva. Hitherto three imperfect lists were known, which occur in the Navas√°has√°nkacharita of Padmagupta1151."), in the N√¢gpur Pra≈õasti1152, and in the landgrants of V√•kpati and Bhoja1153. A comparison of their contents with those of the document under consideration yields the following results:‚Äî

<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709385173Screenshot2024-03-02182339new.png"/>

I. Udepur Prasasti.Param√¢ra. Upendra. Vairisimha I. Vak pati II. Sindhuraja. II. Navasahasankacharita. III. Nagpur Pra≈°asti. Paramara. Slyaka I. 1 Vakpati I. Vakpati I. Vairisimha II.-Vajrata. Vairisimha. Harsba. Bhoja. Udayaditya. Param√¢ra. Upendra. Siyaka-Harshax Va·∏çajƒÅ. VAkpati II.-Utpalaraja. Vairisimha. Styaka. 1 Mu≈æja. Sindhur√¢ja, or Navasahas√°≈àka, or Kumaran√¢- rayana. Sindhuraja.‚Å∑IV. Land-grants. 223 Krishna. Bhoja. Udayaditya. Vairisimba. Styaka. 1 Vakpati, or Amoghavar- sha, or Prithivfvallabha, or Brivallabha; A. D. 974-975, and 979. Sindhuraja. Bhoja. A. D. 1021-22. _____________________________________
7This name does not appear in either of the two publishede ditions. I owe it to Mr. J. F. Fleet, who possesses a paper impression of the inscription. Professor Kielhorn will give a new edition of the Prasasti in the Indian Anti. quary.

It appears that the Udepur Pra≈õasti alone presents an unbroken line of kings from Upendra to UdayƒÅditya. Even the Navas√°ha√°·πÖkascharita, which is more explicit than the other inscriptions, omits two names after Upendra. It moreover contains (XI, 80) the careless statement, that “other kings” reigned between Upendra and V√¢kpati. I. The use of the plural naturally leads to the suggestion, that they were at least three in number. This seems now impossible, as, according to the Udepur Pra≈õasti (verses 8-10), the first four kings after Param√¢ra followed each other in the direct line of descent.

In considering the other not less interesting historical statements of the Pra≈õasti, it will be advisable to add to them the information contained in the Navas√°has√°·πÖkacharita, i·πá the Jaina Prabandhas and in the other accessible inscriptions.

The legend regarding the origin of the Param√¢ras given here, is the same as that which the Navas√°has√°·πÖkascharita and the N√¢gpur Pra≈õasti tell1154. When in ancient times the great Br√¢hma·πáVasish·π≠ha was living on Mount √Çb√ª, Vi≈õv√¢mitra forcibly abducted his famous cow. Vasish·π≠ha then created out of the firepit a hero who slew the enemies and brought the animal back. In reward of this deed the sage gave to him the name Para·πÅ√¢ra, the slayer of the foes, and promised to him that he should become a king. The myth, which figures also in the stories of the bards, probably has arisen on Mount √Çb√ª, where Para·πÅ√¢ra princes for a long time held the fort of Achalga·∏çh while their capital was at Chandr√¢vati, a few miles south-cast of the mountain. Some≈õvara’s Pra≈õasti in Teja·∏•p√¢la’s temple1155at Dailv√¢·∏ça enumerates an older line of Param√¢ra princes, Dh√ªmar√¢ja, Dhandhuka, and Dhruvabha·π≠a, regarding whom nothing is known, as well as a later series of kings, R√¢madeva, Ya≈õodhavaƒæa, Dh√¢r√¢varsha, Prahl√¢dana, Somasi·πÅha, and K·πõish·πáar√¢ja, who belonged to the twelth and thirteenth centuries A. D., and were vassals of the Chaulukyas of A·πáhilv√¢·∏ç. As the Param√¢ras of M√¢lv√¢apparently believed in the origin of their heros eponymos from the firepit at √Çb√ª, it seems probable that they came from the north-west and formed a branch of the rulers of Achalga·∏çh.

Regarding Upendra, the first historical king of the family, it is said (verse 8) that he gained ’the high honour of kinghood’ or ’the honour of exalted kinghood’ by his bravery. It may, therefore, be inferred that the author of the Pra≈õasti considered him to be the conqueror of M√¢lv√¢and the founder of its Param√¢ra dynasty. Padmagupta (N. Char. XI, 76-79) is not explicit on this point. He merely names Upendra as the first king. But he agrees with the Udepur Pra≈õasti in praising him for the performance of numerous Vedic sacrifices, on the occasion of which he is said ’to have adorned the earth with golden sacrificial posts.’ Moreover, in the ambiguous verse (XI, 77),1156‚Äî‚ÄúWhose fame, that was ever moving on and the cause of S√Æt√†’s song, crossed the ocean just as Hanumat, who was ever nimbly moving and whose motive (for jumping across the ocean) was to console S√Æt√†"‚Äîhe seems to indicate that a poetess S√Æt√†, whom the Prabandhas1157")place in Bhoja’s reign, composed a Pra≈õasti or a Charita in his honour.

This king, no doubt, as Dr. F. E. Hall and Sir A. Cunningham h√¢ve long since assumed, ƒ´s identical with the K·πõish·πáar√¢ja of the land-grants. The two names are synonyms, and, if the new list is complete, there is no room for a K·πõish·πáarƒÅja besides an Upendra.1158The fact that in the land-grants Vairisi·πÅha is said ’to meditate on K·πõish·πáa’s feet,’ need not cause any difficulty. The phrase does not necessarily indicate that the two kings immediately followed each other. For, though usually it refers to an immediate predecessor, there yet are cases where it is used with reference to a remoter king. Thus some of the Chaulukya land-grants (Indian Antiquary, vol. VI, pp. 184,194) assert that Durlabha meditated on the feet of Ch√¢mu·πá·∏ça, though Vallabha was his immediate predecessor. The time when K·πõish·πáa-Upendra ruled, may be ascertained app-roximately by counting backwards from V√¢kpati II., who, as will be shown below, died between A. D. 994 and 997, after reigning for about twenty years. About 150 years are required for six generations, and the acquisition of Malv√† by these Param√¢ras may thus be placed shortly after 800 A. D.

The descriptions of the next kings, Vairisi·πÅha I., Siyaka I., and V√¢kpati I., are purely con-ventional. Not a single historical fact is recorded regarding them either in the Udepur Pra≈õasti or in any other document, except that they followed each other in the direct line of succession. Their reigns probably filled the period from about 840 to 920 A. D. With respect to V√¢kpati’s successor Vairisi·πÅha II., the case does not stand much better. But we learn at least through the Udepur Pra≈õasti that ‚Äúthe people called him by another name, Vajra·π≠asv√¢min." This fact may prove to be of importance hereafter.

The next king is called ≈öri-Harshadeva in the Udepur Pra≈õasti, Sri-Harshadeva or Siyaka in the Navas√°has√°nkacharita, simply Siyaka in the other epigraphic documents, and Si·πÅhabha·π≠a in Merutu·πÖga’s PrabandhachintƒÅmani.1159 The readingAs. Soc. Beng. vol XXXI, p. 117, note 11") The complete name probably was Harshasi·πÅha (Hara-khsi·πÖgh), both parts of which were used as abbreviations instead of the whole. The form Siyaka is a half Pr√¢k·πõitic corruption of Si·πÅhaka. For in modern Gujar√¢t√Æ and other dialects the termination si·πÅha becomes in names not only si·πÖgh or sa·πÖgh, but very commonly s√≠, which is immediately derived from the Pr√¢k·πõit s√≠ha. Thus we find Padams√≠instead of Padmasi·πÉha, Nars√≠ for Narasi·πÅha, Ars√≠ for Arisi·πÅha, Amars√≠ for Amarasi·πÅha. According to the Navas√°has√°-·πÖkacharita (XI, 89‚Äì90) Siyaka conquered the lord of Ra·∏ç√¢p√¢»õ√Æ and a king of the H√ªnas. Who these persons were and where their territories lay, cannot as yet be ascertained. With respect to the H√ªnas or H√ª·πáas, it may be noted that those mentioned here and in other medieval inscriptions are not IIuns, but a Kshatriya racc.1160For the bards and the Jaina Prabandhas regularly enumerate the H√ª·πáas among the thirty-six Kshatriyakula, and their matrimonial alliance in the eleventh century with the Kalachuris precludes the possibility of their having been then considered foreigners. It is, however, a different question whence they originally came. Among the R√¢jputs there are certainly elements of un-Aryan origin. The new inf-ormation, furnished by verse 12 of the Udepur Pra≈õasti, according to which Siyaka II.‚ÄîHarsha,“equalling the snake-eater (Garu·∏ça) in flerceness, took in battle the wealth of king

Kho·π≠·π≠iga” possesses greater interest. This Kho·π≠·π≠iga is no doubt the homonymous R√¢sh·π≠rak√ª·π≠a king of M√¢nyakhe·π≠a, whose S√°sana, published by Mr. Fleet,1161was issued on the occasion of a solar eclipse on Sunday, the new-moon day of the ·πÉonth √Ç≈õvayuja of ≈öaka Sa·πÅvat 893, or Sunday, October 22, 971 A.D., when an annular eclipse of the sun took place. Kho·π≠·π≠iga died before September 25, 972 A.D., on which day the Kard√¢plates of his nephew Karkar√¢ja are dated1162, when an eclipse of the moon took place. The eolipse is, therefore, that which occurred on September 25,972, the day 2076349 of the Julian period, and consequently a Wednesday. It happened at 14 hours 51 minutes, Green-wich time, or about 8 P.M., La≈àk√• time, and hence was visible in India.").The latest inscription of his predecessor K·πõish·πáar√¢ja was issued in ≈öaka Sa·πÅvat 878 or A.D. 956-57.1163As the first land-grant of V√¢kpati II. is dated in Vikrama Sa·πÅvat 1031 or A.D. 974-75,1164there can be no doubt that his father S√Æyaka II. and Kho·π≠·π≠iga were contemporaries. There is further clear proof that about this time the Param√¢ras of M√¢lv√¢were at feud with the R√¢sh·π≠rak√ª·π≠as. For Dhanap√¢la says in his P√°iyalachchh√≠ (verse 276) that he composed his work “when one thousand years of the Vikrama era and twenty-nine besides had passed, when Mannakhe·∏ça or M√¢nyakhe·π≠a had been plundered in con-sequence of an attack (made) by the lord of M√¢lav√¢.” As this date, A.D. 972-73, is very close to that of the first grant of V√¢kpati II., I have formerly (P√°iyalachchh√≠, p.7) conjectured that it was the latter prince who plundered the capital of the R√¢shtrak√ª·π≠as, and that his opponent was Karkar√¢ja, the donor of the Kard√¢≈ö√¢sana. With the new information furnished by the Udepur Pra≈õasti, this becomes doubtful, and it must be conceded that Dhanap√¢la may allude to S√Æyaka’s expedition against Kho·π≠·π≠iga. According to the Navas√°has√°nkacharita the name of S√Æyaka’s consort, i.e., of his firstqueen, was Va·∏çaj√¢.

Siyaka’s son V√¢kpati II. bore also the secondary names Utpalar√¢ja, Mu√±ja, Amoghavarsha, P·πõithivivallabha, and ≈ör√Ævallabha. The three last occur only in his land-grants, while the first is found in the Navas√°has√¢≈àkacharita (XI, 92) and in some other literary works. The identity of V√¢kpati and Mu√±ja, which was first recognised by Dr. F.E.Hall, is proved, not only by the NƒÅgpur Pra≈õasti where Mu√±ja appears instead of V√¢kpati, but still more clearly by two quotations in Dhanika’s commentary on the Da≈õar√∫pa. There the same verse is attributed on p. 184 of Hall’s edition in the Bibliotheca Indica, to “the illustrious king VƒÅkpatir√¢ja,” and on p. 186, to “the illustrious Mu√±ja.”

The Pra≈õasti (verses 13-15) praises V√¢kpati for his learning, eloquence and poetical gifts as well as for numerous victories. On the first point his poet-laureate Padmagupta is likewise most emphatic. He says (Nav. Char. I, 6):‚Äî

“We worship his majesty king V√¢kpati, the only root of (that) creeper of paradise, Sarasvati,‚Äîhim through whose favour we, too, walk on the path trodden by princes among poets;”1165.")and again (Nav. Ohar. XI,

‚ÄúAfter VikramƒÅditya departed, after S√¢tav√¢hana went, divine Sarasvati found rest with this friend of poets."1166.")

There is also evidence that this praise was not undeserved. Altogethor irrespective of the somewhat suspicious verses attributed to Mu√±ja-V√¢kpati in the Prabandhachint√°·πÅa·πái, in the Bhojaprabandha, and similar works, the anthologies and works on Alamk√°ra quote occasionally compositions of VƒÅkpatir√¢ja the son of Harshadeva,of Mu√±ja or of Utpalar√¢ja, which show that he possessed some talent. He also was a liberal patron of poets, on which point Padmagupta lays particular stress in the verses quoted above. And it agrees with his statement that Dhana·πÅjaya, the author of the Da≈õar√∫pa, boasts of having belonged to the court of Mu√±ja,1167.")as well as that his brother Dhanika, who wrote the Da≈õar√∫p√°valoka, calls himself the mah√°s√°dhyap√°la of the illustrious great king Utpalar√¢ja.1168. Dr. Hall has left out this note in his edition, though he found it in one of his MSS. It is no doubt genuine, because a later Pa·πá·∏çit would not have been able to put in the little-known Biruda of Vakpati-Mu√±ja.")Both names refer, as is now plain, to V√¢kpati. Further, Halayudha, the commentator of Pingala’s work on metrics, praises V√¢kpatir√¢ja as “the tree of paradise that grants the wishes of all applicants,” and Dhanika, who quotes it, makes the note that Mu√±ja is the king referred to.1169Halayudha was, therefore, too, one of the prot√©g√©s of VƒÅkpati II. It is finally not improbable that Dhanap√¢la, the author of the Paiyalachchhi, likewise enjoyed his favour, though the later Prabandhas make him one of the court-poets of Bhoja.1170")The latter statement must be erroneous, as I have shown in the introduction to my edition of the Paiyaluchchh√≠, p. 10.

As regards V√¢kpati’s military exploits, the Udepur Pra≈õasti asserts (verse 14) that he subdued the Kar·πáƒÅ·π≠as, L√¢»õas, Keralas, and Cholas, as well as (verse 15) that he vanquished Yuvar√¢ja, slew his generals and raised his sword on high in Tripur√Æ. The last-mentioned foe is, as Dr. F.E.Hall and Sir A. Cunningham have stated,1171 the Chedi king Yuvar√¢ja II., who ruled during the last quarter of the tenth century A. D. V√¢kpati’s success cannot of course have had any lasting effects, as the Haihayas of Chedi continued to flourish for at least two centuries longer. With respect to the victories reported in verse 14, little can be said. Padmagupta does not give any information regarding the wars of his first master, probably because the tragical end of the latter was fresh in men’s memory and he thought it improper to praise for his warlike exploits one who had been taken captive and executed by his foe. Further, as has been shown above, Dhanap√¢la’s remark about the plundering of M√¢nyakhe≈£a cannot be referred any longer with full confidence to an expedition of V√¢kpati. It is only Merutu·πÖga who supports a portion of the statements in versc 14. He says1172")that Mu√±ja had conquered the Oh√¢lukya Tailapa II. sixteen times, before he undertook his last expedition, in which he lost his throne and his life, and that he hence despised him. This statement would agree with the assertion of the Pra≈õasti that V√¢kpati had subdued the Kar·πá√¢»õas; and it is not incredible that he really may have gained some successes over the

southern kingdom: The alleged submission of the Keralas and Cholas, on the other hand, is extremely doubtful. It is difficult to understand how he could have come into contact with the latter two, whose countries lay at such a great distance from M√¢lv√¢. As regards the L√¢·π≠as or tlie inhabitants of Central Gujar√¢t, a raid on and a success over them is not at all improbable. Northern GujarƒÅt had been conquered soinewhat earlier by M√ªiar√¢ja1173, and Indian Antiquary, vol. VI, p. 181.")and Central GujarƒÅt had come intothe possession of his opponent B√¢rapa.1174The time was certainly not a quiet one, and it may have been that the king of M√¢ivƒÅthen attacked his western neighbours, as happened sofrequently during the next following centuries.

As might be expected, the pra≈õastiis silent about VƒÅkpati‚Äôs end, just as Padmagupta says nothing about it. According to the account of the Prabandhachint√°ma·πái(Joc. cit.), the king undertook his last expedition into Tailapa‚Äôs country against the advice of his minister Rudr√¢ditya: He was defeated, after crossing the God√¢var√Æ, which formed the northern boundary of Tailapa‚Äôs kingdom, and was taken captive. After a protracted captivity he made a futile attempt to escape, in consequence of which he was first treated with great indignity and finally executed.1175 say that he was bung on the branch of a tree. The Bombay edition omits the passage.")^(291175 say that he was bung on the branch of a tree. The Bombay edition omits the passage."))The story is embellished with numerous touching incidents and with many verses which the captive king is saidto have composed. Though all these details are probably worthless, it is certainly true that Mu√±ja-V√¢kpati was destroyed by Tailapa; for two Ch√¢lukya inscriptions hoast of this feat.1176It is likewise true that Rudr√¢ditya was V√¢kpati‚Äôs minister, as he is mentioned in the ≈ö√¢sana of A. D. 979. The date of his death probably falls between A, D, 994 and 997. For in the colophon of Amitagati‚Äôs Subh√¢shitaratnasa·πÅdoha, it is stated that the work was composed during the reign of Mu√±ja in Vikrama Sa·πÅvat 1050 or A. D. 993-94,1177and Tailapa II. himself died in ≈öaka Sa·πÅvat 919 or A. D. 997-98. The beginning of V√¢kpati‚Äôs reign is probably not far distant from A..D, 974, the date of his first land-grant.

V√¢kpati II. was succeeded by his younger brother Sindhur√¢ja, who, according to the Navas√¢has√¢·πÖkacharita, had the Birudas Navas√¢has√¢·πÖka and Kum√¢ran√¢raya·πáa. The half Pr√¢k·πõitic familiar form of his name, used in the Prabandhas, is Sindhula or S√Æmdhala. The Udepur Pra≈õasti allots only verse 16 to him, and reports of him the single feat that he conquered a king of the H√ª·πáas. TheNavas√¢has√¢·πÖkacharita (X,14-20) mentions the same victory, and in addition others over the prince of the Kosalas as well as the inhabitants of V√¢ga·∏ça and L√¢ta and the Muralas.1178 and p. 46 (626). ‡•§")Successful expeditions against the three first-named countries are not incredible. For there was a southern Kosala kingdom, which included portions of the Central Provinces and Berar and therefore lay not far distant from M√¢lv√¢.1179 Further, there is a district still called V√¢ga·∏ç, which lies close to the north-western frontier of M√¢lv√¢. It corresponds with

the modern Dungarpur in R√¢jput√¢n√¢,1180which even in recent times has been tributary to the Mar√¢≈£ha ruler of Dh√¢r. It is not at all unlikely that Sindhur√¢ja made attacks on these two neighbouring districts as well as, imitating his father, on L√¢≈£a, just beyond his south-western frontier. But a war with the Muralas, who are the same as the Keralas in Southern India, is not probable, except by assuming that the term has been used inaccurately, with that poetical license of which the Sanskrit writers frequently avail themselves, for the inhabitants of the Dravidian districts in general. If that may be done, the passage probably refers to a continuation of the feud between the kings of M√¢lva and the Ch√¢lukyas of Kaly√¢n√Æ during the reign of Sindhur√¢ja. It also continued, as we shall see, during the next reign.

A great deal more is told about Sindhur√¢ja in the Navas√°has√°nkacharita, which describes the manner in which he gained the N√¢ga princess ≈öasiprabh√¢, after destroying the Asura Vajr√¢nku≈õa who resided in Ratnavat√Æ “fifty gavy√∫tis from the Narmada,” and after obtaining his golden lotus.1181-23 (603), and especially pp. 18 and 22.")The whole story, as it stands, is purely mythological. But it has no doubt a historical basis, and Padmagupta has intentionally, possibly for poetical reasons, distorted the facts. One of the points which I consider as certain, is that the N√¢ga princess, whom the king is said to have gained and wedded, belonged to the race of the N√¢ga Kshatriyas, of whose former existence in Rajput√¢n√¢ and Central India we have documentary evidence.1182The Asura Vajr√¢≈Ñku≈õa, whose golden lotus was the bride-price paid by Sindhur√¢ja, is very likely some historical person in disguise, because otherwise the situation of his capital would not be specified in so matter-of-fact a manner. But it is for the present impossible to guess who may be meant, or who the Vidy√¢dharas were with whom the king was allied. Another certain historical fact, to be learned from the Navas√°has√°nkacharita, is that Sindhur√¢ja’s chief minister was called Ya≈õobha·π≠a and bore the Biruda Ram√¢ngada.1183.")

The poem furnishes also some indications as to Sindhur√¢ja’s relation to his brother V√¢kpati and permits us to make a guess as to the duration of his reign. According to the Prabandhas, Sindhur√¢ja was a very unruly character, and was treated by his brother with great severity. Merutunga asserts1184")that owing to his misdeeds he was first banished and went to Gujar√¢t, where he settled in the neighbourhood of the town of K√¢sahrada, or, according to Mr. K. Forbes,1185K√¢sindra-P√¢la·∏çi near Ahmad√¢b√¢d. Later he returned to M√¢lvƒÅ and was at first received well by Mu√±ja-V√¢kpati. But, when he again behaved ill, he was deprived of his eyesight and confined in a wooden cage. During his captivity his son Bhoja was born. When Bhoja grew up, Mu√±ja was warned against him by a prophecy and ordered his execution. Just before the order was carried out, Bhoja sent a verse to his uncle, which produced a change in the latter’s disposition. The order was not only revoked, but Bhoja was made Yuvar√¢ja or

heir-apparent. He mounted the throne after Mu√±ja had been killed by Tailapa. Against this the Navas√°has√°≈àkacharita (XI, 98) says that “V√¢kpati placed the earth in Sindhur√¢ja’s arms, when he started for Ambik√¢’s town.” Strictly interpreted, this sentence would mean that he made his brother Yuvar√¢ja on his death-bed and solemnly appointed him his successor. Considering what we know of V√¢kpati’s manner of death, this view is not admissible. But the passage may indicate that Sindhur√¢ja had become Yuvar√¢ja some time before V√¢kpati’s fatal expedition. At all events it does not give one the idea that enmity reigned between the two brothers. And there is a further fact which favours the same conclusion. For Padmagupta, who had been first V√¢kpati’s poet-laureate, later held the same position in Sindhur√¢ja’s court. He himself says (Nav.Char. I, 7):‚Äî1186, ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§Ç‡§Ø‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§É‡•§‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§£‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§¨‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§É‡••")

“When his majesty V√¢kpati was about to ascend to heaven, he placed a seal on my song; Sindhur√¢ja, the younger brother of that brother of poets, now breaks it.”

Had the brothers been deadly enemies, Padmagupta would certainly have been left in obscurity after his first patron’s death.

As regards the second point, the duration of Sindhur√¢ja’s reign, his various military undertakings, which the Navas√°has√°nkacharita reports, certainly prove that he must have reigned for at least seven or eight years before the poem was written. As V√¢kpati II. died between A. D. 994 and 997, it is not possible to assume that Padmagupta composed it earlier than about the middle of the first decade of the eleventh century. How much longer Sindhur√¢ja may have reigned, cannot be determined at present.

The statements of the Udepur Pra≈õasti regarding Sindhur√¢ja’s son Bhoja are most extravagant. Verse 17 asserts that he ruled the earth from KailƒÅsa in the HimƒÅlayas to Malayagiri in Malab√¢r and from the mountain where the sun rises to that where it sets, and thus gives a most ridiculous account of the extent of his dominions, which in reality never much exceeded the limits of modern M√¢lv√¢. Verse 18 names as the kings and nations vanquished by him the lord of Chedi, Indraratha, Toggala (?), Bhima, the king of the G√ªrjaras, the lord of L√¢»õa, the Kar·πá√¢»õas, and the Turushkas. Verse 18 alludes to his extensive knowledge and bestows on him the title KavirƒÅja, king of poets. Verse 20 informs us that he built numerous temples dedicated to various forms of ≈öiva and to Vish·πáu-R√¢me≈õvara. Verse 21 finally admits that he succumbed to foreign foes, and that at his death his capital Dh√¢r√¢ was in their possession.

As regards Bhoja’s wars, the first was probably one with the Kar·πá√¢»õas, i.e., the Ch√¢lukya king of Kaly√¢ni. For, in an inscription1187of the reign of Jayasi·πÅha III., dated ≈öaka Sa·πÅvat 941 or A. D. 1019-20, it is said that this king was “a moon to the lotus which was king Bhoja,” i.e., that he took away Bhoja’s glory just as the moon causes the day-lotuses to close their flowers; and again that he “searched out and beset and pursued and ground down and put to flight the confederacy of M√¢lava.” These statements indicate that the king of M√¢lv√¢was the aggressor, and that his attack was carefully planned. The southern inscription, of course, represents the Chalukya as successful, and the numerous documents from Jayasi·πÅha’s reign certainly prove that he

cannot have suffered any serious reverse. But it is quite possible that Bhoja gained in the course of his expedition to the south some advantage which might be magnified by the MƒÅlva court-poets into a great victory over the Kar·πáƒÅ·π≠as.

This war must have taken place between ≈öaka Samvat 933ar A.D. 1011-12, the latest known date of Jayasimha’s predecessor, and that of the inscription. Besides this encounter of Bhoja with the C·∏•ƒÅlukyas, we hear of a second through Bilhana, who tells us in the VikramƒÅ·πÖkadevacharita (I, 91-94) that Jayasimha‚Äôs successor, Some≈õvara II., who ruled from about A. 0, 1042-3 to 1068-69, took DhƒÅra by storm and forced Bhoja to flee. The event is not mentioned in the southern inscriptions, but Bilhana celebrates it as the greatest deed of the father of his hero.

Bhoja‚Äôs victory over the Chaulukya Bhima I. (A. D. 1021-22 to 1063-64) is acknowledged by one of the later PrabandhakƒÅras of Gujarht. Merutunga narrates1188 that, while Bhima was engaged in the conquest of Sindh, Bhoja sent a certain Digambara Kulachandra with an army against A·πáhilvƒÅ·∏ç. The town was taken. The conqueror sowed cowries at the gate of the palace and returned to MƒÅlvƒÅ, taking with him a jayapatira or letter of victory. Hemachandra‚Äôs silence regarding this defeat of Bhima does not mean much. For, being a court-poet, he could not speak of reverses which his master‚Äôs grandfather had suffered. It may be nevertheless a fact, and that particular one to which the Pra≈õasti alludes. Merutu·πÖga has several other anecdotes regarding the relations subsisting between Bhoja and Bhima. There is, however, only one among them, and that referring to Bhoja‚Äôs end, which deserves any notice. It will be discussed below. Regarding Bhoja‚Äôs wars with the kings of Chedi and LƒÅ·π≠a and the Turushkas, nothing more can be said than that they are not improbable. For the first was also, as we have seen, the foe of VƒÅkpati II. and appears as the chief actor in the story of Bhoja‚Äôs end, while the second was the object of the attacks both of Siyaka II, and of VƒÅakpati II. TheTurushkas are, as always in the inscriptions of this period, the Muhammadans. The expeditions of Mahmud of Ghazni against SomnƒÅth and later against Gwalior may very probably have forced Bhoja to fight against him. But it is very unlikely that the armies of MƒÅlva should have gained a victory over him. I am unable to say who Indraratha and Toggala, the other two foes mentioned, can have been.

The praise of Bhoja‚Äôs learning and proficiency in poctry in verse 18 is well deserved. The modern researches in the Indian libraries have brought to light a considerable number of hand-books of, or commentaries on, various Hindu ≈öƒÅstras, which all bear the name of the MahƒÅrƒÅjƒÅdhirƒÅja Bhoja and are alleged to have been written by him, no doubt with the help of his Pa·πá·∏çits. Besides the well-known Sarasvatika·πá·π≠hƒÅbhara·πáa on poetics and the equally famous RƒÅjamƒÅrto·πáda on the Yoga≈õƒÅstra, the Bombay collectionscontain two works on Jyotisha, the RƒÅjamriƒÅrta·πá·∏ça and the RƒÅjam·πõigƒÅ·πÖkakarana1189and the SamarƒÅgana on architecture.1190 In Tanjore there is the Vidvajjanavallabha on Jyotisha. The list in the1191")PrabhƒÅvakacharita1191")(written about A.D. 1250) shows that still a good many more works of the same description have to be recovered. A poetical composition by Bhoja, the ≈ö·πõi·πÖgƒÅrama√±jarikathƒÅ, is partly

preserved in a fragment which I found in 1874 in the B·πõihajj√±√°nakosha at Jesalmir.1192A colophon on fol. 149bruns as follows: ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡•ã‡§ú‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•É‡§Ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§ú‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡§•‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡§ï‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡•• The work is partly in prose and partly in verse.

Regarding the extensive building operations which Bhoja undertook according to verse 20, I am not able to bring forward any corroboration from other sources. But it is very probable that a prince, so fond of display as he was, adorned his capital and perhaps even foreign sacred places with architectural monuments.

The hints regarding Bhoja’s end in verse 20 of the Udepur Pra≈õasti agree very closely with those given in the N√¢gpur Pra≈õasti, and are perfectly reconcilable with Merutu·πÖga’s story1193according to which he succumbed to a combined attack of Kar·πáa of Chedi and of Bhima I. of Gujar√¢t, or died, just when this attack took place. Both these kings, no doubt, were his contemporaries1194and his neighbours in the east and in the west. Nevertheless an implicit acceptance of the story has its difficulties. For the Chedi inscriptions do not even hint that Kar·πáa worked the destruction of the most famous monarch of the eleventh century. Nor does Hemachandra, who wrote his Dvy√°≈õraya K√°vya about 150 years before Merutu·πÖga’s times, say that Bhima I. had a share in Bhoja’s reverses, though otherwise he is anxious to place Bh√Æma’s military exploits in the best possible light. It seems strange that the Chedian court-poets and older Gujar√¢t√Æ writers should both have forgotten to notice an event which must have reflected so much glory on the ancestors of their patrons. Owing to these considerations I cannot at present give as unqualified an assent to Merutu·πÖga’s story as I have done on a former occasion.1195Neither the date of Bhoja’s accession to the throne, nor that of his defeat and death, can, I fear, be accurately ascertained. All that can be said regarding the former event is that it must have happened between the date of the composition of Padmagupta’s Navas-√°has√°nkacharita about A. D. 1005, and that of Bhoja’s war with Jayasi·πÅha III. of Kaly√¢·πá√Æ, which latter occurred, as has been shown, between A. D. 1011-12 and 1018-19. It seems probable, however, that it lay closer to the lower than to the remoter of these two limits. For Padmagupta does not mention Bhoja in his poem. This is a certain sign that Bhoja was not grown up at the time when he wrote. For, if that had been the case, Padmagupta would have felt it his duty to put in a compliment for the heir-apparent, as the court-poets invariably do in similar cases. Bhoja may then have been a boy of ten or twelve or even fourteen years, but he cannot have reached as yet the Indian age of majority, his sixteenth year. If I am right in placing the composition of the Navas√°has√°·πÖkacharita about the year 1005 A. D., the time when Bhoja can have assumed the reins of government must fall about A. D. 1010, or even somewhat later. Further, certain dates during his reign are furnished by his land-grant of Vikrama Sa·πÅvat 1078 or A. D. 1021-22, by the statement of Ber√ªn√Æ, that Bhojadeva ruled over Dh√¢r√¢ and M√¢lvƒÅ when he wrote his Indica,1196in A. D. 1030, and by the date in the R√°jam·πõig√°nkakara·πáa, ≈öaka Sa·πÅvat

9641197or A.D. 1042-43. For the question when Bhoja died, the most important passage is that in Bilha·πáa’s Vikram√°nkadevacharita, where he says (XVIII, 96):‚Äî

“Assuming the voice of the pigeons that nested on the lofty turrets of her gates, Dh√¢r√¢ cried as it were to him (Bilha·πáa) in pitiful tones: ‘Bhoja (is my) king. He, indeed, is none of the vulgar princes.Woe is to me! Why didst thou not come into his presence?”

I still believe that the verse means that Bilhana might have, but did not visit Bhoja for reasons not stated, and that Bhoja was alive when he reached Central India on his travels. If that is so, the death of Bhoja must fall some time after the year A.D. 1062, the earliest in which the departure of Bilha·πáa from Ka≈õmir can be placed1198. And it agrees with this assumption that Kalha·πáa declares, R√°jatarangi·πái, VII, 259 (Calcutta edition):‚Äî

‡§∏‡§ö ‡§≠‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§∞‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•å‡•§
‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡•á ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§¨‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§µ‡•å ‡••

“He (Kshitipati) and king Bhoja, famous for their great liberality (and) sages, were at that moment both equally the friends of poets.”

The expression ‚Äúat that moment‚Äù refers to the time after the coronation of Kala≈õa in A.D.1062, which is mentioned in verse 233. In estimating the value of Kalla·πáa’s assertion, it must be borne in mind that he wrote nearly one hundred years after the time of Bilha·πáa’s travels and after Bhoja. He is, of course, not a contemporary witness. But as his statement agrees with Bilha·πáa’s, it must be allowed some weight. I do not think that the date Vikrama Sa·πÅvat 1116 and ≈öaka Sa·πÅvat 981, assigned to Bhoja’s successor UdayƒÅditya in an inscription in the great temple at Udepur, proves anything against this. As Dr. F. E. Hall has stated1199, the document is a horribly incorrect scrawl, which, according to lines 13-14, was written by order of one S√¢garavarman in Vikrama Sa·πÅvat 1562, ≈öaka Sa·πÅvat 1447 (read 1427) or Kali Yuga 46071200, and it is absolutely worthless for historical purposes.

Regarding UdayƒÅditya our Pra≈õasti states merely that he was a Param√¢ra and Bhoja’s successor, and that he freed his country from the enemies who had conquered it. It also implies that he restored a temple or statue of Vish·πáu in the boar incarnation. Whether he was related to his predecessor or not, does not appear.

TRANSCRIPT
