‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§®‡§ø ‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•á‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§§‡•Ä‡§µ ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à ‡§∏ ‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§∂‡§Ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§É ‡•• [‡•ß]‡••]1201
2. ‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç‡§¶‡§®‡§Ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡§∏‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¶‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•à‡§É ‡•§
[‡§®‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç] ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø [‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç] ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§µ‡•á‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ã ‡§≠-

**[‡§µ‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡§É ‡§∏ ‡§∏‡§ø‡§µ‡§É ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø ‡•• [‡•®] ‡••]1202
L.3. ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ [‡§Ö‡§∏‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§®] ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§≠‡•ã‡§∞‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡§ò‡§ü‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§‡•Ä ‡•§ **

‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§•‡§µ‡§∏‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç

4 . ‡§∏[‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ó‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§®‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•• [‡•©] ‡••]1203

**‡§ó‡§£‡•á‡§∂‡•ã [‡§µ]: ‡§∏‡•Å [‡§ñ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ] ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§∂‡§É ‡§ï‡§∞‡•á ‡•§ **

5. ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø[‡§ï‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§á‡§µ‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§É ‡•• [‡•™] ‡••]1204

6. ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ß‡•ç‡§∞‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§®‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§¶‡§Ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§É
‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§≠‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§‡§´‡§≤‡§¶‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡•§

‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã ‡§µ‡§∏‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§¶‡§π‡§∞‡§§ ‡§µ[‡§≤]‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç‡§°‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§µ‡§≤‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡§®‡§Ç ‡§Ø[‡§∏‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§ï ‡§è‡§µ ‡•• [‡•´] ‡••]1205

7. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•á ‡§∏ ‡§§‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§É ‡•§
‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•á , ‡§§‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§É‡•§

[‡§â‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‚Äî ‚Äî ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§ø ‡•• [‡•¨] ‡••]1206
8. ‡§§‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ω‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ß‡§§‡•É‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡•É‡§§‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç ‡•§
[‡§â‡§™‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç‡§ó‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§µ[‡§Æ‡§æ]‡§®‡§É ‡•• [‡•≠]]1207‡••1208
9. ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§¶‡§∞‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç‡§†‡•Ä‡§∞‡§µ‡•ã

‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§É ‡•§
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡•à‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç [‡§ú‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç‡§≠‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡•• [‡•Æ] ‡••]1209
10. ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§¨‡§≠‡•Ç‡§µ ‡§µ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§™‡§Æ‡•å‡§≤‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡§∞‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡•Ä‡§†‡§É ‡•§
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§ï‡§É ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡§ú‡§≤‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡•ã[‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§Ø‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§É ‡•• [‡•Ø]]1210‡••1208
11. ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•Å‡§£‡•Ä‡§®‡§Ø‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§É \‡•§
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§§‡§Æ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡§Ç‡§ó‡§æ [‡§ó‡§Ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§≤‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§™‡§ø‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡•• [‡•ß‡•¶] ‡••]1208

L. 12. ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§æ ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ã ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§§‡•á [‡§µ‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ü] ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡•§
[‡§∂‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ø‡§∏‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§π‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡•• [‡•ß‡•ß] ‡••]1211

13. ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§≠‡•Ç‡§¶‡§∞‡§ø‡§®‡§∞‡•á‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ò‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§ú‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∞‡§µ‡§∏‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¶‡§∞‡§§‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§É ‡•§
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§π‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ñ‡•ã‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§ó‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ß‡§ø ‡§®‡§ó‡§æ‡§¶‡§∏‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞1212[‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§É‡•• [‡•ß‡•®]]1212‡••1211

14. ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø[‡§≠‡•Ç]‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡§ß‡§∞‡§æ‡§≠‡•ã‡§ó‡•ã ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•à‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡§Ç
‡§∏‡•å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§µ‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§¶‡§Ø‡§É ‡•§

**15. ‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•ã‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡§ï‡§≤‡§®‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§§‡§∂‡§æ[‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ]‡§ó‡§Æ‡§É
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø [‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•• [‡•ß‡•©] ‡••]1213 **

16. ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§ü‡§≤‡§æ‡§ü‡§ï‡•á‡§∞‡§≤‡§ö‡•ã‡§≤‡§∂‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§ø‡§™‡§¶‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡§É ‡•§
‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ó‡§£‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‡•• [‡•ß‡•™543[]]1213‡••543
‡§Ø‡•Å‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡•å ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä‡§™‡§§‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç ‡•§

17. ‡§ñ‡§°‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® [‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§ø‡§ó‡•Ä‡§∑‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡•• [‡•ß‡•´]]1214‡••1215
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ú‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§£‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§É‡•§

18. ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡•ã‡§ú‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§ø ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§Ç‡§®‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§ï‡•É‡§¶‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡•• [‡•ß‡•¨1215[]]1213‡••1215
‡§Ü ‡§ï‡•à‡§≤‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§¶‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§π‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ
‡§≠‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§™‡•É‡§•‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡§™‡§§‡•á‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•á‡§£ ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡•§

19. ‡§â‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§≠‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å[‡§ó]‡§£‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä‡§≤‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ
[‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§ö ‡•• [‡•ß‡•≠]]1216‡••1215
‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§® ‡§ï‡•á‡§®‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡•§

20. ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø [‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡•ã‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•• [‡•ß‡•Æ]]384‡••1215
‡§ö‡•á‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∞‡§•[‡§§‡•ã‡§Æ‡§æ]‡§≤[‡§≠‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•Å]‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§ü‡§≤‡§æ‡§ü‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§ó‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§∞‡§∞‡§æ‡§ü‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡•§

21. ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§≤‡•ã[‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø] ‡§Æ‡•å‡§≤‡§æ ‡§¶‡•ã‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§ø [‡§ï‡§≤‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§® [‡§Ø‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•É] ‡§≤‡•ã[‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç] ‡•• \‡•ß‡•Ø1217[]]384‡••1217
‡§ï‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§•[‡§∏‡•Å‡§Ç]‡§¢‡•Ä‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§≤‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞-

‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•à‡§É ‡•§

L. 22. ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞[‡§Ø‡•à]‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§Ç [‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡••[‡•®‡•¶]]1218‡••1218
‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡•á ‡§ó‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§¶‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á
23. ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§µ ‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∞‡§≠‡§∞‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡•å‡§≤‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç ‡•§
‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ü‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡§ø[‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∞‡§≠]‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ñ‡§°‡•ç‡§ó‡§¶‡§Ç‡§°‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•Å‡§ú‡§æ‡§≤‡•à‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§¶‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§É ‡•• [‡•®‡•ß1219[]]1219‡••1218
24. ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§ß‡§∞‡§£‡•Ä‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡•ã[‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ã] ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ[‡§§‡•ç] ‡•§
[‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≠‡•Ç] ‡§Æ‡•á‡§∞‡•Å‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§µ‡§§ [‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§É ‡•• [‡•®‡•®]]1220‡••1218
[‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‚Äî] ‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§ú‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§∞‡•Å-1221

TRANSLATION.

O·πÅ, adoration to ≈öiva!

(Verse 1.)May that ≈öambhu tend to thy welfare, on whose head the pure crescent of the moon looks like a sprout of the creeper of paradise that is desired by the worshippers, (standing) in a basin of snakes sprinkled by the water of Ga·πÖga!1222

(2.) May that ≈öiva conduce to your happiness, before whom the harlots of the abode of the gods1223needs ever dance to the sound of the loud, beautiful time beating of joyful Nandin’s hands and to the tunes of Tumburu’s soul-enchanting songs!

(3.) May the daughter of the mountain (P√°rvat√≠) grant you prosperity,‚Äîshe who, out of jealousy, as it were, of the a√´rial river (Ga·πÖg√°) that rests on ≈öambhu’s head, firmly clings to one half of his body, joining hers (to his), and who feels pleasure in every limb when she sees the subjection of her lord!1224

(4.) May Ga·πáe≈õa grant you happiness, in whose hand a sharp axe is raised in order to cut off, as it were, the root of the great sinfulness of his worshippers!

(5.) There is in the west a son of the Himalaya, that lofty mountain, called Arbuda (√Åb≈´), that gives the desired reward to those possessing (true) knowledge, and (is) the place where the conjugal union of the Siddhas is perfect.1225 There Vi≈õv√¢mitra forcibly took from Va·π£ish·π≠ha (his) cow. Through his (Vasish·π≠ha’s) power a hero arose from the firepit, who singly worked the destruction of the enemy’s army.

(6.) When he had slain the enemies, he brought back the √ßow; then that sage spoke: “Thou wilt become a lord of [kings, called] Paramara.”

(V. 7.) In his line there was Upendrar√¢ja, whose fame was proclaimed by the immortals, satisfied by the multitude of all sacrifices,‚Äîwho was a jewel among the twice-born and gained high honour of kinghood1226 by his valour.

(8.) His son was a lion for the elephant-like hostile kings, the best of heroes, the illustrious Vairisi·πÅha, who composed his own eulogy by (erecting) pillars of victory (everywhere) on the earth that is bounded by the four oceans.

9.) From him sprang the illustrious Siyaka, a prince (standing) in the first rank of conquerors, whose footstool was resplendent and coloured1227by the rays of the jewels in the diadems of kings,‚Äî(he) the crowd of whose enemies was submerged in the waves of the water of the blade in his hand1228.").

(10.) From him sprang the illustrious V√¢kpati, a sun for (those) water-lilies, the eyes of the maidens of Avanti, (he who was) resplendent with the rays of the sword in his hand, who resembled ≈öatamakha (Indra), and whose armies drank the waters of GangƒÅ and of the ocean.1229 water-lilios, the eyes of the maidens of A vanti,")

(11.) From him was born Vairisi·πÅha, whom the people call by another name, the lord Vajrata; by that king famous Dh√¢r√¢ was indicated, when he slew the crowd of his enemies with the sharp edge (dh√°r√°) of his sword1230.

(12.) From him sprang he who is called his glorious majesty Harsha, the sound of whose trumpets was beautiful like the noise of the roaring of mighty elephants in the armies of numerous hostile kings, he who, equalling the snake-eater (Garu·∏ça) in fierceness, took in battle the wealth of king Kho·π≠·π≠iga.1231

(13.) His son who, (being) the sole abode of good qualities, adorned the whole globe of the earth, the growth of whose riches was proportionate to the deposits of wealth (which he received) from all foes that were conquered by his bravery,1232 who, cultivating eloquence, high poetry and the art of reasoning, completely mastered the love of the ≈öastras, was he who is ever praised by the virtuous as his glorious majesty VƒÅkpati;

(14.) He whose lotus-feet were coloured by the jewels on the heads of the KarnƒÅ·π≠as, LƒÅ·π≠as, Keralas and Cholas, and who possessed the fame of a tree of paradise, since he granted to a crowd of supplicants whatever they desired;

(15.) Who, conquering Yuvar√¢ja and slaying his generals, as victor, raised on high his sword in Tripuri.

(16.) His younger brother was the illustrious Sindhur√¢ja, who conquered the king of the H√ª·πÖas and who gained glory by his victories. He begat the illustrious Bhojar√¢ja, a jewel without a rival, (a hero) who caused the best men to tremble.

(17.) He, who resembled king P·πõithu, possessed the earth up to KailƒÅsa, up to the

Malaya hills, and up to the two mountains of the setting and the rising sun; he scattered in (all) directions the weighty crowd of earth-supporters,1233 easily uprooting them with the shaft of his bow, and gave highest joy to the earth.

(V. 18.) He accomplished, ordered, gave and knew what (was) not (in the power) of anybody else; what other praise can be given to illustrious Bhoja, the poet-king?

(19.) Seeing the Kar·πáƒÅ·π≠as, the lord of L√¢ta, the king of Gurjara, the Turushkas, chief among whom1234 were the lord of Chedi, Indraratha, Toggala(?) and Bhima, conquered by his mercenaries alone, his hereditary warriors1235thought only of the strength of their arms, not of the numbers of the fighters.

(20.) He made the world (jagat√≠) worthy of its names1236 by covering it all around with temples, dedicated to Ked√¢re≈õvara, R√¢me≈õvara, Soman√¢tha, Sum·∏çira (?), KƒÅla, Anala, and Rudra.

(21.) When that devoteeof Bharga (≈öiva) whose brilliancy resembled that of the sun, had gone to the mansion of the gods, the earth, like Dh√¢r√¢, was filled with dense darkness, his foes, (and) his hereditary warriors became infirm in body. Then arose1237king Uday√¢ditya, another sun, as it were, destroying the dense darkness, the exalted focs, with the rays issuing from his strong sword, (and thus) gladdening the hearts of his people by his splendour.

(22.) Lo! how easy was the rescue of this earth for that Param√¢ra, by whom the primeval boar was restored without a difficulty.1238

(23.)…………………………………………………..

XXIX.‚ÄîTHE NEW INSCRIPTION OF TORAMANA SHAHA.
By G. B√úHLER, PH.D., LL.D., C.I.E.

The present edition of the inscription of Toram√¢·πáa Sh√¢ha, or Sh√°hi, Ja√ªvla has been prepared according to two paper impressions furnished to me by Dr. Burgess. The inscription, which was found at Kura in the Salt Range and is now in the Lahore Museum, is incised on a sandstone slab, measuring 2’ 4" by 1‚Ä≤ 8‚Ä≥, the lower part of which, about six inches in height, has been left blank. The inscription consisted of thirteen lines of unequal length, the first three of which have been seriously injured at both ends, while the right-hand portion of the twelfth and the thirteenth seem to have been obliterated by the writer of the original and to have been partly re-written. A good many strokes are visible on the injured portions. But I do not dare to propose any restoration.

The characters resemble those found in the older Buddhist nail-headed inscriptions

of the Gupta period, but show certain peculiarities. Very characteristic are the curves attached to the left-hand limbs of ga and ≈õa, the peculiar angular form of the sa, the horizontal stroke of which has been attached to the left-hand limb and forms with it a triangle open at the top just as in the modern handwriting of Rajput√¢n√¢. The roundness of va is likewise remarkable. The language is the mixed dialect, incorrect Sansk·πõit strongly modified through the influence of the vernacular Pr√¢k·πõit, which once used to be called the GƒÅtha dialect on account of its occurrence in the metrical portions of the sacred writings of the Northern Buddhists. In my opinion it has been produced by the efforts of half-educated people to write the sacred language of the Br√¢hma·πás. The earliest specimens usually show the greatest number of abnormal forms. Those occurring in this inscription have been discussed in detail in the notes to the translation.

The object of the inscription is to record the construction of a Buddhist monastery by one Ro»õa-Siddhav·πõiddhi, the son of Ro·π≠·π≠a-Jayavriddhi, for the teachers of the Mahi≈õ√°saka school.

The donor states (1. 7) that his father was honoured by the lord of Na≈õchira, either a town or a district, and was the lord or manager of many Viharas (see note 19 to the translation). The inscription was incised during the reign of the king of kings, the great king Toram√¢·πáa ShƒÅha, or Sh√¢hi, Ja≈´vla, to whom and to whose family the donor wishes to make over a share of the merit gained by his pious gift., The date unfortunately not readable with the exception of the month and of the day, the second tithi of the bright half of M√¢rga≈õiras. This circumstance makes it impossible to accurately fix the age of the inscription. On pal√¶ographical grounds it may be assigned to the fourth or the fifth century. I am not able to assert that the Toram√¢≈Üa of our inscription is identical either with the Toram√¢·πáa of the Er√¢n inscription or with the Toram√¢·πáa of Ka≈õmir, who is mentioned by Kalha·πáa and who has left behind so many coins inscribed with Gupta characters. The fact that this Toram√¢·πáa bears the title or surname Sh√¢ha or Sh√¢hi and receives the epithet Ja≈´vla which may be a tribal name or a Biruda, is, it seems to me, sufficient to prevent the identification with the other Toram√¢·πáas, who are not characterised in this manner. All I would say regarding him is that he ruled over north-western India, and that he was an independent king. The latter point is indicated by his titler√°j√°[dhi]r√°ja, ‚Äòking of kings,’ or, more accurately, ‘superior king of kings.’ It is also highly probable that he was not a native Indian. The name Toram√¢·πáa is neither Sanskrit nor PrƒÅk·πõit, but in all probability a foreign one. Professor J. Karabacek of Vienna informs me that it is Turkish, where t√∂ram√°n, t√∫ram√°n or t√∂remen means ‘a rebel or insurgent’; and he is inclined to connect Ja≈´vla with jvl, ‘a faleon.’ A Laga-Turman is mentioned by Alber√ªn√Æ, vol. II, p. 13 (Sachau’s translation), as the last king of the Thibetan (?) or Turk ShƒÅhidynasty of northern India, among whom was Kanik (Kanishka ?).

TRANSCRIPT.

L. 1. - [‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ] - ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§§‡•ã‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§∑‡§æ [‡§π‡§ø] ‡§ú‡§ï‡•ç‡§§- - [[‡§≠‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á —-‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•á]’]1239

2.- - - - -‘‡§Æ‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§∂‡§ø‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§∂‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ö‡§æ [‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞] ——- ——–‡§ó‡§ó1240

L. 3. - -‡§µ‡§∞- - ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§®‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ï‡•Ç‡§≤‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§ø [‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü- - - - - - - -[‡§®]- -

4. ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ã ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø [‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§£‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§§ [‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø]]1241

5. ‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§∏‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡§æ[‡§¶‡§∂‡§¨‡§≤‡§¨‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§Ç [‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ]]1242

6. ‡§Ö‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§£‡•Ä‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§§‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ó‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§≤‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§£‡§ø‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¨‡•Å1243

7. ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§ö‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∂‡•á ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ò‡•á ‡§¶‡•á‡§Ø‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§™‡§® ‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ-
8. ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§É ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§ú‡§Ø‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ã ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•Å

9. [‡§Æ‡§æ]‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã ‡§Ü‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ï‡§™‡•ã‡§∑‡§ï‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ú‡§Ç‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§∂‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡§•‡§æ
‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ã

10. ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ü‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ó‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•Å‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•É‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§§‡•ã‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§ú ‡§ä‡§µ‡§É ‡§∏-

11. ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§¶‡•Å‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡•á ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã-1244

12. ‡§™‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§ö‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∂‡•á ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ò‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•á ‡§Ü‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§∂‡§æ [‡§∏‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§æ1245 ‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡§ï‡§™‡•Å] - - - - -‡§§‡•á‡§£ [‡§Ü‡§ö‡§æ]
13- - - - - – ‡§§ - - - - - - - - -

TRANSLATION.

In the prosperous reign of the king of kings, the great king Toram√¢·πáa Sh√¢hi Ja√ª-; in the…… th year, on the second (lunar day) of the bright half of the month of M√¢rga≈õiras. Under the ……. Nakshatra, which is propitious for pure, tranquil meditation, study and reflection on salvation ………. this appropriate and meritorious gift,1246the erection of a Vih√¢ra for the congregation of the monks of divine Buddha, the god of gods,1247 freed from all sin and endowed with all holiness,1248the saviour of beings that have crossed the ocean of births,1249 who possesses1250 the power of theten powers,1251. Regarding the ten powers of Buddha see Dharmasahgraha (Anecdota Oronionsia, vol. I, part v ), No. lxxvi, and Professor Max M√ºller’s notes thereon.")who

has attained the four subjects of confidence,¬π‚Å¥the four analytical sciences,¬π‚Åµ the eighteen independent conditions,¬π‚Å∂the supernatural condition,¬π‚Å∑who cherishes all creatures and is most compassionate,‚Äîof which (congregation) Buddha is the chief and which comes from the four quarters of the world,‚Äî(has been made) by the virtuous son of Rotta-Jayav·πõid·∏çhi,¬π‚Å∏the lord of many Vih√¢ras,¬π‚Åπwhose name, praised and honoured by the lord of Na≈õchira, (indicates d) particularly (great) prosperity.

Whatever merit (there is) in this (act), may it be for the attainment of supreme knowledge by (my) parents, the instructors¬≤‚Å∞ of Jambudvipa that is famous for nurses and nourishers,‚Äî(their) sharebeing a preferential .one,‚Äî¬≤¬πmoreover by all the brothers, sisters, wives, sons and daughters of the lord of the VihƒÅra Rotta-Siddhav·πõiddhi,¬≤¬≤by all the queens, princes and princesses¬≤¬≥ of the great king Toram√¢·πáa Sh√¢ha Ja√ªvla 24(and) by all creatures. But this benefaction¬≤‚Åµby a Vih√¢ra (is) for the congregation of the monks of the four quarters, for the acceptance of the teachers, the Mah√Æs√¢sakas.¬≤‚Å∂ By the son of S√•ddhaka…………

  1. If chatuvaisaradya is the correct reading, the form chatu for chatu·∏• or chatur is Prakritic. Regarding the four subjects of confidence, see Dharmasa·πÅgraha, No. lxxvii. The translation is that of Childers’ Pali Dictionary, sub voce vesdrajja.

15.Chatasrapratisa·πÅvid√¢ is a monstrons form for chatushpratisamvid, in which the mutilated inflected form of the nominative has been preserved; compare above t√•rayitd. Regarding the four analytical sciences, secDharmasu·πÅgraha,No. li.

  1. Regarding the eighteen independent conditions, see Dharmasa·πÅgraha, No. lxxix.

  2. I translate adbhutadharma according to its etymological rense. The Dharmasa·πÅgraha, No. Ixii, and other works know the word as the name of one of the nine kinds of scriptures. It cannot have that meaning in this passage.

  3. I take Ro·π≠·π≠a, which stands hore before Jayavriddhi and appears below 1. 10 in the form Rota before the name of the donor Siddhavriddhi, to be the name of a caste, clan, or family. The case termination of the preceding ¬∫vi≈øeshavriddhi·∏• is, of course, utterly wrong. It ought to be ¬∫vriddhe·∏•, as the next following word shows. Ad√¢rita is the perfect past participle of the causative of adri.

19.The expression anekavih√¢rasvamino, ‘of the lord of many Viharas,’ indicates that Ro·π≠·π≠a-Jayavriddhi superintended several monasteries. The explanation of vih√°rasv√¢min is given in Beal’s Life of Hiuen-Tsiung, int. p. xxvi. See also Fleet, Corpus Inscriptionum Indicarum, vol. III, pp. 263, 272, note 3.

  1. Dur≈õayitdro evidently is to be taken with m√¢i√¢pitro and, like the lattor, a genitive of the dual. Its irregular formation from the strong stem has many analogies in the mixed dialect. The meaning of the phrase seems to be that, though India possesses many tender mothers and dutiful fathers, yet all can learn something from the donor’s parents.

  2. The translation of agrebh√°vapratyamsat√¢y√¢s tu by “(their) share being a preferential one” is only according to the general sense. Literally it means “but according to the condition of a preferential share.” Agrebh√°va stands for agrebhara. Regarding pratyamsa, see the Index to the Divy√¢vad√¢na, od. Cowell and Neill.

  3. The uninflected base Rotasiddhavriddhi has to be taken in the senseof a genitive as the preceding viharasvamino indicates. The form bhratar√¢·πá√¢m is derived from an a-stem bhr√¢tara, formed according to the analogy of numerous Prakrit forms.

  4. The incorrect form rajaduhit√¢nam, derived from an a-stem duhit√¢, is particularly interesting as the correct Sanskrit form duhitrin√°m occurs in the preceding line 10. It proves the utter loss of all feeling for the rules of the language.

  5. The nominative Toramanashahaja√ªvla·∏• has to be taken in the sense of a genitive governed by the following genitives.

  6. Upakara·πáa stands for upakara·πáam and, though a neuter, is connected with the masculine of the pronoun ayam. Puna is the ancient Prakrit form for punah.

  7. The fact that the Mahisasakas, one of the subdivisions studying the H√Ænay√¢na, weresettled in the Panj√¢b, is known from Hiuen-Tsiang’s description of the country; see Beal, Si-yu-ki, vol. I, p. 121. The meaning of the last sentence seems to be that all Buddhist monks shall partici-pate in the use of the Vihara, but that it is specially made over to the Mahisasaka teachers. The Mahisasakas formed one of the five branches of the Sarv√†stivada or Vaibhashika school.

XXX.‚ÄîAN UNDATED PRASASTI FROM THE REIGN OF MAHENDRAPALA OF KANAUJ.

BY G. B√úHLER, PH.D., LL.D., C.I.E.

A portion of the subjoined inscription was discovered many years ago by Mr. Bowring at Pehoa, together with the grant of the horse-dealers, dated [Sriharsha] Sa·πÅvat 276, in the reign of king Bhoja (ante, p. 184), and was published, together with the latter, by Dr. Rajendral√¢l Mitra in the Journal of the Asiatic Society of Bengal, vol. XXII, pp. 675 ff. Of late the whole document has been recovered, and the circumstances leading to its recovery are as follows. Dr. Burgess found that the stone slab, on which it is incised, was fixed in the wall of a house, in the bazar, belonging to a Siddh1252,close to the jamb of a door, and was used as a seat. As this jamb partly rested on the slab and covered a portion of the inscription, Dr. Burgess got Mr. Rodgers, the Archeological Surveyor in the Panj√¢b,.to try to prevail on the owner of the building to allow the slab to be removed. The latter, however, was unwilling to allow this, and Mr. Rodgers was then asked to undertake further negotiations and to get the countenance of Mr. Drummond, the Deputy Commissioner of Karn√¢l, in either purchasing the slab or in exchanging it for another that would do the same service to the owner. Through the kind offices of Mr. Drummond the stone was finally secured and sent to the Lahore Muscum, where Mr. J. L. Kipling, C.I.E., took two excellent paper-impressions, which were forwarded to Dr. Burgess by Mr. Rodgers and made over to me for preparing a new edition of the inscription. The inscription is now complete, while in the copy used by Dr. Rajendral√¢l about one third of each line-its left-hand portion‚Äîwas missing.

Judging from the impression, the slab on which the inscription is incised measures 36 inclies by 24. The stone-mason has done his work with great care; for there are very few Indian epigraphical monuments which show an equal amount of neatness and artistic finish in their execution. Owing to the rough treatment which the stone has undergone, a certain number of letters have, however, been either obliterated or become indistinct. Lines 3-7 have lost from four to seven letters at the beginning; in lines 1-6 the letters 17-21 on the left-hand side have been partly rubbed out, and lines 20-21 have lost a piece out of the middle. Moreover, a number of single letters and small groups have been defaced in various places on the right-hand side of the inscription. It is, however, fortunately possible to restore most of the lost signs with some degree of certainty by conjecture.

The characters of the inscription are of the ordinary N√¢gar√Æ type, current in Northern and Western India during the ninth and tenth centuries; and they resemble most closely those of the horse-dealers’ grant, mentioned above. The superscribed m√°tr√°s show, however, ornamental additions, similar to those used in the Jh√¢lr√¢p√¢·π≠a·πá Pra≈õasti (Indian Antiquary, vol. V,‘p. 180), and the same ornaments appear occasionally in the tails of some letters (see, e.g., note 10 to the transcript). The language is very good Sanskrit and throughout metrical. As regards the orthography, the constant substitution of va for baand the frequent use of the Jihv√¢m√ªl√Æya and Upadhm√°n√≠ya deserve to be noted, as well as some rather unusual sandhis,-e.g., in samani√°dyatu for samant√°ddyatu, line 4; sa≈õ≈õr√≠m√°n for sa ≈õr√≠m√°n, line 5; nirm√°n√°dve for nirm√°·πá√°ddve, line 12; satphal√°nammram√∫rti·∏•, line 15; and so forth.

The object of the inscription is to record the building, it would seem, of a triple temple of Vish≈Üu, and it contains a so-called Pra≈õasti or eulogy, as is expressly stated in verse 26. It opens with a ma·πÖgala of four verses, verses 1-2 being addressed to Vish·πáu, verse 3 to the Kurukshetra, and verse 4 to the sacred stream Sarasvati, which flows near P·πõithudaka-Pehoa. Verse Verse 5 praises the ruling king of the country, Mahendrap√¢la1253.

The next portion of the poem (verses 6-19) gives an account of certain members of the Tomara family (verse 6), the last three of which dedicated the temple mentioned in the inscription. The pedigree of the Tomaras enumerated is as follows:‚Äî

<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1709655064Screenshot2024-03-05160006.png"/>

Jaula (verses 6-8).
Vajrata, married to Mangaladevi (verses 9-10).

Jajjuka, married to Chandra and to N√¢yik√¢ (verses 11-13).
Gogga P√¢rnaraja Devaraja
(verse 14). (verses 15-16). (verses 17-19).

Regarding J√¢ula it is said that he was a r√°j√°, ‘obtained prosperity by looking after the affairs of a king,and built many temples. It appears, therefore, that he was in the civil employ of some king or other, and received, as was often the case with ministers and other high officials, the title of raj√°. How many generations intervened between him and Vajrata, the next person mentioned, cannot be made out. But the remark (verse 9) that the family was ‚Äúthe home of joyful, prospering intimates of kings,‚Äùindicates that its members continued to hold high places in the service of their sovereigns. The same seems to have been the case with Vajra»õa, who, it is alleged, ‚Äúgained a lofty exaltation through most pure business transactions.‚ÄùJ√¢ula’s title was probably likewise inherited by his descendants, since Gogga is called bh√∫n√°tha·∏•, protector of the earth,‚Äôwhich appellation may be considered as a poetical rendering of the moreprosaic r√°j√°. If the general description in verses 11-19 may be trusted, Jajjuka and his three sons entered the military service of their sovereign. For nothing is said of their success in business, but their bravery and their victories over their enemies are highly extolled. Verse 20 states that the three brothers built here,’ i.e., in Pehoa, temples of Vish·πáu, and verse21 attributes (that) in the middle’ to Gogga, (that) at the back to P√¢rnar√¢ja, and (that) in front to Devar√¢ja.’ Nevertheless verse 22, which contains the usual wish for the long duration of the building, speaks only of one single temple (idam ayatanam). The only possible solution of this contradiction seems to be that the structure was a triple temple, containing three statues and three adyta, united under one roof. Temples of this description do occur elsewhere, and we still have a very fine specimen in the famous Vastup√¢lavili√•ra on Mount Girnar1254.

The next verso (23) gives the name of the architect, Achyuta, son of R√¢ma, who was a native of K√¢mboja, or a K√¢buli. Verse 24 enumerates the names of three villages, YakshapƒÅlaka, Gejjara, and P√¢»õala, which were assigned for the bhoga of the deity,

EPIGRAPHIA INDICA.

i.e., for the service of the temple; and verse 25 exhorts future princes to respect this donation. In verse 26 the poet gave his own name which, unfortunately, has not been fully preserved. It began with mu and contained three [syllables1255. The poet’s father was Bha·π≠·π≠a R√¢ma. The name of the mason (verse 27) who incised the inscription‚Äî.al√¢ditya‚Äîis likewise mutilated; that of his father Durlabh√¢ditya has been preserved.

Though the inscription is not dated, its age can yet be fixed within very narrow limits. For the paramount sovereign Mahendrap√¢la, whom it mentions, belonged without doubt to the dynasty of Kanauj, and was the successor of the Bhoja who, according to the Pehoa grant of the horse-dealers, ruled in A.D.882. Professor Kielhorn’s article on the Siya·∏ço·πái inscription, ante, p. 171, establishes the following series of sovereigns who ruled at Kanauj during the second half of the ninth century and the first half of the tenth.

  1. Bhoja, A.D.862, 876, and 882.
  2. MahendrapƒÅla or Mahindrap√¢la1256,A.D.903 and 907.
  3. His son Kshitip√¢la or Mah√Æp√¢la, A.D.917.
  4. His son Devap√¢la, A.D.948.

The identity of our MahendrapƒÅla with the second sovereign of this list is proved (1) by the fact that the inscription belongs to Pehoa, which, as the grant of the horsedealers shows, Tormed part of the kingdom of Kanauj, and (2) by the close resemblance of the letters of our inscription to those of the grant just mentioned, which makes it impossible to assume that they are separated by a long interval. If this identification is admitted, our Pra≈õasti must have been incised between A.D. 882 and A.D.917.

With respect to the four Tomaras, mentioned in our inscription, I may add that they possibly may have been in the employ of the kings of Kanauj. But, as no direct statement to that effect occurs, it is impossible to be positive. For Prithudaka‚ÄîPehoa was a place of so great sanetity, that even pious men from distant countries may have built temples there; and if strangers did so, their inscriptions, as a matter of course, would mention the ruling king of the country. Equally uncertain remains the relation of these Tomaras to the Tomara dynasties which reigned at Delhi and in Central India. But the early occurrence of the name of this race in Northern India still possesses some interest, and may hercafter, when more documents bearing on the history of the Tomaras are found, become of importance. Though the positive historical results, obtained from this Pra≈õasti, are not very important, its complete publication has nevertheless some value, as it shows how entirely unfounded were the curious deductions made from the earlier imperfect edition. Its contents are now perfectly reconcilable with the information furnished by the other contemporaneous documents.

‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ã[‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡§Æ]‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ò‡§æ‡§§‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§¶‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§
‡§Ö‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§ó‡§£‡•à‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡•ã‡§ß[‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ó‡§æ‡§¢‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§ü‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ã‡§¶‡•à‡§É‡•• [‡•©] ‡••]1259
4. ‡§™‡•Ä‡§§‚Äî ‚Äî‚âç‚Äî‡§ß‡•å ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§™‡§•‡§ó‡§Æ‡§®‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•Å [‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó],‚Äî ‚Äî ‚Äî‚Äî‡§§‡§µ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•á‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡§Ø‡§ú‡§≤‡§ß‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡•§
5. ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ö‡•Å‡§∞‡§§‡§∞‡§§‡§Æ ‚âç‡§™‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§≠‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡•Ä‡§∞‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•Å ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø‡§§[‚âç‚Äî ‚Äî ‚âç[‡§∏‡§æ] ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§É ‡•• [‡•™]‡••]1260
‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§É‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤ ‚âç‚Äî ‚âç‚Äî ‚âç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ
‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‚âç ‡§™‡§∞‡§µ‡§≤‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§
‡§∏‡§∂‡•ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§π‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§É
[‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç ‡§∂‡§∂‡§ß‡§∞‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡§É ‡§∂‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡•• [‡•´] ‡••]1261

  1. ‡§Ü‡§∏‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∂‡§§‡§ø[‡§≤‡§ï‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§™‡•ç‡§∞] ‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡•ã‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡•ã
    ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ ‡§∞‡§Ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§[‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§¶‡•Å]‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∂‡•à‡§≤‡§æ‡§∂‡§®‡§ø‡§É ‡•§
    ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§â‡§≤ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ã ‡§¶‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø[‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§ø‡§§‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§≤‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡•ã‡§¶‡§Ø‡§É‡•• [‡•¨] ‡••]1262
  2. ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§ï‚Äî ‚âç‚âç ‚âç‚Äî ‡§®‡•Ä] ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§¶‡§Ç
    ‡§õ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§∂‡§ï‡§≤‡•àX ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•ã‡§™‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§É ‡•§
    ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö ‡§®‡§æ‡§ï‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã[‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Å‡§∞‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•Å‡§≤‡•Ä‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• [‡•≠] ‡••]1263
    ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§¶‡§ø‡§∂-

[‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡§æ]‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‚Äì

‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ó‡§ø‡§§‡§∂‡§∂‡§ß‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡•§
‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§§‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø
‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§∂‡§á‡§µ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•Å‡§Ç‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§µ‡•ã ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§ñ‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡••[[‡•Æ‡••]]1264
‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§π‡•ã‡§¶‡§ß‡•á‚âç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§ú‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‚Äì

‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§ô‡•ç‡§ò‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§®‡§Æ‡•å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¶‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡§ú‡§®‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§ô‡•ç‡§∂‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡§ï‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§∞‡§ü‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‚âç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•Å‚âç
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§∞‡§•‡§∂‡•ç ‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡§§‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•Å‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§§‡§ø‡§É[‡••[‡•Ø‡••]]118
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Å‡§∞‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø‡§É ‡§∂‡•å‡§∞‡•á‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ ‡§ú‡§≤‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ [\‡•§]

‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§≤‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•Ä ‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§ú‡•á‡§µ ‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø[‡••[‡•ß‡•¶‡••]]127
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•Å‡§ï‚âç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§¶‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§∂‡•ç ‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•Å‡•§
‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§∞ x ‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§ï‡•Å‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§∞‡§ô‡•ç‡§ò‡§æ‡§®‡§∞‡•å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•á[‡••[‡•ß‡•ß‡••]]1265

‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Å‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§ñ‡§°‡•ç‡§ó‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∂‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‚Äì
‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§£‡•ã‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡§ï‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡•á
‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§¨‡§≠‡•Ç‡§µ‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡§∂‡§∂‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á[‡••[‡•ß‡•®‡••]]114
‡§è‡§ï‡§æ ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ç‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö‡•§

‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§è‡§µ ‡§∏‡§¶‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§É[‡••[‡•ß‡•©‡••]]1266
‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø ‡§ó‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡•§
‡§≠‡•Ç‡§®‡§æ‡§•‡•ã ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø[‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§§‡§≤]‡§∂‡•ç ‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§É[‡••[‡•ß‡•™‡••]]1267

‡§Ö[‡§∏‡•Ç]‡§§ [‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø-]‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§Ç
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§≤‡§∏‡•à‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•ã‡§∞‡•Å‡§π‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§®‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡§®‡•Å ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§Ç
‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∂‡§ó‡§ó‡§®‡•ã‡§¶‡§∞‡•á ‡§§‡•Å‡§π‡§ø‡§®[‡§¶‡•Ä‡§ß‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø]‡§ï‡§æ [‡••[‡•ß‡•´‡••]]1268

‡§ï‡§∞‡§§[‡§≤] ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ó‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§ß‡§∞‡§™‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§µ‡§æ ‚âç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§®‡•Å‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§™‡•ã‡§≤‡§§‡§≤‡•ã‡§¶‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡§ø‡§∑‡§ø‡§ö‡•Å‡§∞‡§∏‡•Å‡§ú‡§≤‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ö‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§ú‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§æ‡§É[‡••[‡•ß‡•¨‡••]]1269
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ã‡§¶‡§∞‡•ã‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§É

‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§ú‚âç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§§‡§™‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§É‡•§

L.15 ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø‡§Æ‡§≤‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡§É
‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§§‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§´‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É[‡••[‡•ß‡•≠]]696
‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§ü‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡§Ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•Å‡§ü‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•§
‡§¶‡•É‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ß‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ó‡§æ‡§¢‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç

16. ‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç‡§∏‡•á ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§≤‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡•É‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§É‡•§ [[‡•ß‡•Æ‡••]]1270

‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡•Ä‡§∞‡•Å‡§π‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ-
‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡§É‡•§
‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§§ ‡§ö ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡§ü‡§ô‡•ç‡§ò‡§®‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç
‡§ò‡§ü‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ò‡§ü‡§®‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•Ä

17. ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§É[‡•• [‡•ß‡•Ø‡••]]1271

‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§ü‡§ø‡§§‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ x ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§£
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç ‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡§§‡§∞‡§ß‡§ø‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§ø‡•§
‡§µ‡§ø‡§£‡•ã‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•å‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡§Æ‡§π‡§∏ X ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®
‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä[‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ú‡§≤]‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó[‡§Æ‡§æ-]‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§µ‡•ã‡§ß‡•à‡§É[‡••[‡•®‡•¶‡••]]1272

**18.**‡§ó‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§§‡•ã ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•á‡§® ‡§ò‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§§‡§Æ‡§∏‡§õ‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡•§[[‡•§‡•®‡•ß‡••]]1273
‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡•á‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§§‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§á‡§¶‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡§®‡§Ç ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§¶‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§É[‡••[‡•®‡•®‡••]]115

‡§ß‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§ø[‡§™‡•ç‡§∞]‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø-
19. ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§ü‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•ã‡§ú‡§ú‚âç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•Å‡§Æ‡§® X ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§´‡•ã
‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø‡§π ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§µ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§µ‡•• [[‡•®‡•©‡••]]1274

‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•à‡§ï‡•ã ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§ó‡•á‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§∞‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡§æ‡§ü‡§≤‡§æ[‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø]‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•É‡§§‡•Ä[‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§ø ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ-]

20. ‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§≠‡•ã‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§É[‡••[‡•®‡•™‡••]]1275

‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§•‡•à‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•§‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡•ã‡§ö‡•à‡§É ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§É[‡•• [‡•®‡•´‡••]]1276

‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§ó‡§ó‡§®‡§≠[‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§É] -‡§ø -‡§æ‡•í‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§É
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß‡•ã‡§≠‡§ü‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ x ‡§ï‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§ï‡•É‡§§ ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞ [‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å] - ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø

L.21‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§≤‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•Ä‡§≤‡§Ø‡•á‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡••[‡•®‡•¨‡••]
‡§µ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§µ ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§≤‡§≠‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§
—Ö—Ö—Ö—Ö - - \‡•§‡§≤‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§§‡§æ‡••[‡•• ‡•®‡•≠‡••]

TRANSLATION.

Om! Adoration to M√¢dhava!

(V. 1.) May that chief male (purusha) Vish·πáu protect you; he who, alone (remaining) sleeps, when the regent of the night (the moon) has disappeared, when the mountainshave completely crumbled away, when the foe of darkness (the sun) has been destroyed,when mankind have been annihilated, when the host of stars has tumbled down, whenthe circle of the earth has fallen, and thus the oceans have become one.

(2.) May lovely Vish·πáu’s beautiful eye, that is pleasing through the quivering ofthe brow and charming with its resplendent pupil, protect all the three worlds‚Äî (the eye)of him who plunges into the ocean of nascent deep love, (of him) whose lustre [is increased by] the great splendour of Lakshm√Æ’s moon-like face, (of him) whose cheek isdimpled with smiles.

(3.) May the field of Kuru grant a happiness, free from all pain, ‚Äî(that field)which is able to remove the impurity of sins of many kinds, that is inhabited by crowdsof sages, who have destroyed the dense darkness (of ignorance) by gaining the knowledgeof the self (and hence) are filled with deep joy.

(4.) And may that [beautiful] water of Sarasvat√Æ’s (stream) entirely cut your [bondsof] misery‚Äî (that water which is) a boat [for crossing the ocean of births], a chariot fortravelling along the road of the gods, a cloud such as appears on the destruction of theworld, shedding copious showers on the fire of . . . . . .the virtuous (and)a sun to destroy the thick mud-like darkness of a concatenation of various diseases^(6).

(5.) Victorious is his glorious majesty Mahendrap√¢la, who is able [to bless] hisrace with prosperity and destroys the courage of the armies of his foes all around, whoseenemies are subdued, who is beautiful like the moon and grants protection.

(6.) There was a king, J√¢ula by name, the front ornament of the exalted Tomararace, resplendent with [fiery] bravery, who gladdened the hearts of the virtuous, whowas a thunderbolt for (those) mountains, the wicked, who was famous for his wonderfuldeeds, adorned with compassion, (and) acquainted with truth, who gained prosperityby looking after the affairs of (his) sovereign
____________________________________

6. I take ‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•Å in the fourth P√¢da to stand for ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç and ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•Å, just as ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•áin verse 13 line 12) stands for‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡•ç and ‡§π‡•á. The words placed between square brackets are, here and in the sequel, translations of my conjecturalrestorations.

(V. 7.) He conducted his relatives to highest prosperity . . . .., presentingas offerings to the earth, pieces cut off from the temples of the mighty elephants of his foes;and his fame, that possessed a splendour fair like the glittering moon, assumed the guiseof the stream of heaven (Ga·πÖg√¢), since it clave to the heavenly elephants and united withthe sky.

(8.) That (man), possessed of far-spreading lustre, built in this world in every regionnumerous palaces of the immortals, that obscure the moon with their lofty tops, (and)they look from afar like posts fixed (by him) at the quarters of the horizon in order to setlimits to his fame.

(9.) From his famous ocean-like race, that is the home of joyful prospering intimatesof princes, that is difficult to overcome, and possesses great riches of numerous resplendent pearls^(1),sprung a lord, called the illustrious Vajra·π≠a, the front-ornament of hisfamily, who obtained all his wishes and gained a lofty elevation through most purebusiness transactions.

(10.) He wedded a wife, charming like the glittering moon, called Ma·πÖgaladev√Æjust as ≈öauri (Vish·πáu) (took) the daughter of the ocean (Lakshm√Æ) and Giri≈õa (≈öiva)the daughter of the mountain (P√¢rvat√Æ).

(11.) He begot by her Jajjuka, who (was) exceedingly peaceful among good menwho are free from envy, (but) a terrible comet for the army of his invincible foes, thatinspired terror through the trumpeting of the angry war elephants.

(12.) He (Jajjuka), who cut down his enemies with his sharp sword and gained widespreading glory by succouring the fearful, the blind and the distressed, had two wives,who were almost the front-ornaments of virtuous, attached women, and lovely like thenoble moon.

(13.) One was famed as Chandr√¢ and the second as N√¢yik√¢; being created outof the most excellent virtues, they were both abodes of happiness.

(14.) From Chandr√¢ was born a prince, called Gogga, whom the creator placed atthe head of firm men, who gladdened the earth with the pearls issuing from the rentsin the temples of the elephants of his foes, who possessed a sharp sword.

(15.) And afterwards N√¢yik√¢ bore a clever son, P√ªr≈Ü·πáar√¢ja, a destroyer of thesplendour of the adherents of his enemics, a conglomerate of the rays of the sun for thoselotuses, the soldiers of his army, a foe of unrighteousness, a moon in the womb of hisrace (that is pure) like the sky.

(16.) The wives of his foes, covering their lips, (red) like young shoots, with theirhands, and straightening their rich curls, moistened their hollow checks, that possessedlittle splendour, with the water of their tears.

(17.) Devar√¢ja, a storeof virtues, was his uterine brother; he who destroyed thedense darkness, the armics of his foes, by a sudden burst of his brilliant courage, (hewho was) the abode of forbearance, destroyed the impurity of the Kali age, cast off loveand the other sinful passions, and resembled a tree, giving agreeable shade and bendingunder good fruit.^(2)

^(_______________________________)

1. In order to make the translation less cumbersome, I have not given the second meanings of ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§ú‡§Ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Øand‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§π. Referred to the ocean, they mean which is the abode of joyful rising snakes and which is difficult to cross.“Regarding the meaning of ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ú‡§Ç‡§ó, ‘an intimate of a king’ (not a dissolute intimate of a king), see the smaller St. PetersburgDictionary, sub voce.

**2.**The double meanings of ‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ø and ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§´‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø have been intentionally omitted.

(V. 18.) When the proud (foes) whose exceeding brilliancy unfolded itself in thebattle merely heard the most famous name of that (warrior) who angrily furrowed hisface with frowns, then their strong swords fell from their hands.

19.) When suppliants with rapture looked on his lotus face, their mental anxietycompletely vanished in an instant; and the crowd of hostile, trumpeting elephantsalways shook before him in battle, ready to disperse.

(20.) These three (brothers), who thus were lovable on account of the manifestationof extraordinary famous virtues, who gradually gained wealth, who were most pureminded and attached to holy men, caused to be built here temples of Vish·πáu, who isendowed with unequalled greatness, because they were afraid of the dreadful ocean ofexistences that is difficult to cross for men of little wisdom.

(21.) (The temple) in the middle has been built by Gogga’s order, (that) at theback by P√ªr·πáar√¢ja’s, and (that) in front by Devar√¢ja’s, in order to destroy thedense, deep darkness.

(22.) As long as this earth is bounded by the four oceans, so long may this temple beresplendent as a mansion of ≈öri.

(23.) A man of K√¢mboja descent, the son of R√¢ma, whose famous name isAchyuta, was here the overseer (k√¢rayit√¢), he who is an image of Dhanvantari, an incarnation of the quintessence of learning, a friend of the virtuous, and a bee on the lotus ofthe heart of his master.

(24.) One village called Yakshap√¢laka, a second named Gejjara, and a thirdnamed P√¢»õala, have been assigned for the enjoyment (of the god)1277,’ i.c., for the temple-service.”).

(25.) With respect to this (gift), noble protectors of the earth, considering the courseof mundane existence, must show an entirely virtuous disposition1278for the welfare oftheir bodies.

(26.) There was, indeed, a Bhatta R√¢ma, the sun of his sky-like race, attached to . …, learned and modest; his son, Mu …. . . made in play (as it were) this sweetly composed, graceful eulogy that is full of sentiment.

(27.) Here was a mason named Durlabh√¢ditya. [His son], wise . . . . .√¢l√¢ditya,[has engraved it.]

XXXI.‚ÄîBILHARI STONE INSCRIPTION OF THE RULERS OF CHEDI.

BY PROFESSOR F. KIELHORN, PH.D., C.L.E; G√ñTTINGEN.

The stone which bears this inscription^(1)is said to have been found at Bilhari, theBalihrior Bilheree of the maps, Indian Atlas, quarter-sheet No. 70 S.E., Latitude 23¬∞ 48’ North, Longitude 80¬∞ 19‚Ä≤ East, described as one of the oldest towns in the JabalpurDistrict of the Central Provinces. In 1861 it was at Jabalpur, where it was reportedto have been carried about 20 years before ; and it is now in the N√¢gpur Musceum.

The inscription consists of 33 lines which cover a space of about 6’ 3" broad by 3’high, and are surrounded by a raised edge all the way round. With the exception of oneor two aksharas at the end of the lines, the writing is well preserved up to line 30, andthe reading, in consequence, is so far hardly anywhere in the least doubtful. But inthe last three lines, as will appear from my transcript of the text, altogether between 30and 40 aksharas have become illegible, at the lower proper left corner of the stone andin the first half of the last line. The average size of the letters is ^(3/4"). The characters areN√¢gar√Æ of about the eleventh century; they were well and carefully written by N√¢i,the son of the kara·πáika or writer of legal documents Dh√Æra, and skilfully engraved byNonna, the son of the artisan Sa·πÅgama (verse 86).

The language is Sanskrit; and, excepting the introductory o·πÅ o·πÅ nama·∏• ≈öiv√¢ya, thewords api cha and ki√±cha in lines 1 and 19, and short passages in lines 30-33, the inscription is in verse. The verses 1 to 45 were composed by ≈ör√Æniv√¢sa, the son ofSthir√¢nanda; the remaining verses, at any rate up to verse 78, by Sajjana, the son ofTh√Æra (verses 77-78). As a piece of poetry, the inscription possesses little merit, and ofits two authors Sajjana is inferior to ≈ör√Æniv√¢sa, both as a poet and as regards his knowledge of the language. In respect of orthography, there are few things that need here bedrawn attention to. The letter bis throughout denoted by the sign for v. The sibilantsare generally employed each in its proper place, and we find the dental sibilant used forthe palatal only in visarppat-saurya-, line 14; k√Ærttis=Saiv√°√¢gama-, line 20; and sho·∏çasik√¢,line 31. Instead of anusv√°ra we have the dental nasal in the interior of simple words invan≈õa, lines 3, 21, and 29; vidhvansa, line 4; uttansa, line 6; m√¢nsa, line 9; tap√¢nsitej√°√¢nsi, line 20; hansa, line 28; ‚Äîand at the end of words before a sibilant, e.g., insans√¢ra, line 24 (twice); evan-sambhavatsu, line 6; iltthan-sadvandi-, line 13, etc. Freequently a final m has been left unchanged before an initial v, e.g., in ¬∫·∏çamvaram=va·∏• and¬∫t√¢m-vibhrati, line 3; bhuvam-vilebhe, line 8; yam-v√≠√Ækshya, line 14, etc.; ‚Äîand final n hasremained unchanged before j and ≈õ in bhagav√¢n-jyotsn√¢m, line 16, and gu·πá√¢n-≈õakshyati,line 26. The dental nasal has been wrongly changed to the lingual in *dhenur-·πá·πáanu,*line 15, and it has been wrongly retained in vair√¢gyena, line 21. Before r, t has been
____________________________

1. The text has been published before, with an abstract of the contents, by Dr. F. E. Hall in the Jour. As. Soc. Beng. vol. XXX, pp. 317-334; and the contents of the inscription, as furnished by Dr. Hall, have been discussed by Sir A.Cunningham, Arch√¶ological Survey of India, vol. IX, pp. 80 and 102-105. My own text, which will be found to differin some important particular from Dr. Hall’s, has been prepared from two good impressions, one of which I owe to Dr.Burgess and the other to Mr. Fleet.

frequently doubled, e.g., in ≈õvet√¢tapattr√¢yita·πÅ, line 1; nettr√¢d-Attrer-ddharittr√Æ-, line 8;Datt√¢ttreya, line 5, etc.; ‚Äîand, on the other hand, a single consonant has been employedinstead of a double consonant in ujvalim√¢, line 3; ujvalam, lines 28 and 30; ·µílasadyu¬∞ (for¬∫lasad-dyu), line1; √¢sidvishad¬∫ (for √¢sid-dvishad¬∫) and proc·∏•chhalajv√¢l√¢¬∞ (for prochchhalaj-jv√¢l√¢¬∫), line 4. Lastly, the syllable ri has been used instead of the vowel ·πõi indripta, line 12, and in saty√¢dritas, line 14. As instances of wrong grammatical forms.I may point out ak·πõita, used in a passive sense (for ak√¢ri) in verse 54, and the masculine¬∫srakchandan√¢d√Æn in verse 62, wrongly employed instead of the neuter ¬∫srakchandan√¢d√Æni.

The inscription may possibly have contained a date at the end of the last line; but,if such was the case, it has become entirely effaced, and is no longer legible. I havealready stated that the inscription has been composed by two different authors; andI have no doubt that, what is now its first portion, from verse 1 to 45, originally was,or formed part of, an independent pra≈õasti, and that this original pra≈õasti was renewedand enlarged by the addition of the verses 46-86 of the present inscription, two or threegenerations after the composition of the first part.

The object of the first part (versces 1-45) is, to record that the queen Nohal√¢, thewife of (the Chedi ruler) Key√ªravarsha, erected a temple of ≈öiva at which the inscription may be supposed to have been put up; that she endowed this temple with (therevenues of) the villages Dha·πÖga·π≠ap√¢·π≠aka, Po·πá·∏ç√Æ, N√¢gabala, Khailap√¢·π≠aka,V√Æ·∏ç√¢, Sajj√¢hal√Æ and Gosh·π≠hap√¢l√Æ; and that she also gave the villages of Nip√¢n√Æyaand Ambip√¢·π≠aka to the sage √é≈õvara≈õiva, a disciple of ≈öabda≈õiva, who again was adisciple of Pavana≈õiva (verses 40-45). Nohal√¢ was a daughter of Avanivarman,a son of Sadhanva and grandson of Si·πÅhavarman, of the clan of the Chaulukyas (verses 33-37). And her husband Key√ªravarsha was a son of the princeMugdhatu·πÖga (verse 18), who was a son of Kokkalladeva (verse 12), described as adescendant of Arjuna (K√¢rtav√Ærya, verse 8), of the tribe of the Haihayas (verse 7),who belonged to the lunar race. Of Kokkalladeva it is recorded (verse 17) that he setup two unprecedented columns of his fame,’ which I understand to mean that he wasallied with, and supported the rule of, K·πõish·πáar√¢ja in the south and Bhojadeva inthe north; and Mugdhatu·πÖga is eulogised as having conquered the lines of country bythe shore of the eastern sea and wrested P√¢li from the lord of Kosala.

The second part of the inscription (in versc 46) opens with the statement thatNohal√¢’s son by Yuvar√¢jadeva was Lakshma·πáar√¢ja, ‚Äîfrom which it is clear that theprince Key√ªravarsha, who is spoken of in the preceding, was surnamed Yuvar√¢jadeva. Lakshma·πáar√¢ja, called ’the moon of the Chedis’ (verse 56) and ’the powerful Chedilord’ (verse 59), made over the sacred buildings which had been founded by Nohal√¢ tocertain sages whose spiritual lineage is detailed in verses 48-58. On his warlike expeditions he is said to have reached the shores of the western ocean, where he worshipped≈öiva at the famous temple of Some≈õvaraor Soman√¢tha in Gujar√¢t; and he also isreported to have defeated the ruler of Kosala, and to have despoiled him of a valuableeffigy of K√¢liya which had been obtained from the lord of O·∏çra, and which subsequently

was by Lakshma·πáar√¢ja likewise dedicated to Some≈õvara (verses 59-63). His son was≈öa·πÅkaraga·πáa (verse 64), and the younger brother of this prince was Yuvar√¢jadeva(verse 67). Nothing of historical importance is recorded of either of these two brothers.

We have then here presented to us the following line of Chedi princes:

(1.) Kokkalladeva; supported K·πõishnar√¢ja in the south and Bhojadeva inthe north.

(2.) His son Mugdhatu·πÖga; wrested P√¢li from the lord of Kosala.

(3.) His son Key√ªravarsha-Yuvar√¢jadeva; married Nohal√¢, the daughterof the Chaulukya Avanivarman.

(4.) Their son Lakshma·πáar√¢ja; defeated the king of Kosala and worshippedSome≈õvara in Gujar√¢t.

(5.) His son ≈öa·πÅkaraga·πáa.

(6.). His younger brother Yuvar√¢jadeva.

Reserving a full account of the history of the Chedi rulers for a future occasion, Iwill only state here that I agree with Sir A. Cunningham in assigning the Kokkalladeva of this inscription to the end of the ninth century A. D., and in distinguishinghim from Kokalladeva, the son of Yuvar√¢jadeva and father of G√¢·πÖgeyadeva, of otherChedi inscriptions, who must have lived about 100 years later. For there can beno doubt that the K·πõsh·πáar√¢ja and Bhojadeva, who are spoken of as his contemporaries, are the R√¢sh·π≠rak√ª·π≠a K·πõsh·πáa II., whom we know to have married a daughterof Kokkalla,and who reigned from about A. D. 875 to about A. D. 911, and Bhojadevaof Kanauj, for whomwe have the dates A. D. 862, 876, and 882, and who had ceasedto reign in A. D. 903. And considering this point to be certain, I feel no hesitationin assigning our inscription to about the end of the 10th or the beginning of the11th century A. D., ‚Äîa period to which it may be assigned also on pal√¶ographicalgrounds.

There are still one or two points in our inscription which may here be drawn attention to. The account of the sages who are mentioned in connection with the princeLakshma·πáar√¢ja opens by glorifying a place Kadambaguh√¢ (verse 48), and mentions aprince, named Avanti, who apparently made over to one of the sages a town whichwas perhaps called Mattamay√ªra. These (and one or two other) names occur alsoin an inscription at Ranod, which has been edited in the Jour. *As. Soc. Beng.*vol. XVI, p. 1080, but which must remain useless for the elucidation of the presentinscription until it has been edited properly. Besides, we find towards the end of ourinscription, between verses 83 and 84, the names of the towns Tripur√Æ, Saubh√¢gyapura, Lava·πáanagara, Durlabhapura, and Vim√¢napura (?), the inhabitants of whichwould seem to have had to contribute towards the support of the temple founded byNohal√¢. Of these towns, which no doubt all belonged to the Chedi kingdom, Tripur√Æhas been identified with the village of Tewar near Jabalpur, and Saubh√¢gyapura probablyis the town of Soh√¢gpur in the Hoshang√¢b√¢d District; the others I am unable to identify. And lastly, it may be pointed out that verse 85 contains a curious reference to thepoet R√¢ja≈õekhara, whom in my account of the S√Æya·∏ço·πá√Æ inscription I have shown tohave flourished at the beginning of the tenth century A. D. The manner in which

his name is mentioned here1279,shows that he must have been a poet of great repute aboutthe commencement of the eleventh century.

In conclusion, it may be stated that, of the villages which are said to have beengranted by the queen Nohal√¢, Po·πá·∏ç√Æ has by Sir A. Cunningham1280 been identified withthe village of Po·πá·∏çi which still exists 4 miles to the north-west of Bilhari, and that,according to the same authority, Khailap√¢·π≠aka most probably is now represented byKhailw√¢ra, 6 miles east-north-east of Bilhari.
