  11. ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§ø‡§ï‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§≤ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø [*] ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡§£‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡••

TRANSLATION.

O·πÅ. Vikrama-Sa·πÅvat 1148, Vai≈õ√¢kha ≈öudi 15, on Monday. To-day, here, in the prosperous A·πáahilap√¢taka, the illustrious Tralokyamalla, (alias) the illustrious Kar·πáadeva, the mah√∫r√°j√°dhir√°ja, who is adorned with a continuous-line of kings (his ancestors), informs all royal officers connected with the one hundred and twenty-six villages belonging to (the division of) the prosperous √Çnandapura which is in his (the king’s) possession, and the Br√¢hma·πáas and other people who inhabit this (division) :—

“Be it known to you that, to-day, at the festival of an eclipse of the moon, having
worshipped the lord of the world, the blessed husband of Bhav√¢n√Æ(In, Siva), having considered the vanity of the world, and believing in the rewards (of charity) in this world and in the next, we gave, in order to increase the merit and fame of our parents and of ourselves, by an edict, with a libation of water, to the tank which the Rasovika (?) ·π¨hakkura Mah√¢deva caused to be constructed in the village of S√ªnaka,‚Äîhala 4, i.e., (in words) four ploughs of land, carrying (i.e., requiring as seed corn) 12 p√°il√°m (or 48 sers),¬π‚Åµ1534.” See Sh√°purj√≠ Edalji’s Gujar√°t√≠ and English Dictionary, 2nd edition, s.V. ‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•å.") belonging to the householders (kutumbin) Jasap√¢la (i.e., Yasa·∏•p√¢la), L√¢l√¢, and Bakulasv√¢min, and designated by (their) names, in the village of Laghu-Dabhi. On the east of this land is the field of Bhatt√¢rik√¢, and the fields of the Brahma·πáas Rudra, Neh√¢, and L√¢l√¢; on the south, the field of Mahishar√¢ma; on the west, the boundary of the village of Sandera; on the north, likewise, the boundary of the village of Sandera. Knowing this land, thus defined by its four boundaries, (and) being obedient to (this) order on hearing (it), the people inhabiting this (land) shall deliver for that tank, as they are being levied at present, all shares, enjoyments, taxes, gold, &c. And, remembering that the reward of this meritorious gift is common (to all), nobody shall cause obstruction (to its owner). And the holy Vyasa has said: He who gives land remains in heaven for sixty thousand years; both he who takes (it) away and he who assents (to its being taken away) shall stay as long in hell.’ This edict (≈õ√¢sana) is written by the keeper of records (√°kshapa·π≠alika) Kekkaka, the son of the Kayastha Vate≈õvara. The messenger (d√ªtaka) for this (grant) is the great minister of peace and war (mah√°s√°mdhivigrahika) Sri-Chahila."

(The signature) of the illustrious Kar·πáadeva.

XXXVII.‚ÄîPRASASTI OF THE TEMPLE OF VADIPURA-PARSVANATHA AT
PATTANA.
BY G. B√úHLER, PH. D., LL.D., C.L.E.

The subjoined edition of the Prasasti1535of the temple of P√¢rsvan√¢tha of V√¢d√Æpura at A·πáhilv√¢d-Pattana has been prepared according to an excellent paper-impression taken by Mr. H. Cousens and made over to me by the editor.

The inscription is incised on a stone-slab measuring about 28 inches by 16 ¬Ω, and contains 52 lines of ordinary Jaina N√¢gar√Æ letters. At the top there are rude ropresentations of two lotuses in the left and right-hand corners, and in the middle a figure, somewhat like a Nand√°varta, in the centre of which stands the syllable hra. The execution is good, and the preservation almost perfect. The language is incorrect Sanskrit mixed with Gujar√¢t√Æ, and a few Persian and Arabic words. Prakriticisms and Gujar√¢ticisms are:-1. 2-likhana for lekhana, arham for arhantam, l. 16‚Äîbham·∏ç√¢r√≠ for bh√°·πá·∏ç√°g√°rika, 1. 33-milana, 1. 45-bahini for bhagini, b√¢√Æ, ‚Äòlady,’ l. 47-paushadha≈õ√°l√°, as well as a good many Guj√¢r√¢t√Æ names like 1. 15-Ukav√°la, 1. 40-Osav√°la, ibidem S√∫havade for Subhagadevi and so forth. Persian and Arabic words are ll. 3, 26, 33, 39‚Äîp√°lis√°hi, I.e.Paulsh√°h, 11. 14, 37-p√åra, ‘a Muhammadan saint,’ 1. 35‚Äîphuram√°na, ‘firm√¢n,’ 1. ‚Ç¨8, alldi, ’tho Il√¢h√Æ era’. The case terminations are mostly omitted, and the rules of euphony are frequently disregarded even in compound words. Of some interest, too, is the inflected form samvati from samvat, which occurs twice, 1. 4 and 1. 36. The whole inscription is in prose, with the exception of the Mangala.

The latter consists of a slightly corrupt Ary√¢ verse, which invokes a blessing on the pious founder of the temple :‚Äî

“Hail! May the glorious Jina P√¢r√©va of V√¢·∏çipura, who resides in Pattana, ever grant wealth, prosperity and eternal happiness to him who built the temple of the community (samgha).”

The next lines, 2-4, give a summary of the contents of the inscription and a date
which probably refers to the beginning of the building operations :‚Äî

“In the temple of glorious P√¢rsvan√¢tha of Vadipura, is written the eulogy (of the founder), preceded by an account of the succession of the venerable pontiffs of the famous B·πõihat Kharatara-(gachchha,) after bowing to the Arbat. In the reign of the P√¢dish√¢h, the illustrious Akabbara, in the year 1651 after the time of the illustrious king Vik·πõama, on the ninth (lunar day) of the bright half of M√¢rga≈õ√Ærsha, on the civil day (called) Monday (i. e., according to Dr. Schram, on November 16, 1594), under the constellation P√∫rvabhadra during a lucky planetary hour (took place) the first beginning.”

The Pa·π≠·π≠√°vali, 11. 4-40, enumerates the following spiritual chiefs of the Kharatara school:‚Äî

  1. Uddyotanas√ªri (Klatt1536,No. 38), who, descending in an unbroken line from the ruler of the faith, the glorious lord Mah√¢v√Æra, made vih√°ras resplendent.

  1. Vardham√¢nas√ªri (Klatt, No. 39), who consecrated the temple (vasati) built on Mount Arbuda (Ab√ª) by the da·πá·∏çanayaka Vimala, and worshipped the s√ªrimantra that had been corrected by the glorious lord S√Æmandhara.

  2. Jine≈õvaras√ªri I (Klatt, No. 40), who in (Vikrama Sa·πÅvat) 1080 obtained the title Kharatara after overthrowing the Chaityav√°sins in the Darb√¢r of Durlabhar√¢ja, king of A·πáhilv√¢·∏ç1537.

  1. Jinachandras√ªri 1 (Klatt, No. 41).

  2. Abhayadevas√ªri (Klatt, No. 42), who, in consequence of a revelation from the guardian deity of the faith, made known the image of P√¢r≈õvan√¢tha of Stambhan√¢(Th√¢sr√¢ ?) and thereby was freed from his loathsome leprosy, who obtained fame by composing the Nav√¢ngi and other works.

  3. Jinavallabhas√ªri (Klatt, No. 43), who awakened 10,000 ≈ör√¢vakas of the V√¢ga·∏ça country (i. e., either eastern Kichch or Du·πÖgarpur) by sending a letter con- sisting of ten kulakas, and exalted the Jaina faith by composing excellently written good poems and various ≈ö√¢stras, such as the Pi·πá·∏çavi≈õuddhi1538.

  1. Jinadattas√ªri (Klatt, No. 44), who by his power subdued the company of the 64 Yogi·πÅs1539, 52 Viras, (and ?) Piras of Sindh, who obtained the rank of Yuga- pradh√°na by reading the golden letters written by Ambada’s hand, and by magic walked across the five rivers of the Panj√¢b1540.

  1. Jinachandras√ªri II (Klatt, No. 15), who awakened the illustrious Mahati- y√¢·πáa, chief (pradh√°na) of the Usavalas (Osv√¢ls) and other clans in Srim√†la (Bhinm√¢l), and had the naramani in his foreherd.

  2. Jinapatti (thus all the inscriptions, but Jinapatis√ªri, Klatt, No. 46), who accomplished the vidhipaksha through the sha·π≠trimsadvada in the shape of the Prabodhodaya and other works which were examined by Bha·πá·∏ç√°ri Nemichandra (??).

  3. Jine≈õvaras√ªri II (Klatt, No. 47), who consecrated the ≈ö√°ntiviravidhichaitya in L√¢thaula-Vij√¢pura.

  4. Jinaprabodhas√ªri (Klatt, No. 48).

  5. Jinachandras√ªri III (Klatt, No. 49), who was adorned with the title R√¢jagachchha, because he converted four kings.

  6. Jinakusalas√ªri (Klatt, No. 50), who consecrated the Kharatara temple vasati), the ornament of famous ≈öatrumjaya.

  7. Jinapadmas√ªri (Klatt, No. 51).

  8. Jinalabdhis√ªri (Klatt, No. 52).

  9. Jinachandras√ªri IV (Klatt, No. 53).

  10. Jinodayas√ªri (Klatt, No. 54), who granted happiness, viz., the dignity of samghapati and so forth, by throwing his dress (over people) at the dev√°√±gan√°vasara(?).

  11. Jinar√¢jas√ªri (Klatt, No. 55).

  12. Jinabhadras√ªri (Klatt, No. 56), who founded excellent libraries in various sacred places1541.

  1. Jinachandras√ªri V (Klatt, No. 57).

  2. Jinasamudras√ªri (Klatt, No. 58), who by magic subdued five Yakshas.

  3. Jinaha·πÅsas√ªri (Klatt, No. 59), whom the illustrious p√°dish√°h ≈öikandar (i.e., Sikandar bin Bahlol who ruled A. D. 1489-1510), being astonished at his austerities and meditation, honoured by releasing 500 prisoners.

  4. Jinamaniky√°s√ªri (Klatt, No. 60), who by magic crossed the five rivers of the, Parj√¢b, and prevented (or warded off) a violent attack of the Yavanas (Mubammadans) through the power of his exceeding meditation.

  5. Jinachandras√ªri VI (Klatt, No. 61), the ruling sp√¨ritual head, who conquered many opponents in disputations. He was called by the lord Jal√¢ludd√én, the glorious
    P√§dish√¢h Akabbara, who was desirous of seeing him, having heard of his immeasurable greatness that unfolded itself in consequence of his stay at Stambhat√értha (or Cambay) during the rains of (Vikrama) Samvat 1618. He met the emperor, pleased him by the multitude of his virtues, and obtained one edict (phuram√°·πáa) forbidding the slaughter of animals during eight days in Ash√°·∏çha and a second protecting the fish in the Gulf of Cambay (Stambhatirthasamudra), as well as the title “the most virtuous, glorious pontiff of the age” (sattama≈õr√Æyugapradh√°na). Further, at the command of the emperor, he crossed by magic the five rivers of the Panj√¢b on the twelfth lunar day of the bright half of M√¢gha, (Vikrama) Samvat 1652, and made five Piras appear, by which feats he obtained the distinction of paramavara, and so forth, and exalted the Samgha. He was attended by √Åch√°rya Jasimha,1542 on whom he had conferred the dignity of √°ch√°rya in the presence of the emperor Akbar. It was by his advice that the temple of V√¢d√Æpura-P√¢r√©van√¢tha was built.

This list of names fully agrees with the much later one, from which Dr. Klatt made
his extracts, and it shows that Dharmas√¢gara’s violent diatribe against the Kharatara Pa·π≠·π≠√°vali in his Kupakshakau≈õik√†ditya1543contains some gross misstatements or nistakes. First, Dharmasagara says that he wrote in Vikrama Samvat 1629, and that the head of the Kharataras was in his time Jinahamsa. That is utterly irreconcileable with the statements of our inscription which asserts that his second successor Jinachandra VI was Yugapradi√¢na in Vikrama Samvat 1618 and 1652, and that Jinahamsa himself was honoured by Sult√¢n Sikandar, who ruled until A.D. 1517 or Vikrama Samvat 1573. This latter assertion, on the other hand, agrees with the dates of Dr. Klatt’s Pa·π≠·π≠√°vali, where it is said that Jinalamsa died in Vikrama Samvat 1582. Secondly, Dharmasagara erroneously omits in his Kharataru-Ra·π≠·π≠√°val√Æ the name of Jinasamudra between Jinachandra V and Jinahamsa. Thirdly, he puts Jinavardhana in Jinabhadra’s place, though an incidental remark of his regarding a Kharalara-Pa·π≠·π≠√°val√≠, incised in Vikrama Samvat 1505 in the temple at Jesalmir, shows that he was aware of Jinabhadra’s position. Dr. Klatt’s Pall√°val√≠ states that Jinavardhana indeed was first made Yugapra·∏çh√¢na, but deposed for misbehaviour, and that Jinabhadra was put into his place. Since Dharmas√¢gara, as would appear, intentionally omits the latter and names the sinner, it looks as if he had wished to taunt his opponents with this misfortune. I may add that the date of the Jesalmir Pa·π≠·π≠√°vali, given by Dharmas√¢gara, is wrong. According to the notes which I took at Jesalmir in 1873, Jinabhadra is named, on the large slab in the temple of P√¢r√°van√°tha, as pa·π≠·π≠adh√°rin in Vikrama Sa·πÅvat 1473. This date differs also by two years from that in Dr. Klatt’s extracts, according to which Jinabhadra was installed as spirit al head of the Kharataras in Vikrama Samvat 1475.

These facts, I think, show that Dharmas√¢gara’s statements regarding other schools can only be used with great caution.

The events from the lives of the various Yugapradh√¢nas reported in the inscription are for the greater part well-known, and those which are new, are mostly not particularly interesting. The account of the last Jinachandra’s relation to the emperor ‚ÄúAk bar, forms, however, an exception. The later Pa·π≠·π≠√¢val√≠, from which Dr. Klatt made his extracts, boldly asserts that this worthy converted the emperor Akbar to Jainism. The statements of our inscription are much more moderate and much more credible. They show, too, how the later fable arose. The Muhammadan historians admit1544,regarding Akbar, that “Samanis and Brahmanas managed to get frequent private interviews with His Majesty,” and that “they brought proofs, based on reason and testimony, for the truth of their own and the fallacies of other religions, and inculcated their doctrines so firmly, and so skilfully represented things as quite self-evident which require consideration, that no man, by expressing his doubts, could now raise a doubt, in his Majesty.” As the term “Samanis” means ascetics, and includes the Jaina monks, there is no reason for doubting the assertion that Jinachandra, the head of the great Kharatara community, was granted admission to Akbar’s religious discussions. Nor is it incredible that the emperor granted him the two firm√°ns and the title mentioned in the inscription. More doubtful is the statement that Jinachandra pretended to perform miracles before ‘Akbar, and that his pupil received the dignity of Acharya in the emperor’s presence. With respect to the first point it must however be borne in mind that the Jaina S√ªris, even in the present day, claim to possess supernatural powers, and that, according to all accounts, they formerly often tried to impose on credulous kings by what can only be called jugglery. It seems to me, therefore, not absolutely impossible that Jinachandra may have attempted some trick in order to gain Akbar’s confidence. In favour of the second point a note in Dr. Klatt’s Patt√°vali may be brought forward, according to which Jinasimha received the √°ch√°ryapada in the winter of Vikrama Samvat 1649 at Lahore, which, according to the Muhammadan writers, at the time was the imperial residence. Nevertheless it is difficult to believe that Akbar should have gone to the Jaina temple where the ceremony must have taken place. The difficulty would disappear if we might takƒó ≈õr√≠p√°tis√°hisamaksham to mean that Jinasimha accompanied his teacher into the imperial presence and was introduced as one worthy of the √°chdaryapada.

The remainder of the inscription, lines 40-52, contain the Pra≈õasti. The pedigree of the founder of the temple, who belonged to the Osv√¢l clan and the line of Mantrin Bhima, is given as follows:-

‚Ä¢Mantrin Ch√¢mp√• married to S√ªhavade.
‡•§

‚Ä¢Mantrin Mahipati married to Amari.
‡•§

Mantrin Vastup√¢la married to Siriy√¢de.
‡•§

Mantrin Tejap√¢la married to M√¢n√ª.
‡•§

S√¢ha Amaradatta1545 (the ornament of the Kuke≈õa-race) married to Ratan√¢de.
‡•§

Ratnakumyaraj√Æ married to s√¢bh√¢gade.

Moreover, a sister, probably of Ratnanku·πÅyaraj√Æ, named B√¢√ÆV√¢chh√Æ, and a daughter, B√¢√ÆJ√≠va·πá√Æ, are mentioned as co-founders of the temple. The image of the temple was consecrated in (Vikrama) Samvat 1652, in the All√°√Æ, i. e., Il√¢h√Æ year 41, on the twelfth lunar day of the dark half of Vaisakha, a Monday, under the constellation Revati. The Ilahi year 41 began on the 10-11th March of 1596^(12)1546 The Vikrama year must be, as the preceding date ( 1. 36 ) Sa·πÅvat 1662, M√¢gha sudi 12, shews ‚Äîthe ‘southern one, which began on K√¢rttika sudi 1 in A.D. 1595. The date corresponds according to Dr. Schram’s calculation with Thursday, May 13, A. D. 1596.

TEXT.

L. 1. ‡••‡§î‡§Ç‡•• ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡•Ä‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§™‡§æ‡§¨‡§Ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ò‡§ö‡•à‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø ‡•§
‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§∏‡•Å‡§¶‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§™-
‡§∏‡§®‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ ‡•• ‡•ß \‡••^(13)1547
2. ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡•Ä‡§Ç‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡§æ‡§•‡§ö‡•à‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¨‡•É‡§π‡§§‡•ç ‡§ñ‡§∞‡§§‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§™‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§µ‡§≤‡•Ä-
3. ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ‡§®‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§π ‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ï‡§¨‡•ç‡§¨‡§∞‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§∏‡§Æ-’^(14)1548
4. ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡•ß‡•¨‡•´‡•ß ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§∂‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§®‡§µ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•á ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•á ‡•§ ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§¶‡§®‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§≤‡§æ -^(15)1549
5. ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ü‡§¶‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç‡§≠‡§É ‡•§ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§∂‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡§ñ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§™‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç‡§™‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã-^(16)1550
6. ‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ø‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡§≤‡§¶‡§Ç‡§°‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ï‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§ö‡§≤‡§µ‡§∏‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§™‡§ï‡•§‚Äù^(17)1551
7. ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ú‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ß‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§ï‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ø ‡•§‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡•É‡•¶‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§π‡§ø‡§∂‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§ß‡•Ä ‡•§ “^(18)1552
8. ‡§Æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§≤‡§≠‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡•á‡§™‡§æ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§¶‡§∂‡§∂‡§§‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ñ‡§∞‡§§‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø-
9. ‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡•É‡•¶ ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø ‡•§‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡•É‡•¶ ‡•§ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§ü‡§ø‡§§-
10. ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ï‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§•‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç‡§≠‡§®‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡§æ‡§• ‡•§‡§®‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡•Ä‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä - ^(19)1553
11. ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§Ø‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∞‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡•É‡•¶ ‡•§ ‡§≤‡•á‡§ñ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§¶‡§Æ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§ï‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡§£‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§ó‡§°‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§¶‡§∂‡§∏‡§π-
12. ‡§∏‡§ú‡§æ‡§µ‡§ï ‡•§‡§∏‡•Å‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§™‡§ø‡§Ç‡§°‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§£‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§®-^(20)1554
13. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§≠‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•¶ ‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§ ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§É‡§∑‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§°‡§ø‡§™‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ-
14. ‡§∂‡§π‡•Ä‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ß‡•Å‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§™‡•Ä‡§∞ ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§¨‡§°‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ‡§ï‡§ï‡§∞‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§ö‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ-
15. ‡§®‡§™‡§¶‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∏‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§™‡§Ç‡§ö‡§®‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§ï‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ø ‡•§‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡•É‡•¶ ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡§â‡§∂‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§®-
16. ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§ï ‡•§ ‡§®‡§∞‡§Æ‡§£‡§ø‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§°‡§ø‡§§‡§≠‡§æ‡§≤‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§≤‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞ \‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•¶ ‡•§ ‡§≠‡§Ç‡§°‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡•á-
17. ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡•ã‡§¶‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç‡§•‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§∑‡§ü‡•ç ‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø^(21)1555
18. ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡•É‡•¶ ‡•§ ‡§≤‡§æ‡§†‡§°‡§≤‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ú‡§æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§§‡§∂‡§æ‡•ë‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§ö‡•à‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§∞‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§π-
19. ‚Ä¢ ¬∫‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü ‡•§ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§π‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§∂‡•ã‡§≠‡§ø‡§§ ‡•§
20. ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞ ‡•§‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡•É‡•¶‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç‡§ú‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§°‡§®‡§ñ‡§∞‡§§‡§∞‡§µ‡§∏‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§™‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§æ-
21. ‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡§Ø‡§≤‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡§ï‡•Å‡§∂‡§≤‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•¶ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡•É‡•¶ ‡•§‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡§≤‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç-
22. ‡§∞‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§π‡•¶ ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ ‡•§‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™ ‡•§‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§™‡•ã‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ò‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§¶‡§æ-^(22)1556

.L. 23. ‡§¨‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§¶‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡•ã‡§¶‡§Ø‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡•É‡•¶ ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡•É‡•¶ ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§§-^(23)1557
24. ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§≠‡§æ‡§Ç‡§°‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡§≠‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡•É‡•¶ ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ ‡•§‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡•É‡•¶ ‡•§ ‡§™‡§Ç‡§ö-
25.‡§Ø‡§ö‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø ‡•§‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡•É‡•¶ ‡•§ ‡§§‡§™‡•ã‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§ö‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•É-
26.‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∏‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç‡§¶‡§∞‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§°‡§ø‡§™‡§Ç‡§ö‡§∂‡§§‡§¨‡§Ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ö‡§®‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡§á‡§Ç‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡•É‡•¶
27. ‡§™‡§Ç‡§ö‡§®‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§® ‡§¨‡§≤‡§∂‡§ï‡§≤‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡§§‡§Ø‡§µ‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä-
28. ‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø 1 ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§Ø‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§∂‡§∞‡§£‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§ø-
29. ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡§∞‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ú‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§µ‡§à‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§¶‡§Ø‡§∏‡§¶‡§Ø‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§®-
30. ‡§ú‡§®‡§µ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§£‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§µ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§∂‡•ã‡§≠‡§ø‡§§‡§™‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§≤‡§Ø‡§ü‡•Ç-
31. ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ú‡§§‡§∏‡§ï‡§≤‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§™‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡§≤ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§£ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç
32. ‡•ß‡•¨‡•™‡•Æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç‡§≠‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§£‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç-
33. ‡§†‡§ø‡§§ ‡•§ ‡§ú‡§≤‡§æ‡§≤‡•Å‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§¶‡§ï‡§¨‡•ç‡§¨‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§ó‡§£-
34. ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡§Ç‡§ú‡§®‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§≤‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§≤‡§æ‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡§ú‡§Ç‡§§‡•Å‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§æ‡§¢‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§π‡§ø-
35. ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§´‡•Å‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç‡§≠‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§®‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§´‡•Å‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•Å-
36. ‡§ó‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§™‡§¶‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§ö‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§ö ‡•§ ‡§®‡§Ø‡§®‡§∂‡§∞‡§∞‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ò‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ-
37. ‡§¶‡§∂‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§§‡§ø‡§•‡•å‡§Ö‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§§‡§™‡§Ç‡§ö‡§®‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§ü‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§™‡§Ç‡§ö‡§™‡•ã‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§™-
38.‡§∞‡§Æ‡§µ‡§∞‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ò‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡•ß‡•¶‡•Æ
39. ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§≠‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø-
40. ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•á‡§® ‡•§ ‡§ì‡§∏‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•á "
41. ‡§Æ‡§Ç¬∞ ‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ç‡§™‡§æ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§π‡§µ‡§¶‡•á ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Æ¬∞ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§µ ‡§Æ‡§Ç¬∞ ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§≤
42.‡§§‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•á ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§µ ‡§Æ‡§Ç¬∞ ‡§§‡•á‡§ú‡§™‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ’ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•Ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§∏‡§∞‡•ã‡§Æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞
43.‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§ú‡§®‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§≠‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡§£‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∏‡§æ‡§≤‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§§‡•ã ‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç-
44. ‡§§‡§ï‡•Å‡§ï‡•á‡§∂‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§°‡§® ‡§∏‡§æ‡§π ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§∞‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∞‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•á ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§µ ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡§ú‡•Ä ‡•§‡§§‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡••
45. ‡§∏‡•ã‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§¶‡•á ‡•§ ‡§¨‡§π‡§ø‡§®‡§ø ‡§¨‡§æ‡§à ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡•§ ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§¨‡§æ‡§à ‡§ú‡•ã‡§µ‡§£‡•Ä ‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡•å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡•á‡§®
46. ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§π‡§ø‡§≤‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§∂‡•É‡§Ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§®‡§∞‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡§Ç‡§ú‡§®‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ-
47. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§ö‡•à‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡•• ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§™‡•å‡§∑‡§ß‡§∂‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§ü‡§ï‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡§®‡•Å ‡§ï‡§∞-
48. ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ï‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§à ‡•™‡•ß ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•á ‡•§ ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡§æ‡§∑ ‡§µ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§π‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡•Ä‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§∞‡•á ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å^(24)1558
49. ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•á ‡§∞‡•á‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§®‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡§É‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ ‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡•Ä‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡§æ‡§•‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ
50. ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§è‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§ó‡•Å[‡§∞‡•Å]‡§ó‡•ã‡§µ‡§ú‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•Ä‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§® ‡§¨‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡•§‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∏‡§Ç-
51. ‡§ò‡§∏‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡•§ ‡§è‡§∑‡§æ ‡§™‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§™‡§Ç‡•¶ ‡§â‡§¶‡§Ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§ó‡§£‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§≤‡§ø‡§™‡•Ä-
52.‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§™‡§Ç‡•¶ ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ã‡§¶‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§ø ‡§Ü‡§¶‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡•• ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§ó‡§ú‡§ß‡§∞‡§ó‡§®‡§æ‡§ï‡•á‡§® ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•Å ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç [‡••]

XXXVIII.-TWO CHANDELLA INSCRIPTIONS FROM AJAYGADH.
BY PROFESSOR F. KIELHORN, PH.D., C.I.E., G√ñTTINGEN.
I.

ROCK INSCRIPTION OF VIRAVARMAN; OF THE VIKRAMA YEAR 1317.

According to Sir A. Cunningham¬π, this inscription is at Ajaygadh, a hill-fort about 16 miles in a straight line south-west of Kala√±jar, Long.. 80¬∞ 20’ E., Lat. 24¬∞ 54’ N., Indian Atlas, quarter-sheet 70, N.E. It is engraved on a rock, with a crack dividing it into two portions, and contains altogether fifteen lines, of which the first seven lines are on the proper right and the following eight on the proper left side of the crack. The writing of the right-hand portion covers a space of about 2‚Ä≤ 4¬Ω” broad by 6¬Ω" high, that of the left-hand portion a space of about 3‚Ä≤ broad by 6 1/2" high. It is on the whole fairly well preserved, and everything of historical importance may be read with certainty throughout. But, towards the end, the rubbings at my disposal (owing, probably, to the condition of the rock) are not at all distinct, and in consequence the exact wording of one or two passages in the concluding lines, of minor importance, remains doubtful, and about a dozen aksharas are altogether illegible. The size of the letters is about 5/8". The characters are N√•gar√Æ of the 13th century. The language is Sanskrit and, with the exception of the i√±troductory om om siddhi·∏• and the date at the end, the inscription is in verse. It was composed by Ratnap√¢la, a son of the poet Harip√¢la and grandson of the poet Visar√¢ja (verse 21), and engraved by the artisan R√¢ma (verse 22). As regards orthography, b is denoted by the sign for v in v√°lo, line 5, amvudhi, line 6, vali-, line 13, and vudha·∏•, line 14, but not in babh√∫na, lines 8 and 10; the dental sibilant is used for the palƒÖtal in va·πÅsa·∏• and vamse, lines 2 and 8, yasasvin√≠, lino 13, sydh·∫©msu, line 14, and visuddh√°tm√°, line 15; and the palatal for the dental in ≈õuto, line 8, -≈õ√≠m√°, line 9, and -k√°≈õ√¢[ram], line 13; and sh is employed for kh in Vai≈õ√¢sha-, line 15.

The proper object of the inscription is, to record (in verses 18-20) that Kaly√¢nadevi, the wife of the (Chandella) king V√Æra or V√Æravarman, built a well, called the Nirjara-well, and in connection with it a hall, within the fort of Ajayga·∏çh, which in other inscriptions is called Jayapura, but is here apparently denominated N√¢ndipura. And by way of introduction the inscription in verses 2-9 treats of the ancestors of the king, and in verses 10-13 gives an account of Kaly√¢·πáadevi’s own descent. From the latter we learn that in the race of Dadhichi there was onc [Oh√¢]dala, whose son was ≈ör√épala, whose son again was Mahe≈õvara, ’to be revered even by crowned heads.’ Mabe≈övara married Vesaladevi (P), a daughter of the prince Govindaraja; and their daughter was Kaly√¢·πáadevi, who became the chief queen of the king Vira. Nothing is known to me of the queen’s ancestors from other inscriptions.

____________________________________________________________________________________

1-See Sir A. Cunningham’s Archeological Survey of India, vol. XXI, p. 51. The inscription has not been previously edited, but a photo-lithograph of it will be found ib., plate xiii. And an abstract of the contents of the inscription, as read by a Simla Pandit, is given ib., p. 51. Of this abstract I can only say that the Pandit has done his work very carelessly. Thus-the name of Sallakshana he has read Sulakshapa; between Madana and Trailokyavarman he has omitted Paramardin; to Trailokyavarman he has given two sons, Yasoyarman and Viravarman, while the inscription does not mention any Yasovarman at all; and Kaly√¢·πáadev√Æ he has made the daughter of Raja Govinda, while in reality she is described as the daughter of Mahesvara and granddaughter, by her mother’s side, of Govindaraja. Moreover, he has interpreted the date of the inscription to be Vikrama 1312, while it is really, in words and figures, 1317. My own text of the iuscription has been prepared from Sir A. Cunningham’s rubbings, kindly placed at my disposal by Mr. Fleet.

As regards the king’s own descent, we have here the following line of sovereigns presented to us, who (in verse 2) are said to have been born in a family which derived its origin from the moon, and which from other sources we know to be the Chandrella, or Chandella, or Chandr√¢treya family:‚Äî

(1.) K√értivarman, who defeated Kar·πáa and evidently, by doing so, restored the independence of the (Chandella) kingdom (v. 3).

(2.)Sallaksha·πáa, who is said to have taken away the fortune of the M√¢lavas and Chedis (v. 4).

(3.) Jayavarmadeva (v. 4).

(4.) P·πõithvivarman (v. 5).

(5.) Madana (v. 5).

(6.) Paramardin (v. 6).

(7.) Trailokyavarman, who freed the country from the dominion of the Turu»ôhkas (v. 7).

(8.) V√Æra (vv. 8 and 9), or, as he is called in line 15, V√Æravarman.

The Karna1559; for Kirtivarman the date Vikrama 1154=A.D. 1098 (ib., vol. XVIII, p. 238). Karna was also defeated by Bh√émadeva I. of Aphilwad, A.D. 1021‚Äî1063, by the Ch√¢lukya Some≈õvara I., A.D. 1040-1069, and by Uday√¢ditya of M√¢lava, for whoin we have the certain date A.D. 1080.") mentioned in the above, whose defeat by K√értivarman is related also in line 15 of the fragmentary inscription from Mahob√¢, edited by Dr. Hultzsch in Zeitschrift D. Morg. Ges., vol. XL, p. 49 (Archeological Survey of India, vol. XXI, plate xxi), and apparently in an inscription from K√¢lanjar (ib., p. 29, verse 8), is the
famous Chedi king of that name who ruled about the middle of the 11th century A. D., and whose defcat by Kirtivarman, or rather by K√Ærtivarman’s friend and general1560 Gop√¢la, is referred to in the introductory scene of the play Prabodhachandrodaya. And the Turushkas mentioned in connection with Trailokyavarman are the Muhammadan invaders whom we know1561to have defeated Paramardin and to have taken K√¢la√±j√°r in A.D. 1202.

The inscription is dated (in lines 14 and 15), in words and figures, in the Vikrama
year measured by the seas (7), the moon (1), the fires (3), and the moon (1), i.e., in the Vikrama year 1317, on Thursday, the 13th of the bright half of Vai≈õ√¢kha, while the R√¢uta, the illustrious Jetana (?), was in office, in the reign of Viravarman. The possible equivalents for Vikrama 1317, Vaisakha ≈õukla 13, would be:-

for the northern current year-Tuesday, 6th May, A.D. 1259;
for the northern expired or southern current year-Sunday, 25th April, A. D. 1260;
for the southern expired year-Thursday, 14th April, A. D. 1261, when the 13th tithi of the bright half ended 21 h. 45 m. after mean sunrise.

The true date accordingly is Thursday, 14th April, A. D. 1261, and the Vikrama year mentioned in the inscription must be taken to be the southern expired year.

TEXT.1562

L. 1. ‡§ì759 ‡§ì ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§É ‡••

** ‚óè ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§∂‡§§‡§®‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ ‡§∂‡§ø‡§≤‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§§‡§§‡§Ç ‡•§
‚óè ‡§à[‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•ç‡§£]‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡§ï‡§•‡§æ ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•á ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡•ã1563 ‡§Ω‡§Æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä ‡•• ‡•ß ‡••1564.")
‡§Ö‡§∞‡§ï‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§Ç ‡§®‡§Ø‡§®‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ã-**

2. ‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π‡§ø (‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø) ‡§∞‡•ã‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§Æ‡•å‡§≤‡•á‡§É ‡•§

** ‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ö‡§™‡§≤‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡§®‡•Ä‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§ß‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∏ (‡§≠): ‡•• ‡•® ‡••1565
‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç‡§≠‡•ã‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§µ‡§É ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ß‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡•á‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§®‡•Ç‡§§‡§®‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§∑‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•å‡•§
‡§§[‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§æ]-**

3. ‡§∏ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ß‡§∞‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•ã ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡••

‡§∏‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡§µ‡§ö‡•á‡§¶‡§ø‡§≤‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≤‡•Å‡§Ç[‡§ü‡§æ] ‡§ñ‡§ó‡§É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§£‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§
‡§ú‡§Ø‡•á‡§ï‡§ß‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§ú‡§Ø-

**4. ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ[‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ] ‡§ö ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏ [‡§ß‡•Ä]‡§∞‡§É ‡•• ‡•™ ‡••

‡§™‡•É‡§•‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§Ω‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶ [‡§•] ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡•Ç‡§™‡§Æ‡§É ‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡•ã‡§™‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§¶‡§®‡§É ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§Ω‡§≠‡•Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§É ‡•• ‡•´ ‡••1566.")
‡§Ö‡§•‡§æ‡§≠‡§µ[‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä]-**

5. ………[‡§™] ‡§∞‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§µ‡§æ(‡§¨‡§æ) ‡§≤‡•Ä‡§™‡§ø ‡§®‡•á‡§§‡§æ ‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡•§

** [‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ] ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø[‡§≤]‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§∂ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú‡§ó‡§æ‡§Æ ‡•• ‡•¨ ‡••1567
‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•Ä ‡§Ω‡§• ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç [‡§≠]-**

6. [‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§¶‡•Å] ‡§ó‡§Ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡•á‡§ß‡§æ‡§É ‡•§

** ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§µ‡•Å (‡§¨‡•Å) ‡§ß‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ß‡§æ[‡§¨‡•Ä] ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç ‡•• ‡•≠ ‡••
‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∞‡•á ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§ï‡§ï[‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß]: ‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞[‡§Æ‡§π‡•Ä]-**

7. ‡§Æ‡§π‡•á‡§∂‡•ã ‡§ú‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•å ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ù‡§≤‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§É‡•• ‡•Æ‡••

** ‡§§‡§æ‡§ö‡•á (‡§ö‡•á) ‡§£ ‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡•É‡§∑‡•á‡§£ ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ [‡§∂‡§ø]‡§≠‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡•§
‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡§É ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å ‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ã ‡§ú‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡•• ‡•Ø ‡••**

8. ‡§¶‡§ß‡•Ä‡§ö‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•á (‡§∂‡•á) ‡§Ö‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§§‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø [‡§ß‡§æ] ‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä[‡§ö‡§æ ] ‡§¶‡§≤‡•ã1568‡§Ω‡§≠‡•Ç‡§®‡•Å‡§ú‡§ú‡§∏‡§µ‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡•§
‡§Ö[‡§•‡§æ] ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã (‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§É)1569 ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§™‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§∂ (‡§∏‡•Å) ‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§É ‡•• ‡•ß‡•¶ ‡••
¬®‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∑‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•à‡§∞‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡§Ç‡§¶‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§π‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§¨‡§≠‡•Ç-

9. ‡§µ‡•§

** ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•É‡§∑[‡§≤‡•Ä] ‡§≤‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•• ‡•ß‡•ß ‡••
‡§ó‡•ã‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§¶‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§™‡•Å‡§µ‡•Ä ‡§§‡•á‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§Ø‡•á‡§Æ‡•á ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§∂‡•Ä (‡§∏‡•Ä) ‡§Æ‡§æ ‡•§**

‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•à‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§µ ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡•• ‡•ß‡•® ‡••
‡§®‡§æ‡§¨‡§æ [‡§µ‡•á‡§∏ ?]-

‡§≤‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•å‡§Ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡§∂‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä ‡•§

10.‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§æ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§• ‡§µ‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä ‡•• ‡•ß‡•© ‡••¬π‚Å¥
‡§∏‡•á‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ ‡§ï‡•à‡§ü‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•á[:] ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞[‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•ã] ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§∑‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§æ [‡•§^(√ó)]
‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§π‡§∞‡•á [: ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ] ‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•à‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡§≠‡•Ç‡§µ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ ‡•• ‡•ß‡•™ ‡•§ (‡••)¬π‚Åµ
‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§µ[‡§∞‡•ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø]‡§§‡•á ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞[‡§∏‡•Ä]‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§π‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡•§

11.‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ ‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞[‡§≠‡•Å‡§Ç] ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡§æ ‡§ú‡§ø‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ø ‡•• ‡•ß‡•´ ‡••
‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§Ç[‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§]‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§µ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§¶‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•á‡§É‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ó‡§ï‡§Ç
‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§ø‡§≤ ‡§§‡•á ‡§ó‡§Ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡•à‡§É ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡•§
‡§§‡•á [‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ] ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§µ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§¶‡•É‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡•ã‡§ö‡§∞‡§æ [‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ?] -

12.[‡§Ø‡•à] ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•á‡§É ‡§∂‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§®‡•Å‡§É ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•Ä [‡§ó‡§ø]‡§∞‡§æ ‡•• ‡•ß‡•´‡••
[‡§Ü‡§Ø‡•Å]. ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡§Ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä[‡§™] ‡§¨‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§£-
‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§™[‡§Ø] ‡§®‡§§[‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§µ‡•ã ?] ‡§®‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡§ø[‡§§‡§æ] ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§π‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ò‡§®‡•á ‡•§
[‡§è‡§ï] ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡•á
‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•å‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡§£‡§æ - ‡§Æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•Ä [‡§ó‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ]] ‡•• ‡•ß ‡••

**13.[‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§≤‡•Ä ?] ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ (‡§¨) ‡§≤‡§ø‡§Æ[‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ?] ‡§ó‡•Å[‡§∏‡•Ä] ‡§®‡§ø‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§ï‡•É‡§™‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ ‡•§
‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡§µ‡•á ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£[‡§§]‡§®‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§™‡§Ø‡•ã‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§∞‡§ï‡•Ç‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§®‡§Ç ‡•• ‡•ß‡•Æ ‡••¬π‚Å∑
‡§∏‡§æ ‡§™‡§æ[‡§µ‡§Ç] ¬π‚Å∏‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡•á[‡§ï‡§Ç]¬π‚Åπ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡§∏ ( ‡§∂) ‡§ñ‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä ‡•§
‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø[‡§Æ‡•á]¬≤‚Å∞ ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™ (‡§™‡§æ) ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö ‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§°‡§™‡§Ç ‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•• ‡•ß‡•Æ ‡•• 2
‡§∏‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ (‡§∏‡§æ) [‡§∞‡§Ç ? ] **

14. [‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∂‡•á ?] ‡§ñ‡§∞[‡§Æ‡§Ç]‡§¶‡§ø‡§∞‡§Ç
[‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç]‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•á [‡§ö]‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•å ‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ã‡§ß‡§µ‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡§ø‡§É ‡•• ‡•®‡•¶ ‡••
‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ï‡§µ‡•á‡§É ‡§™‡•å‡§µ‡•Ä ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§µ‡•á []‡§§‡§É
‘‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§™‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§á‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§°‡•Å (‡§¶‡•Å)‡§ß‡§É ‡•• ‡•®‡•ß ‡••
‡§∏‡§ó‡§∞‡•á‡§á‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•Å (‡§∂‡•Å) ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•á"
15. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•á ‡•§
‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•Å (‡§∂‡•Å ) ‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß‡•ã ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ[‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ] ‡§ï‡§É ‡•• ‡•®‡•® ‡••
‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡•ß‡•®‡•ß‡•≠ ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ú‡•á[‡§§] ‡§®‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞ ‡•• ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡•• ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡§æ‡§µ (‡§ñ) ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø ‡•ß‡•´ ‡§ó‡§§‡•á ‡••
————————————————————————————————————————————–

14 Metre, Sloka (Anushtubh )
15Metie of verRes 14 and 16, Upajati [In pada 3 of verse 14, the metre requires ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•á ]
16 Motre of verRes 18 and 17, Sard√∫lavikiidita,
17 Motie UpaJ&t1.
18 The ah ohara in brarketa appears to be ‡§µ‡•á, altered to a
19 Of this akshara only the sign of the anusvdra is dez btful.
20 This akshara appears to be #, altered to
21 Metre of verses 19-22, Sloka (Annalitubh).
22 The original has ‚Ä¢ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç.
23 Here follow about eleven akshar as (probably containing & blessing), which are illegible in the rnbbings.

TRANSLATION.

Om! Om! (May) success (attend) !

(Verse 1.) May the divine Ganga on Siva’s head protect you, (she who is) attenuated as it were with jealousy, at seeing half his body appropriated by the daughter of the mountain !

(2.) Glory be to that one friend of the god of love, who gladdens the eyes (and is )the head-ornament of the moon-crested (Siva), the moon, from whom here on earth there has sprung a race which has freed Fortune from the blemish of fickleness !

(3.) In that (race) there was a ruler over the earth whose fame is sung by the Vidy√¢dharas, (who was) the pitcher-born (Agastya1570) in swallowing that ocean-Karna, (and) the lord of creatures in creating anew the kingdom,1571the illustrious Kirtivarman.

(4.) From him (sprang) the prince Sallakshana whose sword took away the fortune of the M√¢lavas and Chedis; and after him the faliant Jayavarmadeva ruled the kingdom, whose one glory was victory.

(5.) After him P·πõithv√évarman was king, similar to Prithu; and then Madana
ruled over the kingdom, a god of love1572to opponents.

(6.) Then came the illustrious king Paramardin, who, as a leader, even in his youth, struck down opposing heroes, (and) to whom the fortune of universal sovereignty quickly came, like an enamoured damsel choosing him of her own free will.

(7.) Then the prince Trailokyavarman ruled the kingdom, a very creator in providing strong places. Like Vishnu he was, in lifting up the earth, immerged in the occan formed by the streams of Turushkas.

(8.) Victorious is his son V√Æra, that ruler of the earth of spotless bravery who has delighted the damsels of heaven by sending them, as lovers, the hostile heroes whom he cut down on the field of battle.

(9.) Victorious (and) to be worshipped by all men is he whom, when he strikes
down the wicked (and) disperses crowds of opponents, people gaze at-wondering whether he be Vish≈Üu riding on Garuda or Siva roaming about on his bull.-

(10.) In the race of Dadhichi there was the illustrious [Ch√¢]dala, cndowed with marvellous true glory, an object of reverence for the Kshatriyas; and he had a most
excellent son, named Srip√¢la, who was bravery, as it were, incarnate.

(11.). His son, to be revered even by crowned heads, was Mahe≈õvara, whom people declare to be properly so named, when he disports himself, valiant like a bull.

(12 and 13.) He married the prince Govindar√¢ja’s daughter, unsurpassed for virtuous conduct, who, for her Extraordinary deeds, like Siva’s wife, must always be honoured by faithful wives,-the lady Vesaladevi (?), endowed with both beauty and excellent qualities. Her daughter, now, is Kaly√¢·πáadev√Æ, of great renown.

(14.) When she became the chief queen of the illustrious king Vira, like unto ≈ör√Æ (when she became the wife) of the enemy1573of Kaitabha, this lady by her pleasing, noble and holy deeds became famous for ever.

(V. 15.) What need is there to describe her, unsurpassed for pleasing conduct (and) well-known the earth over for her pure fame,-her, who by truthful speech has at once surpassed that world-renowned lord of justice (Yudhish·π≠hira)?

(16.) To some Va≈õish·π≠ha’s wife1574 is an object of reverence; others indeed √£dore the splendid daughter of the mountain who is the half of Siva’s body; some again havo glorified Gang√¢, (and) others take pains to praise the beloved of K√¢ma. They all cannot have set eyes on the unblemished Kaly√†·πáadev√é, who for truth and other excellent qualities is famed in song.

(17.) Having perceived that life, fortune, and the charms of youth stay no longer than the water which glitters on a lotus-leaf, that widely praised beautiful women(?) have fallen into the gross darkness of delusion, (and) that the creeper of good fame alone is everlasting, Kaly√¢·πáadev√Æ, to make that (creeper of fame) grow,. . . . the qualities of truth and generosity.

(18.) Then, having ascerta√≠ned that (this) spot is guarded by the arms of strong men (?), she, full of compassion, made this Nirjara1575 well, filled with nectar-like water, to sustain life.

(19.) She, of great renown, gave for the Nirjara (well) one drinking cup (?) and she built this pure, bright hall for the supply of water (?).

(20.) She, who has brightened the earth with her fame, has made at N√¢nd√épura a tank which resembles the ocean, (and) a hall with a lofty top (?).‚Äî

(21.) The intelligent Ratnap√¢la, a son of the poet Harip√¢la and grandson of the poct Vatsar√¢ja, has composed this pure eulogy.

(22.) In the Vikrama year measured by the scas (7), the moon (1), the fires (3), and the moon (1), has the pure-minded, skilful R√¢ma engraved it.

In the year 1317, during the office of the R√¢uta, the illustrious Jetana (?), in the reign of the illustrious V√Æravarman, on Thursday, the 13th of the bright half of Vai≈õ√¢kha.

II.
ROCK INSCRIPTION OF THE TIME OF BHOJAVARMAN.

This inscription1576is on a rock near the “Tarhaoni” or “Tirhawan” gate of the fort of Ajayga·∏çh. It contains sixteen lines of writing which cover a space of about 6’ 10 1/2" broad by 2’ 3" high. The first fifteen lines extend over the whole breadth of the inscribed surface; the last line measures only 1‚Ä≤ 4‚Ä≥ in length, and is engraved in very small characters close below the beginning of line 15. With the exception of about ten aksharas at the commencement of line 15 which cither have gone altogether or are greatly damaged, and the whole of the short line 16 which is illegible in the rubbing, the writing is well preserved. The size of the letters in lines 1-15 is about 1 1/5." The characters are the peculiar kind of N√¢gar√Æ which we find also in several Mahob√¢ and K√°la√õjar inscriptions of the 12th and 13th centuries, and the special features of which

may be seen in the photo-lithographs, published in Arch√¶ological Survey of India, vol.XXI, plates xv and xxi-xxiii. Here I need only state that in the present inscription it is somewhat difficult to distinguish between the signs for ch and v, those for chch, vv, and gh, and those for p and b; and that a sign representing both the jihv√°m√°l√Æya and the upadhm√°n√Æya, which does not differ at all from the ordinary sign for sh, has been employed before the words kara·πá√°s and padm√£¬∫, in line 2.

The language of the inscription is Sanskrit, and, with the exception of the introductory om nama·∏• Ked√°r√¢dya, the whole is in verse. The language is fluent, but not always correct. Thus, to mention some of the most striking mistakes, in line 1 we have sha·π≠trimsati·∏• or sha·π≠trimsata·∏• for shattrimsat; in line 4 nikipati for ni≈õ√°pati ’the moon;’ in line 13 v√°nmin for v√°gmin; in line 15 the form kr√©yat√°m, derived from the root kri ’to make;’ and the verses 19 and 20 do not admit of a proper construction. A term, which I have not met with elsewhere, is vikisha, in lines 4 and.8, probably denoting the superintendent or commander of a fort. As rogards orthography, the consonant b is generally denoted by the sign for v, when it is preceded and followed by a vowel (e.g., in vivudha, line 1, Savar√¢n, line 10, etc.), and by its own proper sign, when combined with another consonant (e.g., in garbbha and avilambitam, in line 3); but we have twice babh√∫va, even after a vowel, in lines 6 and 7. The dental sibilant is nine times used for the palatal (e.g., in ≈õasi-, line 1, √°su and saila-, line 4), and the palatal for the dental in pra≈õ√∫nair, line 6, and vil√°≈õa-, line 13. Besides it may be noted that, instead of yy, we have the conjunct jy, in viga·πáajya, lines 8 and 10, and, instead of khy, ksh, in Jay√°kshe, line 8 (but not in line 11), and praksh√§ta, line 14; and that ujjvala, as usual, is spelt ujvala, in line 9.

The immediate object of the inscription would appear to be, to record (in verses 28-31) the construction of a temple by Subhata, the superintendent of the treasury of the king Bhoja or Bhojavarman. But in reality the inscription furnishes an account of the clan to which Subha·π≠a belonged, or of the more prominent members of that clan, the V√¢stavy a race of K√¢yasthas, some of whom held positions of importancc under the Chandella kings Ganda, Kirtivarman, Paramardin, Trailokyavarman, and Bhojavarman.

The K√¢yastha clan of the V√¢stavyas derived its origin from V√¢stu, who resided at Takk√¢rik√¢, one of a group of thirty-six1577 towns which were purified by the fact that men of the writer caste dwelt in them’ (vv. 2-4). In this clan was born the Thakkura J√¢j√ªka, who held a position of trust under king Ganda, and was honoured by him with the grant of the village of Dugau·∏ça (vv. 5-7). From him was desconded M√¢he≈õvara, who by Kirtivarman was appointed Visisha of K√¢la√±jara and endowed with the grant (of the village) of Pipal√¢hik√¢ (vv. 8-9). The next member of the family mentioned is Gadadhara, counsellor and chamberlain of king Paramardin (v. 10), who with his younger brother Jaunadhara fought at K√¢la√±jara (v. 11), and who had another brother, M√¢l√¢dhara, also distinguished as a warrior (v. 12). After them came Alh≈Ø, his son Sobhana, and his son.Vidana (vv. 13-15). Vidana’s son was V√¢se or V√¢≈õcka, who by king Trailokyavarman was appointed Visisha of the fort of Jaya or Jayapura (the present Ajaygadh), and endowed with the grant of the village of Varbhavari. He

defeated one Bhoj√ªka, who had either risen in rebellion against Trailokyavarman or conquered part of his territory, and he generally pacified the kingdom and rendered it secure against foreign enemies. H’e also built a temple and a tank at Jayapura (vv. 16-20). His younger b·πõother was √Çnanda who, as governor of the fort, subdued the wild tribes of Bhillas, ≈öabaras, and Pulindas. (vv. 21-22). √Çnanda’s son ‘was Ruchira (vv. 23-25), who had three sons, Gopati (v. 26), Mahip√¢la (v. 27), and Subha·π≠a, of whom the last, as stated above, was superintendent of the treasury of king Bhojavarman (vv. 28-30). After verso 31, the inscription has two more verses’, the second of which is illegible, and the first of which relates that Mahip√¢la again had three sons, one of whom was named Kirtip√¢la.

The VƒÅstavya family. is mentioned also in other Chandella inscriptions.‚Å¥1578 Thus, the two inscriptions from Mahob√¢, of which we have photo-lithographs in ArcheologicalSurvey of India, vol. XXI, plates xxii and xxiii, and one of which is dated’ in Vikrama 1240, record that in the illustrious great VƒÅstavya family there was one S√ªhila, the son of Hallana (?). An inscription from Ajaygadh, referred to ib., p. 53, mentions, according to Sir A. Cunningham, the Thakkura, the illustrious Vidana, who no doubt is the Vidana spoken of in the present inscription. And the inscription from Ajaygadh, edited in the Journal As. Soc. Beng., vol. VI, pp. 882-884, in its concluding lines, contains the name of another member of the Vastavya family of K√¢yasthas, who is described as pratolik√°nvita-Jayapuradurgg-√°dhipa, governor of the fort of Jayapura with the street (pratolik√°) belonging to it."

The five Chandella kings mentioned in this inscription are all well known from other inscriptions. But attention may be drawn to the circumstance that K√értivarman (in verse 9) is here described as the crest-jewel of the princes in the P√Ætasaila or YellowMountain districts, a territorial name which, so far as I know, has not been met with elsewhere. The name of Bhoj√ªka, the opponent of Trailokyavarman (whose latest known inscriptional date1579 at present is Vikrama 1298), occurs perhaps in an inscription at Ajayga·∏çh1580of the Vikrama year 1325, which mentions one Abhayadeva, apparently described as the son of Bhoj√ªka1581.

The town of Takk√¢rik√¢, and the villages of Dugauda, Pipal√¢hik√¢, and Varbhavar√Æ, which are mentioned in the inscription, I am unable to identify.

The inscription closes rather abruptly, and it neither contains the names of the composer, writer, and engraver, nor is it dated. But, since for the king Bhojavarman we have the date^(8) Vikrama 1345, it may be assigned to about the end of the 13th century A.D.

**8.**In the inscription of N√¢na, the minister of Bhojavarman, badly edited in the Journal As. Suc. Beng., vol. VI, pp. 882-884. Nana was one of the three sons of Ratuasimha, of whom that inscription reconds :-

‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§®‡§∞‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§ö‡§ø‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡•• ‡•®‡•™ ‡••

‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§∏ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§ß‡§ø(‡§®‡§ø)‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§¶‡•å ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§® ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡•Ä‡§ú‡§µ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§• ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§µ‡•Ä‡§¶‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§® ‡•• ‡•®‡•´ ‡••

which will dispose of “the horse sent to Bhoja Varma.” The inscription was composed by the poet Amara (not Amarapati), in Vikrama 1345, expressed in figures and in words (the latter, contrary to the ordinary rule according to which the unit should be mentioned first, being‚Äî‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§ó‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§∏‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•á).
