‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§®‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§£[‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏]‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• - [27].
‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§≤‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§£‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‚Äì

27.‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•á‡§ó‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§§‡•Ç‡§≤‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§≤‡§≤‡•Ä‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ó‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡§É ‡•§
‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§£‡§™‡§ü‡•Å ‡§∞‡§ú‡§É ‡§™‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‚Äì
‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡§∏ ‡§â‡§¶‡§ó‚Äì

  1. ‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§É161 ‡•• - [28].
    ‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡•á‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§§‡§Æ‡§∏‡•á ‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§É
    ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∞‡§£‡§ø‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§Ç[‡§Ø‡§Æ]‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§
    ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§™‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§∂‡§ø‡§®‡•á‡§µ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≤‡§§

  2. ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Å‡§∞‡§§‡•á‡§ú‡§∏‡§æ
    ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§¶‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡•å‡§∞‡§∏‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§É1695 ‡•• -[29].
    ‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡§æ‡§∞‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡§µ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§π‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§É‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§π‡§ø-
    ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡•Å‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡•à

30.‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡§≠‡§∞‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ó‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§ú‡•à‡§É ‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§Æ‡§†‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡•ã
‡§≠‡•Ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡§∏‡§æ ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§µ‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡§É ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∞‡•á‡§ú‡§ø‡§∞‡•á ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö ‡•• - [30].
‡§∏‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§ò‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§∏‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏

  1. ‡§è‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∂‡§É
    ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§
    ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§µ(‡§Ö)‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç
    ‡§™‡•Å‚Äì

32.‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ã‡§µ‡§®‡§ø‡§∏‡•É‡§ú‡§æ ‡§™‡•Å‡§Ç‡§ú‡•ã ‡§µ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§µ ‡•• -[31].
‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§ó‡•ã‡§ö‡§∞‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç
‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§ó‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏(‡§∑)‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•à‡§∞‡§¶‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡§Ç ‡•§
‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ(‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ) ‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡•à‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞-

L. 33. ‡§ö‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§§‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ ‡§§‡•á‡§ú‡•ã‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç
‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§ ‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•Å‡§ö‡§§‡§Æ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§ñ‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• -[32].
‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§æ
‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ ‡•§

  1. ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§§‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ú‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§∞‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§É
    ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ö‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π‡§æ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§π ‡§§‡§™‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï [[‡§∞] ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡••]1696 -[33].
    ‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡§æ‡§≤‡§®‡§ò‡§æ‡§§‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§Ø‡§¶‡§≤‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§≠‡•Ä‡§∞‡§≠‡•á‡§∞‡§µ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡•á‡§®‡•ã‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‚Äì

‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ (‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞) ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡§É ‡•§

35.‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§Ø‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§§‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§ü‡§ø‡§Ç
‡§ö‡•à‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§û‡•ç‡§´‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ñ‡§µ‡•Ç‡§µ‡•á‡§≤‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§µ‡§æ‡§É ‡••1697 -[34].
‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç‡§Æ ‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§™‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ-

  1. ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡§æ
    ‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ (‡§µ‡§æ) ‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§π‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§§‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§ú ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§
    ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§∞‡§≤‡§ò‡•Ç‡§¨‡§Æ‡§π‡•Å‡§£‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞(‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞) ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§Æ‡§æ‡§°‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨ (‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ) ‡§∞-
    ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∂‡§§‡§ï‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ (‡§µ‡§æ) ‡§π‡•Å‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ß‡•à‡§É ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡§É ‡•• - [35].

  2. ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Æ‡§π‡•á‡§∂ ‡§è‡§∑ ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡§≠‡•Ä‡§∞ ‡§ö ‡§ï‡§£‡§æ‡§∂‡§ø‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§ï‡§£‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•å ‡§ú‡•à‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§É ‡•§
    ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§ñ‡§Ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ï‡§™‡§ø‡§≤‡•ã ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§π‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡•Å (‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡•ç‡§¨‡•Å) ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§µ‡•Å (‡§¨‡•Å) ‡§π‡§Æ‡§§‡•á

  3. ‡§ú‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡§É ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§§‡•ã ‡•• - [36].
    ‡§Ø‡§π‡•Ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ß‡•Å‡§®‡§æ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§ö‡§ø‡§π‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á
    ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§¶‡§æ ‡§§‡§¶‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç ‡•§
    ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Å‡§ü‡§Æ‡•á‡§∑

39.‡§ï‡•ã‡§™‡§ø ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡•å ‡§∂‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã
‡§ß‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§® ‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ß‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Æ‡§¶‡•É‡§ö‡•å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§™‡•Å‡§É ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• - [37].
‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ö‡•Å‡§∞‡§§‡§∞‡§§‡§™‡§É‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§ø
‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§[‡§∏‡§æ?]-

  1. ‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡•É‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§≠‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§∞‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§£‡§ø ‡•§
    ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Æ‡•ç‡§£‡§ø ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§∂‡§∏‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§ø
    ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡§ï‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ ‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§§ ‡§® ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§É ‡••1698 - [38].
    ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§≤‡•Ä‡§®‡§Ç
  1. ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ó‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç
    ‡§¨‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö ‡§ú‡•à‡§Æ‡§ú‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•Å (‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•Å) ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§§‡•à‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡•§
    ‡§∏‡•ã‡§¢‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•Å ‡§® ‡§ú‡•à‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡•å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•Ä‡§≤‡§æ‡§≤‡§∞‡•ç‡§§ ‡§π‡•Å‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§Ç
    ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡§ó‡§®‡•á‡§∂‡§µ‡§æ‡§®

L 42 ‡§®‡§™‡§§‡•á‡§É ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡••1699 [39].
‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§ï‡•á‡•à‡§É‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Å‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ ‡§§‡•á‡§ú‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡•§
‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§®‡§®‡•Å ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§∞‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‚Äì

  1. ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡••1700 -[40]
    ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Å‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§∞‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§≤‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡•Ä‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ß
    ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Æ‡§∂‡§®‡•ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§ú‡§≤‡§ß‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏ ‡§ñ‡§≤‡•Å ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§É ‡§∏‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§≠‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ã‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§É ‡•• [41]

  1. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§®‡§Ø‡•ã‡§®‡§≤‡§∏‡§§‡§æ ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ó‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§É
    ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ß‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§Ø‡§µ‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏ (‡§ò) ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡§É ‡•§
    ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ã‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§∏‡§ø ‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡§æ‚Äì
    ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏-

  2. [‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ]‡§Æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ç. ‡§™‡§•‡§ø ‡••1701 - [42].
    ‡§∞‡§Ç‡§ú‡•Å‡§É ‡§∏‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ ‡§∏‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§ß‡•á-
    ‡§¨‡§ø‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§ø ‡§ï‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§ï‡•ã‡§°‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø ‡•§
    ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ñ‡§≤‡•Å ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ

46.‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡§®‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡•ã‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§É ‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡§É
‡§∏‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§µ‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§É ‡•• - [43].
‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ï‡•å ‡•§
‡§Æ ‡§Æ‡§†‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∞‡•à ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§∞‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‚Äì

47.‡§ö‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡•ç ‡••1702.") - [44].
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§™‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø (‡§¨‡§ø) ‡§ó‡•ç‡§µ (‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨) ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≤‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡§ø ‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§ó‡§£‡•á ‡•§
‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡§§‡•Ä‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•à‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡••1703 [45].
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‚Äì

  1. ‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§§‡•á ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ó‡§≠‡•Ä‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§É‡•§
    ‡§µ‡§ø‡§°‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨ (‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨) ‡§Ø‡§∏ ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ (‡§¨)‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§µ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§∂‡•ã‡§≠‡§Æ‡•ç ‡••885 - [46].
    ‡§∂‡•à‡§≤‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§™‡•ã‡§∞‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§∂‡§ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡•§

49 ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡§≤‡§π‡§Ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•á‡§∂‡§≤‡•á‡§® ‡••1704[47].
‡§ß‡•É‡§§‡•ã‡§¶‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡§§‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§∞‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ (‡§§‡•ç‡§®) ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§É ‡•§
‡§§‡•ã‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§§‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø (‡§¨‡§ø) ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§µ(‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨) ‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§≠‡•É [‡§∂‡§æ?] ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø (‡§¨‡§ø) ‡§≠‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡•ã‡§≠‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• - [48].

  1. ‡§Ö‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§ï‡•á‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¶‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§µ ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ ‡•§
    ‡§∏‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ ‡•• -[49].
    ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§® ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ã‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ(‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ)

  2. ‡§≤‡§æ‡§É ‡•§
    ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¨‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Æ‡•á‡§∂‡§Æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ã‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ú‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ ‡§á‡§µ ‡••621.")

  • [50].
    ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡•Ä‡§≤‡§ï‡§£‡•ç‡§†‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡§ü‡•ã‡§™‡§ï‡§£‡•ç‡§†‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡§æ ‡§ß‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡•§
    ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∞‡§Æ‡§£‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§É ‡§∏‡§¶‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§ö‡§ï‡§æ-

L. 52.-‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡••1705 - [51].
‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§¨‡§ø‡§ß‡•å‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡•§
‡§≠‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§≠‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§ù‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§ñ‡§æ ‡•• -[52].
‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§≠‡•ã‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§∞‡§∂‡•à‡§≤‡•Ä‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§¨‡§ø‚Äì

53 ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•á‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø ‡•§
‡§§‡•á‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•á‡§§ ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Å‡§ü‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§ï‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§ü‡§π‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä ‡•• - [53].
‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§´‡§≤‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡•ã‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§¶‡•à‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡•§
‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ã‡§¢‡•Å‡§ï‡§æ‚Äì

54.‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡•á‡§∞‡§≠‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• - [54].
‡§Æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§≤ ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ã‡§ú‡•Ç‡§≤‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ã‡§ú‡§≤‡§ß‡§ø‡§É ‡•§
‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§æ ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡§§‡•ç‡§§ ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§π‡•Å‡§Å ‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§® ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡•• -[55
‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ

55.‡§®‡•ã‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§∏‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§ó‡§≠‡•Ä‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡•§
‡§ú‡§≤‡•à‡§∞‡§®‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡•á‡§≠‡•É‡§∂‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§´‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡•Ä‡§®‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡•• -[56].
‡§Æ‡•É‡§ó‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø (‡§¨‡§ø)‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•á (‡§¨‡•ç‡§¨‡•á) ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ó‡§§‡•á ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Å‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§≤‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‚Äì

56.‡§≤‡•ã‡§≤‡•á ‡•§-
‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§æ‡§¶‡§∏‡•å‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§ß‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§§‡§≤‡§µ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡••1706 - [57].
‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§§‡•Å‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡•ã‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø (‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑) ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§µ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡•§
‡§∏‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•Ä‡§µ ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ï‡•Ç‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É

57.‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡•• - [58].
‡§á‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§®‡§≠‡§É ‡§ï‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡•ã‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§•‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡§Ø‡•Å [‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ] ‡§ú‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§®‡•å‡§ß‡§É ‡••1707 -[59].
‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§ù‡•Ä‡§®‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§∞‚Äì

58.‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§¨‡•å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡•ç‡§∏ (‡§¨) ‡§π‡•Å‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ ‡§ö ‡•§
‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§∞‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§ß‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡•• - [60].
‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§°‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á ‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§¶‡•à‡§µ ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡•§
‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§µ‡§æ‡§π ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§æ‚Äì

59 ‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§®‡§ø‡§≤‡•Ä‡§®‡§Ø‡§æ [‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ] ‡§§‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•à‡§É " ‡•• - [61]
‡§∞‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡§∞‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§∞‡§Æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç ‡§∞‡§•‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§∞‡•Å‡§™‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ß‡§∞‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡•§
‡§¶‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ö‡§ø‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§´‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡§ü‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§®‡§ö‡•Å‡§ö‡•Å‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡•• - [62].
‡§Ø‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§ö‡§ø

60.‡§¶‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡§§‡•Ä‡§π ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡•§
‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§ï‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡•à‡§ß‡§∏‡•ã‡§ö‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§ò‡§ü‡§ø‡§§‡§µ ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡•• - [63].
‡§ï‡•Å‡§µ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§§‡•ã‡§∑ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§Æ‡§¶‡§É ‡•§
‡§ö‡§ø‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‚Äì

‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

  1. The second of the two aksharas in bracketa was originally ‡§™.

  2. ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§µ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§∂‡§Ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡§§‡•á ‡••677 - [64].
    ‡§ñ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•Ä ‡§ó‡§ó‡§®‡§∂‡§∂‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ã‡§≤‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ã
    ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§™‡§∏‡•ã ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§∂‡§∏‡§É ‡•§
    ‡§¨‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•á ‡§≠‡§æ‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§∞‡§¶‡§Æ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç‡§°‡§µ‡§≤‡§æ

  3. ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§ü‡§§‡§ü‡§™‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡•á ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ñ‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡•Ä ‡••1708 ‚Äì[65].
    ‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•Ä‡§§‡§É ‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡§ü‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§Ø‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø [‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø]: ‡•§
    ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏ ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§ï‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§ñ‡§≤‡•Å ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§Ø‡•á ‡••1709 ‚Äì [66].
    ‡§™‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ

  1. ‡§§‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ñ‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å ‡§∂‡§†‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§†‡•á ‡§Ø‡•á‡•§
    ‡§Ø‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•á ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§¢‡§ß‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§∞‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§∏‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡••370 ‚Äì [67]
    ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§™‡§™‡•Ç‡§¨‡§Ç‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡•§

  2. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ (‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ) ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ [‡§∏‡•Å‡§¶‡•á‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å [‡§∏‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç] ‡••]1710.")‚Äì [88].
    ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§∑‡§æ‡§π‡§∞‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡•§
    ‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•Ä[‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂] ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ú‡•á‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§ï‡•á‡§®‡•ã‡§¶‡§ñ‡•ã‡§ü‡§ø ‡§ö ‡•• - [69].
    ‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡••

XLII. - HAMPE INSCRIPTION OF KRISHNARAYA, DATED SAKA 1430.
BY E. HULTZSCH, PH. D.

The original of this inscription is in the great ≈öiva temple of Pamp√†pati1711at the modern village of Hampe, which is situated on the southern bank of the Tu·πÖgabhadr√¢ river and at the north-western extremity of the ruins of Vijayanagara. It is engraved on the south and north faces of a stone tablet, which is set up in front of a ma·πá·∏çapa. The south face is badly mutilated at the bottom. The second half of the inscription, which is in fair preservation, was published by Mr. Fleet from a photograph by Dr. Pigou1712 T. C. Hope in 1866, No. 32; sud reproduced by the Arch. Survey of Western India in P√¢li, Sanskrit, and Old Canarese Inscriptions (1878), No. 116."). A rough transcript and paraphrase of the Sanskrit portion and a translation of the Kaharese portion of the inscription had already before appeared in the Asiatic Researches1713, and p. 34 (twelfth inscription )."). I re-edit the whole from an estampage made in 1889.

A second copy of the same √énscription is engraved on the north and south faces of another stone tablet, which is set up to the left of the entrance to the Pamp√¢pati temple. This copy is much worn, but helps to ascertain how many verses are lost at the bottom of the south face of the first copy.

The inscription opens with 29 Sa·πÖsk·πõit verses, which contain a genealogical account of the second Vijayanagara dynasty down to K·πõish·πáar√¢ya. Then follows a passage in Sanskrit prose, which records a gift to the temple by this king. The document ends with a Kanarese version of the same donation.

The genealogy consists of a mythical and a historical part. The former (verses 3 and 4) runs as follows:‚Äì

The Moon
\‡•§
Budha.1714
\‡•§
P√ªrtiavas
\‡•§
ƒÄyus.

\‡•§
ahusha.

\‡•§

Yay√¢ti, md. Devay√¢ni.

\‡•§

Turvasu.

The historical part begins with verse 5:-" In his (viz., Turvasu’s) race shone king Timma, who was famous among the princes of Tuluva, just as K·πõish·πáa shone in the race of Yadu." From this verse we learn, first, that the founder of the second Vijayanagara dynasty was a native of Tulu or Northern Malay√•·∏∑am, the country of the Juluvas. Secondly, he must have been a usurper, as he claims only a mythical relationship to the princes of the first dynasty of Vijayanagara. For, while the kings of this dynasty used to derive their origin from Yadu, Timma selected, in opposition to his predecessors on the throne, Yadu’s younger brother Turvasu as the mythical progenitor √¥f his race. The inscription continues the pedigree from Timma as follows:-

  1. Timma, md. Devaki.

\‡•§
2. Isvara, md. Bukkam√¢.

\‡•§
3. Natasa or N·πõisimha (Saka 1404 and 1418)1715
\‡•§

a. by Tipp√¢ji‚Äî b by N√¢g√¢li‚Äî

4 V√éra-Nrisimha or V√éra-N√¢rasimha. 5. Krishnar√¢ya(Saka 1430 to 1451)1716.

The description of the reigns of these kings is purely conventional. At first sight a historical fact seems to be contained in verse 10, according to which king Narasa conquered Srirangapattana. But a reference to a published inscription of Harihara II1717.shows that this verse was borrowed, together with others, from an “office copy” of the first dynasty, in which it had formed part of the description of the reign of Samgama. Regarding the successors of Krishnaraya, the reador is referred to the Indian Antiquary, vol. XIII, p. 154.

The second part of the inscription, which is written in Sansk·πõit prose (north face, lines 11 to 25), records that K·πõish·πáadeva‚Äìmah√¢rAya gave the village of si·πÖgen√¢-yakanahalli to the ≈öiva temple called Vir√ªp√¢ksha, and built an assembly-hall (ra·πÖga-ma·πá·∏çapa) in connection with the same temple. Vir√ªp√¢kshadeva, the old name of the Pamp√¢pati templƒô, occurs already in inscriptions of Bukka and Harihasa II. of the first dynasty1718. By the assembly-hall must be meant the ma·πá·∏çapa, in front of which the stone tablet is set up. In a verse (30), with which the ≈öansk·πõit portion ends; the inscription is called an edict (≈õ√°sana) of K·πõish·πáar√°ya.

The same donation is referred to, with some additions, in the Kanarese portion, where, however, the name of the village is spelt Si·πÖgin√¢yakanahalli, with an iinstead of an e in the second syllable1719. Lines 27f. of the north face contain the date of the grant, S√¢liv√¢hana-≈öaka-varsha 1430 expired, the ≈öukla-sa·πÅvatsara current1720."),MƒÅgha ≈öu 14, on which day was the festival of the king’s coronation. Though no earlier inscriptions of K·πõish·πáar√¢ya are known, it is at present impossible to say, whether the real day of the coronation or an anniversary of it is intended.

In the Sansk·πõit portion of the inscription occur two Kanarese birudas, to which the Sansk·πõit case-termination is affixed (bh√°shege tappuvar√°yara ga·πá·∏ça·∏•, north face, line 4, and m√∫·πõu-r√°yara ga·πá·∏ça·∏•, line 5f.), also & Sansk·πõitized form of an Arabic word (suratr√¢·πáa= …, lines 6 and 14) and of a Per≈õian word (hindu = …., line 6 ) ; instead of r√¢jan, the Kanarese tadbhava r√¢ya is frequently used.

TEXT.
A.‚ÄîSouth face.

L. 1. ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä
2. ‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡•§ ‡§®‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç‡§ó‡§∂‡§ø‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¨‡§ø‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ö‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞[‡§µ‡•á] ‡•§
3. ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§ó‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç‡§≠‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§∂‡§Ç‡§≠‡§µ‡•á ‡••[‡•ß *]
4. ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§π‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡§π‡§Ç‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡§ú‡•ã‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡§ú‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç-
5. ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ö ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§ [‡•®*] ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π‡•á‡§µ‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§Ç‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡•á‡§É‡•§ ‡§®‡§µ-
6. ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§Æ‡§ø‡§µ‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§™‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§§‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§π‡§É‡•§ [‡•©*] ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡•ã‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•à‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ
7. ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡§É (1) ‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ú‡§¨‡§≤‡•à‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§ò‡•É‡§§‡§É‡•§ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ
8. ‡§∑‡•ã‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á ‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡•å (‡•§) ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡•Å ‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§≠‡§É1721
9. ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§™‡§§‡•á‡§É‡•• [‡•™ *] ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•á‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡•á ‡§§‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•Å‡§µ‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•Å
10. ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ã‡§É ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£ ‡§á‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•á ‡•• [‡•´ *] ‡§§‡§§‡•ã‡§≠‡•Ç‡§π‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç-
11. ‡§∂‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•å‡§≤‡§ø‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§≠‡•Å‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ç ‡•• [‡•¨*] ‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ã ‡§¨‡§≤‡§ø‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡•à‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ[:]
12. ‡§∂‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡§ï‡§∞‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§®‡§Ç‡§¶‡§®‡§É‡•§ ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§§‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø
13. ‡§Ø‡§æ1722‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç (‡•§) ‡§™‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡•á (‡•§) ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§æ‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡•É‡§∂‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§≠‡•É‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ-
14. ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•• [‡•≠*] ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•á‡§ï‡§™‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã‡§π‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§Ç (‡•§) ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Ç‡§®‡§π‡§®‡•ç ‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡•ã‡§™‡•á-

L. 15. ‡§§‡•ã‡§®‡§™‡•á‡§§‡•ã ‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ü‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§π‡•á‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ö‡§≤‡§Ç (1) ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ö ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§µ‡§ø‡§§-

16. ‡§∞‡§£‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡§§ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡§∞‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç ‡•• [‡•Æ*] ‘‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§¶‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§É ‡•§ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§®‡§Ç‡§¶‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ-

17.[‡§ï‡•Ä] ‡§®‡§Ç‡§¶‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ ‡•• [‡•Ø*] ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡•Å ‡§¨‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ1723‡§¨‡§π‡§≤‡§ú‡§≤‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ò‡•à‡§∞‡§µ ‡§∂‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§Ç (1) ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ

18. ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ú‡§¨‡§≤‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡•§ ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§Ç‡§ó‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§§‡§¶‡§™‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡§µ‡§∂‡•á ‡§™‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§¨-

19. ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•á (1) ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç‡§≠‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§ñ‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡§≠‡§µ‡§∞‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§É ‡•• [‡•ß‡•¶*] ‡§ö‡•á‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•ã‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§™‡§æ‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡§Æ-

20. ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ö ‡§Æ [‡§ß‡•Å] ‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§≠‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§≠‡•Ç‡§µ‡§Ç (1) ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§¶‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§ú‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§§‡§¶-

21. ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ü‡§ó‡§Ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡§ö‡§∞‡§Æ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ü‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§‡§Ç (‡•§) ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§§‡§É [‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ã] ‡§£‡•Ä‡§™‡§§‡•Ä-

22. ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§Æ‡§ø‡§µ ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§¨‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡•• [‡•ß‡•ß*] ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§∏‡•Å‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡•á ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§°‡•ç‡§°-

23. ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡§§‡•ç‡§§ ‡§Ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø1724‡•§ ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§ø

24. ‡§∑‡•ã‡§°‡§∂ ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡§ú‡§®‡•ã‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Ä‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§∂‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§æ [‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç] [ ‡••‡•ß‡•®‡•• ‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§ó*]‡§≤‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡§ï‡•å‡§∏-

25. ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡•§ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ ‡§®‡•É‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ [‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§Ç] [‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§•‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ1725‡•• ‡•ß‡•© ‡•• ‡§µ‡•ã‡§∞‡•å*] ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§Ø‡§ø‡§®‡•å ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ-

26. ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ ‡§®‡§Ç‡§¶‡§®‡•å‡•§ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•å‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡§®‡•É‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§∞‡§æ[‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§™‡§§‡•Ä1726" ‡••‡•ß‡•™*] ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ1727

27. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§Ø‡§®‡§ó‡§∞‡•á ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ1728‡§∏‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É" ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•É [‡§ó‡§®‡§ñ‡§®‡§π‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ*] ‡§®‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ [‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø] [‡§Æ‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡••

28. ‡§Ü ‡§∏‡•á‡§§‡•ã‡§∞‡§æ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡•á‡§∞‡•ã‡§∞‡§µ‡§®‡§ø‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§ö‡•ã‡§¶‡§Ø‡§æ [‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∞‡§æ ‡§™‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö*]‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤-

29. ‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏ ‡•• [‡•ß‡•´ *] ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ[‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä][‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§®‡§ï‡§∏ *]‡§¶‡§∏‡§ø [‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä] ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§¶‡•á‡§µ-

30. ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡§™‡§ø ‡§®‡§ó‡§∞ ‡§¨‡•á‡§Ç‡§ï[‡§ü‡§æ]‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•å ‡§ö ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç [‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç] ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡•à‡§≤ ‡§∂‡•ã‡§£‡§∂‡•à‡§≤‡•á ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡§ø

31. ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§π‡§∞‡•á‡§π‡•ã‡§¨‡§≤‡•á ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡•á ‡§ö (1) ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§Ç‡§ó‡•á ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç‡§≠‡§ò‡•ã‡§£‡•á [‡§π]‡§§[‡§§‡§Æ]‡§∏‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§©‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•å ‡••[‡•ß‡•¨*] ‡§ó‡•ã‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•á1729

32. ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•á‡§§‡•å‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞[‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡§æ*]‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§¨‡§π‡§≤‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ

33. ‡§π‡•à‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§¶‡§Ç‡§ö‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡§Ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡§ñ‡•Å‡§∞‡§∞‡§ú‡§∂‡•ç‡§∂‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡§Ç[‡§≠‡•ã‡§ß‡§ø‡§Æ*]‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§ï‡•Å

34. ‡§≤‡§ø‡§∂‡§ß‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§Ç‡§†‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç‡§†‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡•ç ‡•• [‡•ß‡•≠*] ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç [‡§ò‡§ü*] ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§ß‡•á[‡§®‡•Å‡§Ç]

35. ‡§∏ [‡§™‡•ç‡§§] ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§≠‡•ã‡§ß‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§ö¬≤‚Å∞ ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§π‡§≤‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•á‡§®‡•Å‡§Ç ‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç¬≤¬π " ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡•Å-

36. [‡§≤‡§æ‡§™‡•Ç*]‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•ã‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞ (‡•§) ‡§π‡•á‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§π‡•á‡§Æ‡§ó‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•à ‡§ï‡§®‡§ï‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§∞‡§•‡§Ç ‡§™‡§Ç‡§ö‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç ‡•• [‡•ß‡•Æ] ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ[·∏π]

37. [‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç*] ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§æ[‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø] ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ò‡•ç‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§µ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç‡•§ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•á [‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ó]-[‡§§‡•á ‡••‡•ß‡•Ø*]

38. [‡§§‡§§‡•ã* ] ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø[‡§µ‡§æ]‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§¨‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§£‡§ø‡§ï‡•á‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§∞‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø[‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡•Ä*]

39. [‡§≠‡•Å*][‡§ú‡•á] ‡•• [‡•®‡•¶] ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞[‡§∏‡•É‡§§] ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡•à‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡•á- (‡•§) ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø [‡§™‡•Å]-[‡§∞‡§æ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§∞‡§≠*]-

40. [‡§µ‡§ô‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ* ]‡§≤‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∂‡§É ‡•§ ‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ã‡§™‡§ø ‡§ö[‡§§‡•Å][‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§ú‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§ø ‡§ö*]‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ[‡§≠‡•Ç‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§ñ‡§°‡•ç‡§ó*].-

41. [‡§Æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ *][‡§Æ] ‡§ö [‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ç] ‡§µ‡•Ä[‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç] [‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≤ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§∞‡•á ‡•• ‡•®‡•ß*]

—————————————————————————–

20. Read ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•Ä‡§∑

**21. **Read ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç

HAMPE INSCRIPTION OF KRISHNARAYA

[ Here two verses are entirely lost through the mutilation of the stone. The following transcript of them is made from the duplicate copy with the help of other
Vijayanagara insoriptions :‚Äî]

‡§∂‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡•á ‡§¶‡§¶‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç‡§¨‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡•á‡§®‡§æ1730‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡§Ç‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§ü‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§§‡•Ä‡§ß‡•Ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ-‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‡•§ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ñ‡•á‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡§ø¬≤¬≥ ‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§ú‡§≤‡§ß‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á (‡•§) ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§°‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡•ç‡§®¬≤‚Å¥‡§Æ‡•á‡§∞‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§§‡•ã‡§Ø‡•à‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡•á‡§É1731‡•§ [‡•®‡•®*].

** ‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ[:*] ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§π ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•Å‡§Ç‡§ú‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø [:*] ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§π‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•ã‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡§®‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç¬≤‚Å∂‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç [*] ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§ú‡•à‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ø¬≤‚Å∑ ‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡§™‡§¶‡•à‡§∞‡§Ç‡§ï‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§®‡•Å‡§§ ‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§ø ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§≠‡•É‡§¶‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∑‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡•• [‡•®‡•©*]**

B.‚ÄîNorth face

L 1. [‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç] ‡§ö‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡•à‡§≤‡§∂‡•ã‡§£‡§æ‡§ö‡§≤‡§ï‡§®‡§ï‡§∏‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§Ç‡§ï‡§ü‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ[‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø][‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏-
2.‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§Ç[[‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ] ‡§§‡§®‡•Å‡§§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Ø‡§∏‡•á ‡§Ø‡§É [‡•§*] ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ï‡§®‡§ï‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡§æ‡§™‡•Ç-
3. ‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ‡•ã[‡§™] ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•à‡§∞‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡•à‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡•• [‡•®‡•™*] ‡§∞‡•ã‡§∑‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø-
4. ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ø‡§µ‡§¶‡§Ç‡§°‡•ç‡§°‡§∂‡•ç‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§≠‡•Å‡§ú‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§∂‡•å‡§Ç‡§°‡•ç‡§°‡•§ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡•á‡§ó‡•á ‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§µ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∞ ‡§ó‡§Ç‡§°‡•ç‡§°‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§∑‡§ï‡•É
6. ‡§¶‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ø [‡§∑‡•Å] ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§∞‡§£‡§ö‡§Ç‡§°‡•ç‡§°‡§É ‡•• [‡•®‡•´ *] ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§É‡•§ ‡§Æ‡•Ç 69 ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø-
6. ‡§∞ ‡§ó‡§Ç‡§°‡•ç‡§°‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§™‡§∞‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§≠‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§É ‡•• [‡•®‡•¨*] ‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•ã‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§∂‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ç‡§≤‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§®‡§É‡•§ ‡§ó‚Äì
7. ‡§ú‡•å‡§ß‡§ó‡§Ç‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§Æ‡•á‡§∞‡•Å‡§Ç‡§£‡•ç‡§° [‡§á] ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡•• [‡•®‡•≠*] ‡§Ü‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú ‡§ú‡§Ø ‡§ú‡•ã‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§æ
8. ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ó‡§µ‡§Ç‡§ó‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ø‡•à (:) ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§ö ‡§Ø‡§É ‡•• [‡•®‡•Æ*] ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•å‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏
9. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§Ø‡§®‡§ó‡§∞‡•á ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç[‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§•]: (1) [‡§Æ‡§æ]‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§ï‡•É[‡§£] ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§ß‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡•É.
10. ‡§ó‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä[‡§®‡•ç ]‡•§ ‡§Ü‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∞[‡§•]‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§[‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø]‡§§‡§ø‡§ß‡§∞‡§ï‡§ü‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§π‡•á‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ö‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§‡§æ (1) ‡§¶‡§æ ‡§∏‡•á‡§§‡•ã‡§∞‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§∏‡§æ-
11. ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•ç‡§•‡§∂‡•ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§π1732‡§¨‡§π‡§≤‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ß‡•á ‡•§[‡•®‡•Ø]‡§ï‡§ø‡§≤ ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§µ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡§Ç-
12.‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•à‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡§Ø‡§∂‡§É‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§¨‡•ç‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§°‡•ç‡§°
13. ‡§ï‡§∞‡§Ç‡§°‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡§ö‡§Ç‡§°‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§π[‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç] ‡§§‡§®‡•É‡§ó‡§®‡§≤‡§®‡§π‡•Å‡§∑‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§¶‡•Å‡§Ç‡§ß‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞1733‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡•É‡§≠‡§∞‡§§‡§≠-
14. ‡§ó‡•ã‡§∞‡§•‡§¶‡§∂‡§∞‡§•‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§£‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•á‡§® ‡§ó‡§ú‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§ó‡§ú‡§ï‡•Ç‡§ü.
15. ‡§™‡§æ‡§ï‡§≤‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§ø[‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ] ‡§ï‡§≤‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§¶‡§®‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç‡§≠‡•ã‡§ú‡•á‡§® ‡§≠‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§£ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ü‡§ï‡§æ1734‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ-
16. ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á [‡§®] ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø[‡§§] ‡§ï‡§®‡§ï‡§µ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§π‡•ã‡§§[‡•©]‡§®‡§∏‡§µ‡•á‡§®¬≥¬π ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á
17. [‡§®] ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á‡§® ‡§®‡§ø‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§•‡•á‡§® ‡§ß‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§® ‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ç‡§¨‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§á‡§∞‡§∏‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§®‡§Ç‡§¶‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§Æ‡§ø
18. ‚Ä¢ ‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤ ‡§¶‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç‡§¶‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§Ø-
19. ‡§®‡§ó‡§∞‡•á ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ò‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ú‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á-
20. ‡§™‡§£ ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á‡§£ ‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡§≠‡§∞‡§£‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ[‡§ß] \‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ-
21, ‡§•‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø [‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§£1735‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§§‡§ú‡§®‡§π‡•á‡§Æ‡§ï‡•Ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§π‡•á‡§Æ‡§ï‡•Ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§-
22. ‡§®‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡•á ‡§∂‡•Ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡•á ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡§´‡§≤‡§™‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§®‡•à‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ó‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ï-
28. ‡§®‡§π‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§™‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡§æ

——————————————————————————————————————–

23 Read ‡§ñ‡•à‡§∞‡§Æ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§ø
24 Read ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ…‡§ñ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£.
26 Read …..
27 Read ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§ú‡•á‡§ö‡§¨‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ø.
31 Read ‡§Æ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§µ‡•á‡§ó‡§∏‡§µ‡§Ç‡§ó.

L. 21. ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§®‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∞‡§Ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§°‡•ç‡§°‡§™‡•ã‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§§‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§ü‡§ø‡§§-
25. ‡§®‡§∞‡§ú‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®‡§ß[‡§®‡•Å]‡§∑‡§æ ‡•• ‡§§‡§¶‡§ø‡§¶‡§Æ‡§µ‡§®‡•Ä‡§µ‡§®‡•Ä‡§™‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡§ß‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø
26. ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§§‡§ø‡§¨‡§≤‡§∂‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∏‡§®‡§§‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ [‡§∏‡§æ‡§™‡§¶]‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø \‡•§ [‡•®‡•¶ *]
27. ‡§ñ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§¨‡•ã‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§¶‡§Ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§®‡§∂‡§ï‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑ ‡•ß‡•™‡•©‡•¶ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•Å
28. ‡§Æ‡•á‡§≤‡•á ‡§Æ‡§°‡§µ ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡§¶ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ò ‡§∂‡•Å ‡•ß‡•™‡§∂‡•Å ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ-
29 ‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§¨‡•ã‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§£‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§π‡§æ-
30. ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∞‡•Å ‡§™‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∑‡•á‡§ï‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§µ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§¶‡§≤‡•Å‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§™‡§æ
31. ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§™‡§°‡§ø‡§®‡§á‡§µ‡•á] [[‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡•á]"]1736 ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ï‡§®‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ø‡§® ‡§∏-
32. ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§∏‡§ø ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§¶ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§ü‡§™‡§µ‡§®‡•Ç ‡§ß‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¶.
33. ‡§µ ‡§ó‡•ã‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§µ‡§® ‡§ï‡§π‡§ø‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§¶‡§£ ‡§π‡§ø‡§Ø ‡§ó‡•ã‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§µ‡§®
34. ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡•ã‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§® ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§°‡§ø‡§∏‡§ø ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§ö‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ó‡•á ‡§®‡§µ-
36. ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§ñ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡§µ‡§®‡•Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§≠‡§∞‡§£‡§µ‡§®‡•ç
36. ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•Å [‡•§ *] ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§®‡•à [‡§µ‡•á]‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ã [‡§ó] ‡§£‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§°‡•Å‡§µ‡§¶‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡§Æ-
37. ‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§"1737 ‡§ö‡§ø‡§Ç‡§¶ ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§£ ‡•ß ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§≤‡§ó‡•á ‡•® ‡§µ‡•á‡§≤‡•á‡§Ø
38. ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡•®‡•™ ‡§á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§® ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•Å \‡•§ ‡§Ø‡•Ä ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡•á
39. ‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§¶‡§µ‡§∞‡•Å‡§ó‡§≤‡•Å ‡§ó‡•ã‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø[ƒ´‚âç]‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ-
40. ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§ï‡§ó‡§≤ ‡§Æ‡§æ[‡§°‡§ø‡§¶] ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡•á ‡§π‡•ã‡§ó‡§≤‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§µ‡§∞‡•Å [‡••‚âç]

TRANSLATION.

A. Sanskrit portion.
(This is an ediot of) the illustrious Krishnadevar√°ya.
Hail ! Let there be prosperity !

( Verse 1. ) Adoration to Sambhu ( Siva), who is adorned, as with a ch√°mara, with the moon that kisses his lofty head, and who is the principal pillar at the building of the city of the three worlds‡•§ 351738

(2) May that lustre ( Ganeba ), - which dispels the darkness of obstacles, and which, though ( it has the head of) an elephant ( gaja), was born from the mountain-daughter (Agaja), and is worshipped even by Hari ( Vishnu), - produce happiness ‡•§ 361739

( 3 ) There was produced, like fresh butter, from the great ocean of mflk, when it was churned by the gods, the luminary which dispels darkness (i.e., the moon).

(4.) The son of this (moon ) was Budha, whose name ( tode made) true to its nean- ing1740by his unequalled austerities. In consequence of his pious deeds (he obtained a
son), Pur√°ravas. ( The son ) of him, who destroyed the life (√§yus) of his enemies by

the strength of his arm, was √Çyus. His (son) was Nahusha. His (son) was Yayati, who was fier-ce in battle (and) famed on earth. (The son) of this husband of the glorious Devay√¢nt was Tur-vasu, who resembled the Vasus.

(V.5.) In his race shone king Timma, whose wife was Devaki, (and) who was famous among the princes of Tuluva, just as Krishna (shone) in the race of Yadu.

(6.) From him was born king √é≈õvara, whose wife was Bukkam√¢ (and) who was the fearless and virtuous crest-jewel1741of kings.

(7.) Oh wonder! Though (like K·πõishna) he was the son of the glorious Devaki, though (like Vish·πáu) he had lotus eyes, though he acquired tribute (bali) by his valour which was able to subdue the three worlds, (just as Vish≈Üu in his V√¢man√¢vat√¢ra dequired the three worlds from Bali hy his three steps), and though he bore (the anspicions marks of the conch and the discus in his hand‚Äîhe became still more famous by the name of √é√°vara, as he obtained prosperity (bh√∫ti, universal worship, and the daughter of a king, (just as the god √é√©vara wears ashes [bh√ªti], is universally worshipped, and is the husband of the daughter of the mountain).

(8.) Like another sun, who always dwelt on earth, he, ‚Äî who was continually rising, who was surrounded by poets and wise men, who never fled from war (and) who was highly famed from the eastern to the western ocean (and) from (R√°ma ºs) Bridge to the golden mountain (Meru),‚Äîkilled the enemies, (as,the sun conquers) the Mandehas,1742and shone, surpassing the trees of heaven by his gifts.

(9.) From this lovely son of Devak√Æ was born king Narasa, just as K√•ma from (Krishna) the son of Devaki.

(10.) Resplendent was he, who quickly bridged the Kaveri,1743 (though) it consisted of a rapid current of copious water, crossed over it, straightway captured alive in battle with the strength of his arm the enemy, brought his kingdom and (the .city of) Srirangapa·π≠·π≠a·πáa1744 pa·π≠·π≠a·πáa, the first member of which is Sriranga.‚Äô On similar expressions, see Hultzsch’s South-Indian Inscriptions, vol. I, p. 166, note 6. This is the celebrated place of pilgrimage on an island, 33 miles east of B√¢mnad. According to Mr. Rice (Mysore Inscriptions, p. lvii, note), another R√•me≈°vara-tirtha is situated on an island near the junction of the Tung√• and Bhadr√• rivers. Three other R√•mesvaras are noticed by Mr. Sewell in his Lists of Antiquities, vol. 1, pp. 38, 41, 125.")under his power and set up a pillar of fame,‚Äîhis heroic deeds being praised in the three worlds, (which appeared to be) the palace (of his glory).

(11.) Having conquered the Chera, the Chola, the proud P√¢ndya (who was) the lord of Madhur√¢, the brave Turushka, the Gajapati king and others, he, who was exceedingly famed from the banks of the Gang√• to La≈Ñk√• and from the slopes of the eastern to those of the western mountain, spread his command like a garland on the heads of kings.

(12.) At R√¢me≈õvara42and every other shrine on earth which abounds in sacredness, he, with joyful heart, surrounded by wise men, repeatedly performed the sixteen kinds of gifts according to rule, (thus) making superfluous (his previously acquired) great fame, which was sung by the inhabitants of the three worlds.

(Vv. 13 and 14.) Just as Rama and Lakshma≈Üa (were born) to Da≈õaratha by his queens Kausaly√¢ and the glorious Sumitr√¢, (thus) two brave (but) modest sons, prince Vira-Nrisimha and prince K·πõishnaraya, were born to king N·πõisimha by his queens Tipp√¢ji and Nagala (respectively).

(15.) The illustrious V√Æra-N√¢rasimha,-seated on a jewelled throne at Vijayanagara, surpassing in fame (and) wisdom N·πõiga, Nala, Nahusha and (all) other (kings) on carth, being voluntarily praised by the Br√¢hma·πáas (and) winning all hearts,+-ruled the kingdom from (R√°ma’s) Bridge to (Mount) Sumeru and from the mountain of the east to the western mountain.

(16.) He performed various gifts at the Golden Hall1745, at the shrine of the holyVir≈´pƒÅksh-adova,1746at the town of the holy lord of KƒÅlahasti1747,on Venka»õ√¢dri,1748 near Tirupati in the North Arcot distriot.") at K√¢√±chi, at ≈ör√Æsaila,1749at Sonas-ala,1750 at the sacred (city of) Harihara,1751[]1751at Ahobala1752,1753at Samgama,1754at Sriranga1755 at Kumbhagho·πáa1756,at the sinless tirthaofMah√¢nandi1757 (and) at Nivritti.1758, which is now in the Madras Museum :— ‡§ó‡•ã‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•Å‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§∏‡§ö‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•á‡§∑ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡§æ‡§£………………………………..‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§™‡•Ä‡§°‡§ú‡•ç‡§û ‡§µ‡§π‡§®‡§ø ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡•• Here Suvarnasamgha refers to the Golden Hall at Chidambaram; Viri√±ohipura is in the North Arcot district; the remainlocalities are mentioned in verses 16 and 17 of the text.")

(17.) The streams of water (poured out) at copious great gifts of various kinds, which he performed at Gokar·πáa,1759at R√¢ma’s Bridge, and at all other sacred places in the world, frustrated the eagerness of (Indra) the bearer of the thunderbolt, who was ardently rising to clip the wings1760of the mountains, which were immersed in the ocean, that was being dried up by the dust of the hoofs of the troops of his prancing horses.

(18.) He performed (the gifts of) a mundane egg, a wheel of the universe, a pot containing the (five) elements, a jewelled cow, the seven oceans, a tree and a creeper of paradise, a celestial cow of gold, an earth of gold, a horse-chariot of gold, the weight of a man (in gold), a thousand cows, a horse of gold, a (golden vessel called) hemagarbha, an elephant-car of gold, and five ploughs.1761 agrees with that given in the Mitsyapur√¢nu, as quoted in Dr. Aufrecht’s Catalogus Bibliotheee Budlesund, p. 48, and in Hem√•dri’s D√¢nakhanda, in 1661of tha Culontte aditia n")

(Vv. 19 and 20.) When, having ruled his great kingdom without obstacles, this Indra of the earth, who was famed for virtue, had gone to heaven, as if it were in order to rule heaven (too), the illustrious king K·πõishnar√¢ya, whose valour was irresistible, bore the earth on his arm like a bracelet of jewels.

(21) It was probably through fear, lest everything should assume an identity of lustre from his fame, which was spread everywhere, that, of old, Siva adopted a (third) eye on his forehead (as a distinguishing mark), Vishnu four arms, Brahman four faces, Kall a sword, Ram√¢ a lotus, and V√¢≈Ü√Æ a lute in her hand.

(22.) Was it through anger, because they gave refuge to his enemies, that he dried up the seven oceans with the clouds of the dust of the earth, which was split by the horses of his numerous armies, and of his own accord created in their stead masses of oceans by the immeasurable waters (poured out) at his great gifts, which consisted of a mundane egg, a Meru of gold, &c. ?

(23.) It was probably in order to obstruct the path of the chariot of the sun in the sky, with the view that the crowds of suppliants should enjoy as long as possible the riches given by him, that this lord of the earth set up in every part of the earth firmly fixed pillars, which were marked with (an account of) his expeditions for conquering each quarter and with (his) surnames (biruda), and the tops of which touched the clouds.

(24.) Again and again, for the sake of supreme happiness, he performed according to rule those various gifts which are prescribed in the holy books, viz., the weight of a man in gold, &c., together with all minor gifts, at K√¢√±chi, at Srisaila, at Sonachala, at the Golden Hall, on Ve·πÖka·π≠adri1762 and at all other temples and bathing-places.

(25 to 27.) Some of his surnames (biruda) were :‚ÄîThe angry punisher of rival kings; he whose arms resemble (the coils of the serpent) ≈öesha; he who is versed in protecting the earth1763; the destroyer of those kings who break their word1764 and 189."); he who satisfies suppliants; he who is fierce in war; the king of kings and the supreme lord of kings; the destroyer of the three kings (of the South)1765; he who terrifies hostile kings; the Sult√¢n among Hind√ª kings; he who crushes the wicked like tigers; and the doubleheaded eagle which splits the temples of troops of elephants1766 and Ar√≠bhagan·∏çabherunda in a grant of Venka»õa II. (Ind. Ant., vol. XIII, p. 131, plate iva, liue 10).") !

(28.) He is served by the Anga, Vanga, Kalinga and other kings, who speak thus :‚Äî ‚ÄúLook (upon me), Oh grent king! Be victorious ! Live (long) !‚Äù

(29.) Seated on a jewelled throne at Vijayanagara, king K·πõish·πáar√¢ya, whose liberality was worthy to be praised by the learned, having surpassed Nriga and other kings in wisdom, and having bestowed abundant riches on all suppliants on earth, was resplendent with fame from the pastern mountain to the slopes of the mountain of the west and from the mountain of gold (Meru) to (R√°ma’s) Bridge.

He, who filled the world, as a box with camphor, with the flood of his fame, which arose from liberality, firmness, valour and other (virtues), that were being praised by the crowd of all poets in this world; who was fierce in battle; who surpassed the

deeds of N·πõig√°, Nala, Nahusha, N√¢bh√¢ga, Dhundhumara, M√¢ndh√¢tri, Bharata, Bhagi- ratha, Da≈õaratha, R√¢ma and other (kinga); who protected Br√¢hma·πáas; who subdued Sult√°ns; who was (like) the fever to the elephants of the Gajapati (king); who knew many arts; whose face surpassed the lotus; who, (like) a second Bhoja, knew the mysteries of poetry, of the drama and of rhetoric; who knew the law; who, every ycar, performed a sacrifice to (K√°ma) the lord of the golden festival of spring;"1767 who fulfilled the desires of the crowd of Brahma·πáas; who was rich; who was the chief of all princes; who was fortunate; who was the son of Nag√†mbika"1768 and of king Narasa; who delighted all hearts; who was victorious at the head of battles; who conquered (all) quarters; who, having ascended the throne at Vijayanagara, was ruling the whole earth; who won battles hy (the strength of) his arm :-K·πõish·πõadeva-mah√¢r√¢ya gave a village, which was famed by the name of Singenayakanahaƒºƒºi and which was adorned with its four boundaries,’ for (providing) pleasant oblations (naivedya), (consisting of) sweet fruits, cakes, &c., to S√ªlin (Siva), called the holy Virupaksha, to whom pious people have presented’ heaps of gold, who abides on the Hemakuta,1769 is Hemakuta; the most auspicious Tungabhadra is the moat that surrounds it; the guardian of it is visibly the god Sri-Virupakshadeva.") and who is diligent in protecting the world. The same (king), who assisted (others) with his wealth like (Karna) the son of the sun, and who was Kama manifest in a human birth, built an assembly-hall (ranga-ma·πá·∏çapa) (for the use) of the same god.

(Verse 30.) This is the edict of the heroic Krishnaraya, whose path on earth was praised by the beggars of the earth, and the gifts of whose hand surpassed (those of) the tree of Indra.1770

B. Kanarese portion.

Hail! On the 14th day of the bright half (of the month) of M√¢gha of the ≈öukla- sa·πÅvatsara, which was current, after the 1430th year of the illustrious, victorious and prosperous ≈ö√¢livahana-Saka had passed, the illustrious mah√°r√°j√°dhir√°ja and r√°ja. parame≈õvara, the illustrious Virapratapa,1771 the illustrious Vira-Krishnaraya-mah√¢- r√¢ya, gave, at the auspicious time of the festival of his coronation (pa·π≠·π≠√°bhisheka), for (providing) daily oblations of food (amrita-padi-naivedya), to the holy Virupakshadeva (the village of) Singinayakanahalli, caused to be built in front of the shrine a large assembly-hall (ra·πÖga-ma·πá·π≠apa) and a gopura before it, caused to be repaired the great gopura in front of that, and gave to the holy Virupakshadeva a golder lotus, set with the nine (kinds of) gems, and a snake ornament (n√°g√°bhara·πáa). For eating1772 the

oblations (naivedya), he gave to the god-1 goldeh vessel, 2 drums (to be used) duringthe ceremony of waving lamps, (and) 24 silver lamps.701773 Those who injure this meritorious gift (dharma), shall incur the sin (of those) who have committed the slaughter of a cow, the murder of a Br√¢hma·πáa, and the other great crimes:

XLIII. ‚Äî NEW JAINA INSCRIPTIONS FROM MATHURA.

BY G. B√úHLER, PH.D., LL.D., C.I.E.

The first eighteen among the following inscriptions formth part of the most valuable discoveries,’1774made by Dr. A. F√ºhrer in the Kank√¢li Tila at Mathur√¢ during the working season of 1890, and I edit them according to the excellent impressions1775 which he has kindly forwarded to me. I add also the five cognate inscriptions found by Dr. Burgess and originally published in the Wiener Zeitschrift f√ºr die Kunde des Morgenlandes, vol. II, pp. 141ff., and vol. III, pp. 233ff., and five small unpublished fragments, found by Dr. F√ºhrer in 1889. All of them, whether bearing kings’ names and dates or not, clearly belong to the Indo-Skythic period, or-if the era of Kanishka and his successors is identified with the Saka era-to the first and second centuries A.D. This is evident from the type of their characters and of their language, which closely agrees with that of the documents found near the same place by Sir A. Cunningham, Mr. Growse, and Dr. Burgess. The general characteristics of the alphabet, its rather clumsy look, which is owing to its squat and square letters and to the thickness of the single strokes, and itsotherwise strong resemblance to the writing in the inscriptions of the Sunga and Andhra periods, strike the most superficial observer. But it possesses another peculiarity, which consists in the occurrence of a number of cursive and modern-looking forms side by side with archaic ones, which, I think, deserves special mention, since it possesses considerable interest for Indian pal√¶ography. This peculiarity is particularly noticeable in the following ten signs. Among the vowels, the initial a looks mostly like that of the Andhra inscriptions; but sometimes it shows cursive forms. Thus in aryya (No. VIIc,1. 1) and in ‘asya (Sir A. Ounningham’s No. 8, 1. 5)¬≥1776 the left limb is represented by a wavy line, drawn by a single stroke, which is not even attached to the vertical on the right; again in Aya-Balatratasya (No. VB, 1. 1), it consists of a curved stroke on the left which is connected with the right hand vertical by a short horizontal line: this form is very common in the K√°ls√≠ version of A≈õoka’s edicts, especially in the thirteenth and fourteenth. Further, the medial √° is expressed sometimes, as in A≈õoka’s edicts, by a short horizontal stroke, more frequently by a curve or by a straight line, rising up wards towards the right, and sometimes by an almost vertical downward stroke, resembling the form found in the inscriptions of the seventh and later centuries. All these

varieties occasionally occur in one and the same document; compare, e. g., ndgendrasya (No. XVIII, 1. 2), m√°thur√°·πáam (ibid., 1. 8), √©ail√°lak√°nam (1. 4) and m√°ta (1. 8). The mediali has likewise three forms, one of which is a well-developed semicircle, while the second, a cursive one, looks very much like the medial e, and in the third the tail of the curve is drawn down at the back of the consonant just as in the Gupta i; all three forms occur in the word divase and in its abbreviation di. The initial u consists usually of an angle open to the right, as is invariably the case in the older inscriptions; but in uchchendgarasy√°¬∫ (No. XIII) it resembles a da with a well-developed nail-head at the top. The same inscription shows also in the word Kum√°ranandi a medial u, which exactly agrees with the modern Devanagar√Æ form. Less perfect examples in the same syllable occur in other inscriptions, while usually, except in tu177741777and gu, where an upward curve on the right side of the consonant is used, the vowel is expressed simply by a straight stroke. The medial ri has again three forms, being expressed (1) by the curved line, turning to the left, which usually denotes the subscript ra,177851778e.g., in gri for gr√≠shma (No. IVA, 1. 1) and in Srigrih√°to (No. III B, 1. 2); (2) very frequently by a straight line, slanting sharply from the lower right extremity of the consonant towards the left, e.g., in g·πõi for gr√≠shma (No. IIA, l. 1), and in Aryya-M√¢tridina·∏• (No. IIIA, 1. 3-4) ; (3) by the curve open to the right, which is constantly used in the Gupta and the later northern alphabets, e.g., in gri for gr√≠shma (No. XIII, 1. 1). Among the consonants ’the forms of ka, ksha, na, na and sa deserve particular attention. Ka is usually expressed by a cross with a serif at the top, but occasionally it has the Gupta form with a curved line instead of a straight cross-bar and with a serif or a nail-head at the top; see, e.g., Kum√°ranandi (No. XIII). The lower portion of ksha is mostly made square, but in kshune (No. XIII) and in bhikshuaya (Cunningham, No. 12) the left side is round. Na is usually formed of two small curves at the top, springing from a short vertical stroke, the lower end of which stands on the ‘middle of a curved base line or on the apex of an angle formed by two straight lines. Sometimes, however, we find archaic forms agreeing in part with the older ones of the A≈õoka edicts and of the earlier Andhra inscriptions. Thus in some cases, e.g., in ≈õrama·πáa¬∫ (No. XVII, 1. 1)1779 stands for priyasya. Instead of frigrih√°to I have given erroneously (Wiener Zeitschrift, vol. II, p. 289) ≈õriguhato.") and tora·πáa·πÅ (ibid., 1. 2), the base line is made perfectly straight, while, e.g., in v√°ra·πáato (No. XIB, l. 1), the ancient straight top line appears instead of the two curves. On the other hand, we meet also with a cursive form, a further development of the usual one, which some-what resembles our letter and evidently has been made with two strokes; see, e.g.,ga·πáato ( No. VIIA, 1. 1) and k√§hune (No. XIII). As regards the dental na it usually consists of a thick straight base line with a short vertical stroke above its centre which’ bears at the top a serif, or a nail-head. Sometimes also, as in the difficult word hanagrisya (No. IX, 1. 1), Haginamdia (ibid., 1. 2), the serif is wanting and the vertical stroke longer, so that the letter does not differ from the form used in Asoka’s edicts.The letter sa, finally, has nearly throughout the form used in the Andhra and other old inscriptions, but in No. V the left-hand limb is invariably converted into a loop, and the

letter is almost exactly like the Gupta sa. The alphabet of these Indo-Skythic inscrip-tions may therefore be called a transitional one, which was modified through the influence of the current hand, used in every-day life, the latter being almost identical with the so-called Gupta characters. I may add that cursive forms are met with even among the numeral signs. Thus, in No. VIII, the left-hand limb of the figure 4, which usually is square, has been made round, and the cross-bar consists of a curved stroke. In the same inscription the figure, probably to be read as 40, looks exactly like a Roman V, as the whole lower portion of the two strokes, which has been preserved in the crosslike forms of the same sign on Sir A. Cunningham’s Nos. 11, 12 and 13,1780 4, not 40 (+)4. The inscription belongs to the reign of Vasudeva, whose other dates range from Samvat 80 (see No. XXIV) to 98, while Huvishka certainly ruled from Samvat 39 to 48. The oldest known form of the figure 70 consists of a vertical line, to which two short horizontal strokes are attached, one on the right and one on the left side. Made ourelessly, this would readily become a cross, somewhat resembling the Roman I.")71780 4, not 40 (+)4. The inscription belongs to the reign of Vasudeva, whose other dates range from Samvat 80 (see No. XXIV) to 98, while Huvishka certainly ruled from Samvat 39 to 48. The oldest known form of the figure 70 consists of a vertical line, to which two short horizontal strokes are attached, one on the right and one on the left side. Made ourelessly, this would readily become a cross, somewhat resembling the Roman I.")[]1780 4, not 40 (+)4. The inscription belongs to the reign of Vasudeva, whose other dates range from Samvat 80 (see No. XXIV) to 98, while Huvishka certainly ruled from Samvat 39 to 48. The oldest known form of the figure 70 consists of a vertical line, to which two short horizontal strokes are attached, one on the right and one on the left side. Made ourelessly, this would readily become a cross, somewhat resembling the Roman I.")has been omitted.

Some peculiarities in the spelling, the frequent use of single consonants for double ones, the use of short i and u for long i and , and the occasional omission of the long √¢( see, e.g., hema·πÅtamase (No. V), maharajasya a≈Ñd masa (No. IX4), agree with the usage prevailing partly in all, partly in some, yersions of Asoka’s edicts and of other ancient inscriptions. They make it difficult to decide, whether some of the curious forms, to be discussed below, are due to negligence in spelling or to grammatical irregularities.

The language of these inscriptions shows the mixed dialect, consisting partly of Prakrit and partly of Sanskrit words and forms, as clearly as the formerly discovered documents. A fixed principle, according to which the mixture has been made, so far asI can see, is not discoverable. All one can say in this respect is that, in certain in. flexions and words, the Sanskrit forms are more common than in others, and that in others the Prakrit or hybrid forms prevail. Thus the genitive termination aya is much more frequently found after a and i stems than the Prakrit sa which stands for ssa. Neverthe- less the latter is not entirely wanting. It occurs four times in No. VI A, B, No.-VII B,1. 2, and perhaps once in No. XIV B, 1. 2. Pure Sanskrit are also the only two verbal forms which occur,-the imperatives bhavatu (No. XVIII, Il. 7, 8) and priyat√°m ( No. VIII, 1. 2). The latter is so much the more remarkable, as in nearly all other casesthe terminations in √°m are either changed to am or are otherwise mutilated. Thus we have in the genitive plural, with one exception-sarvvasatv√°n√°·πÅ (No. XXI, 1, 6), in- variably nam, e.g., ≈õi≈õ√Ænina·πÅ (No. IIC, 1. 1), araha·πÅt√¢nam (No. XVI, 1. 1), m√¢thur√¢·πáa·πÅ, etc. (No. XVIII, 1.3 ff.). Similarly the Sanskrit locatives asy√°m, etasy √°m and p√∫rov√°y√°m remain each once or twice (No. III4, 1. 1, No. VIIA, 1. 1. No. VIII, 1. 1) unchanged; in all other cases the hybrid or mutilated forms asyam, asy√° or asya and etasya·πÅ, etasy√°, etasya or etasa are used. In the nominative cases the Prakrit forms prevail. The nomi-native singular of the a-stems ends always in o, except in the one word M√°tridina·∏• (No. III4, 1. 4), which is a very curious hybrid form, the first part m√°tri being Sanskrit and the second Prakrit. The singular nominative of i-stems mostly loses the Visarga, e. g., in Kum√¢rabha»õi81781 (No. VIIB, 1. 2), but it is preserved in Rishabƒßa≈õr√≠·∏•(No. VIII, 1. 2). The same inscription furnishes also a solitary example of a Sanskrit

nominative formed from a consonantal stem, bhagav√°n, while its genitive bhagavato (No. IIC, 1. 2) and arahamta, the only other originally consonantal stem which occurs,show Prakrit forms. The nominative plural drops its Visarga as in Prakrit, as in Sthd (No. IVA, 1. 2). The other cases show either Prakrit or hybrid terminations. In the singular instrumental of the feminines in f¬∫ and √° the termination is yet e.g., in sukhit√¢ye, ku»õumbiniye (No. VI), and there is in the same inscription one Pali form,dhitura (i. e., dh√≠tar√°) for duhitr√° (No. VIA).

The masculine a-stems added e·πáa, as in No. XVII, 1.4, we have ≈õa≈õure≈Üa. The dative of the √¢-stems takes ye in arahamtap√∫j√°ye, and ya (as in Pali) in mah√¢bhogat√°ya (No. VIII, 1. 2). The difference is probably merely graphic, because ya is invariably pronounced ye, and the stress, which lies on the preceding t√°, makes the quantity of the following syllable indistinct. In hit√°sukh√° (No. XXI, 1. 6) we have possibly a contracted form for hitasukh√°a. The ablative of the masculine and neuter a-stems ends sometimes in √°, e.g., always in the word nirvvarttan√° (No. IIIA, 1. 4), but more,usually in √°to, e.g., in gandto (No. IA, 1. 1) and kul√°to (ibid.), which termination is a precursor of the Jaina Prakrit and Maharashtri do and of the Sauraseni ado or √°du. With respect to the variants ganato (No. VB, 1. 1) and kulato (ibid.) it is difficult to be positive. They may stand for Sanskrit ganata·∏•, kulata·∏• or, as the long √° is sometimes omitted, for kul√°to. The feminine √° and i-stems take to and the latter invariably shorten their vowel, as in Uchenagarito101782 ≈õ√°kh√°to (No. 14, 1. 2), and thus agree with those of the Jaina. Prakrit,where we find kann√°to and devito. As regards the genitives not yet noticed, the femi-nines in √¢, √≠ and √∫ form dye or aye, iye or iye and √ªye or uye; compare, e. g., Khu·∏ç√¢ye (No. IA, 1. 2), Sangamikaye (No. IIO, 1. 1), Vasulaye (No. IID, l. 1), dharmapatniye (No. IIIO, 1. 1), ku»õumbiniye (No. VIII, 1. 2), vadh√∫ye (No. XIA, 1. 3) and vadhuye (No. X): Three times, in ku·πÅ»õ√∫bin√Æya (No. VB, 1. 2), Sangamikaya and ≈õi≈õiniya (No. XII) we have the termination ya, which in my opinion was likewise pronounced ye or ye. The genitive of the representatives of Sanskrit duhitri, dh√≠tu or dhitu, agrees with the Pali form, and so does m√°tu (No. IIC, 1. 2). A remarkable mutilated Sanskrit form is r√°j√±a (Cunningham, No. 20, 1. 2), and very peculiar is the genitive of the male name Haginandia (No. IXB). The last sign is very distinct; else one would be tempted to conjecture Haginamdisya. Tasya (No. VIIB, 1. 2) must stand for tasyah, as it refers to the feminine Kumarami[tr√°], compare etasya for etasyam. The locative of the masculines and neuters in a shows e as in Sanskrit and in most Prakrits; that of the feminine ends in y√°m, yam, y·∫©‚Äùor ya, e.g., p√∫rvv√°y√°m (No. IA, 1. 1), p√∫rvv√¢y√° (No. IV A,1. 1), ≈õ√°kh√°y√° (No. VIII, 1. 1), Haritam√°laka·∏çhiya (No. IXB). Sir A. Cuninngham’ Nos. 2, 3, 7, 11 show the Jaina Prakrit and Mah√¢r√¢shtri forms p√∫rvv√°ye or p√∫rvvaye.The two locatives of the pronoun idam, asmi and asma (No. VA, 1. 1, No. VI, No. XIII,and No. XXV), are corruptions of Sanskrit asmin. The few pure Sanskrit forms have been noted above. In the plural, which also does duty for the dual, none but Pali, Jaina Prakrit or hybrid forms occur. The nominatives have already been mentioned.Instances of the instrumental are m√°t√°pitihi (No. XVII, l. 3) and putrehi Nandibala-pramukhehi d√°rakehi (No. XVIII, H. 5-6). Among the genitives, the Jaina Prakrit form Aryya-Veriy√°na (No. VIII, 1, 1), among the hybrid forms tesham (No. XVIII, 1. 5) and m√°t√°pitrinam (ibid. 1. 6) deserve to be mentioned in addition to the Pali formsMostly spelt i.

enumerated above. With respect to the use of the cases it must be noted that the nominative not rarely takes the place of the crude form, and that the crude form occasionally takes the place of an inflected form.. Instances of the former kind are found in [gr√°]miko Jayandgasya (No. XIB, 1. 3), sisho Sadhisya (No. VB, 1. 1), sraddhacharo v√°chakasya Aryyadatasya (No. IVA, 1. 2); further in ganisya Aryya-Buddhisirisya sisho v√°chako Aryya-Sandhikasya (No. XIX, 1. 2)1783,Hastahastisya sishyo ganisya Aryya-M√°ghahastisya fraddhacharo v√°chakasya Aryya-Devasya (No, XXI, 11. 4-6). Two perfectly certain instances of the second irregularity occur in brihamta (?) v√°chaka cha ganina cha Ja..mitrasya (No. IVA, 1. 1) and v√°dhara…..vadh√∫ Haggudevasya dharmmapatniye Mittraye (IVB, l. 1). The omission of the case terminations in words which qualify others standing in the same case is common, as Professor von Roth has shown1784,‚Äùin the Rigveda." It occurs also not rarely in P√¢≈Üini’s S√∫tras, is very frequent in the Northern Buddhist works, and is a fixed principle in the modern Indian vernaculars as well in other languages. The use of the nominative instead of the crude form is not known to me from other Indian dialects than that of the Northern Buddhists; but in Zend it is not-uncommon. A third syntactical anomaly in our inscriptions is the violation of the rules of concord, in phrases like v√°chako Aryya-Sih√° (No. IVA,1. 2), ga·πáina cha Ja..mitrasya (ibid., 1. 1), √©i√©√≠ninam Aryya-Sangamikaye (No. IIC, 1. 1), araha·πÅmt√°na·πÅ Vadham√¢nasya (No. XVI, 1. 1), where a noun in the plural has to be construed with another in the singular. The explanation is, of course, that the plural is a pluralis majestatis, and that the terms quoted must be taken in the sense of the ‚Äúgreat‚Äùor ‚Äúvenerable‚Äù ganin, ‚Äúthe great or venerable female pupil‚Äùand ‚Äúthe venerable arhat‚Äù.

With respect to the words, especially the nominal bases, it must be admitted that the pure Sanskrit forms are mostly as numerous as, and in some documents much more numerous than, the Prakrit and hybrid formations. Thus in No. XVIII, there are only three words, st√°na for sth√°na, pratish·π≠√°pita for pratish·π≠h√°pita, and perhaps ch√¢ndak√∫ for ch√°ndrak√° showing the influence of the Prakrit, though the great majority of the terminations are Prakritic. Again, in No. I, we find among fifteen completely readable words nine pure Sanskrit bases, three Prakrit formations, sethi for fresh»õhi, dhitu for duhitu·∏•, and Ko·π≠·π≠iya, and three hybrids, Bahmad√°sika for Brahmad√°sika, Uchen√•gar√≠ for Uchchairn√°gar√≠ and sahachari-Khu·∏ç√° for sahachari-Kshu-dr√°. It is only in a few documents like Nos. XII, XIV, and XVI that Prakrit and hybrid form prevail. Irrespective of the numerical question, it is worthy of note that certain words are alwa-ys given in their Sanskrit form and some invariably in Prakrit. To the former class belong mah√°-r√°ja, deva, putra, ≈õ√°kh√°, dharmapatn√≠, sahachur√≠, pratim√°; to the latter araha·πÅta for arhat, the representatives of duhitu·∏•, dhitu and dhitu, and those of the name Vajr√≠ or Vajr√•, Veri (No. IIIB, 1. 3), Vair√° (No. VIIB, 1. 1), Veriya (No. VIII, 1. 1), Vair√° (No. XXI, 1. 3). In all the other words, which occur more frequently, there are vacillations, sometimes in one and the same document.

The great interest, which the development of the Prakrits possesses for the history of Indian literature, would make it desirable to determine exactly the character of the vernacular of Cen-tral India used in the first and second centuries A.D., which influenced

the language of these documents. Unfortunately the number of the inscriptions is still so small that it is impossible to obtain in this respect perfectly certain results. Never theless I will state that from the materials accessible to me, I consider it to have been in some points more similar to the Jaina Prakrit and the Maharashtri than to the Pali and to the language of Asoka’s edicts and of the older Andhra inscriptions. Words like the representatives just enumerated of Fajri and Vajrd, like Kottiya for Kottika, Brahmad√°siya for Brahmad√°sika, Siriya for Sirika, lohav√°n-iya for lohav√°nija, and Haganamdi for Bhaganandi, seem to indicate that the destruction of the medial and initial consonants had begun, and it is quite possible that among the numerous counter-instances some, at least, may be due to the desire of the authors to make their langu-age sound like Sanskrit, i.e., that they may be attempts at a retranslation of more advanced Prakrit forms into Sanskrit. Thus the two forms Bahmad√°sika and Brahmad√°siya lead me to suspect that the real popular form was Bamhaddsiya orev√©n Bambhad√°siya, which was retran-sliterated into Sanskrit in two different ways, both times with indifferent success. In two points this Prakrit probably differed from nearly all the literary Prakrits, agreeing at the same time with the modern vernaculars. First, it probably possessed, like the latter, only two sibilants, sa and √©a, which were, as is done in the present day, frequently interchanged. The inscriptions have, it is true, the three signs used in Sanskrit, and their use remains unchanged in pure Sanskrit words. Even the lingual sha keeps its place in such words and in the hybrid forms with shka and sh»õa, e.g., in Kanishka, Huvishka, pratish»õ√°pita, Goshtha…, Jesh·π≠ahastin, vish·π≠√∫yam√¢na, sishya. But, when regular Prakrit forms are substituted for, or derived from, the Sanskrit words, the lingual sha almost disappears. The palatal sa, on the contrary, mostly remains and even cxtends its sphere; here and there sa appears in its stead. Thus we find in the Prakrit equivalent for sishya, once sisha (No. VB, 1. 1), once ≈õi≈õa (No. XIVB, 1. 1), and twice ≈õisa (No. IX, 1. 2, and Cunningham‚Äôs No. 10, 1. 1, sasasya, according to the facsimile). The Prakrit feminine of sishya is spelt once sishini (No. VIB, 1. 2) and six times ≈õi≈õ√Æni or ≈õi≈õini (No. IIC, 1. 1 ; No. VII B, 1. 1; No. XIA, 1. 2; No. XII, 1. 2; No. XIV B, 1.1). Further, √©vasura becomes sasura (No. XVII, 1. 4); sr√≠ is invariably siri in the names Sirika or Siriya and Buddha≈õiri (No. XIX, 1. 2); Pushyamitr√≠ya is changed to Pu≈õyamitr√≠ya (No. VI, 1. 2). The dental sa is put instead of ≈õa in sethi (No. IA, 1. 2), suchila (No. III.B, l. 3), and in sakr√∫ for ……. (No. XVII, 1. 4). Hence I regard the occurrence of sha in Prakrit words as merely graphic, and assume that sa and sa were the only two sibilants of the Prakrit vernacular, but were occasionally used the one for the other. That is just what is done in all the vernaculars of Northern, Western, and Central Indin, which from Kasmir down to the Marath√¢ country possess only the dental and the palatal sibilants and exchangethem very frequently, especially in their true popular varieties. The second point, in which the Prakrit of our inscriptions agreed with the modern vernaculars, not with the literary Prakrits, is the neglect of the aspiration of conjunct hard aspirates. We have st√°ne for sth√°ne (No. XVIII, 1. 2), pratisht√≥pito for pratishth√°pito (No. XVIII, 1. 4), Jeshtahastisya (No. XIVB, 1. 1, twice) for Jyesh·π≠hahastisya, sarttav√°hiniye (Cunningham, No. 7, 1. 2) for s√°rtthav√°hiny√°h, Sreshtaputrena and freshtin√° (Cunningham, No. 9, 1. 3) for ≈õreshthiputrena and sreshthind. It is just in these very groups that, according to the popular pronunciation of the vernaculars of Northern, Western, and Central India (with the exception of the Marathi ), the aspiration is om-itted, though in writing it is frequently expressed. The numerous Sanskrit words, like kanish·π≠ha, pra-

tish·π≠h√°, pratish·π≠hita, used in all the vernaculars, are in Ka≈õmir, the Panjab, R√¢jputana, Gujar√¢t, M√¢lv√¢ and the portions of the North-Western Provinces known to me, √Ænvariably pronounced kanis√©·π≠, prati≈õ·π≠d and prati≈õ»õit, and one hears st√°na quite as often as sth√°na. It is only the learned Pandit who will at least try to sound the tha or tha. Hundreds, nay thousands, of mistakes in Sanskrit inscriptions and manuscripts show that this neglect of the aspiration, especially in the group sh·π≠ha, is not of recent date. The examples in our inscriptions are sufficiently numerous to warrant at least the inference that in the first and, second centuries of our era the omission of the aspiration did occur, and perhaps was optional.

As regards the origin of this mixed dialect, as well as of all other mixed dialects, I agree with Professor Kern, Jaartelling, p. 108 ff., and Dr. R. G. Bh√¢·πá·∏çarkar, Indian Antiquary, vol. XII, p. 146, that it is the result of the efforts of half-educated people to express themselves in Sans-krit, of which they possessed an insufficient knowledge and which they were not in the habit of using largely. All the Jaina inscriptions from Mathur√¢ were no doubt composed by the monks who acted as the spiritual directors of the laymen, or by their pupils. Though no inscription has been found in which the author is named, the above inference is warranted by the fact that numerous later documents of the same character contain the names of Yatis who are said to have composed them or to have written them. The Yatis in the first and second centuries, no doubt, just as now, for their sermons and the exposition of their scriptures, used the vernacular of the day, and their scriptures were certainly written in Prakrit. It was a matter of course that their attempts to write in Sanskrit were not very successful. This theory receives the strongest support from the fact that the character and the number of the corruptions varies almost in every document, and from various single sentences, such as v√°chakasya aryya-Baladinasya ≈õishyo aryya-M√°tridina·∏• tasya nirvvarttand, which latter reads exactly like a piece from a stupid schoolboy’s exercise. It is also confirmed by numerous analogies, such as the language of the janmapattras of the badly educated. Joshis mentioned by Dr. Bh√¢nd√¢rkar, the books of mason-s and carpenters, which give the rules for building houses in most barbarous Sanskrit, and ma-ny modern inscriptions, composed by clerks or Yatis. A large number of specimens of the latter kind are contained in the collection of votive inscriptions from P√¢lit√¢n√¢ lately copied by Mr. H. Cousens. I give a short one, which shows a mixture of Sanskrit, Gujarati and M√¢rv√¢·∏ç√Æ :‚Äî

‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡•ß‡•Æ‡•¨‡•¶ ‡§®‡§æ1785‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§¶‡§ø ‡•´ ‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•á1786‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§Ø ‡§Ü‡§£‡§Ç‡§¶‡§∏‡§∞‡§ø‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•à1787‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§Ø‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§¨‡§ø‡§Ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∞‡•á1788‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§-‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§â‡§∏‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§ù‡§µ‡•á‡§∞‡•Ä1789‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Æ‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶ ‡§ù‡§µ‡•á‡§∞‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶1790‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•Ä1791‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§á‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§® ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§π‡§∞‡§æ ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡§æ‡§• ‡§®‡§µ‡§ø‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§æ‡§¶1792‡§®‡§µ‡•Ä‡§® ‡§¨‡§ø‡§Ç‡§¨ ‡§≠‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç1793‡•§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§ù‡§ï‡•Å‡§≠‡§æ‡§à ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶ ‡§≠‡§æ1794‡§Æ‡§≤‡•Å‡§ï‡§ö‡§¶ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§Ö‡§≠‡•á‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Æ‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§® ‡§¨‡§ø‡§Ç‡§¨ ‡§≠‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç‡•§ ‡§§‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•à‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§Ø‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡•á‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§§1795………1796

TRANSLATION.

‚ÄúOn the fifth lunar day (of) the bright half (of) Vai≈õ√¢kha of the year 1860, on a Monday, during the reign of glorious and victorious Devachandra S√ªri, in the gachchha of glorious and victor-ious Ananda S√ªri, dwelling in the famous harbour of Surat, (was) the jeweller Premchand Jha-verchand, (his) wife (was) Joyat√Æ; (by) his son Vaichanda was erected a new image (in the) new temple (of) Vijjahar√¢ (Vidy√¢dhara?) P√¢r√©vanath1797 a new image.‚Äù").‚ÄùThe image was erected in the name of Promchand, brother of Ratnachand (and) Malukchand, son of M√¢t√¢j√Æ (?) Jhakubh√¢; consecra-ted by Vijaya Jinendras√ªri in the Tap√¢gachcha.‚Äù

The contents of the older inscriptions Nos. XIX-XXIII have been discussed in the Wiener Zeitschrift f√ºr die Kunde des Morgenlandes, vol. II, pp. 141ff., and vol.III, pp. 233 ff.
