  552. “The first three relative sentences in the first and second P√•das of verse 3 have each a double sense, and they refer to-I. fire, sun and poon; II water and the sacrifice, III, the earth and air or akdsa, while the wind is described in the fourth relative sentence. The use of the word paksha in the sense of fin’ is easily explained by its meaning side’ and ’ wing.’ Mr. √Çpte’s English-Sanskrit Dictionary is the only lexicographical work which mentions this rare meaning of paksha.” ↩︎

  553. “The wording is rather obscure. By ’this’ seems to be meant the third eye of Siva, the fire of which, the so called Sar√¢gni or arrow-fire (see Sr√Ækanthacharita, I, 16; V, 18; XXIV, 7ff ↩︎

  554. “The text has a pun on tasa’ milk and sentiment’ which has not been rendered in the translation.” ↩︎

  555. “From him’ refers, I believe, to Buddha. If it referred to tanayam, it would be necessary to assume that an unnamed son, who perhaps died in his father’s lifetime, intervened between Buddha and Vigraha. The latter explanation is, of course, by no means impossible,” ↩︎

  556. " Rohana is really the name of the mountain in Ceylon, called Adam’s Peak. The poet seems to have chosen it as the instance of a big mountain, most suitable for his purposes:” ↩︎

  557. " These two verses, as also the next two, forin a Yugma or Fugaluka. The epithet sadhu, ‘holy’ which Lakshma·πáa receives, ja explained by verses 21-26 of No. I.” ↩︎

  558. “Lingas, standing in the open, are frequently found in the north of India. Thus I remember having seen three very large ones not far from Ushkar in Ka≈°mir, which stand in the middle of the forest. If pur√Æ means here a temple, that is easily explained by the tower-like shape of the adytum of the Indian temples.” ↩︎

  559. “The verse refers to the belief that a particularly pious deed ensures the joy of heaven to the performer as well as to ten ancestors and ten descendants. All the latter may reach this goal, but the donors themselves desire moksha.” ↩︎

  560. “The European dictionaries do not give for mandapikd the meaning a custom-house.’ But its existence is proved by various passages in the inscriptions, compare, e. g., the term ma·πÅ·∏çarika ante p. 7 and by the analogy of its modern represent. ative mandavi which is a common term for custom-house’ in Marathi, Gujarati and other vernaculars.” ↩︎

  561. “The meaning is that the Telis who worked the oilmill had either in lieu of rent to furnish gratis the oil for the lamps of the temple or that the whole net income of the oilmill was to go to the temple for the purpose stated.” ↩︎

  562. “I am unable to find the word in the dictionaries and to say what the office was. According to its etymological import it ought to denote some kind of spiritual councillor. See ante, p. 97. The present edition of the inscription has been prepared according to a very good paper impression, furnished by the Panjab Archaeological Survey through the Editor.” ↩︎

  563. “See Klatt, Indian Antiquary, vol. XI, pp. 248 and 254.” ↩︎

  564. “General Cunningham recognised that it could have no connexion with the history of the temple of Siva-Vaidyanatha.” ↩︎

  565. “‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ì‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ö‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç the and ‡§Ø of ‡§ï‡•ã‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø cur are connected and form a misshaped group; read ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ above ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ a m√¢tra out by mistake, has been obliterated; possibly the correct reading is ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•É‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç waarat, & and being absolutely undistinguish-able in the alphabet of the inscription.” ↩︎

  566. “L. 2.-The ‚ñ° of it has been destroyed; the ar of war≈ø has been damaged.” ↩︎

  567. “I translate ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•á by ‘in the (civil ↩︎

  568. “The form of the text w is half Prakrit and half Sanskrit.” ↩︎

  569. “I leave the expression ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§Ç af literally ‘root-image’ untranslated, because I am not certain about its technical meaning. I suspect that it means ‘chief image’ and is intended to distinguish this statue, which stood in the adytum, from the numerous smaller ones in the bhamti or the cloisters,” ↩︎

  570. “‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§öis bad Sanskrit, but common in Jaina books. The correct expression would be ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ ‡§ö or ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ö” ↩︎

  909. “L. 5. The ‡§§ of ‡§Æ‡•É‡§ó‡§æ‡§π‡§∏‡•Å‡§§ is a correction and standsbelow the line, its place being indicated by the sign +. The first letter of ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï is nearly destroyed. Possibly ‡§≤‡§æ‡§π‡§üto be read.” ↩︎

  910. “L. 6. Possibly ‡§∏‡•å‡§π‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø to be road. The last two syllables of ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•Å‡§§ arenearly effaced; the last seems to have been added above the line.” ↩︎

  911. “L. 7. The consonant of the second syllable of ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ß‡•Å‡§ïis blurred and not quite certain. Restore ‡§∏‡•å‡§π. Three or four letters have been lost before ‡§ï‡§∂‡§ø‡§≤‡§ø.” ↩︎

  912. “L. 8. The first letter is not certain. Possibly ‡§≠‡•á‡§ü‡§æ or ‡§π‡§Øto be read; the following letter is haf preserved and seems to have been a compound one, consisting of a ‡§§ or‡§®and somothing else, possibly a ‡§ü.Read ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï.The sign rendered ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å is damaged and abnormal. The first consonant of ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§∂‡•åis uncertain; the word may have been ‡§µ‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡•Ä. Of ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Øonly the initial ‡§∏ and the top ends of ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø are visible.” ↩︎

  913. “L. 9. The first letter is nearly effaced, only the ‡•ãis recognisable Only thesecond ‡§® ofthe two bracketed signs in ‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ[‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§®] is distinct. The reading may have been ‡•¶‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•á.” ↩︎ ↩︎

  914. “L. 11. The bracketed letters in the beginning of the line are blurred, but recognisable. The quantity of the first vowel of ‡•¶‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡•¶and ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Ç is doubtful. The last vowel of ‡•¶‡§ú‡§®‡§™‡§¶‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡•¶is doubtful.” ↩︎

  915. “L. 12. The letters bracketed are blurred, but recognisable. Read ‡•¶‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡§§‡§ø‡•¶.” ↩︎

  916. “L. 13. The bracketed letters areblurred, but recognisable with the exception of the syllable ‡§ï. which is entirelygone” ↩︎

  917. “L. 14. The bracketed letters are all blurred, but recognisable.” ↩︎

  918. “L. 15. The bracketed letters are blurred, but recognisable with the exception of ‡§∑‡§ü‡•ç ‡§§‡•¶ do, which are gone, The restoration is made certain by the calculation, 12-4-2 = 6.Read ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§Ø.” ↩︎

  919. “L. 16. The following among the bracketed letters are not recognisable, but conjectural:-‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç ‡•§ ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§§‡•ç,likewise the bracketed Visarga. The word ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç is superfluous.” ↩︎

  920. “L. 17. The bracketed letters are nearly all unrecognisable. But the restoration is nevertheless certain.” ↩︎

  921. “Instead of " ↩︎

  922. “I translate the crude form of the participle sam√¢y√¢ta by the preterite, " ↩︎

  923. “Adhishth√¢na, ’town,’ may also mean capital. But there is no evidence to show that king Bhoja resided in Prithudaka.” ↩︎

  924. “Though y√¢tr√¢ usually means ‘pilgrimage’ or ‘religious festival,’ the statements in the sequel show that it here means fair. The fair may have been connected with a religious festival.” ↩︎

  925. “Pisachichaturdasi, literally the fourteenth (lunar day ↩︎ ↩︎

  926. “In ch√∫»õav√¢rshiketya, and further on in utpaliketya and so forth the affix tya, which denotes the inhabitant of’ or means ‘found in,’ has been erroneously added to the locative instead of to the crude form of the names. The same anomaly occurs in the Chaulukya Inscriptions, Indian Antiquary, vol. VI, p. 204, No. 7, plate ii, I. 2, etc.” ↩︎

  927. “Rajyavala is perhaps the modern name R√•jbal which occurs in Kasm√Ær.” ↩︎

  928. “With Chonaraka compare the modern name Chonda, Indian Antiquary, vol. VII, p. 165.” ↩︎

  929. “Kalluka is the modern name Kalu, Indian Antiquary, loc. cit., p. 166. Dada is perhaps a variant for Dadda, the modern D√¢da.” ↩︎

  930. “Jayaraka may stand for Jayar√¢√ªka and be equivalent to the very common name Jeraj, Indian Antiquary, loc. cit.,p. 166.” ↩︎

  931. “√Çdityar√¢ka probably stands for √Çdityar√¢√ªka and corresponds to the modern √Çdit or √Çditraj.” ↩︎

  932. “V√¢muka is known as a Br√¢hma≈Üical name; Jour. Bo. Br. R. A. Soc., vol. XII, extra number, p. 67.” ↩︎

  933. “Compare the modern name Dhana, Ind. Ant., loc. cit.,p.165.” ↩︎

  934. “Manikka is the very common modern name M√¢nek from m√¢≈Üikya, ‘a ruby.’ Uehari is a very peculiar compound,but perfectly distinct on the impression.” ↩︎

  935. “≈ö√¢rankadika may possibly be the modern Sh√¢rakpur in the Pa√±j√¢b; see Imperial Gazetteer,sub voce.” ↩︎

  936. “N√¢ra is probably, like the modern name Naru which is frequently used in Gujar√¢t, an abbreviation of N√¢r√¢ya·πáa. If L√¢hata is the correct reading, its first part may be connected with the modern name L√•dh√¢, Indian Antiquary, loc. cit., p. 166.” ↩︎

  937. “Compare the modern name Poml√¢, Indian Antiquary, loc. cit., p. 167.” ↩︎

  938. “As the preceding word is mutilated, it is not rertain if I have divided the syllables correctly. But Mana seems to be the equivalent of the modern name M√¢n√†, Indian Antiquary, loc. cit., p. 166.” ↩︎

  939. " I do not dare to propose any correction for the mutilated word bha·π≠a- or haya- which I do not understand and hence leave it untranslated. As vyuvaharaka no doubt stands for vyavaharaka, trader, dealer,’ it is, however, not improbable that the immediately preceding word referred to that in which the traders dealt, and that some word meaning horses’ or ‘animals’is hidden under the meaningless syllables. The word desi, which I have translated by foreman,’ means literally, ‘guide, instructor.’ It would seem that the dealers had appointed a manager, who acted in their name. Though this is possible, I should have expected at the end of the compound Srent or some equivalent term.” ↩︎

  940. “Sthana, literally ‘a place,’ is frequently used in the sense of a place sacred to a particular deity,’ see, e.g., the inscription from the temple of Bhadra K√•lf in Somnath Pattan, Vienna Oriental Journal, vol. III, p. 7, verse4, 6, p. 8, verse 9, etc. Here the sanctuary of the chief deity in Prith≈Ødaka is probably intended.” ↩︎

  941. “Though the god is not named to whom this and the next mentioned temples were dedicated, it may be conjectured that Vishnu is meant, because the other two temples are Vaishnava buildings.” ↩︎

  942. “Nagara is either the name of the subdivision of the Brahmans to which Prabhakara belonged, or an honorific title indicating that he was the Chief Bhatta of the town of Kanauj.” ↩︎

  943. “The sacrificial boar’ is Vishnu in the boar-incarnation.” ↩︎

  944. “R√ªpa has the meaning ‘an animal’ according to the Koshas, and is used in that sense by B√¢≈Üa.” ↩︎

  945. “The Thakkuras are the Th√¢kurs or Rajput landholders; by janapada,’ the provincials,’ the common people must be understood.” ↩︎

  946. “Dharma denotes here and further on, where one dharma is mentioned, a kind of tithe set apart for religiouspurposes. The exact amount cannot be ascertained. It no doubt was regulated by custom, and so well known that its specification seemed unnecessary. In the translation the relative pronoun yad which precodes dharmmadvayam has been left out intentionally, and the word and has been inserted in its stead, in order to make the sentence more intelligible.” ↩︎

  947. “When it is stated that the two dharmas are given as a perpetual endowment, the meaning probably is that the sum was to be paid at each of the annual horse-fairs in Prith√ªdaka, Traigh√¢»õaka and other places where the traders dealt. This follows from the further exhortations addressed to the sellers and buyers as well as to the Goshthikas.” ↩︎

  948. “Bh√¢gaika·∏•, ‚Äò one share,’ which occurs here and further on, as well as dharmaika·∏•, ‚Äòone dharma,’ is bad Sanskrit caused by the vernacular expression bhag ek.” ↩︎

  949. “The ablative prith√∫dakasth√¢n√°t is altogether wrong; it ought to be the dative or the genitive, as further on.” ↩︎

  950. “The Goshthikas are the members of the Panch or committee entrusted with the management of the religious endowments; seealso Indian Antiquary, vol. IX, p. 171, note 26, where the modern Nepalese name of such a committee, gu·π≠·π≠hi, i.e., goshthi, is given.” ↩︎

  951. “Metre of verses 1-9, Sragdhar√¢. The word ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§≠in P√¢da 3 is not certain. The consonants of the first syllable look like dhchh, an impossible combination,” ↩︎

  1161. “15 Indian Antiquary, vol. XII, page 255. The date is perfectly certain, because the week day is also given. The 22nd October of 971 A. D. corresponds according to Oppolzer, Canon der Finsternisse, p. 208, to the day 2076010 of the Julian period, and hence is a Sunday. The middle of the eclipse happened at 3 hours 45 minutes, Greenwich time, or about 9 ‚ñ≤.M., Lanka time. According to the map No. 104 in the same work, the beginning of this eclipse was visible in Central India.” ↩︎

I, page 276, the language of Dungarpur is called Bagar. This word, too, is probably derived from the old name of the country. When I wrote my German article on the Navasdhas√°nkacharita, I was not aware of the existence of this Vagada and identified the country, named by Padmagupta, with eastern Kachh, which is also called Vagad.The greater distance of the latter district from Malva makes the identification now improbable.” ↩︎

  1222. “Sesha being coiled rouud Siva’s neck, forms an alavala or basin which retains the water of Ganga when it flows from the head of the deity.   1246. “In accordance with the usage of the mixed dialect, the Anusv√¢ras of deyadharmoya and vihdrapratish·π≠h√¢pana have Leen left out. With respect to the word deyadharmoh I accept Mr. Fleet’s correction of the translation, Corpus Inscr. Ind. vol.   1302. “Sthana has both meanings.” ↩︎

  1303. “The use of a verb equivalent to abh√ªt for ‘was made’ is not uncommon in the modern Indian vernaculars, and it is not improbable that our poet has fallen into a Gujaraticism.” ↩︎

  1304. “Though I consider the identity of K√¢roha·πáa and K√¢rv√¢·πá to be certain, I do not mean to say that the two names are identical. With respect to the word k√¢rv√¢n, I adhere to the opinion, expressed in the Indian Antiquary, vol.   1305.  ↩︎

  1306. “Regarding the substitution of na for la and of la for na see Kuhn, Beitr√§ge zur Pali-Grammatik, pp. 38 and 44; Hemachandra, I, 230, 257; Beames, Comparative Grammar.¬ß248; Hoernle, Grammar of the Gandian languages, ¬ß 111. My reasons for considering Lakul√Æsa as the older form are, (1 ↩︎

  1307. "” ↩︎

  1308. “This must be the title of a high local official. For, below (verse 65 ↩︎

  1309. “Gha·π≠ik√¢laya is the modern Gujar√¢t√Æ gƒßadi√¢l, the usual term for any kind of timepiece.” ↩︎

  1310. “The text has ¬∞v√¢sam adhishthit√¢ni, literally ‚Äõstanding on the dwelling of.‚Äô This may mean either that the five temples were built on the site of an ancient decayed temple or that the site was sacred to the god mentioned. Vasa seems to correspond here to the Jaina term vasahika, the ‘precinets‚Äô of a sacred building.” ↩︎

  1311. “The word ‘statue’ does not occur in the text. But if a Hindu speaks of ‘a Sarasvati or a Ga≈Üe≈°a,’ etc., he usually means images of these deities. [Antarala is the second Mandapa of a temple, between the ardhamandupa and the shrine.‚ÄîJ. B.]” ↩︎

  1312. “Kavadi is apparently the Gujarati and Marathi k√¢rad, which means the same as the Sanskrit riradha, ‘a bamboo or pole for carrying burdens,’ in this case pitchers which are attached to the ends by ropes. Two kavadis of water are therefore two loads, equal to four pitchers of water, which quantity was required for the daily ablutions of the Lingas.” ↩︎

  1313. “Kolini I take as an equivalent of kolamayf, made of kola or branches of the Zizyphus jujuba.” ↩︎

  1314. “Jagati has here the meaning vastu, given for the word in the Vaijayanti of Yadavaprakasa. Compare also the vernacular jago, jagya, ’ place, spot,’ etc.” ↩︎

  1315. “The verb kri is used here, just as in Gujarati and other vernaculars, in a very loose manner, and must be variously rendered, as the context requires, by ‘procure,’ ‘assign,’ etc. The meaning is here that the Batuka or Chelft is not only to procure the things mentioned, butalso to use them. It will appear in the sequel that he is to do all the manual work of the worship.” ↩︎

  1316. “Naivedya food are the offerings, destined for the meals of the deities, which are invariably made over to the temple-servants. See Ind. Ant., vol. XII, pp. 317ff.” ↩︎

  1317. “Regarding the allowance for the Chel√¢, see below, verse 61.” ↩︎

  1318. “I am unable to explain this word, which looks suspicions. But the letters are perfectly distinct.” ↩︎

  1319. “Kanavira is the Pr√¢krit and vernacular form of Sanskrit karavira. The equivalent which the gardeners received for furnishing these flowers is mentioned below, vorse 65.” ↩︎

  1320. “I am unable to give a full translation of this verse, as I do not understand the words dh√¢tivdha and parikshipa·π≠·π≠a. Parikshi may be the Sanskrit for the modern P√¢rikh or P√¢rakh, a kind of money-changer.” ↩︎

  1321. “M√°naka was, according to Ber√ªn√Æ, Indica, vol. I, p. 166, in Somn√¢th, a measure equal to five mand. The word may be connected with Gujar√¢t√Æ m√¢na, ‘a large earthen jar.’” ↩︎

  1322. “Chosha·∏• is a bad spelling for Gujarati chokha, ‘husked rice.’” ↩︎

  1329. “A bijaka is the little three-cornered parcel of ground arecanut, lime, etc., which is wrapped up in a betel pepper leaf and held together by a clove stuck into the leaf, what is usually called p√¢n-sup√°r√≠.” ↩︎

  1330. “Pasup√¢la means usually ‚Äõa herdsman.’ If the word is to be taken here in that sense, it is difficult to understand how a herdsman was connected with the Saiva worship. I suspect that it is the title of Saiva priest connected with the worship of Siva, the Pasupati.” ↩︎

  1331. “If the rostoration Somanatha is correct, it shows that the store-house mentioned above in verse 53 is that of the great temple.” ↩︎

  1393. “M√¢paka means literally ‘a measurer.‚ÄôIt must have here a technical meaning.   1454. “The poet means to say that Kar·πáa made only lawful conquests (dharmya vijaya`, and by his adherence to the sacred law injured wicked Kali.” ↩︎

  1455. “The poets did not say ‚ÄòJayasimha is as brave as a lion, but the lion is as brave as Jayasimha.’ Bhakty√°krishtedy√°di may possibly also be translated ’to whom Siva, attracted by his devotion, personally appeared.’ Vv. 12 and 13 are too frag-mentary to be translated.” ↩︎

  1456. “L.e. probably Siva.” ↩︎

  1458. “The goddess Chandi always must be propitiated by blood, especially by human blood. She is said to be seated on the king’s aru, because he possesses chandapratƒÅpa, ‘fierce prowess.’” ↩︎

  1459. “The Prabandhas mention that Kumarapala used to worship Kante≈õvariand other Devis in the month of √Ç√©vina according to the custom of his family; see Ueber das Leben des Jaina M√∂nches Hemachandra, p. 45 f.” ↩︎

  1460. “Compare the expression in the land-grants, Um√¢pativaralabdhapras√¢da, which invariably stands before Kunara. p√•la’s name.” ↩︎

  1461. “Srutydfrayam, ‚Äòplaced in its ear,’ must probably also be taken with Nagara in the sense of ’ a home of the Vedas.’” ↩︎

  1462. “Dharma loses in each Yuga one foot, and one-legged in the Kali ago.” ↩︎

  1463. “I take toyanilaya·∏• as a synonym of prapa·∏•.” ↩︎

  1464. “The occan yields many ratnas, the rampart enhances the security and the prosperity of the town.” ↩︎

  1465. “The lord of the Rakshasas is, of course, R√•va≈Üa, who was conquered by R√¢mawith the help of the monkeys. The monkeys’ heads peeping over the rampart of Vaduagar are the ornamental projections in its coping, which are conventionally called kapisirsha.” ↩︎

  1466. “Sesha, too, is white.” ↩︎

  1467. “The hoods are the small domes erected at intervals over the towers of the wall.” ↩︎

  1468. “For brevity I omit the second translation of the first three padas, merely noting that‚Äîreferred to the ground outside the town‚Äîramarama·∏• has to be taken with the sense of lovely gardens,’ dvija as ‘birds,’ and sali as ‘rice.’” ↩︎

  1469. “I take this to mean that a temple of Lakshmi adjoined and partly rested on the wall. The epithets applied to the rampart fit the king likewise. But I intentionally omit the second translation.” ↩︎

  1470. “Prithu, finding the earth thickly covered with mountains, pushed then, ashnder with his bow.” ↩︎

  1471. “Compare with this Prabhavakacharitra, xxii, 206, quoted above.” ↩︎

  1472. “The inscription has been published before, with a translation which fairly gives the general sense of the original, by Mr. C. T. Metcalfe, and introductory remarks on the Sena kings of Bengal, by Dr. Rajendral√¢l Mitra, in the Journal As. Soc. Beng., vol. XXXIV, part I. pp. 128-154. I now re-edit it from an excellent impression taken by Dr. Burgess. The village of Deop√¢r√¢ is in the God√¢g√¢ri th√¢n√¢ in the west of the Rampur pargana. God√¢g√¢ri is on the Gauges, Lat. 24¬∞ 28‚Ä≤ N., Long. 88¬∞ 23’ E.; and on sheet 120 of Indian Atlas, there is a Daopoor’ north-north-east of God√¢g√¢ri, but no Deop√¢r√¢ is marked near the place; there isother ’ Deopoor,’ 12 miles east from God√•g√•ri in Lat. 24¬∞ 27’, Long. 88¬∞ 34}’ E.-J. B.J.” ↩︎

  1473. “Varendriis identified with that part of Bengal which is now called Rajshahi (or Rajasahi ↩︎

  1509. “I understand this verse to mean that the wives of the Srotriyas, suddenly become rich in pearls, emeralds, etc., of which they had no knowledge before, had to be told by the wives of the townspeople, that the things looking like cotton-seeds were pearls, etc.” ↩︎

  1510. “As she is represented to be in the Kali-age. Compars Journal Amer. Or. Soc., vol. VII, p. 26, verse 10.” ↩︎

  1512. “Viz. the compact by which the Vindhya mountain, which had prostated itself before Agastya, was to remain in that position, so long as the sage should stay in the south. See e.g. S. P. Pandit’s note on Raghuvamsa, vi, 61.” ↩︎

  1560. " I follow here the authority of the commentator of the Prabodhachandrodaya. Judging from the wording of the text, I should say that Gopala was an ally of Kirtivarman, but I am not able to identify him with any prince known to me. I may add here that all the above dates prove that the Prabodhachandrodaya was composed during the second half of the 11th century A.D., not, as stated in English and German handbooks, towards the end of the 12th century. [Compare now also Dr. Hultzsch’s account, anto, pp. 217-222, where the Mahoba inscriptin, mentioned above, has been reedited.-J.B.]” ↩︎

  1655. “The following passage, which is not Sanskrit, I do not understand.   1822. “50 Sarvatobhadrika pratima,‚Äîliterally ‘an image lovely on all sides,’ is apparently a technical termfor a ‚Äòfourfold‚Äô image, one being curved on each side of a four-faced column. Compare the use of sarvatobhadra dev√°laya, which, according to Varahamibira’s Brihat-Samh., LVI, 27, means ‚Äú a temple with four doors and many spires,’ i.e., such a one which looks equally pleasing from all sides.” ↩︎

  1823. “51 Incised on the pedestal of a four-faced image (ohaturmukha ↩︎

  1845. “73The phrase asmi or asma kshune occurs four times-here and in Nos. VI, XIII and XXV-in the place of etasyam or asya·πÅ p√ªrvdyam. It also occurs once in a second collection to be published hereafter, and twice we have the corresponding life or sta chhunami in Kharoshtri inscriptions from the Pa√±jab; see Sir A. Cunningham’s Arch. Surv. Rep., vol. V, Pl. xvi, Nos. 1 and 2, and Jour. Asiatique, 8me s√©rie, vol. XV, Pl. i, No. 3. It must, of course, have the same or a similar meaning. The first word is without doubt the equivalent of Sanskrit asmin; the second I take to represent Sanskrit kehane, though there is no other instance in which the first vowel of this word becomes w; asmin kshane might mean either” ↩︎

  1865. “93 I take sasita to stand for samsita, the past participle of si, and makhita to be a half Prakritic form for mrakshita.These two participles, which I have translated above according to their literal meaning, must no doubt be understood in a figurative sense. They probably refer to the sharpening and polishing of the understanding and of the character by study and penances.” ↩︎

  2030. “The term talavarike is derived from talavara or tal√¢ri (Tamil talaiydri

          **B‚Äî Sanskrit portion.**
     ↩︎

  2031. “The tables published by me in the Indian Antiquary. vol. XVII, pp. 147-181, are based on the S√ªrya Siddhanta as now current. They yield therefore the end of a tithi, the principal item of a Hindu date, in accordance with that Siddhanta only.” ↩︎

  2032. “My previous tables give the beginning of the solar month according to the Arya Sildhanta only; the present furnith the same also according to the other Siddhantas available to me.” ↩︎

  2033. “It should however be kept in mind that the Christian year does not quite correspond to the year of the Kaliyuga. For, roughly speaking, the three first months of the corresponding Christian year belong to the preceding year Kaliyuga; and the same mouths of the following Christian year form the end of the given year of the Kaliyuga.” ↩︎

  2034. “Compare however ¬ß 39, on the tropical Samkrantis.” ↩︎

  2035. “Though the purnim√¢nta or northern scheme is decidedly the older of the two, yet for practical reasons the lunar tables are primarily intended for the am√¢nta scheme.” ↩︎

  2036. “It is evident that generally only a part of the lunar month falls in the eponymous solar month; in the am√¢ntascheme the last part of the lunar month extends into the next solar month; in the purnim√¢nta scheme either the beginning of the lunar month falls in the preceding solar month, or the end of the lunar month in the following solar month,” ↩︎

  2037. " According to a verse quoted from Brahmagupta, a lunar month which begins and ends in the same solar month receives the name of the preceding solar month. This custom however has long since gone out of use. See Fleet’s Corp. Insor. Ind. vol. III, p. 88, note 5.” ↩︎

  2038. " According to Warren (Kalasankalita ↩︎

  2039. “For full-moon and new-moon form the end of the bright and dark fortnights respectively.” ↩︎

  2040. “The sidereal day which is shorter than the civil day by about 10 vinddis or p√•las (correctly 3 minutes 56.555 seconds ↩︎

  2041. “It may perhaps be worth while to note that in Saka 0, the mean solar year began with full-moon.” ↩︎

  2042. “We may also take the tithi which is equal to the Index or even a little larger.” ↩︎

  2043.  ↩︎

  2044. " The calculation of mean intercalations is easier by the Special Tables, as will be seen from the example in ¬ß 56. Sitzungsberichte der phil, hist. Classe der Kais. Akademie der Wissenschaften, Wien 1885.” ↩︎

  2045. The true longitude of the sun for the beginning of every day of the solar year is furnished by the column headed O’s longitude in Table VIII, but a correction must be applied for the interval between the beginning of the mean solar year and the beginning of the given day.

    Rule.‚Äî Having found ‘Cor.’ for the year under consideration, add as many minutes to the longitude of the sun as ‘Cor.’ contains ghatik√°s, if ‘Cor.’ is negative; if positive, subtract the amount from the sun’s longitude.

    Thus for the 28th M√¢rgasira 4319 K.Y. we must subtract 14’, for ‘Cor.’ (+19gh.35p.‚Äî 5 gk. 6p.) +14 gh..29p. from the longitude of the sun given in Table VIII for the day under consideration, viz. 237¬∞ 49’. The result, 237¬∞ 35’, is the sun’s longitude at the beginning of 28th Margasira 4319 K. Y.

    To the longitude of the sun must be added the distance of sun and moon; the result, ; retrencbing 360¬∞ if necessary, will be the truc longitude of the moon. Turning with the longitude of the moon to Table IX, we find in which Nakshatra the moon was at the moment calculated. In the same way Table V shows through which zodiacal sign she was then passing through. ↩︎

  2046. “According to the Siddhanta Siromani, however, in 3628 K.Y.” ↩︎

  2047. “The rule for the Siddhanta Stromani is-subtract 3628 from the given year K.Y.; the remainder in the ayan√¢mica in minutes. Subtract from this result, if a high degree of accuracy is wanted, the tenth part of the above remainder taken &A seconds.” ↩︎

  2048. “Denkschriften der Kaiserlichen Akademie der Wissenschaften, math. natur. Qlasse, Wien, fol. LII.” ↩︎

  2054. “This part of the rule, which is wanting in Varsha Mihira, is absurd. The remainder should be multiplied by 381 days 1 gh. 21 p. The Kshepa too does not correspond with the results of the Arya Siddhanta, on which the rule is based; it ought to be 8626 instead of 8589 or 8582.” ↩︎

  2057. “As this is practically the same in odd years, the corresponding column has been omitted in the table for odd years.” ↩︎

  2059. “In this instance it would have been easier to start from anomaly 90¬∞, and subtract the increase for 25’; the resulting equation will then be found to be 5% 42” ↩︎

  2060. " I cannot account for the difference in the result, but I should think that the native method of calculation sdruits of various abbreviations of the process which in the end bring about a slightly different result.” ↩︎

  2061. “It may be remarked that the minutes and seconds of the mean motion of the sun nearly correspond to as many gha·π≠ik√°s and palas.” ↩︎

  2062. “The Hindu solar year is the sidereal year. The tropical year on which European Chronology is based is hardly ever used by the Hindus. So also, in Hindu astronomy the revolutions of the planeta, &c., are sidereal, and not tropical. The precession of the equinoxes is taken into account in such cases an are affected by it, but it is neglected in all others.” ↩︎

  2063. “The European value of this sidereal year is 365-2563744 days, while the tropical year consists of 365-24224 days; and taking the precession of the equinoxes at 180 revolutions in a yuga, according to the S√∫rya Siddhdnta, the Hindu tropical year would be 1,577,917,8284,320,180 = 365243599667 days.-J.B.” ↩︎

  2064. “The Julian date advances by one day after each century of 36,526 days, but remains the same after a century of” ↩︎

  2065. “Hence the synodical period of the S. S. is 1,577,917,828 d. + 53,433,336 r. = 29-53058795 days.‚ÄîJ.B.” ↩︎

  2066. “This is found by dividing 360¬∞ by the synodical period; ses preceding notg.‚ÄìJ. B.” ↩︎

  2067. “Hence the anomalistic revolution takes place in g.= 1577,917,8284.+57,265,138 rov. = 27.5545999 days; and the daily motion = 360¬∞ + g = 13¬∞ 3‚Ä≤ 53‚Ä≥¬∑889.‚ÄîJ. B.” ↩︎
